 On her fleeting Hollywood career (45 secs)
 On working with Bergman after their break-up (55 secs)
fields.bodyText: Liv Ullmann on: working in America | auditioning for Richard Rodgers | the relationship between art and life | on the state of modern cinema Shane Danielson: Some of you might have heard that this event tonight is in some way a reprise of an interview in August at the Edinburgh Film Festival, and in the car on the way here both of us confessed that this is something like a second date for us. But one of the things I found out that night was that she didn't particularly like the word icon, though it's been used many times to describe her. She didn't object to it violently, but she did point out that an icon is something that is a couple of centuries old and covered in dust and can usually be found hanging on the wall of an Orthodox church rather than in front of a camera making good films. In place of icon I would like, therefore, to offer another word for Miss Ullmann, which is 'emblematic'. Because in the minds of cinema goers, particularly cinema goers of a certain generation, she is the personification of a certain kind of cinema, and identified too with a certain kind of director - in this case Ingmar Bergman. And it occurred to me that this was similar to the way another Scandinavian born actress, Anna Karina, was with another great director, Jean-Luc Godard. But the differences couldn't be more profound. Karina exemplified capriciousness and everything that, for Godard, was about the unknowability about women. Whereas Ullmann was always known: she projected a woman who laid herself open on the screen for us to see and seemed comfortable projecting the most naked and raw emotional states, and that's, I think, what we recognise in her and what many of us love and admire in her as well. Tonight, to start off, I've chosen two clips which I think highlight both sides of her career - both as a great screen actor and as a film-maker of international renown. The first clip is from the Bergman film The Shame - a single take framed almost entirely on her face - and the second clip is from her debut feature Sofie, in which she tried to retain the values in Bergman's films: the unflinching emotional honesty, the truth to characters and their motivations and the respect and compassion for everyone that is on the screen. The other difference between her and Karina is that Godard and Karina burned brightly and briefly whereas Ingmar Bergman and Liv Ullmann have enjoyed a professional relationship which has varied between lover, muse, collaborator, actor for well over 30 years now, from Persona in 1966 to Faithless today. Here are the clips. SD: When we turned up here in the car tonight there was a big crowd standing outside the doors and Liv looked out of the car and said in typical Liv terror, "Ah! They hated the film! Everybody's walked out of the film.It's going to be a disaster. Why have you brought me here?" And they turned out to be the hoards of autograph hunters. But the point is that one of these people just held out something for her to sign and said over and over again, "You are lovely, you are lovely." And she certainly is, and one of the great film-makers of our day, Liv Ullmann. SD: So, not an icon? Liv Ullmann: Not an icon. Actually, what Shane said about outside the theatre was nicer than what I heard in the airport not so long ago. A lady, she came very close to me and looked at me and said, "Didn't you use to be Liv Ullmann?" So that was nicer! SD: You've tried to preserve many of the lessons you learnt with Bergman. Bergman casts such a long shadow over your career, for better or for worse... LU: Well those are your words... SD: I go on the basis of the book you wrote, Changing. LU: Well I wrote it 25 years ago... SD: So it was fresh from the heat of it in a way. LU: Well, yes, but then I lived 25 more years. More than that. After we split up as a loving couple - that's 32 years because we have known each other for 36 years. I think it is. Yes, he is absolutely the best director I've worked with, as an actress on, I think, 10 films and as a director on two scripts. But I think what you are as a person is also part of what you reflect in your work, and so his shadow is not what I'm walking under. It's my life I'm working with and it is my life and my experience which I present. In terms of learning, what you learn the most from is - if it comes to directing - it's really the bad directors you have, because it's through the bad directors that you learn what you shouldn't do with actors and the people you are working with. Those that trample on your fantasy and do not respect your experience. You learn more from that if you want to be a director yourself. I would say I work in the sunlight of so much that Ingmar's given me. Actually, I don't work under anyone's shadow. SD: I'm glad we cleared that one up. LU: That was the long answer. SD: You talked about bad directors, it seems to me that your biggest experience of those would have been when you went to work in America. There's a game I like to play on stage with somebody which is bringing up their worst film, and I have to say two words: Lost Horizon. LU: Yeah, that was rather bad. There are a lot of critics who have that on their list of the 50 worst films that were ever made, and it almost tops them. But I had a fantastic time, and the cast - Charles Boyer, John Gielgud, Peter Finch - it was a great cast. SD: That's what puzzles me. When you're on something like that and it turns out to be such a monumental turkey... I remember interviewing George Clooney about Out Of Sight and he'd just come off that Batman movie and he said that even when he was making it, he and the guy who played Robin were sitting there going, "This is going to suck." Did you know that at the time? LU: No! Well I knew that I couldn't dance and I couldn't sing... SD: Which for a musical is kind of an obstacle... LU: Yes, I know! I did say that to them and they said, "Oh, it doesn't matter, you're so sweet and so charming, we'll work around it." So somebody sang my voice and then I danced, and that looked kind of stiff and strange, but what I said was true. It was my first time in Hollywood and I believed everything they said, and they said every woman in Hollywood wants to do your part in Lost Horizon, and I believed that too. I lived in this incredible house with this swimming pool and my friends came over, and the bathroom in the house was like, like this whole room! It was fantastic! Give that to any 31-year-old from Norway and they will think that it's the greatest time in their life. I still feel that the film wasn't a success, but it was a fantastically good time. As a matter of fact, that first year I was in Hollywood - it was my last year too - I did four movies. As opposed to Greta Garbo, who just grew and grew, I managed to close down two studios. And this is true! And it's fun for me because the tragedy never reached me, because by the time I'd done my year - and none of the films were out yet, so I still thought, "Oh, what a success I am" - I went to Sweden and the film I did then was Scenes From a Marriage, so I wasn't really aware that I had closed the two studios. [Listen to the soundclip (45 secs)] SD: At the time did you say in interviews in Sweden, "They love me in America"? LU: Yes I did that. And they said, "She's really got stuck up now." They didn't understand that it was a great time. I still think it was a great time. I took the best of it with me and I went on from there and that was, like, 30 years ago, so who cares? SD: Absolutely. You're associated with Bergman in so many films. You're also blurring the lines between collaboration and life partnership... LU: That was only for two films. SD: But even then, after that, you're still in his orbit, in his films. When you got out of that, how was he about you being in The Emigrants (directed by Jan Troell), for example? Many directors get possessive and don't allow people to play in other fields... LU: He's a little like that. I did it anyway. And by the time I did The Emigrants it was more or less over in terms of the love relationship. As a matter of fact it was not Ingmar who brought me to Hollywood but The Emigrants... SD: Because of the Golden Globe - you were nominated, yes? LU: I won. And I was nominated for an Oscar and that was when I went to Hollywood and got the four films. He kind of realised that I wanted to taste that world and when all that was over I went back and did a film for him, and he thought, "Well, she has learnt now and she'll do Scenes From a Marriage, and she'll be happy to be here." SD: How big a priority was it for you to be a success in America, in that after the European success you would have to start almost from the bottom... LU: You don't start from the bottom when you get a lead in a musical... SD: But Lost Horizon... LU: But it didn't seem like a tragedy. And what they couldn't do with me... because I was 31 years old, they couldn't do what they'd planned: create me into something different, because I was secure with the kind of person I was. And I had very good luggage because I had worked with Ingmar Bergman. I don't know if I had dreamt of being a success in Hollywood, I don't think I've ever been ambitious in that way. I just thought it was an incredible opportunity of life, and it came to me and I did it. And I don't regret it and for me, it gave me great pleasure. I think you should say "Yes", even if you do fall on your... behind. SD: If you say "No" all the time then I suppose you never live. LU: That's true, because I did another musical. That one was on Broadway. That was maybe more sad because that was Richard Rodgers, and that was the last musical he ever wrote, and again they said it doesn't matter because I was still sweet, and I said I couldn't sing and to look at Lost Horizon. They thought it would go anyway. The musical was called I Remember Mamma, it was newly written, and I was taken to Richard Rodgers and I told him I really don't sing and he said, "I'm used to that. I've had a lot of singers that don't sing. I just want to know your range." And I said, "This is really embarrassing because I really don't" and he said, "Don't fear". He was already sick and old and close to 80 at that time, and just sitting at his piano and he was so sweet and thin, and he said, "Just sing Happy Birthday." So I sang Happy Birthday and he aged 10 years, just like that. The incredible thing with him was, and this was his last musical, and he knew he was making it for me - seven songs that I mishandled, and he came each night to the theatre and he was loving and nice and just kind. It was eight months of a fantastic thing on Broadway. And because I was older I knew what I was doing. I thought that this was going to be fun to tell my grandchildren, you know: "I don't dance, I don't sing, and here I am a star in a musical." SD: Which killed Richard Rodgers... LU: No. It didn't kill him. Because he was already sick before he met me... SD: Moving swiftly along. You said you weren't particularly ambitious for success. You just wanted to make the films you wanted to make, and yet at the same time from an early age... LU: If life presents itself to you, you have to say 'Yes'. Or at least that was what I felt. Now I am more careful with my choices. Now I know it is more serious because I am older and everything. But you have to allow yourself, in my business, fiascos. Because that is what you really learn from. The other things you get so much praise from you can't learn anything from that. But when you do bad you have to think, why did I do badly, was it my choices, was it the way I did it, and you go on and have a better life because of that. SD: Did you believe the publicity you got, or were you always doubting yourself? LU: I would doubt myself after the reviews of the mistakes, but that doesn't live forever either. It's now many years since I read reviews in that way and it doesn't mean what it used to mean because life is so much grander and more exceptional than to read reviews of what you do at work. Life is what you fill your day with, why you wake up in the morning and what you want to do in terms of being a human being. I'm not portrayed by what was bad and what was good in terms of my work, I'm portrayed by what I try to give in to my work. SD: Sure. LU: Was that too serious? SD: No, not at all. In the second clip, from Sofie, I thought it showed the difference between Bergman, say, and yourself, that you've just touched on. The fact that you draw this distinction between life and your work and that one doesn't necessarily consume the other. The portraitist in the clip will take any emotion he can get, it's all grist to the mill, and that's what Bergman does, clearly. LU: Yes, that's a kind of cannibal, but not necessarily in the wrong way. Some artists use every moment, how can I do this, how can I note this down, how can I use it. There are some people that do that, but also just live. I would rather be of that kind. When you die and God says, 'What did you do in life?' you can't just say, "I did good work.' You have to say a lot of other things as well. SD: You tried to live a good life. LU: Yeah. I hated and I loved and I sang and well, whatever. I cam from the States this morning so if I say things like that it might be jet-lag too. SD: You said in Edinburgh that you had remained friends with Bibi Andersson. There was a community of women around Bergman, but it didn't seem to be competitive, or if it was, not in a way that destroyed the group from within. I don't mean because you were women, but a group of creative people around a director doesn't necessarily encourage good behaviour. LU: We were very close friends, the women who worked for and with Bergman. Bibi Andersson and I are the best of friends and we are like sisters. The first time that we worked together was in Norway many years before I worked with Ingmar in a film, it was a Danish film. My first film, Sofie, I sent him the cut of the film when I was finished and asked him what he thought about it. And I thought a lot about what I had learned from Ingmar when I did that movie. For me to have been an actress was the best of schools to be a director because I know what it feels inside and I started to respect acting so much more. While I was still an actress I sometimes felt a little ashamed of being an actress... SD: Why? LU: I don't know. Because here I am, and there's so much going on in the world, and here I am an actress and people sit with you at dinner and they think they have to ask how it is to act, and how you learn your lines and things like that... SD: Nothing very substantial... LU: No, because they think you don't. And so I almost felt ashamed. But I knew deep down, when it didn't have to be me, that actors are so creative and actors are so fantastic, the really good ones, to build on their own life and to use that, without being themselves, but to use the best and the wisest thing that they know about life. And the movie you have just seen (Faithless), to see Lena Endre give so much of her life so freely, I think it is the best performance in a movie. When you think of films and theatre you can take away the lights and the stage, everything, but you can never do without the word and the actors. SD: I would imagine that actors want to work with you because you come from that background, because you understand. There is a level of trust established there immediately. LU: There has to be a lot of trust. First of all you have to be very open with who you are so that they know you are not hiding something. Then they really have to trust you so that they know whatever they give you, you are not going to misuse them. They must feel that, while you are sitting there with the camera, you are like a lover. If you are with someone who really loves you, and they look at you and they show you that you are the most wonderful person in the world, you will suddenly bloom. If you are a kind of rose, which these people are, they will be the best of roses if you allow them to be roses, and don't try to make them into a blue copy of some idea you had in your own workroom. SD: Did you ever feel close to cinema as a whole, were you a film fan? Did you feel passionately involved in the film world, or was it more isolated, because you were in Scandinavia? LU: But, you know, we see films in Scandinavia too. SD: I'm from Australia. We just got them last year. LU: When I was in Australia, Doris Day was still the icon. SD: She's a big pinup for all of us. There's that sense, in the 60s and 70s, of an enclave up there, making a very specific kind of cinema that doesn't appear to be influenced by French cinema or Hollywood cinema. It was a parallel cinema. LU: That is true. Although I must say that we saw a lot of films undubbed. We saw Italian films, and French and Russian and from Czechoslovakia and from Poland, so we had a fantastic education in foreign films. Our films in the end did not look like these films, though these films really inspired us. When I was young and saw Vittorio De Sica's films, like The Bicycle Thieves, my whole view of life changed seeing these films. That's why it's so important the type of films young people see today. They sneak into your fantasy, maybe even more so today than before, because today people seem more isolated, and there are very few places where they are face to face with others, and cinema is one of the few places now that they can still be influenced. That is why it is so sad today that they are getting all these cartoon movies and slice movies, when in my time we had much more grownup movies. It is cut-cut-cut-cut, you never get to see what life is about, what your heart is about, what your pulse is about. When you look at people you don't look back and forth; you look at people and movies should reflect that, and they don't do that anymore. SD: With DVD and video, even the communal experience is declining. There is a breakdown of that community. Do you feel endangered by Hollywood in Norway? Is that as strong there as in the rest of Europe, and is the push to resist that as strong? LU: It's like, I'm sure, it is in England. I think something like 80% of the films that we see are Hollywood movies, and the more people see these kinds of movies the harder it is to get them in to other movies, because they don't want to see it, because it's long, and slow. People have this haste: "It can't be too long because then I have to go out and... " What do they have to do? Life is long! Can't they give two hours, or more, and see if something changes in their life? Or maybe they'll have something to talk about with someone? Or maybe they are shocked and they decide something is going to be different in their life. It is good to be influenced. It's great to be in a movie house and be a participant. In so many movies you are not a participant. But to be a participant, even if you don't like the movie, something is somehow shaken within you. That is good. We need to be part of life, we can't just be watching a screen, and watching what is happening, and watching the politicians, and watching everything. We have to be part of it. Not passive. So much in our time is making us passive because we don't know what's going on anymore. Wars happen and we don't know what the war is about. Politicians are elected and people don't even know how to elect them! SD: The core of Bergman's films is a watchfulness and almost a 19th century view that character decides destiny. Yet that is so unpopular and radically unfashionable. Do you get depressed in terms of whether you can keep making films, or if the films will find an audience? Do you just make something and hope it will connect with an audience somewhere? LU: Yes, I hope. But then I'm 62 years old. If I was 30 I would be more worried because I would wonder whether I could continue to make films this way. But I am not worried for me or for what my future will be, but I am worried for the audience and the film-makers. It is tough for film-makers if they want to make a more serious, or even a comedy, done seriously. But most of all I am worried for young people because they cannot go to the cinema and experience the wonder when the bell rings and the curtain goes and something is happening there. On the plane nowadays, the Farrel brothers? SD: Farrelly brothers. LU: They were raping a chicken! It's not even fun! SD: I know. In Australia you have to take what you can get. LU: I was in Australia and they have a very different way of seeing things. Many years ago I did this Cocteau play called The Human Voice. It's about a woman, and she's on the phone, and that's all you see. She is on the phone with her lover who is apparently breaking up with her and she just cannot let him go. It's a really sad monologue. And she says, "Please don't hang up, don't hang up." And she's struggling for her life. It had been a success everywhere we'd been, and then we came to Sydney. On the second night, people had come because I was a star in Australia at that time, I was saying, "Don't hang up, oh, please, don't hang up." And I hear from the gallery, "Oh, please hang up!". And that's what I felt. To next page Sound clips  On her fleeting Hollywood career (45 secs)  On working with Bergman after their break-up (55 secs)

webTitle: Election turnout to slump, poll says

fields.headline: Election turnout to slump, poll says
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Turnout at the next general election could be the lowest since the second world war, according to a Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.body:
Turnout at the next general election could be the lowest since the second world war, according to a Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

But Tony Blair's fears that a "stay-at-home" factor among heartland Labour supporters could cost him a second term are not borne out by the survey, which shows that while the Labour turnout in the party's safe seats is likely to slump, it is still doing well enough in its key marginals to deliver a comfortable election victory for Mr Blair.

The poll, which shows Labour maintaining last month's 10-point lead over the Conservatives, also shows that 42% of Tory voters expect Labour to win a second term.

Only 25% of the Tories' own supporters believe William Hague can pull off a surprise victory, and 52% of Labour voters expect the government to get a second term.

But one in three voters say they are unsure about the outcome, suggesting that there are a lot of voters who are yet to be persuaded - and that the result is far from a foregone conclusion.

The number of people who say they would be certain to vote if there were an election tomorrow now stands at 60% of the electorate, compared with 64% in January 1997 at the same stage before the last general election. These figures suggest that eventual turnout in a general election this May could be in the range of 67% to 69% -significantly below the May 1997 figure of 71.5%. That would be the lowest turnout of any general election since 1945.

The ICM poll also shows that the Conservative vote has hardened slightly since the last election with the likelihood of Tory supporters turning out to vote rising slightly on a statistical scale from 9.02 in January 1997 to 9.10 now. At the same time the likelihood of Labour voters going to the polls has dropped sharply from 9.11 to 8.68 now.

But applying a new technique - the "variometer", which was devised by the psephologists John Curtice and Nick Sparrow to take account of differences in swing between different regions and between eight different types of seat - it is possible to show that intended turnout is lowest in Labour's safe seats, while it has held up at levels similar to January 1997 in marginals.

This means that while there will be a stay-at-home factor in Labour's heartlands, it is unlikely to affect the scale of Mr Blair's second-term victory as the party maintains its voting strength in the key marginals where it counts. The poll translates on the "variometer" to a Labour majority of 153 if there were a general election tomorrow.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,004 adults across the country by telephone on January 19-21. Results were weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Spending: Hague ups the stakes
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague launched a dramatic attempt to neutralise Tony Blair's central pre-election assault on the Tories last night by announcing that he would double the number of areas in which a Conservative government would match Labour's spending plans.
fields.body:
William Hague launched a dramatic attempt to neutralise Tony Blair's central pre-election assault on the Tories last night by announcing that he would double the number of areas in which a Conservative government would match Labour's spending plans.

Mr Hague declared that he would ringfence the government's budgets for law and order, transport and defence. Until yesterday, he had only pledged to match Labour spending on health and education.

Speaking on ITV's News at Ten last night, the Tory leader reiterated his pledge to cut £8bn from the government's overall spending plans to pave the way for tax cuts. But Mr Hague declared that there would be no cuts in the five key areas.

"We will be saying to the people of this country at the election [that] under a Conservative government your local hospital will be better provided for than it is today," he said. "Your children's school will be better funded than it is today. There will be more policemen on the streets than there are today because we are not taking any of the savings we are talking about from these vital areas."

Mr Hague's intervention, which follow a relentless attack by the prime minister on the Tories' tax and spending plans, is designed to head off Labour claims that a Tory victory would threaten key public services.

Mr Blair has triumphed dur ing recent tussles with Mr Hague in the Commons by claiming that the Tories have no credibility because they would cut funds from services which they claim to champion. At their first encounter after the Christmas recess Mr Hague was accused of making policy on the hoof when he responded to a strong assault from Mr Blair by pledging to match Labour spending on the police.

Under Mr Hague's plans, a Tory government would extend this to match Labour's entire annual £10.6bn budget for the Home Office. The Tories will also match John Prescott's £180bn transport plan and the entire annual £25bn budget for the Ministry of Defence.

Labour wasted no time in dismissing Mr Hague's announcement. Last night Andrew Smith, the chief secretary to the Treasury, insisted that the Tories' pledge to keep spending at the same level as forecast growth in the economy meant that they would have to cut £16bn from the government's spending plans, rather than the £8bn pledged so far.

"The Tories' plans just do not add up," he said. "Their arithmetic is falling apart. No one will believe a word Mr Hague says about the Tories' tax and spending plans. Far from being able to match Labour's plans, Mr Hague must admit that he will have to cut into health, education, law and order and other services to meet the £16bn gap in Conservative spending plans."

Labour will claim that Mr Hague's announcement is a panic measure in the face of Labour attacks. But Con servative central office insisted last night that the new pledges were the latest phase in the tax and spending plans that have been rolled out since the autumn.

The Conservatives rounded off a series of announcements about cuts at the weekend when they pledged to change student loans and Channel 4.

A Tory spokesman said last night: "We have been completely consistent. We have never said that we will make savings in transport, the Home Office and defence. William Hague's pledges in those areas come with a strong commitment that the £8bn cuts stand and we will cut taxes. We will make our savings in areas where spending is wasteful and inappropriate."

But the Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, insisted that the Tories could not "have something for nothing". He said: "Conservative tax and spending plans become more laughable by the day. The Conservatives say they will match Labour pound for pound in every spending area while claiming they can also cut taxes and balance the books - not for one minute will anyone believe these phoney figures."

He added: "It was Margaret Thatcher who pointed out what every housewife knows - you can't have something for nothing. Perhaps William Hague should take a leaf out of her book."

webTitle: Millbank grabs reins to secure favourites seats

fields.headline: Millbank grabs reins to secure favourites seats
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership will today take control of parliamentary selections, paving the way for "favoured" candidates to be parachuted into safe constituencies ahead of the coming election.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership will today take control of parliamentary selections, paving the way for "favoured" candidates to be parachuted into safe constituencies ahead of the coming election.

The party's national executive committee is expected to get the power to draw up shortlists in any seats that fall vacant after January 31, amid grassroots pressure to ensure that more women get the chance to fight for seats and maintain the number of women MPs at Westminster - a record 101 in 1997.

The move at today's monthly NEC meeting is further evidence that an election is imminent, probably on May 3, and it will give Millbank considerable influence over who is selected. Although local Labour parties will have final say in a ballot, the Labour leadership will be able to promote, or oppose, individuals.

There is particular concern that, of the 35 Labour MPs standing down, (five of them women) only five of their replacments - they include Mo Mowlam's successor in Redcar - are female. Without drastic last minute action the number of Labour women is certain to fall.

A series of safer seats are expected to fall vacant as sitting MPs step down at the last minute, some possibly tempted by the offer of peerages or another post. The most recent was announced on Friday when Giles Radice, 64, veteran MP for North Durham and chairman of the Treasury select committee, said he was standing down.

Among those Millbank is thought to be seeking a seat for is Shaun Woodward, the Tory-turned-Labour MP exempted from the "chicken run" ban after deciding not to stand again in the Witney seat, which he won for the Conservatives in 1997.

Five Labour held seats, where a new candidate has yet to be picked, are Jeff Rooker's in Birmingham Perry Barr, Mr Radice's in North Durham, Lawrence Cunliffe's in Leigh, Paul Marsden's in Shrewsbury and Atcham, and Tom Pendry in Stalybridge and Hyde.

The NEC is likely to step in and take control of the selection procedures if they are not completed by the middle of March, at the latest.

Tom Cox, veteran MP for Tooting, is also singled out by some MPs as probably likely to retire. Sometimes, though, MPs decide to hang on. Tam Dalyell, now aged 68, found himself the object of Millbank-inspired rumours that he would quit, but consulted activists in Linlithgow - and decided to stay on to "mentor" younger colleagues in parliamentary skills.

webTitle: The highs and lows of Marks & Spencer

fields.headline: The highs and lows of Marks & Spencer
fields.standfirst: M&S results 'not good enough'
fields.trailText: 1884 Michael Marks, a Russian refugee, opens a market stall in Leeds
fields.body:
1884 Michael Marks, a Russian refugee, opens a market stall in Leeds

1894 Marks forms a partnership with Tom Spencer, a cashier from the wholesale company IJ Dewhirst.

1926 Marks & Spencer becomes a public limited company

1928 M&S trademarks its own-brand label, St Michael.

1930s The company opens its flagship store at Marble Arch in London and sets up a food department.

1975 M&S begins international expansion with stores in Paris and Brussels.

1988 M&S acquires Brooks Brothers, an American clothing company and Kings Super markets, a US food chain.

1997 Company pays £192m for 19 Littlewoods stores 14 of them fail to achieve profitability by 2001

October 1998 M&S reports the first fall in profits since the beginning of the decade. City traders predict: "Things are starting to slide." M&S stock hits a high of 664p per share.

December 1998 Despite banking £1.2bn in profits, the company's share price is down 32% for the year. Stocks trade at 412p on December 30.

February 1999 Long-time chief executive Sir Richard Greenbury is succeeded by Peter Salsbury as stock price continues to tumble.

February 2000 Luc Vandevelde takes over as chairman after M&S pay him a £2m golden hello.

May 2000 Vandevelde announces a boardroom cull, forces out three executive directors. Shareholder dividend slashed for the first time in its 74 years as a public company.

September 2000 Salsbury resigns under shareholder pressure. Vandevelde takes over as chief executive.

January 2001 Christmas sales figures mark out M&S as the worst-performing high street chain for the 3rd consecutive year. Profits expected to reach only £473m. Stock trading at just over 200p.

fields.headline: M&S results 'not good enough'
fields.standfirst: Timeline: the highs and lows of M&S
fields.trailText: It was a tough Christmas for most major retailers, but Marks & Spencer today released particularly dismal shopping figures for the crucial 16 weeks up to January 20.
fields.body:
It was a tough Christmas for most major retailers, but Marks & Spencer today released particularly dismal shopping figures for the crucial 16 weeks up to January 20.

The company's chief executive and chairman, Luc Vandevelde, said a 5% drop in sales demonstrated that the overall appeal of the retailer's adult clothing ranges was "simply not good enough".

While the number of shoppers coming into its stores increased over Christmas, "the inconsistent appeal of our adult clothing ranges caused lower than expected sales," he said. This led to excess stock and then higher marking down of goods in an effort to clear them.

Sales on a like-for-like basis, excluding income from new and refurbished stores, fell by 5.1% in the period to January 20 and by 2.3% in the critical eight-week Christmas trading period to the same date.

The situation was bleak in clothing, footwear and gifts where total sales fell by 9.3% and 4.8% respectively.

However, Mr Vandevelde remained optimistic that there were signs of progress, with an improving trend in food and home sales, more cost-effective buying and better margins, particularly in general merchandising. Food sales grew 2.1% in the 16-week period and sales of home furnishings saw a 9.5% increase.

"But I am under no illusion as to the main challenges facing the business," he said. "We must offer our customers adult clothing ranges of consistently better design and appeal. I am absolutely committed to making this happen."

The City did not punish M&S for its "dreadful" product ranges and falling sales. By mid-morning its shares were ahead 4%, or 8.5p, at 208.5p. With new-look stores and a revamped buying policy, traders still obviously have confidence that M&S can boost its flagging sales figures.

But the share price shows how difficult the last two years have been for the company. Three years ago, M&S shares were changing hands at 664p, valuing the company at £19bn. The company is now worth less than a third of that figure.

M&S has been focusing on developing a new concept store format, and now has 25 shops with a new look and design. These stores reported a 4% sales increase over the Christmas period.

"But the bottom line is that their ranges are still dreadful," said one analyst. "They have been putting money into stores and refurbishment, but they have not seen a significant uplift. They have an awful long way to go."

Group finance director Robert Colvill insisted now was not the time for the company to hit the panic button and implement a series of cost-cutting measures, such as widespread store closures. He said that the problem was simply a merchandising one - getting the right goods into the right stores.

"We lost touch a bit, if I am honest, and we have to get that back," Mr Colvill acknowledged.

The situation was bleak in clothing, footwear and gifts where total sales fell by 9.3% and 4.8% respectively. However, Mr Vandevelde remained optimistic that there were signs of progress, with an improving trend in food and home sales, more cost-effective buying and better margins, particularly in general merchandising. Food sales grew 2.1% in the 16-week period and sales of home furnishings saw a 9.5% increase. "But I am under no illusion as to the main challenges facing the business," he said. "We must offer our customers adult clothing ranges of consistently better design and appeal. I am absolutely committed to making this happen." The City did not punish M&S for its "dreadful" product ranges and falling sales. By mid-morning its shares were ahead 4%, or 8.5p, at 208.5p. With new-look stores and a revamped buying policy, traders still obviously have confidence that M&S can boost its flagging sales figures. But the share price shows how difficult the last two years have been for the company. Three years ago, M&S shares were changing hands at 664p, valuing the company at £19bn. The company is now worth less than a third of that figure. M&S has been focusing on developing a new concept store format, and now has 25 shops with a new look and design. These stores reported a 4% sales increase over the Christmas period. "But the bottom line is that their ranges are still dreadful," said one analyst. "They have been putting money into stores and refurbishment, but they have not seen a significant uplift. They have an awful long way to go." Group finance director Robert Colvill insisted now was not the time for the company to hit the panic button and implement a series of cost-cutting measures, such as widespread store closures. He said that the problem was simply a merchandising one - getting the right goods into the right stores. "We lost touch a bit, if I am honest, and we have to get that back," Mr Colvill acknowledged. webTitle: Heads will roll: teachers leaving the profession

fields.headline: Heads will roll
fields.standfirst: Two weeks ago, we published the testimonies of two teachers who were leaving the profession. Many more wrote in saying that they, too, felt desperate. Here  Alistair Ross, who has studied teacher recruitment and retention for the past three years, presents the disturbing facts behind the feelings
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago, we published the testimonies of two teachers who were leaving the profession. Many more wrote in saying that they, too, felt desperate. Here Alistair Ross, who has studied teacher recruitment and retention for the past three years, presents the disturbing facts behind the feelings
fields.body:
Our research, currently covering 18 of the London boroughs, suggests that there are at least two different problems regarding the supply of teachers, and that both need to be addressed through long-term strategic management, rather than short-termpalliatives such as mortgage relief or "golden hellos".

For the last three years, we have been examining the demographic structure of London's teaching force, looking at the career patterns of teachers and the motivations that underly them. We've asked teachers whether they intend to stay in teaching, and, if so, whether they intend to stay in London; we've asked all those teachers leaving their jobs - whether for another teaching post or for a job outside teaching - why they left, and we have also been asking those starting new jobs where they have come from and why. In total, we have questioned some 12,500 teachers. And our questions have uncovered problems that have been developing for nearly two decades.

In the mid 1980s, something happened: London schools began to recruit fewer teachers who would spend their entire careers in the city, or teachers in their early 30s began to leave London, or teaching, or both. Either way, the proportion of London teachers in their 30s began to fall, and is still falling.

The result is that, in London, there are now two distinct populations of teachers. Forty per cent are under 35 and most of these intend to stop teaching in London within the next five years. Fifty per cent are over 40, and most of these will stay teaching in London until they retire in their mid- to late-50s. This mixture of young transient teachers - who are either temporary visitors from overseas, or young teachers who spend a few years at the beginning of their career in the capital - and long-term London teachers - who know the local community and its needs well - worked well while the two elements were in balance. But now the balance has gone.

The group of older, long-term London teachers is rapidly declining in size as retirement takes its toll, and London schools are having to try to recruit an ever-larger number of newly qualified teachers to make up the shortfall. But our data confirms the anecdotal evidence from headteachers and others that it is becoming increasingly difficult to find enough young teachers to replace those who move on.

Teacher shortages are not just an English phenomenon - they are also happening in our "traditional" recruiting grounds of Australia, Canada and New Zealand. Fewer young teachers trained outside London are willing to take up their first posts in London. The Teacher Training Agency is trying harder than ever to attract new recruits, but even with the new incentives of training salaries for PGCE students, it is an uphill task. The numbers recruited in this current year are slightly up, but past experience suggests that incentives such as this only work for a year or two before numbers begin to decline again.

The second problem is hidden: it concerns the retention of teachers in mid-career. The young teachers who might have stayed in London rapidly find that when they want to put down roots, with the not unreasonable desire of a professional to own their own home, that house prices are beyond them. Teaching posts are found in all populated areas (unlike almost any other large profession), so it's not difficult to move to a place where one can find both a job and affordable accommodation.

Again, the government is trying - there are new schemes to provide affordable mortgages in London - but the problem is large, and there is a backlog to make up.

Losing experienced teachers means that schools lack teachers with the experience to apply for positions of middle management and leadership. Our evidence shows that the real pinch in terms of the number of applications per post, and the success rate in making appointments, is in posts of responsibility, deputy headships and headships for schools. There's a huge dip in the number of teachers between 35 and 45, the very age group from whom these posts tend to be recruited. And in five years' time, as teachers currently in their 50s retire, that population dip will be of teachers between 35 and 50, and there will be even fewer applicants for headteacher posts. A further five years on, and by 2010 London schools will find it extraordinarily difficult to appoint heads, deputies and middle management.

We have based our projections on what teachers say they intend to do. But even if only half of these intentions translate into action, there is very real cause for concern, and our monitoring of the actual numbers leaving teaching over the past two years suggests that those who say that they will leave the profession or the capital within five years usually do so.

It is predominantly teachers under 30 who are on the move - out of teaching, or out of London. These young teachers can only be replaced by more young teachers - if they can be found - because there are only tiny numbers who can be attracted to teach in London in mid-career.

Only one-tenth of London's young teachers intend to stay teaching in London for the rest of their careers. Older teachers are much more settled in London, but even so, only half of them think that they will see out their working lives as London teachers.

But why do teachers leave teaching? This is a national trend, and our evidence suggests that the experience of Bob Hewitt, who wrote in Guardian Education on January 9 about why he was quitting teaching, is typical: "Initiative and resourcefulness are banned".

We asked those who were leaving for other careers what it was that they saw as attractive in their new work.

Three-fifths of all teachers taking up work outside the profession do not find that teaching allows them to be creative and resourceful. These factors used to be one of the key defining elements of the teaching profession: people joined the profession because it used to offer them autonomy, creativity and the ability to use one's initiative.

What has happened to the profession that has caused these teachers, at least, to become so disillusioned that they seek alternative careers? This question, to teachers, is rhetorical. The ways in which teaching has become managed, has become "accountable" and has been subjected to control and direction, have contributed to demotivation.

We have also found that for teachers leaving the profession, it isn't high alternative salaries that are attracting them out. Of our sample of teachers leaving for other careers, only 27% would be earning more than they earned as teachers; 27% said that they would earn the same as they had earned as in their previous teaching post; and 45% were going to posts paying less than they had earned in their last teaching post.

It is the change in the nature of teaching that is behind the crisis points we have described. Pay is an issue: to enable teachers to stay in the profession, particularly in the areas of high housing costs, substantially more pay is needed. But more pay alone is not bringing new people into training and the profession in sufficient numbers. And more pay is not stopping the haemorrhage of teachers from the profession.

Is this just a phenomenon of London and the south-east? This is certainly the region where shortages and threatened four-day weeks are making headlines. But our research suggests that the underlying problem -the twin peaks of the younger, short-term teachers, and the ageing peak of the longer-term teachers that we found in London is also found across England and Wales as a whole. Fifty three per cent of all teachers are "older" (over 42). In the 10 years starting in 2005, we will see 41.4% of all current teachers retiring.

Someone should be having sleepless nights over this: but the fact that this critical period lies in the next parliament but one means that this is a problem that can be conveniently forgotten by the present generation of ministers and civil servants.

 Professor Alistair Ross is director of the Institute for Policy Studies in Education (IPSE). This article was co-authored by Dr Merryn Hutchings, deputy director of IPSE, and Ian Menter, Head of the School of Education at the University of North London. The work described is part of the Teacher Supply and Retention project. Statistical work by Val Saunders and Sarah McCreith of IPSE.

webTitle: MXR wins South Wales digital radio licence

fields.headline: MXR wins South Wales digital radio licence
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The digital radio licence for South Wales and the Severn Estuary has been awarded to the MXR group, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The digital radio licence for South Wales and the Severn Estuary has been awarded to a consortium led by Chrysalis and Capital Radio.

The MXR group will offer nine music stations to an area covering Cardiff, Swansea, Bath and Bristol, adding to a recent licence win in north-east England.

"This is great news for all concerned. MXR will deliver the next generation of radio that listeners in South Wales and the Severn Estuary have been waiting for," said Phil Riley, Chrysalis Radio chief executive and MXR chairman.

Other MXR shareholders include Guardian Media Group, Jazz FM, UBC Digital and the Ford motor company, which plans to fit digital radios into its vehicles. The consortium is also bidding for the west midlands and north-west licences.

However, big players in the UK radio industry are far from happy with the development of digital radio, and have demanded more digital spectrum and the setting of a date for switching off the analogue service.

Ralph Bernard, head of market leader GWR, has argued that oppressive ownership laws have raised the price of analogue licence prices and forced lower investment in digital stations.

Last December's communications white paper was widely attacked for failing to suggest strong changes to station ownership guidelines. Current rules are based on a points system, which allocates units according to the size of the station.

fields.trailText:
5.30pm: ITN bosses have launched an unprecedented attack on the BBC over claims the corporation has the monopoly on quality journalism, writes Lisa O'Carroll .
2.45pm:Politicians round on BBC
2.30pm: ITV denies 'second rate' claims
1pm: News veterans square up
12.45pm: ITV owes victory to Millionaire
11am: ITV wins landslide victory
10.15am: BBC and ITV in news row
Last night's running order
fields.body:
ITN bosses have launched an unprecedented attack on the BBC over claims the corporation has the monopoly on quality journalism.

In an unusually strongly worded statement, ITN said:"Having lost the first round in the long battle for news viewers, the BBC has sought to undermine the quality of ITN's journalism. This is extremely patronising to the 8.1 million viewers who tuned in to News at Ten last night. The BBC is not the judge and jury of quality journalism - the viewers are."

It was reacting to claims by BBC deputy director of news Richard Sambrook that the BBC offered "the most comprehensive, best quality bulletin for viewers".

"We would rather avoid a war of words but we cannot allow attacks on our journalism to go unchallenged," said a spokesman.

"We are very proud of the quality of last night's ITV News at Ten. Several national newspapers this morning followed ITN's exclusive interview with William Hague and the first television interview with Britain's oldest mother of twins. We also carried new material on the Hatfield rail story.

"By contrast, the BBC's lead story has not been followed up and was described by one newspaper as 'inconsequential'.

"The negative spin from the BBC is another attempt to deflect attention from the real story - that more viewers chose to watch ITV News at Ten rather than the BBC alternative," the ITN spokesman added.

fields.headline: Players and their pages
fields.standfirst: The first in an occasional series keeping an eye on the stars and their personal websites
fields.trailText: The first in an occasional series keeping an eye on the stars and their personal websites
fields.body:
Paul Ince takes on Clinton Morrison

"I read the comments that Clinton Morrison made about Michael Owen in the papers after the Crystal Palace - Liverpool Worthington Cup game and I feel I just have to say this: I think for someone like him to criticise Michael's performance is an absolute joke.

"He's only 21 years old himself and plays for Crystal Palace and just because he happened to score a goal against Liverpool he feels he can come out with all that rubbish about Michael.

"I think it's bang out of order.and for me it's disrespectful as well."

Visit Ince's internet home at bigfanof.com here.

Alfie Haaland gets ready to rock

"Sorry, but this will be quite a short diary entry - I've got to help out with school homework duties now, and later I'm off to a Marilyn Manson concert with my good friend Mr Ostenstad.

"If you're a regular visitor to these pages you'll know I'm a bit of a hard rock fan - AC/DC are one of my favourites - so I'm hoping it'll be a good night."

Alfie lives on icons.com. To visit him click here.

All you wanted to know about Lothar Motthaus, but were too afraid to ask...

Your favourite meal?

Rolled meat with red cabbage.

Your dreams?

I never dream. If you dream, you get punished.

Your most favourite fictional hero?

Sherlock Holmes.

Which person in history do you abhore the most?
Hitler.

Who or what would you have liked to be?

An airplane pilot.

Your idol as football player?
No-one.

The best game of your career?
Against Yugoslavia during the 1990 World Cup.

For more scintillating stuff from lotharmatthaeus.com click here.

His name is Berger, Patrik Berger

"I've arrived back from Colorado with the news I wanted: my knee has shown the desired improvement and I can start running again.

"The temperature in Colorado was below zero, just as it was on my previous visit. On this occasion I was unable to take in neither an NHL game or an American football game, but I did manage to go on a snowmobile! This was a fantastic experience.

"Before you ask, I did get the all-clear before I did it. There was no danger of my knee being harmed because you are just seated all the time. It was like being in a James Bond movie. I felt as if I was 15 again. Mind you, I tend to feel like that all the time!"

Get more Berger for your money at icons.com, or click here.

And it's goodbye from Diego Maradona...

"Thanks! To the soccer players of the world. To my family. To Claudia my wife, who has developed this site. To all my friends who has helped to build this site. To everybody who will do something in the future."

Have a sniff of diegomaradona.com here.

fields.headline: ITN slams 'ragbag' rivals
fields.trailText: ITN has dismissed the consortium seeking to bid for the ITV news contract as a "ragbag partnership", writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITN has dismissed the consortium seeking to bid for the ITV news contract as a "ragbag partnership crafted from desperation".

"BSkyB has been touting round for potential partners for months," said an ITN spokesman.

"After all their efforts, they have ended up with two small UK broadcasters and two cost-cutting American outfits. It's a ragbag partnership crafted from desperation," he added.

The spokesman added that ITN already had access to CBS's video news footage. "We also have strategic alliances with NBC and CNN, both of whom are notably absent from the other grouping.

"It's ironic that this coalition is announced on the day that ITN beat BBC News by a margin on two to one in the battle of the 10pm bulletins," said the spokesman. "It's not great timing on BSkyB's part."

ITN executives believe ITV's largest shareholders, Granada Media and Carlton, which also each own a 20% stake in ITN, are not about to hand over the news supply contract to an outside bidder.

The two companies are lobbying the government for a relaxation in media ownership rules to allow them to increase their stakes in ITN.

ITN executives believe ITV's largest shareholders, Granada Media and Carlton, which also each own a 20% stake in ITN, are not about to hand over the news supply contract to an outside bidder. The two companies are lobbying the government for a relaxation in media ownership rules to allow them to increase their stakes in ITN.

webTitle: £2m to fight violence against social workers

fields.headline: £2m to fight violence against social workers
fields.trailText: A £2m campaign to reduce violence and abuse against social workers by 25% by March 2005 was launched by the government today. By David Batty
fields.body:
A £2m campaign to reduce violence and abuse against social workers by 25% by March 2005 was launched by the government today.

The funding comes in response to a new action plan developed by the national taskforce on violence against social care staff, which outlines measures to protect social care staff.

All 21,000 social care employers across England are being sent a copy of the taskforce's report, A Safer Place, on how to reduce the risk of staff being attacked by violent patients and clients.

The £2m will be administered by the National Training Organisation for Social Care (TOPSS) and used to improve training and qualifications across the social care workforce.

A study of violence conducted in 1999 by the National Institute of Social Work (NISW) found that almost half the 2,000 social care staff interviewed had been verbally abused in the previous year, almost a fifth threatened and one in eight physically attacked.

The national taskforce on violence against social care staff was set up in September 1999 by former health secretary Frank Dobson after the murder of south London social worker Jenny Morrison.

Low morale and fears about violent attacks are causing many people to leave the sector and have contributed to a serious recruitment crisis, particularly among social workers.

Health minister John Hutton said: "Violence, threats and abuse to staff is unacceptable.

"The government is determined to improve the safety of social care workers and volunteers who often face violence and abuse while at work.

"We should not and will not tolerate it - accepting violence is not part of the job."

He added: "The threat of violence causes fear and anxiety to many social care workers, puts many people off from working in the social care field, and makes others leave to work somewhere else."

Chris Davies, chairman of the task force, said: "We dedicate our work to all of our colleagues who have been abused, assaulted and killed in the course of seeking to follow a caring profession.

"We cannot rest content while workers in those occupations which provide the closet personal care and help for people are those who are most often abused."

webTitle: TS Eliot poetry award won by Michael Longley

fields.headline: Sun shines again on poet Longley
fields.trailText: It was poetry's clash of the titans - Walcott, Dunn, Gunn and Donaghy, the bardic equivalent of Joe Louis, Ken Buchanan, Gentleman Jim Corbett and Sugar Ray Leonard - slugging it out for its top prize.
fields.body:
It was poetry's clash of the titans - Walcott, Dunn, Gunn and Donaghy, the bardic equivalent of Joe Louis, Ken Buchanan, Gentleman Jim Corbett and Sugar Ray Leonard - slugging it out for its top prize.

But last night the £10,000 TS Eliot award was not won by any of the big name favourites on the most impressive shortlist in memory, but by Michael Longley, a soft spoken Ulsterman who once went 12 years without publishing a poem. Longley, 61, is used to being overlooked. Fate had already decreed that he should be cast as the "other" great poet to have come out of 60s Belfast, long toiling under the shadow of his famous friend, Seamus Heaney, the Nobel laureate.

This is the second big prize Longley has won for The Weather In Japan - he picked up the venerable Hawthornden award in the summer - a collection fellow Northern Irish poet Paul Muldoon, who chaired the judges, described as "at first glance small scale but which always expands our sense of history, be it of ancient Greece, second world war Germany or Northern Ireland. Longley is a skilled lyric poet of compassion and grace."

Gorse Fires, which broke his long silence through the 80s after he had made his name with No Continuing City and The Echo Gate, won a Whitbread award and established him as a European figure, gifted at drawing universal insight from a minute observation of nature.

Other poets on the list were Derek Walcott for Tiepolo's Hound, Thom Gunn for Boss Cupid; Douglas Dunn for The Year's Afternoon; Michael Donaghy for Conjure; John Burnside for The Asylum Dance; Anne Carson for Men In The Off Hours, Alan Jenkins for The Drift; Roddy Lumsden for The Book of Love and Anne Stevenson for Granny Scarecrow.

Meanwhile, the most lavish of the book prizes are leap-frogging over each other to go downmarket. First the £26,000 Whitbread awards - to be announced tonight - appointed a half-celebrity judging panel and said that they were "not a literary prize in any way".

And yesterday the revamped WH Smith book awards disclosed shortlists in which Nigella Lawson's and Jamie Oliver's cook books and Joanna Trollope's latest novel jostle with authors such as Margaret Atwood and Zadie Smith.

The £5,000 winners in all but one of nine categories will not be chosen by judges. They will be picked by internet surfers and customers who will vote in stores.

Sweetie Papers
Homage to Pierre Bonnard

When sweeties came back to
Mrs Parker's shop we
Drooled over the look of them
and smoothed out at home
Tinfoil and cellophane, a little
bit like Pierre
Bonnard's collection of
sweetie papers, his 'sparkles'
Pinned to the wall, light-
conductors for the late
Self-portraits as Japanese
soldier or collaborator
Punched and kicked in the face
until his eyes close
Or death camp survivor, the
skin across his chest
Transparent as cigarette
paper, and we gazed
Through the squares as
through a stained glass window
And almost understood why
the unremembered
People sheltering inside the
bombed cathedral
Would linger in the changing
light, then disappear
Before the end of the war and
the end of rationing.

Michael Longley

webTitle: Campaign to reduce violence follows a catalogue of deaths

fields.headline: Campaign to reduce violence follows a catalogue of deaths
fields.trailText: Analysis: The launch of a new campaign to reduce violence and abuse against social care workers follows the deaths of several staff attacked by violent clients. By David Batty
fields.body:
The launch of a new campaign to reduce violence and abuse against social care workers follows the deaths of several staff attacked by violent clients.

Ministers and representative bodies hope the new action plan will help to address the recruitment and retention crisis in the sector by ensuring employers implement tougher safeguards and staff receive better training on how to deal with violence.

Social worker Jenny Morrison, 51, was stabbed to death by Anthony Joseph, a paranoid schizophrenic, at the Thurleigh Road hostel in Balham, south London, in 1998.

The national taskforce on violence against social care staff, which drew up the new action plan to protect social care staff, was set up in the wake of her death.

She was killed in the hostel's isolated lounge - a room with no panic alarms and no easy escape route. There was only one member of staff, a woman, on duty.

An inquiry into her death revealed she was not informed that Joseph had previously been convicted for carrying a knife, had threatened mental hospital staff and had a history of sleeping with a machete under his pillow.

Ms Morrison joined Jonathan Newby, who was fatally attacked in 1993, Katie Sullivan, in 1992, and Isabel Schwartz, Norma Morris, Frances Betteridge and Audrey Johnson - all in the 1980s - on the roll of social care staff killed at work.

Many other staff suffer abuse ranging from insults and intimidation to physical and sexual assaults. A survey of 1,000 social workers for Community Care magazine last year found that 56% had been attacked by clients or their relatives.

About 22% said they had been attacked during the past year. Of those attacked, 22% said they had ended up in hospital as a result - one in eight of those interviewed - and 21% said the incident had made them consider leaving their job.

Almost half (46%) of those interviewed said they had received no violence training and 40% said they had entered potentially violent situations without what they considered to be adequate support.

webTitle: Loaded, Radio Times, and Management Today

fields.headline: Loaded, Radio Times, and Management Today
fields.trailText: MAKING EXECUTIVE DECISIONS, THE KENNY DALGLISH WAY
fields.body:
MAKING EXECUTIVE DECISIONS, THE KENNY DALGLISH WAY

Find yourself a company who will offer you a large sum of money for a role with an extremely vague job description. Like Director of golf at Celtic Football Club, for example. Install a man with no experience into one of the most high-profile and difficult posts in your industry. Leave said rookie - let's call him John Barnes - alone to make all the vital decisions while you have a few rounds (of golf). Watch things go totally tits up: perhaps Celtic lose at home against Inverness CT in the Scottish Cup, perhaps the fans are humiliated, perhaps John gets sacked and perhaps you, after winning a tribunal for unfair dismissal, get a cheque for £620,000.

Now for the difficult part: justifying your highly-paid actions. Firstly distance yourself from the loser you employed. Say something along the lines of: "It was John who signed all the players at Celtic. I don't know who was the worst although there were more bad ones than good ones." That should work, but in case of emergencies, keep something like this up your sleeve: "Obviously there was some consultation between us but, at the end of the day, the guy who is responsible for who plays [and] how we played is ultimately responsible for buying players."

By now, you should have distanced yourself from the worst of it, rendering your young charge almost totally unemployable. But it's always nice to chuck in the odd platitude, like: "John had the best start to a season of any Celtic manager other than Jock Stein, although Martin has now surpassed that." However, if the entire world sees through your desperate story, remember that the best executives know to hide in their bunker when the heat is on. An extended golfing holiday it is, then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FROM THE ITALIAN RADIO TIMES

All channels: The New Adventures of Silvio Berlusconi (8pm, repeated at 9pm, 10pm, 11pm, etc.)

From the team that brought you Silvio and the Resignation of the Italian National Coach (winner of the Golden Knob of Montrose) come seven new episodes of cheeky antics from everyone's favourite right-wing media magnate and owner of AC Milan.

1: Silvio and the well-edited video footage

Faithful journalists from Silvio's hit show Studio Aperto take a video camera to Milan nightclub Torqueville. They get great pictures of stars from AC Milan, Roma and Juventus cavorting on the dance floor the night after Serie A action. But when they get back to the studio - oh lordy lordy - only players from Serie A leaders Roma are visible! And only a week after Roma coach Fabio Capello told them to behave themselves off the pitch! What will Studio Aperto do? (Here's a hint, Silvio fans: they broadcast the footage during primetime on Silvio's Italia 1 channel!)

See if you can spot a special cameo by Silvio himself, cheekily shrugging his shoulders as criticism pours down on him from all sides!

What the critics said: "I spent less than one hour in that place. I couldn't sleep, so I went out with some team-mates to have a beer. I joked about with Andriy Shevchenko while I was there - that's it" - Well-known liar Gabriel Batistuta

"They were 'stolen images' that a freelance offered to us. They were recorded with a mini-camera. We thought it would be nice to show what the Roma squad were doing despite Capello's warning" - Intrepid Studio Aperto spokesman

Silvio a-go-go!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The game in England is physical and there is a lack of preparation. It is as though teams are making things up as they go along. There is clearly movement in English football, but it is only in a vertical direction" - Christian Karembeu has had time to consider his views on the English game. Like when he goes walkabout for Boro, for example.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RAIN MAN

When you're struggling knee-deep in the relegation mire, it doesn't just rain, it pours. And things are getting so wet round Coventry way, that you couldn't blame Wee Gord Strachan for going to bed in galoshes. He's been booed by the fans, lambasted by Cedric Roussell ("This is the way they reward me for my loyalty," the two-goal striker said of Cov's failed attempts to flog him to Wimbledon), and now even his family have turned on him.

Kind of. "My family don't come to the games any more," Wee Gord told the official Coventry City website. "My wife felt better when I was a player because at least I was on the field and could do something about it when things were going wrong. I don't think she feels great when I am isolated out there." One way of easing this problem of course would be to appoint Mrs Strachan as Director of Football. Something we hope Wee Gord will suggest to the Cov board.

Meanwhile, Strachan will have been comforted by the news that at least former skipper and longtime pal Gary McAllister is on his side. "Fans do get restless when things aren't going well but I can assure each and every one of them that no-one puts in more than Gordon", he said. More what, exactly? Anyway, as if to rub it in, Gord's day ended with the news that this afternoon Coventry's FA Youth Cup replay at Crewe has been postponed due to a waterlogged pitch. As we said, it doesn't just rain

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bradford striker Stanley Collymore has been linked with a move to Atletico Madrid.

Martin O'Neill has denied reports that Henrik Larsson will be leaving Celtic for Manchester United in a £15m deal. "That is the biggest lot of nonsense I have heard in a very, very long time," said O'Neill.

Sylvain Wiltord has confirmed he is happy at Arsenal, despite reports linking him with a move to Paris St Germain. "I like Arsenal and I'm not going to leave, especially after getting a few more chances in the starting line-up," he said.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Tottenham have admitted an interest in Southampton's Moroccan international Hassan Kachloul. Spurs director of football David Pleat said: "He is one of several players whose situations we are monitoring."

Bayern Munich striker Alexander Zickler has been approached by Liverpool. "It's a great honour for me," the 26-year-old German international said after training with Bayern on Tuesday. "The first talks will take place at the end of the week."

David James has agreed to sign a new three-and-a-half-year contract with Aston Villa after being assured that the club could fulfil his ambitions in the game.

Tony Adams is set to sign a new Arsenal contract to keep him at Highbury for two more years.

Aston Villa today announced a loss before tax of £2.6m for the six months up to November 30 last year. Chairman Doug Ellis admitted the latest figures were not helped by gate receipts and commercial revenue being reduced due to the demolition and reconstruction of the Trinity Road stand. Arsenal should escape expulsion from the FA Cup or a Premiership points deduction if their Lithuanian striker Tomas Danilevicius is expelled from Britain for carrying a false passport. A FA spokesman said Arsenal could only be punished if it was proven they knew Danilevicius had entered the country on a false Greek passport after signing from FC Lausanne.

Fulham have signed Danish international striker Peter Moller Neilsen on loan from Real Oviedo until the end of the season.

Huddersfield manager Lou Macari will face a FA hearing on February 13 following his sending-off against Portsmouth in December for an alleged push on the fourth official.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.15am) [stomp, whack, clang]

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.10am) What's the meaning of all this effing noise?

Channel 5: Style Tribes - Soccer (1.05am) [pencil jabbing, coffee pouring, general creating]

Argentine Football (4am) Gah! We might have known. It's McCaff!

Sky Sports 1: Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11.30pm) [sob, blub, gurn]

Live Second Division Football - Walsall v Rotherham (7.30pm, 12.30am) Hmm, he's unhappy because You're On Sky Sports! doesn't seem to be on this evening at all.

World Football Show (3.30am) [spoilt harrumphing, petulant screeching, incessant interrupting]

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) Stop it! Much more of that behaviour, young man, and you'll be getting a smack instead of a big hug.

fields.trailText: Serie A leaders Roma have reacted angrily to footage on a prime-time Italian TV show which showed several of their players partying after their 3-2 defeat against AC Milan this week.
fields.body:
Serie A leaders Roma have reacted angrily to footage on a prime-time Italian TV show which showed several of their players partying after their 3-2 defeat against AC Milan this week.

The programme Studio Aperto - broadcast on Silvio Berlusconi's Channel Italia 1 - showed Gabriel Batistuta dancing with a young girl, Francesco Totti laughing with friends, and Vincent Candela cheering and shouting in the popular Milan nightclub Toqueville.

No pictures were shown of Milan players, although several were at the same club, prompting accusations that Berlusconi, the owner of AC Milan, was trying to derail Roma's Scudetto bid.

However, a Studio Aperto spokesman claimed the footage was shown in response to Roma coach Fabio Capello's decision to ban his players from visiting bars and clubs - which came after his side's disappointing 1-1 home draw with Bari last week.

The spokesman added: "We thought it would be nice to show what the Roma squad were doing despite Capello's warning."

But Batistuta claimed Italia 1 had twisted the facts. "I spent less than one hour in that place," he said. "I couldn't sleep, so I went out with some team-mates to have a beer. I joked about with Andriy Shevchenko while I was there - that's it."

And Roma managing director Fabrizio Lucchesi added: "It is up to our players what they do in their free time. The club has nothing to say about what they do after matches until they are on the field to train again. I don't suppose players of other clubs confess their sins in church right after defeats."

The nightclub was also crowded with other Serie A stars on Sunday night, including several Juventus players.

fields.headline: Rivals in shock bid for ITV news deal
fields.standfirst:
Dec 12: law change threatens ITN
Nov 13: Sky in bid for ITV news
fields.trailText:
4.30pm : A heavyweight consortium including BSkyB and US giant CBS has made a dramatic bid to wrest the multimillion pound contract for ITV news from ITN writes Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll .
Dec 12: law change threatens ITN
Nov 13: Sky in bid for ITV news
fields.byline: By Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
A heavyweight consortium including BSkyB and US giant CBS has made a dramatic bid to wrest the multimillion pound contract for ITV news from ITN.

The consortium, which also includes leading global financial news provider Bloomberg, Chrysalis Group and Ulster TV, has written to ITV outlining its plans and asking for a meeting.

It has also approached the Independent Television Commission about becoming a nominated news provider to ITV, a step required before a formal bid can be made.

The current ITN contract expires at the end of 2002 but negotiations for the new supply deal have already begun.

ITV is eager to cut the cost of its news and will welcome the competition from the consortium.

Each of the five companies will take a 20% stake in the consortium.

"Our group believes there should be a strong element of healthy competition when the next ITV news supply contract is decided. Indeed we understand that ITV would welcome such competition," said a consortium spokesman.

BSkyB, which operates the highly-regarded 24-hour news channel Sky News, has in the past bid unsuccessfully for the ITV news supply contract.

Its link up with US network CBS, come of the legendary news stars such as Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather, make it a formidable rival to ITN.

Bloomberg gives added weight in the financial news area while Chrysalis brings experience as one of Britain's biggest independent production companies.

Chrysalis has already got strong links with ITV - its sports division produces ITV coverage of Formula One and drama hits such as Midsomer Murders. It also produces Channel 4's Football Italia and owns Heart radio franchises throughout the UK.

The dramatic bid to wrest ITN's £40m plus contract comes from just months after Sky opened talks with ITV about a possible solo bid for the contract.

At the time ITN bosses were dismissive of the move and claimed that Sky would never get the required approval from the ITC.

However, Sky News boss Nick Pollard has been determined to get his bid taken seriously and earlier this summer he wrote to the ITC seeking "nominated news provider" status.

At the moment the rules bar a solo bid from Sky because of the size of Rupert Murdoch's stake in the company. By limiting its stake to just 20 per cent of a consortium, Sky News immediately overcomes previous legal hurdles.

The decision to proceed with heavyweight partners such as CBS and Bloomberg means the bid is a serious threat to ITN and is a major setback to the company's plan for a flotation.

The ITV contract is the main source of income for the company and without it, ITN would not persuade the City to back a flotation.

fields.headline: BBC balloon axe surprises brand experts
fields.standfirst:
Jan 23: BBC scraps balloon logo
Jan 23: History of the balloon
fields.trailText:
1.45pm update: The BBC should ditch its balloon icon altogether rather than tamper with it, says a leading brand consultant. Daniel Rogers reports.
Jan 23: BBC scraps balloon logo
Jan 23: History of the balloon
fields.body:
The BBC would be better advised to ditch its balloon icon altogether rather than tampering with it, according to one of the UK's leading brand consultants.

"I don't think you can adapt an identity like the balloon and make it more down to earth. The BBC would be better off starting with a fresh brief if it thinks its culture has changed," said Rita Clifton, chief executive of Interbrand - the consultancy which transformed ICI into Zeneca and is currently advising Marks & Spencer.

The design industry has reacted with surprise at the news today that BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey is unhappy with the balloon ID.

Martin Lambie-Nairn, founder of the Lambie-Nairn consultancy, which created the ID in 1996, was not willing to comment.

Ms Clifton said British institutions constantly agonised about how to tackle the inherent tension between appearing both "big" and "friendly".

"Companies like British Airways and BT have wrestled with this for years. On the one hand they want stature, grace and distinction - such as provided by the BBC balloon - and yet there's always a requirement to be warm and friendly. It's so difficult to be a cuddly colussus."

She believes this is best tackled by starting afresh.

"The balloon is a powerful symbol but the arrival of Greg Dyke has signalled both change and energy. The BBC now needs to research its staff and customers about its new culture and start again."

However, Ms Clifton warns: "The strongest brands find truth within their organisations. External communications and presentation must reflect the BBC's true character. The public isn't stupid."
