webTitle: Health: Could Boris Becker have a love child?

fields.headline: Seminal truths
fields.standfirst: Angela Ermakowa's claim to be carrying Boris Becker's love child after a fumble in a broom cupboard raises a few biological questions for  Luisa Dillner
fields.trailText: Angela Ermakowa's claim to be carrying Boris Becker's love child after a fumble in a broom cupboard raises a few biological questions for Luisa Dillner.
fields.body:
Boris Becker having sex with a Russian woman in a broom cupboard in a Japanese restaurant is an unlikely story to begin with. For the woman, Angela Ermakowa, to claim she now has his love child (apparently backed up by genetic testing) is even more extraordinary.

But if you're wondering what the odds are of getting pregnant from one act of sex, don't bother. Becker is telling the media he didn't have sex with Angela at all. His lawyers allege that Angela targeted Becker, stealing his sperm and inseminating herself to have his baby. The plan, apparently involving the Russian Mafia, was to blackmail Becker over his "love child".

The case raises a few basic biology questions aside from how Angela hid her mouth full of semen. Their goodbyes must have been limited to nods. But can sperm live for any time outside the vagina? Could they survive being given a saliva bath by the mouth? And if you then inseminate these traumatised sperm, do they have it in them to battle through the hostile female reproductive tract to find their egg?

In fact, sperm can be inseminated (using fingers or more sophisticated syringes) from anywhere they've been deposited outside the vagina. "Its possible for a woman to become pregnant with sperm inseminated into the vagina that's been ejaculated outside," says Dr Steve Brody, of the Advanced Fertility Institute of San Diego. "When sperm is ejaculated it's a gel-like, viscous substance. Within five to 15 minutes it liquifies. This gel phase is probably a mechanism to protect the sperm cells in the initial phase of ejaculation. No one knows for sure why it comes out like this. It's only after it liquifies that it really becomes mobile."

There is some variation with the liquefaction; sperm can take 30 minutes to get going. According to Dr Brody, sperm in a test tube is still moving between 8 and 24 hours after a sample has been given. Sperm held in the mouth will not be damaged as long as it's protected in its gel-like form. "If you check sperm in the vagina two hours after intercourse then most of them are immobilised," says Dr Brody. "They've lost their gel protection. The vagina is acid and semen is alkaline so maybe that's also why they have this coating."

Remarkably few sperm are actually produced with each ejaculation. There's usually 2-6 millilitres (about one half to a teaspoon), which contains between 200-300 million sperm and a mixture of sugar, protein, vitamin C, zinc and prostaglandins (the latter help the sperm travel through the womb). The sperm only make up 5% of the volume. And as anyone dieting will tell you, it's low in calories - just five per teaspoonful.

Immature sperm cells are present in baby boys but need the surge in hormones at puberty to grow into big sperm. Men make millions of sperm effortlessly a day. This is because a sperm's life is perilous and short. Many try to make babies but few succeed. Maybe only 20 of those millions get even close to meeting their egg.

They have to journey up through the vagina, through the womb and into the fallopian tubes that lead to the egg (if there is one, since it's a once-monthly event from the ovaries). Despite most sperm being paralysed by their protective gel, some are mobile as soon as they've landed. Studies show the early sperm reach the fallopian tubes in five minutes, with most of the others getting there by 45 minutes.

"It may be the sperm that get in right away that have the most chance of fertilising the egg," says Dr Brody. "A study in rabbits shows that if you destroy all the sperm in the vagina within five minutes the rabbit still gets pregnant." Humans, of course, don't breed like rabbits. In fact if, as Becker claims, Angela planned to get pregnant, she was incredibly lucky to do so from one lot of sperm. Even a healthy 18-year-old couple, says Dr Brody, only have a 24% chance of getting pregnant from having sex once. Ever wondered why there are so many rats these days? Their equivalent pregnancy rate is 90%.

And if this was a plan to produce another baby Becker, Angela (who at 33 has considerably reduced fertility compared with an 18 year old) would have had to know when she was ovulating. Preferably she would have read the recent research paper in the New England Journal that revolutionised current thinking on fertility.

Traditionally the most fertile period was said to be the day the egg is released (ovulation which occurs around the 14th or 15th day of the menstrual cycle) and the next day. But this latest research shows it's the day before and the day of ovulation that are the most fertile. An egg only lives for about a day but sperm can be sniffing around far longer. "You can find sperm around 85 hours after they've been ejaculated," says Dr Brody. "It's possible for a woman to get pregnant from having sex six days before she ovulates."

While paternity is easy to decide, it may be impossible to prove whether Becker did have sexual intercourse with Ermakowa. Becker's lawyers may argue that Ermakowa stole his sperm to fertilise herself, which could put a whole new spin on the act of ejaculation. Rather than being freely given will men start asking for their sperm back (saying it was only a loan)? Like Bill Clinton, Becker may rue his misconception that oral equals safe sex.

webTitle: Health: Diary of a marathon runner

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: Like a thick fog lifting from the scene of a major accident, things have become clearer with my body. I'm starting to understand how it relates to my brain, and it is beginning to adjust to its new, unwanted schedule of pain. My bottom, it may interest you, has begun to take shape. And running, while not fun, is becoming less of a chore.
fields.body:
Like a thick fog lifting from the scene of a major accident, things have become clearer with my body. I'm starting to understand how it relates to my brain, and it is beginning to adjust to its new, unwanted schedule of pain. My bottom, it may interest you, has begun to take shape. And running, while not fun, is becoming less of a chore.

Two important things in the marathon training plan are working well. I'm on schedule and my running mate Fran - who doubles as my flatmate - is not doing as well as me. This source of satisfaction must be worth at least an extra mile each time we go out.

But the first big test has come and gone. The schedule demands one long run a week. Every training schedule tells you the same: you can mess around with three or four short jogs, but the long run is crucial. It gets your body into a sort of metronomic state, your legs moving at a constant pace, mile after mile, hour after hour.

You build it up from 60 minutes to around three-hour jogs in the run up to the big day. Throughout the training period you're told that the golden rule is that you must not run too fast. What is desirable is to achieve what is called "steady state running" - a speed at which you can still chat to your running mate without being sick or collapsing.

I managed to complete a 75-minute run over the weekend. Past the burned-out cars, carcasses of stolen mopeds, dog mess - the waste that is north London. By the end instead of feeling exhausted, ready to die, I actually felt like running faster. It was a kind of exhilarating feeling knowing that you could go on - even wanting to go on. The second rule of golden rule of training, however, came into play: don't overdo it.

fields.headline: Alternative hero
fields.standfirst: Father of scientific medicine or complete crackpot? We know very little about Hippocrates, but more and more of his wild notions seem to be bearing fruit, says  Oliver Burkeman
fields.trailText: Father of scientific medicine or complete crackpot? We know very little about Hippocrates, but more and more of his wild notions seem to be bearing fruit, says Oliver Burkeman.
fields.body:
Ancient Greece was not a good place to get sick. Standards of public sanitation might have been world-beating at the time, and scientific understanding unrivalled - but nowhere near the standards, say, of the most dilapidated and fetid of Victorian public hospitals.

And so it often seems incongruous that one of the authorities most frequently cited by scientists unveiling innovative new health treatments today is an ancient-Greek physician about whom we know almost nothing except that the majority of his medical theories were complete nonsense. And that he almost certainly wore a beard.

The latest example emerged last week with a study in the British Medical Journal demonstrating that the agnus castus fruit - otherwise known as the chaste berry - offers effective treatment for many of the symptoms of pre-menstrual syndrome. Rued Schellenberg, a researcher at the Institute of Care and Science near Frankfurt, administered dried extract of the fruit to 86 women and found that more than 50% demonstrated a significant improvement in the incidence of irritability, mood alteration, anger, headache and breast soreness.

It sounded like a hopeful innovation - but the idea of exploiting the medicinal properties of the chaste berry had a rather more venerable origin: Hippocrates of Cos, born around 460BC, died, as far as we know, 377BC.

The centrality of Hippocrates to modern medicine, of course, is nothing new. He is partially, responsible both for its most fundamental philosophical foundations - the idea of the body as an organic whole and of diagnosis as science, instead of religious prognostication - and its most hackneyed platitudes: the importance to good health of fresh air, the right food and exercise, along with plenty of bed-rest and the occasional aspirin (another innovation with Hippocratic origins) in the event of sickness.

The rest has long been dismissed as preposterous, from the theory of the four humours - according to which all illness resulted from the imbalance of yellow bile, black bile, phlegm and blood - to diagnosis by smell, whereby a patient reeking of stale beer indicated tuberculosis and the aroma of freshly baked bread pointed to typhoid. The Hippocratic Oath, the archetypal statement of medical ethics - complete with its strictures against "the seduction of females or males, of freemen and slaves" - is certainly not his work.

But attitudes are changing, and a flurry of recent findings have established mainstream medical explanations for the efficacy of herbal remedies that have their origins in Hippocrates' writings. Chief among them is St John's Wort, recommended by Hippocrates as a treatment for demonic possession and now well on the way to medical respectability as a cure for depression.

"What is intriguing is that Hippocrates used to be seen as the father of orthodox, scientific medicine - the first to develop rational theories of health and disease," says Philip van der Eijk, professor of Greek at Newcastle University and an expert on Hippocrates. "But now, complementary and alternative medicine, which seeks to resist and challenge the authority of orthodox medicine, is trying to construct its own image of Hippocrates as a natural healer."

Helpfully for both schools of thought, we know almost nothing about Hippocrates the man. He undoubtedly worked as some kind of physician on Kos, where he founded a medical school. But the 60 works that form the modern canon of Hippocratic writings are at best summaries of his work written by his students - and, at worst, nothing to do with him at all.

"In the 19th and early 20th centuries, when medicine was seeking professionlisation and prestige, people were happy to talk of Hippocrates in the ethical sense," says Rebecca Flemming, a lecturer in ancient medicine at King's College, London. "Now, complementary medicine has colonised him because he is holisitic. But he was used in the same way in the ancient world: as a legendary figure used by everybody to legitimate what they were doing. We actually know almost nothing."

Ironically, the ancient thinker who did the most to separate religion from medical science has taken on something of the status of a god, to be invested with whatever meaning the medics of the time require. "People have always sought to appeal to an earlier authority to bolster their own agenda," says professor van der Eijk. "Chinese medicine is another example: much of what is called traditional Chinese medicine is a construct of the 1950s and the 1960s, an eclectic system of prescriptions and therapies that bears no resemblance to the historical tradition."

And, of course, hypothesising that a plant might be able to cure demonic possession, or rid a patient of the smell of stale beer, is a long way from identifying and measuring its real effects on a real condition. "The concept of PMT, as you might imagine," notes Dr Flemming wryly, "was not very current in the ancient world."

But attitudes are changing, and a flurry of recent findings have established mainstream medical explanations for the efficacy of herbal remedies that have their origins in Hippocrates' writings. Chief among them is St John's Wort, recommended by Hippocrates as a treatment for demonic possession and now well on the way to medical respectability as a cure for depression. "What is intriguing is that Hippocrates used to be seen as the father of orthodox, scientific medicine - the first to develop rational theories of health and disease," says Philip van der Eijk, professor of Greek at Newcastle University and an expert on Hippocrates. "But now, complementary and alternative medicine, which seeks to resist and challenge the authority of orthodox medicine, is trying to construct its own image of Hippocrates as a natural healer." Helpfully for both schools of thought, we know almost nothing about Hippocrates the man. He undoubtedly worked as some kind of physician on Kos, where he founded a medical school. But the 60 works that form the modern canon of Hippocratic writings are at best summaries of his work written by his students - and, at worst, nothing to do with him at all. "In the 19th and early 20th centuries, when medicine was seeking professionlisation and prestige, people were happy to talk of Hippocrates in the ethical sense," says Rebecca Flemming, a lecturer in ancient medicine at King's College, London. "Now, complementary medicine has colonised him because he is holisitic. But he was used in the same way in the ancient world: as a legendary figure used by everybody to legitimate what they were doing. We actually know almost nothing." Ironically, the ancient thinker who did the most to separate religion from medical science has taken on something of the status of a god, to be invested with whatever meaning the medics of the time require. "People have always sought to appeal to an earlier authority to bolster their own agenda," says professor van der Eijk. "Chinese medicine is another example: much of what is called traditional Chinese medicine is a construct of the 1950s and the 1960s, an eclectic system of prescriptions and therapies that bears no resemblance to the historical tradition." And, of course, hypothesising that a plant might be able to cure demonic possession, or rid a patient of the smell of stale beer, is a long way from identifying and measuring its real effects on a real condition. "The concept of PMT, as you might imagine," notes Dr Flemming wryly, "was not very current in the ancient world."

webTitle: Health: Dr Ann Robinson answers your questions

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Is my child autistic? | Polycystic ovaries | Is football crazy?
fields.body:
Is he autistic?

Question

I'm desperately worried about my three-year-old son. His speech is reasonable but he doesn't speak much and seems to live in a world of his own. He started nursery recently which I was hoping would make him more sociable, but the nursery teachers say he plays on his own and gets very upset if interrupted. With all this talk about the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella - which he had), I'm worried that he may be autistic. How can I find out if there's anything wrong?

Answer

Once you get it into your head that your child may have a serious problem, I think it's better to grasp the nettle and get an expert assessment. You may be worrying about nothing, but why not speak to your health visitor and GP and ask for referral to a community paediatrician for an assessment?

The three major aspects of autism are difficulty with social interaction, communication, and imagination. Highly repetitive behaviour such as insisting on one video over and over again can be another sign, though to a certain extent all toddlers do that.

A Checklist for Autism in Toddlers is available from the National Autistic Society (NAS) and provides a useful indicator as to whether you have grounds for concern. Early diagnosis opens the door to professional support and educational assistance and helps your child to progress so don't be fobbed off until you're satisfied that you've had an expert assessment. NAS Parent helpline: 0870 600 8585.

Polycystic ovaries

Question

I have very irregular periods and have been told that I have polycystic ovaries. I am very worried about this and don't know the long-term implications. Does it mean I will find it hard to get pregnant? Will it cause me increased risk of cancer of the ovaries? How can I get more information?

Answer

One third of UK women are estimated to have polycystic ovaries, which means that there are 10 or more cysts on each ovary. One third of women with these ovarian cysts also have symptoms such as unwanted facial hair, acne, erratic periods and particular difficulty losing excess weight. The ovarian cysts together with the symptoms are known as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). You are at increased risk of diabetes because resistance to the effects of insulin is part and parcel of PCOS.

As far as I know, there's no increased risk of ovarian cancer. For most women, it is dealing with the symptoms which is most important. Erratic or absent periods may become a major concern when you're trying to get pregnant. Losing excess weight often helps many of the symptoms and helps to prevent diabetes.

The drug Metformin, which is used to treat diabetes, can aid weight loss if all else fails. Clomid can kick-start your ovaries into action if they remain sluggish. The oral contraceptive pill may help control excess hair and avoid osteoporosis. Most women with PCOS never know they've got it and get pregnant without any trouble.

PCOS self-help group: Verity 52-54 Featherstone Street, London EC1Y 8RT.

Is football crazy?

Question

I'm a 48-year-old, rather unfit and tubby man. Football has been a spectator sport for me since I left school. But now my son has persuaded me to join a fathers' five-a-side team. We had a training session last week which practically killed me. The next day, I could hardly move I was so stiff and achey. But I did enjoy it - especially the social afterwards. Is it safe to continue?

Answer

It's great that you've got off the couch and on to the pitch, but I'd advise a little caution. You've leapt from nothing to all in terms of aerobic exercise. You should ideally try to make the football the centrepiece of your exercise programme, but have two or three shorter bouts of gentle exercise on other days. A 20-minute jog or a swim would do.

Before the game, warm up properly, get a physiotherapist or coach to show you how to stretch and follow a warm-down routine. If you experience any chest pain or the shortness of breath doesn't improve, you need to have a check up of your lungs and heart.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help.

 If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Teamworks faces closure
fields.trailText: 4pm: Marketing agency Teamworks is to meet its creditors with a view to going into liquidation, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Marketing agency Teamworks has called a meeting of creditors for the end of the month with a view to placing the company into liquidation.

An official notice from managing director Robert Punter has been posted on insolvency.co.uk.

It invites creditors to attend a meeting "for the purpose, if thought fit, of nominating a liquidator and of appointing a liquidation committee".

The creditors meeting will take place in Reading on January 31.

Teamworks has pulled down its website and repeated calls to its London office were picked up by an answer machine.

Only two years ago, Teamworks, a technology specialist, embarked on an expansion drive and moved its head office from Basingstoke to London.

At the end of 2000, the agency completed the merger of its London and Basingstoke operations and made an effort to relaunch.

Last year, the agency, which employed 60 staff, was hiring top names.

One of its last high-profile recruits was Colin Wheeler, formerly Bozell's client services director for Europe, the middle east and Africa.

He was appointed business development director in May.

Teamworks's client list included Hewlett-Packard, Nicotinell, Ascend Communications, Datatec, Logical Networks, Loral Skynet, Perkin-Elmer, Racal and Raytheon.

In April 1999 the company set up a new-media arm, Teamworks Interactive, which is also facing closure.

fields.headline: Daily Mail joins Guardian to launch Manchester Metro
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: The Daily Mail and Guardian have formed an unlikely alliance to launch the Metro freesheet in Manchester, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail and Guardian newspapers have formed an unlikely alliance to launch the Metro freesheet in Manchester.

The Guardian Media Group has licensed its Manchester Metro title to Daily Mail owner Associated Newspapers after months of behind-the-scenes negotiations.

It ends a brief circulation war between the two parties, which saw the Manchester Metro competing with Associated's News North West.

"Clearly the free newspaper market has been a great success in London, but there is not enough room for two free titles in the same city, so it's a logical decision," said Ian Ashcroft, chief executive of GMG regional newspapers.

The Manchester Metro newspaper will now close and the new title will launch on February 12 with a circulation of 110,000.

Under the deal GMG will run the local advertising sales operation while DMGT will supply editorial and maintain control of national advertising.

GMG already has a strong hold in Manchester thanks to its ownership of the Manchester Evening News and 30 weekly newspapers in the Greater Manchester area.

"We have said for a while that we found it hard to believe that two free newspapers could be supported in any city the size of Manchester," said Peter Williams, finance director at parent company Daily Mail & General Trust.

"It will be the equivalent of our London and Birmingham Metros, and joins the Metro club."

Associated publishes Metro in London, Birmingham, Newcastle, Leeds, Sheffield, Glasgow and Edinburgh, although today's deal could signal the limit of its ambitions.

"This concept does not work everywhere. You need the right size of city, the right kind of readers and the right kind of commuting public," added Mr Williams.

Associated's plan with Metro is to form alliances with publishers who dominate local markets, such as Trinity Mirror & Regional Independent Media.

Metro's daily circulation of nearly 800,000 makes it the sixth largest morning national newspaper.

fields.headline: Main points of plan
fields.trailText: The new campaign to reduce violence against social care workers proposes improved staff training, better monitoring of violent incidents and national performance targets for employers.
fields.body:
The new campaign to reduce violence against social care workers proposes improved staff training, better monitoring of violent incidents and national performance targets for employers.

The national action plan, drawn up by the national task force on violence against social care staff, aims to reduce violence against staff by 25% over the next five years. Its main recommendations are:

 The Department of Health should commission research to address gaps in the knowledge and training about violence for social care managers and workers.
 National occupational standards for social work and care should include safe working practice related to the risk of violence in its next review.
 The training support grant for violence training should be increased by 50% to £3m next year, and continue at that level for another two years.
 The emerging General Social Services Council's code of practice for social care employers should include a standard that sets out employers' responsibilities for the safety of their workers.
 The new national care standards commission should inspect all regulated employers against that standard.
 The social services inspectorate should include that standard in its annual performance assessment of all social services departments.
 Employers should be subject to external monitoring by other regulatory bodies, such as Ofsted and the Commission for Health Inspection.
 All employers should carry out an audit and action plan relating to violence against staff, and identify what further training is needed by October 31 2001.
 They should remedy any problems identified by their audit, compile comprehensive data on violence against staff and start to implement a new training strategy by March 31 2002.
 They must reduce violence against their staff by 25% by March 31 2005.

fields.headline: BBC balloon burst by Heggessey
fields.standfirst: Jan 23: BBC scraps balloon logo
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Lorraine Heggessey's decision to scrap the hot air balloon will surprise many, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Lorraine Heggessey's decision to scrap the hot air balloon so soon after it was introduced will surprise many, not least the head of presentation at the BBC.

Just four weeks ago he told how warm the public's response to the balloon had been.

"It's been tremenduously popular," he said.

"We're happy to continue with it, but we're looking for witty, warmer ways of updating it," said Peter Robertson, chief assistant, broadcasting and presentation, who has monitored the public's response.

Also in for a shock will be design consultants Lambie-Nairn, who were charged with overhauling BBC1's rather remote image underlined by the spinning globe ident that popped up between programmes.

The globe had been inspired by BBC1's first image back in 1963 when it chose to emphasise its position as one of the world's most prestigious broadcasting organisations with a globe.

At first it was black and white and it changed to colour in 1969.

But in 1996 director of television Alan Yentob explained it was time to move on again.

"The globe has always been associated with the BBC flagship channel and the choice of a balloon seemed an imaginative way of emphasising the universal appeal of BBC1," Mr Yentob said at the time.

And just four weeks ago the enthusiasm for the balloon films seemed as strong as ever.

"It was one of those rare occaasions when the client just says, 'Absolutely. Yes. Gotta have it.' In fact, the reaction was great from everyone," Martin Lambie-Nairn told the Radio Times.

At first the balloon films were restricted to just 10 of Britain's most famous landmarks including Eilean Donan Castle in Scotland, the Giant's Causeway in Antrim and Canary Wharf.

Now there are more than 30 locations including the Millennium Dome, the New Severn Bridge, Blackpool Tower, and industrial sites such as Felixtowe container port, Suffolk.

And to mark Christmas a special Santa Claus version was designed.

The image of the red and orange globe balloon rising above the lakeside castle in Eilean Donan has proved the most popular image with viewers.

"The way it is shot is different from other channel identities. Other channels employ quick cuts and logos and it's all very fast, but this is calm," said Mr Lambie Nairn in an interview with the Radio Times at Christmas.

"It shows you can grab people's attention by being silent, just as you can by shouting at them."

fields.headline: Politicians condemn BBC news bulletin
fields.standfirst:
Jan 23: News veterans square up over ratings
Jan 23: ITV owes victory to Millionaire
Jan 23: ITV wins landslide victory
Jan 23: BBC and ITV in news row
Last night's running orders
Jan 18: BBC plans 'brighter' news
fields.trailText:
2.45pm update: Opposition parties have rounded on the BBC for going head to head with ITV with its news bulletin, reports Jessica Hodgson.
1pm: News veterans square up over ratings
12.45pm: ITV owes victory to Millionaire
11am: ITV wins landslide victory
10.15am: BBC and ITV in news row
Last night's running orders
Jan 18: BBC plans 'brighter' news
fields.body:
Opposition parties rounded on the BBC today for narrowing viewers' choice with the head-to-head battle of the TV news bulletins.

"It's not in the interests of the viewers for the two main channels to have their news bulletins going head to head," said the Liberal Democrat spokesman for broadcasting Norman Baker.

"Greg Dyke is trying to be too clever by half by moving the news. In the public interest, he should move the news back to 9 o'clock."

And shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said the BBC had scored an own goal.

"The BBC's decision to move the news was a commercial one and it ill behoves them to complain when they are treated to a bit of competition in return," he said.

"It cannot be in the viewers' interests. The BBC chose to move the news opportunistically to give them greater freedom, and the impetus is on them to move it back.

"This raises important issues about the BBC's ability to regulate itself, and strengthens the argument that the BBC should be brought under independent scrutiny," he said.

fields.headline: High-profile court cases 'may be televised'
fields.trailText: 3pm: High-profile court cases, such as the recent hearing over conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, may be televised in the future.
fields.body:
High-profile cases such as the Pinochet hearings and the court battle over conjoined twins Jodie and Mary might be televised in the future, it was disclosed today.

Pilot schemes to allow cameras into "appellant" cases - Court of Appeal or House of Lords cases with no witnesses, juries or defendants present - might be under way within five years should demand exist, the Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine said.

"If I was satisfied that there was a demand and if I was satisfied that we could set up pilots, I would discuss it with the higher judiciary and I would not set my face against it," he told the Commons home affairs select committee.

Appellant proceedings of particular public interest might be televised allowing the public to be better informed about the judicial process, he said.

"We can think of many cases recently where there would be a very valuable educative effect potentially in that, for example, the Siamese twins case and, for example, perhaps even the Pinochet case," he said.

But Lord Irvine told MPs that he would "draw a line in the sand" with appellant cases and would not allow cameras into courts to televise trials.

He expressed his "hostile" attitude to televised trials after the US court case involving British au pair Louise Woodward.

"There is a great, great risk that the behaviour and judgment of lawyers, witnesses and indeed the jury itself might be affected by the knowledge that they were participating in a live media event," he told the committee.

fields.headline: Revolution
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 24
fields.trailText: January 24: United Business Media has begun talks about selling top music site dotmusic.
fields.body:
Rivals are set to launch a bidding war for leading music site dotmusic after owner United Business Media started talks on a sale.

Online student bookseller Buyitback.net has gone into receivership only two months after receiving funding from Hollinger Telegraph New Media.

Freeserve is hoping to steal a march on rival BTinternet by launching a package offeringe unmetered web access.

Internet and digital radio station Storm Live is relaunching its entertainment portal following a redesign of the site.

Digital download music site iCrunch is to outsource ad sales and is believed to have shortlisted Que Pasa and The Worldpop Advertising Network.

Community site themutual.net has made 13 of its 19 staff redundant to cut costs.

BSkyB has outlined plans to increase its online live video streaming and video-on-demand content by signing a deal with US group Digital Island.

US music download and entertainment giant Planet is searching for UK and European partners as it gears up for a UK launch.

MTV will enable viewers to interact in real time - using text messaging, WAP and the net - with a live daily TV show, to launch next month.

fields.headline: Hatfield driver cleared of blame
fields.standfirst:
Today's interim report absolves the driver while revealing that the track broke into 300 pieces

Special report: Hatfield train crash
Cartoon: Steve Bell
Source document: Second interim report on Hatfield - Health and Safety Executive
fields.trailText: The driver of the train in the Hatfield rail crash was not to blame, a second interim report into the accident disclosed today.
fields.body:
The driver of the train in the Hatfield rail crash was not to blame, a second interim report into the accident disclosed today.

The report, from the Health and Safety Executive, found that: "some flaws were evident in the operation of the driver training scheme" as the train's driver was a trainee with seven weeks experience, although he was accompanied by a fully-qualified supervisor.

The report said that according to GNER's training regime, a trainee should not have been in control of a train at high speed.

However, the HSE added that the driver was under close supervision, and there was "no evidence that these circumstances contributed in any way to the cause of the derailment".

The report also disclosed that a section of rail at the crash site broke into more than 300 pieces.

A painstaking reconstruction of the fragments showed that there were multiple pre-existing cracks at or near the surface of the rail. A visual examination of the fragmented section of rail also showed that there was extensive flaking of metal, or spalling, the report said.

The cracks in the rail were examples of the track fatigue phenomenon known as "gauge corner cracking", or what the HSE described as "rolling contact fatigue".

Railtrack uses ultrasonic methods to inspect rail defects. However, the HSE report said: "These techniques do not appear to have been developed specifically for the detection of rolling contact fatigue cracks."

The HSE said an independent testing expert has been involved in reviewing Railtrack's current ultrasonic procedures, guided by the finding of the Hatfield investigation.

The report said Railtrack had overall responsibility for the track, while the maintenance on this section was supplied by engineering contractor Balfour Beatty.

Before the derailment there were proposals to renew the length of rail in question, and the most recent visual inspection of the rail was during the week prior to the derailment.

Railtrack's standard contract with Balfour Beatty included the provision, if necessary, of speed restrictions. However, there were no speed restrictions in place at the time of the accident.

Senior Railtrack and Balfour Beatty executives could face manslaughter charges over the Hatfield crash, it emerged at the weekend.

The HSE said in today's report: "Subject to there being sufficient evidence, a prosecution will be considered under the Health and Safety at Work Act.

"But if there is evidence of criminal negligence, the Crown Prosecution Service will first be asked by British Transport Police to consider a charge of manslaughter."

Four people died and 70 were injured in the accident, which happened when a London to Leeds GNER express train, travelling at around 115-117mph, derailed just south of Hatfield on October 17 last year.

The train was carrying 170 passengers and 12 GNER staff.

The four who died, plus the two people most seriously injured, were all in the buffet car, which became uncoupled from the carriage behind, overturned, then collided with at least two overhead power line masts.

Another carriage also became uncoupled, and the report said the failure of the two couplers "may have contributed to the secondary vehicle collisions and overall vehicle instability".

The report said: "All the evidence points to the derailment having been caused by fracture and subsequent fragmentation of a rail between Welham Green and Hatfield on a right-hand curve."

The report also found there was nothing wrong with the train or the signals, and no evidence of vandalism.

Today's report followed an initial interim report published just three days after the accident. A full, final HSE report will be published later this year.

fields.headline: BBC scraps balloon logo
fields.trailText: 9.15pm The BBC is to axe its popular hot air balloon logo less than four years after it was introduced, writes Lisa O'Carroll .
fields.body:
The BBC is to axe its popular hot air balloon logo less than four years after it was introduced.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey says the balloon which flies over more than 30 British landmarks including Tower Bridge and Canary Wharf in London is "irrelevant".

"To be honest, the balloon to me feels very slow; it goes across this majestic landscape but doesn't feel in touch with the viewers," she said.

And it will surprise many who believe the calming sight of the balloon rising from some of Britain's most scenic spots has become a viewers' favourite.

Just four weeks ago, the BBC's Radio Times reported how popular the balloon was, and even invited readers to write in if they had any ideas for new locations for the balloon films.

The balloon was introduced in October 1997, when the BBC decided to axe the spinning globe which flashed up between programmes and replace it with the "friendlier" image of the red and yellow hot air ballon.

The move sparked protests because the BBC was forking out more than £5m to introduce the logo and new lettering for its buildings, vehicles, magazines, notepaper and merchandising. Filming the balloon alone cost £500,000.

At the time critics slammed the BBC for spending money on make-overs too frequently - the spinning globe existed for just seven years.

In today's Independent Ms Heggessey, who was appointed head of BBC1 last September, says she wants to give the station a harder image.

She says she wants to transform the whole "feel and tone" of BBC1 and get away from the image of the corporation as a nannying force that knows what's best for viewers.

"I hate the word 'Auntie'. Auntie suggests somebody who is at least a whole generation older than you, a little remote from you, not part of your immediate family.

"BBC1 is starting to suffer from that image now. The broad strategy is as much about tone and style as it is about content - to feel warmer, more modern.

"The BBC has always been truthful and impartial and has always had integrity. Now we need to emphasis the softer approach, talking on the same level as our viewers, feeling more relevant," she said.

Ms Heggessey however insists BBC1 is "not going to go all pink and fluffy".

"I was a producer on Panorama. I went undercover in the Soviet Union. I was a journalist," she said emphasising her interest in hard news.

Ms Heggessey also admits that she made a mistake in the Christmas schedules, by screening The Ballad of Big Al - a spin off from Walking with Dinosaurs - on Christmas Day.

The show did badly in the ratings.

"In retrospect, I was wrong to put in on Christmas Day. I thought 'this is fantastic for BBC1 - to put a science programme on for Christmas Day'. But people weren't in the mood for it," she admitted.

webTitle: Blueprint for rural renewal drawn up

fields.headline: Blueprint for rural renewal drawn up
fields.trailText: Blueprints to revitalise 100 market towns and 1,000 rundown villages are to be developed by the countryside agency, which will provide grants for essential services such as public transport.
fields.body:
Blueprints to revitalise 100 market towns and 1,000 rundown villages are to be developed by the countryside agency, which will provide grants for essential services such as public transport.

The agency, created by the government a year ago with a budget of £55m this year and £70m next, has produced a strategy to deal with rural area problems made worse by the collapse of farm incomes which have cost 41,000 jobs in the past two years.

Ewen Cameron, chairman of the agency, said: "The challenges facing the countryside are far wider than the farming crisis or the future of hunting. We want to set off a quiet revolution in towns and villages to give people control over their lives."

Around 20% of the population lives in areas classed as rural. While many rich people have moved to the country to retire or commute long distances to work the plight of the rural poor remains dire, according to the agency.

Eighteen rural districts fall within the most deprived 100 in the country. These include large areas of Cornwall, parts of Devon and Somerset, the Isle of Thanet in Kent, and the Isle of Wight.

In the north, Berwick-upon-Tweed, Pendle in Lancashire, the Wear Valley in Durham, and Scarborough in North Yorkshire all qualify.

Among programmes to be started by the agency is a training programme for parish clerks and councillors so they know what the best councils in the country are achieving and how to tap into the grant system. At the moment, parish councils can apply for £10,000 each to start local transport initiatives, but much of the money is unused through lack of applications.

Another scheme is a village- by-village indentification of sites for affordable homes for children of rural dwellers. They are often priced out of village homes because of the influx of second home owners and retired people.

These sites and the houses on them would be reserved for local people. In this way, communities would remain balanced, rather than composed of older country folk and rich incomers.

The agency is to provide health checks for market towns to measure the level of services - transport, banks, businesses, employment, health, education and housing.

One example of a town revitalised was Ulverston in the Lake District, where £2.3m was put in for regeneration and revived local services and new businesses followed, Mr Cameron said. More than 50 new businesses had started up creating 150 new jobs.

Mr Cameron will be on the Countryside Alliance march on central London on March 17, which is being organised to highlight rural concerns but its mainly a focus on the fox hunting debate.

He said yesterday: "I realise hunting is important to certain members of the rural community. Frankly, it is a distraction that takes people's attention away from serious issues like farming, affordable homes, transport and rural services."

Mr Cameron has the job of "rural advocate" - intervening when government policies could be adapted to help rural areas. The agency is attempting to improve new technology links to rural areas.

The agency is also mapping rights of way and improving access to the countryside. This is seen as a direct way of increasing rural incomes by attracting weekend visitors to rural pubs and shops.

webTitle: Arts: Andrew Pulver meets Martin Amis

fields.headline: 'You lying hippies'
fields.standfirst: Martin Amis tells Andrew Pulver about novels, movie-making and the 1970s
fields.trailText: Martin Amis tells Andrew Pulver about novels, movie-making and the 1970s
fields.body:
This week marks a rare event in the career of Martin Amis: the release of a film based on one of his books. This is only the second time in almost 30 years of publishing that such an incident has come to pass. Back in 1975, Dead Babies was Amis's second novel, and now it has become the second Amis adaptation. "Never second-guess the movies," he says, almost wearily. "The only time you can be sure they're going to make a movie of your book is when the film has been out for a couple of weeks. Then it's definitely going to happen."

At 51, Amis appears inured to the unenthusiastic reception that film-makers have given to his oeuvre. "No," he says, "I don't mind. I've noticed some of my writer friends have been taken up - but it's not a frontline concern. You're just making trouble for yourself if you get too involved in all these things. Years ago, I wrote a script for The Rachel Papers. I wrote a script for Dead Babies, too. But now I wouldn't dream of writing a script from my own stuff." The script used in the new film was actually by William Marsh, who also directed.

Amis is terrifyingly spry, sitting bolt upright in an armchair, and hardly moving except to take drags from the ever-smouldering cigarette. He doesn't seem to like having his picture taken, initially refusing to look directly into the camera lens. But after a little cajoling, he complies, sucking in his cheeks as he does so. Then he talks with self-conscious sonority - very slowly, in fully formed sentences. You can hear the punctuation: the semi-colons, the italics, the ellipses.

"I used to say to myself, 'It's a shame I haven't written a script of my own,' " Amis continues. "Ian McEwan is pretty disillusioned with writing movies - but he had a wonderful start with The Ploughman's Lunch, where he and Richard Eyre bloody well got it through pretty much in accordance with how he imagined it. That's still an appealing thing: if you really saw eye to eye with a director, and it was a written film.

"So often when you're watching a movie it's like being present at some desperate script conference. Someone's saying 'We could try this' - and by God they have tried it. Films are terribly underwritten. But if I had the chance to do it now, I don't know that I would, because I want to get on with the stuff I control."

Of course, Amis has written directly for the screen, without ever achieving the chemistry that someone with his talent for dialogue might expect. His sci-fi thriller Saturn 3, which still surfaces occasionally on late-night TV, might have been an unholy embarrassment upon its release in 1980, but provided Amis with raw material for his epic movie-industry novel Money. He says now: "It just seemed to me that when I was working on that film I was head-doctoring and kissing ass, and writing these characters as they saw themselves, as they idealised themselves." Performers Kirk Douglas, Farrah Fawcett and Harvey Keitel re-emerged memorably as characters in Money: Lorne Guyland, Butch Beausoleil and Spunk Davis.

Amis was later hired to work on an early incarnation of Mars Attacks! "I wrote a good script too - the producer said it was 'too hip for the house'." That experience went into the short story Career Move, a brilliant satire of inversion in which poets command seven-figure fees and screenwriters labour over threadbare creations such as Offensive From Quasar 13.

But cinema, and appreciation of it, is a skein that runs through all of Amis's work. Even at the start of his novel-writing, Amis has his Rachel Papers protagonist Charles Highway discourse elegantly on European cinema ("Of course, there are plenty of sound, even urgent reasons for hating French films ... yet I preferred the more rickety and personal conventions ... the more radical attitude to experience, the scrutiny of the single detail and the small moment.")

Film pieces make up a good proportion of Amis's journalism: a hilarious account of Brian De Palma making Body Double in 1984; a nervous audience with Roman Polanski just after the director absconded from the US; a wander around the Houston set of Robocop 2 in 1990; venturing with his chum Salman Rushdie to a suburban multiplex to note the "class betrayal" of "400 berks from Hendon" in their reaction to Four Weddings and a Funeral; a brilliant exegesis of the habits and influence of screen violence for the New Yorker in the wake of the James Bulger murder.

Through his film journalism you get the sense of a mind fully at ease with cinema, able to understand both the skittering hysteria of its transnational glamour, as well as its function as the repository of a global unconscious. Amis, alone among British writers, really gets the movies.

Part of this assuredly stems from an early immersion: as a 13-year-old, Amis was offered a role in the Alexander Mackendrick film A High Wind in Jamaica, a four-month outing that got him expelled from school and ended up as an entertaining few paragraphs in yet another article, an account of a trip to the 1977 Cannes film festival.

"Even at that age," he recalls, "I realised that I had no talent for what I was doing, that I had an anti-talent. A friend of mine said I looked as though I was being heavily bribed to do everything. Anthony Quinn had great force of life, but he was ridiculous. James Coburn was very cool. Alexander Mackendrick, the director, it was impressive to watch him work. But it made me realise how laborious film-making was. I stand by my definition in the Robocop piece: a series of repetitions punctuated by delays. That's movies."

But Amis, whose radical critical intelligence operates brilliantly whether he is genuflecting before Saul Bellow or accompanying Watford FC on a Chinese tour, remains an insightful, liberal critic. "There's a line in my father's novel Take a Girl Like You, when he and his girlfriend are trying to decide what film to see, and the narrator says, 'If it were left to me, I would have gone for the most violent or horrific film available.' This was always my taste. There's no doubt that film has no rivals in creating a strong affect. It can really seize you. So action is a very natural thing for film to deal with - and violence.

"A funny thing happened in film in the late 1960s, when the self-policing Hollywood code was tacitly dispensed with, and suddenly auteurism was it - and violence. Auteurism did more to damage movie audiences than the advent of television. It halved profits. Violence is not what the public wants, and the industry has since realised that, and is much more market-driven - again - with the results that we see.

"Time and again, I've gone to see films that everyone says are great, like The Full Monty, Four Weddings, Billy Elliot ... Everyone says, 'Oh, they're so sweet, they've got a lot of charm', and all that, and I find myself ..." He sighs, irritated. "Well, it's so up your arse. It's so cute, pawky, simpery. I mean, nauseating. And I like the fact that this film bucks that trend."

Oh yes, this film. Amis professes to really admire the movie of Dead Babies, saying that it's "incredibly faithful" to its source, and there's a "wonderful energy" about it. And yet unpardonable liberties have been taken with the time setting: the original story, a laborious, multi-character satire on the drug-addled decadence of the early 1970s, has been roughly yanked into the present day. It's a pity, because Amis is at his most engaging when thinking back three decades, to what informed his writing in his early 20s.

"The currents at work, that you felt threading through you then, were so different. It was pre-feminist, pre-inflation ... The ideas and the culture of the late 1960s and early 1970s were the culture and ideas you get when there is prosperity. You could live for 10 shillings a week in London; then suddenly there was inflation and a cup of tea cost 10 shillings, a bus fare cost 10 shillings. That had an incredibly sobering effect on everyone, which we see to this day: yuppiedom was born then.

"And the wild ideas - political and pharmaceutical - that were going around then had to be dispensed with as leisure-class fripperies. It's also strange to think how left it was: how left-wing, how politicised the culture was. I'm pleased Bill Marsh [who also plays Marvell] looked so much like Charles Manson because he was the dark underside of hippiedom. That was really what the novel was about." Amis pauses. "You lying hippie," he says with relish. "That's what Charles Grodin calls Jeff Bridges in the remake of King Kong." He's suitably tickled.

"Hippiedom had its great benefits," he continues, "especially for me. Because of free love, which was terrific for about three or four years until women suddenly realised that it wasn't in their interests at all. But it was great for a bit - any man my age will tell you the same thing. You'd get off with girls that didn't fancy you - a rather eerie feeling. It wasn't that they liked you, but that there was so much pressure on them to be liberated. But there was always this edge to hippiedom: the 'Pigs out!' edge, the blood of Sharon Tate on the bedroom wall."

Dead Babies remains Amis's most ambitious treatment of his hippie prince past - but the movie adaptation, with its limited release, is unlikely to set the box office on fire. It's a Hollywood truism that bad books make good movies; maybe Amis's work is simply too delicately brilliant to survive the film industry meat-grinder.

 Dead Babies is released on Friday.

Even at the start of his novel-writing, Amis has his Rachel Papers protagonist Charles Highway discourse elegantly on European cinema ("Of course, there are plenty of sound, even urgent reasons for hating French films ... yet I preferred the more rickety and personal conventions ... the more radical attitude to experience, the scrutiny of the single detail and the small moment.") Film pieces make up a good proportion of Amis's journalism: a hilarious account of Brian De Palma making Body Double in 1984; a nervous audience with Roman Polanski just after the director absconded from the US; a wander around the Houston set of Robocop 2 in 1990; venturing with his chum Salman Rushdie to a suburban multiplex to note the "class betrayal" of "400 berks from Hendon" in their reaction to Four Weddings and a Funeral; a brilliant exegesis of the habits and influence of screen violence for the New Yorker in the wake of the James Bulger murder. Through his film journalism you get the sense of a mind fully at ease with cinema, able to understand both the skittering hysteria of its transnational glamour, as well as its function as the repository of a global unconscious. Amis, alone among British writers, really gets the movies. Part of this assuredly stems from an early immersion: as a 13-year-old, Amis was offered a role in the Alexander Mackendrick film A High Wind in Jamaica, a four-month outing that got him expelled from school and ended up as an entertaining few paragraphs in yet another article, an account of a trip to the 1977 Cannes film festival. "Even at that age," he recalls, "I realised that I had no talent for what I was doing, that I had an anti-talent. A friend of mine said I looked as though I was being heavily bribed to do everything. Anthony Quinn had great force of life, but he was ridiculous. James Coburn was very cool. Alexander Mackendrick, the director, it was impressive to watch him work. But it made me realise how laborious film-making was. I stand by my definition in the Robocop piece: a series of repetitions punctuated by delays. That's movies." But Amis, whose radical critical intelligence operates brilliantly whether he is genuflecting before Saul Bellow or accompanying Watford FC on a Chinese tour, remains an insightful, liberal critic. "There's a line in my father's novel Take a Girl Like You, when he and his girlfriend are trying to decide what film to see, and the narrator says, 'If it were left to me, I would have gone for the most violent or horrific film available.' This was always my taste. There's no doubt that film has no rivals in creating a strong affect. It can really seize you. So action is a very natural thing for film to deal with - and violence. "A funny thing happened in film in the late 1960s, when the self-policing Hollywood code was tacitly dispensed with, and suddenly auteurism was it - and violence. Auteurism did more to damage movie audiences than the advent of television. It halved profits. Violence is not what the public wants, and the industry has since realised that, and is much more market-driven - again - with the results that we see. "Time and again, I've gone to see films that everyone says are great, like The Full Monty, Four Weddings, Billy Elliot ... Everyone says, 'Oh, they're so sweet, they've got a lot of charm', and all that, and I find myself ..." He sighs, irritated. "Well, it's so up your arse. It's so cute, pawky, simpery. I mean, nauseating. And I like the fact that this film bucks that trend." Oh yes, this film. Amis professes to really admire the movie of Dead Babies, saying that it's "incredibly faithful" to its source, and there's a "wonderful energy" about it. And yet unpardonable liberties have been taken with the time setting: the original story, a laborious, multi-character satire on the drug-addled decadence of the early 1970s, has been roughly yanked into the present day. It's a pity, because Amis is at his most engaging when thinking back three decades, to what informed his writing in his early 20s. "The currents at work, that you felt threading through you then, were so different. It was pre-feminist, pre-inflation ... The ideas and the culture of the late 1960s and early 1970s were the culture and ideas you get when there is prosperity. You could live for 10 shillings a week in London; then suddenly there was inflation and a cup of tea cost 10 shillings, a bus fare cost 10 shillings. That had an incredibly sobering effect on everyone, which we see to this day: yuppiedom was born then. "And the wild ideas - political and pharmaceutical - that were going around then had to be dispensed with as leisure-class fripperies. It's also strange to think how left it was: how left-wing, how politicised the culture was. I'm pleased Bill Marsh [who also plays Marvell] looked so much like Charles Manson because he was the dark underside of hippiedom. That was really what the novel was about." Amis pauses. "You lying hippie," he says with relish. "That's what Charles Grodin calls Jeff Bridges in the remake of King Kong." He's suitably tickled. "Hippiedom had its great benefits," he continues, "especially for me. Because of free love, which was terrific for about three or four years until women suddenly realised that it wasn't in their interests at all. But it was great for a bit - any man my age will tell you the same thing. You'd get off with girls that didn't fancy you - a rather eerie feeling. It wasn't that they liked you, but that there was so much pressure on them to be liberated. But there was always this edge to hippiedom: the 'Pigs out!' edge, the blood of Sharon Tate on the bedroom wall." Dead Babies remains Amis's most ambitious treatment of his hippie prince past - but the movie adaptation, with its limited release, is unlikely to set the box office on fire. It's a Hollywood truism that bad books make good movies; maybe Amis's work is simply too delicately brilliant to survive the film industry meat-grinder.  Dead Babies is released on Friday.

fields.headline: Procter & Gamble launches marketing company
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble is setting up a company to advise on launching new products, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble, the consumer goods giant that owns many of the world's best-known brands, is to make its marketing expertise available to rival companies for the first time by setting up a company that will advise on launching new products.

P&G, the world's biggest advertiser, spends more than $1.1bn a year on marketing brands from Fairy Liquid and Ariel to Sunny Delight and Pringles.

It will invest an undisclosed amount in the new company, which has the working title Project EMM (enterprise marketing management), as well as lending its marketing expertise.

Project EMM is being set up in a joint venture with Worldwide Magnifi, a web-based marketing company. It already counts major household names such as Coca-Cola and Philips among its clients.

"Three major trends are converging to change the way global marketing is done: brands and businesses are globalising; marketing teams - including agencies, partners and suppliers - are more geographically dispersed; and speed is increasingly a deciding factor in which companies win or lose," said Hunter Hastings, chief executive of the new company.

"As a result, marketers need a true enterprise marketing management system that accelerates the marketing process, allows global collaboration, coordination and control and continually raises marketing proficiency across the enterprise and its partners."

The new company will advise on all aspects of marketing, from product development to advertising and design.

fields.headline: Thumbs up for Scott's Gladiator
fields.trailText: Ridley Scott's Gladiator and Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon took the top prizes at the Golden Globes which often give an indication of who will win the Oscars
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
The British director Ridley Scott carried off a Golden Globe for his film Gladiator at the Hollywood awards ceremony which is supposed to give an indication of who will win the Oscars.

No one film dominated the awards on a lively night during which George Clooney, who won the best comedy actor award for his role as an escaped chain gang prisoner in O Brother, Where Art Thou?, joked that he was the illegitimate child of the deeply religious and conservative John Ashcroft, George Bush's nomination for attorney general.

Julia Roberts won the award for best actress for her portrayal of a paralegal campaigner in Erin Brockovich and was praised by the real Erin Brockovich. Tom Hanks took the equivalent actor's award for Cast Away and Ang Lee won best director and best foreign language film for his martial arts film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

Except for Ridley Scott there was little else for the British to celebrate, with the highly fancied Billy Elliot and Chicken Run both falling at the final hurdle. Judi Dench, however, did win best actress in a TV drama for her role Last of the Blonde Bombshells and Vanessa Redgrave, who was also not present because she is performing in The Cherry Orchard at the National Theatre, won the best supporting actress in the same category for If These Walls Could Talk 2 .

There was much better news on the domestic front yesterday with the Film Council revealing that after a shaky start investment in film in Britain broke all records last year.

The bulk of the £750m was spent by the big US studios on such putative blockbusters as the first Harry Potter film, The Mummy Returns, Tomb Raider and the Liverpool-set 51st State starring Samuel L Jackson.

But a large slice of the £539m of foreign money - up one-third on 1999 - went on less apparently big budget productions such as the adaptation of AS Byatt's Possession starring Gwyneth Paltrow, the weepie Chocolat and Steven Spielberg's TV epic, Band Of Brothers.

The film commissioner, Steve Norris, warned that the advantage could quickly unravel. "Without continued support from the government in terms of tax breaks the incredible success we have seen this year may be shortlived." He is worried that the system of tax incentives does not cater for the really big movies like Titanic.

The rise in spending on UK produced films was less dramatic at £211m on 52 features including the Michael Caine vehicle Shiner, Enigma and Bridget Jones' Diary starring Renee Zellweger, famous for her portrayals of dizzy heroines.

It was Ms Zellweger, who stole the show at the Golden Globes by almost missing her victory as best comic actress for Nurse Betty. She was taking some lipstick off her teeth in the ladies when Hugh Grant announced that she had won.

Kate Hudson won best supporting actress as a groupie in Cameron Crowe's autobiographical Almost Famous, which also won the best comedy or musical prize. Benicio Del Toro took the actor's best supporting award for Traffic in which he plays a Mexican drugs squad officer.

Bob Dylan got a standing ovation when he won the best original song for Things Have Changed in Wonder Boys. Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard won the original score for Gladiator.

On the television front, The West Wing took the best drama series and Sex in the City won best musical or comedy series. Individual awards went to Martin Sheen (West Wing) for best actor in a drama, Sela Ward, (Once and Again) for best actress in a drama, Sarah Jessica Parker (Sex in the City) for best actress in a musical or comedy and Kelsey Grammer (Frasier) for the male equivalent.

Robert Downey Jnr, who won best supporting actor for his role in Ally McBeal, said:"It's really nice not to be under the table." Having only come out of prison last year he faces new drugs charges after being arrested in Palm Springs.

Al Pacino won the Cecil B DeMille lifetime achievement award and Elizabeth Taylor cheered the audience by hamming it up with the autocues.

The winners

 Best picture, drama Gladiator (dir Ridley Scott)

 Best picture, musical or comedy Almost Famous (dir Cameron Crowe)

 Best actor, drama Tom Hanks (Cast Away)

 Best actress, drama Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich)

 Best actor, musical or comedy George Clooney (O Brother, Where Art Thou)

 Best actress, musical or comedy Renee Zellweger (Nurse Betty)

 Best supporting actor Benicio Del Toro (Traffic)

 Best supporting actress Kate Hudson (Almost Famous)

 Best director Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon)

 Screenplay Stephen Gaghan (Traffic)

 Foreign language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Ang Lee)

 Best actress in a mini-series or drama Judi Dench (The Last of the Blonde Bombshells)

 Best supporting actress in a mini-series or drama Vanessa Redgrave (If These Walls Could Talk 2)

 Original score Hans Zimmer & Lisa Gerrard (Gladiator)

 Original song Things Have Changed, by Bob Dylan (Wonder Boys)

fields.headline: Museum-goers face £1 entry fee
fields.trailText: Museums and galleries are still likely to charge a £1 entrance fee when the present system of charges is scrapped in September, government officials said today.
fields.body:
Museums and galleries are still likely to charge a £1 entrance fee when the present system of charges is scrapped in September, government officials said today.

Earlier reports today suggested that the Department of Culture had struck a deal with the Treasury to allow free entry for museums and galleries in England.

However, the Treasury denied that it had made a deal, and the Department of Culture, which would subsidise the institutions, said a £1 entry fee would still be introduced in September.

One of the government's long standing commitments has been to introduce free admission to museums and galleries for everyone.

But the plans, contained in Labour's 1997 manifesto, ran into trouble when it emerged that Treasury rules meant some of these institutions would lose out financially if the scheme was introduced.

By not charging entrance fees museums would lose their status as businesses and therefore would no longer be able to reclaim VAT.

So a compromise, called Quids In, was reached between the Treasury and the Department of Culture which would subsidise institutions while allowing them to charge a nominal £1 fee in order to avoid VAT.

This morning's reports had suggested that the Treasury would allow museums and galleries to reclaim VAT with or without the entry fee. But not all museums and galleries have signed up to the £1 scheme.

The institutions' trustees must agree to the changes - and some fear it is a short-term solution that could be rendered obsolete when the VAT rules are reviewed in 2002.

Related articles

04.04.2000: Museum's give wary cheer to Smith's £1 adult fee plan

webTitle: Dalglish: Barnes to blame for Celtic woe

fields.headline: Dalglish: Barnes to blame for Celtic woe
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish has blamed John Barnes for Celtic's disastrous campaign last season.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish has blamed John Barnes for Celtic's disastrous campaign last season.

Dalglish, who was sacked from his position as director of football by Celtic last summer, claims Barnes's poor signings and his troubled relationship with Mark Viduka were the reasons for the club's poor performance.

Barnes, who joined Celtic in the summer of 1999, broke the Scottish record with the £5.75m signing of Eyal Berkovic and later splashed out another £6m on the Brazilian defender Rafael Scheidt. He also brought in Ian Wright, Olivier Tebily and unknown Stephane Bonnes - all of whom have failed to make an impact.

"It was John who signed all the players at Celtic. I don't know who was the worst although there were more bad ones than good ones," said Dalglish.

"Obviously there was some consultation between us but, at the end of the day, the guy who is responsible for who plays, how we played and where and when we trained is the guy who is ultimately responsible for buying players," he added.

Dalglish also confirmed that a dressing room conflict between Barnes and striker Mark Viduka - now at Leeds - during the Scottish Cup defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle had ended Barnes' reign as head coach.

"John had the best start to a season of any Celtic manager other than Jock Stein, although Martin has now surpassed that," said Dalglish.

"However, after the winter break things started to go wrong. We drew with Kilmarnock and then lost 3-2 to Hearts after being 2-0 up. Inverness Caley then beat us in the Scottish Cup and John had a problem with Mark Viduka in the dressing room. That was the beginning of the end for him."

Barnes was sacked after the humiliating 3-1 defeat, after which Dalglish flew back from the continent to take charge. "I don't think he has been soured by what happened," insisted Dalglish.

webTitle: Government must put free personal care at heart of bill

fields.headline: Government must put free personal care at heart of bill
fields.standfirst: Age Concern director Gordon Lishman urges MPs to enshrine free personal care in the health and social care bill
fields.trailText: Age Concern director Gordon Lishman urges MPs to enshrine free personal care in the health and social care bill
fields.body:
The health and social care bill is being fast tracked through the parliamentary corridors heading firmly towards the statute book. At the heart of the bill is the fact that the government will not implement the proposal of the royal commission on long-term care to provide free personal care.

Age Concern contends that provision of both free personal and nursing care is the only way to avoid the confusion and anomalies in defining health care and social care. Older people and health care professionals will be left baffled by new rules leaving many at a loss to say what they will have to pay.

Although we welcome the end of the anomaly where people pay for nursing care in a nursing home, but nowhere else, it does raise the question: How will the government define nursing care?

In essence, only the people who are currently fully funding themselves in a nursing home will see any difference; by the government's estimate around 35,000 people. With the total number of supported residents in residential and nursing homes rising to 267,000, the question must be posed: What about the rest?

The confusion over the definition of nursing care is widespread and has engulfed even the Commons. The working definition involves the performing, planning, supervision or delegation of nursing care by a registered nurse.

At the second reading of the bill, MP Paul Burstow quizzed the secretary of state on an apparent anomaly: "If a dressing is changed by a care assistant, that must be paid for; if it is changed by a nurse, it is not."

Secretary of state Alan Milburn replied: "No, that is not the position".

Unfortunately, Mr Milburn was not forthcoming with any further explanation simply suggesting that assessment would be undertaken by a nurse.

The 1999 Coughlan case posed the first major legal challenge to define health and social care. The bill will, we believe, lead to more challenges and to a system that is decided through the courts rather than by elected government so prolonging the uncertainty for a very large number of older people.

The government avers that we are in an "either/or" situation: We cannot afford both to improve frontline services and provide free personal and nursing care. The choice then is ours. But I passionately believe that older people should have their personal care provided free. Not only because they have expected and paid for this through their working lives; but also because if any older person is too ill or disabled to do ordinary basic tasks which fit and able people take for granted, then the state should provide for them.

I for one would not voluntarily give up my ability to wash and dress myself - I would have to be too ill to perform such tasks before I would surrender that independence.

Alan Milburn speaks of hard choices. I put it to him that the choice is between fulfilling our responsibility to older citizens or leaving them to struggle in their final years. Of course investment in frontline services is crucial, but it should not be at the expense of the generation with the deepest belief in the National Heath Service.

When MPs vote on this bill, I urge them to think carefully about how our society values older people and, specifically, the older people who will be most affected by their decision; the generation which can remember life without a health service when they struggled to afford a visit to the doctor and pay for health care.

Do we really want them to have travelled so far only to be thrown back to that same struggle?

webTitle: Full steam ahead for MPC abolition

fields.headline: Full steam ahead for MPC abolition
fields.trailText: The government has pushed through controversial plans to abolish the body that controls the distribution of GPs across the NHS, despite disapproval from opposition parties and GP leaders.
fields.body:
The government has pushed through controversial plans to abolish the body that controls the distribution of GPs across the NHS, despite disapproval from opposition parties and GP leaders.

Labour MPs on the standing committee of the health and social care bill voted down a joint Liberal Democrat and Conservative attempt to reprieve the medical practices committee (MPC).

The MPC, a Department of Health committee, had lobbied hard against its abolition arguing that it would herald a chaotic, free-for-all approach to GP distribution.

But health minister John Denham said that removing the MPC and devolving responsibility for ensuring fair GP distribution to local health authorities would allow "under-doctored" areas in the north of England and in inner cities to benefit.

"Enabling development of resource allocation in the way that I have described will make it easier for areas that lack doctors to attract them," he said.

The debate occurred during the first meeting of the standing committee. The government is pressing ahead with a tight schedule to complete its proceedings by February 8 2001.
