Yale, 583 pp., £40, 24 August 2000, 0300082096 Buy it at a discount from BOL The day he first met Wyndham Lewis, shortly after the end of the first world war, Ernest Hemingway was teaching Ezra Pound how to box. The encounter took place in Paris, where Pound had a studio, and Lewis, impassive beneath his trademark wide black hat, seemed content to watch in silence. "Ezra had not been boxing very long and I was embarrassed at having him work in front of anyone he knew, and I tried to make him look as good as possible," Hemingway wrote. So wide was the margin between master and pupil, both in musculature and in technique, that Hemingway could without difficulty refrain from doing his opponent any damage. Lewis, he felt sure, wanted to see Pound hurt. He was careful not to oblige. "I never countered but kept Ezra moving after me sticking out his left hand and throwing a few right hands and then said we were through and washed down with a pitcher of water and towelled off and put on my sweatshirt." What is startling about Hemingway's recollection of the event, in his Paris memoir, A Moveable Feast (1964), is the way in which it uses all this washing-down and towelling-off as the basis for an assault on Lewis's character. Hemingway remembers himself as clean, above all; and clean, furthermore, after his carefully controlled exertions, in a thoroughly modern way. Lewis, on the other hand, wearing the kind of bohemian 'uniform' favoured by the 'prewar artist', remains somehow archaic and insalubrious. "Walking home I tried to think what he reminded me of and there were various things. They were all medical except toe-jam." Lewis is dirt, then, or an abortion. "Under the black hat, when I had first seen them, the eyes had been those of an unsuccessful rapist." There might presumably have been some hope for Lewis had his eyes merely been those of a successful rapist. Lewis describes his visit to Pound's Paris studio in the first of his two volumes of autobiography, Blasting and Bombardiering (1937). No one answered his knock, but the door was open, so he went in. A splendidly built young man, stripped to the waist, and with a torso of dazzling white, was standing not far from me. He was tall, handsome and serene, and was repelling with his boxing gloves a hectic assault of Ezra's. After a final swing at the dazzling solar plexus Pound fell back upon his settee. The young man was Hemingway. Pound got on like a house on fire with this particular statue. By comparison with Hemingway's, Lewis's description of the event is coolness itself. It does subtle damage to Hemingway by not discerning in him the agency or control over events his undeniable physical superiority might be thought to have generated. By this account, it is Pound, rather than Hemingway, who brings the bout to a conclusion; and he does so by falling back on a settee - a fixture not ordinarily available in the average gymnasium for the use of wobbly punters. Statuesque or supine, neither protagonist is left with much of a leg to stand on. And yet there is in the description's coolness a certain residual heat. The stance Lewis favoured was not in fact one of detachment. He liked to get up close, in the world's face. Immediacy mattered to him, and a vivid trace often survives in his writing of the impulse that gave rise to it. Here, for example, he makes no effort to avoid the cliché of the house on fire. The cliché is his first thought about Pound's fondness for Hemingway, we are allowed to think, and the first thought will do. It will do, however, not just because it fills space, but because its familiarity in general terms is also its diagnostic value in this particular context: Pound merits a cliché because he has become a cliché, a walking susceptibility. Such fusions of impulse and diagnosis are the hallmark of Lewis's writing at its best. They also got him into a lot of trouble. Paul O'Keeffe's new Life of Lewis does not hold back on the toe-jam. Lewis became, sometimes by circumstance, sometimes by design, the sponsor of a wide range of opportunities for fear and loathing. Women were especially favoured in this respect. The models available to him included his father, a swashbuckling veteran of the American Civil War who made a habit of infidelity and eventually left his wife for good in 1901, when Lewis was 18; and Augustus John, his celebrated predecessor at the Slade, whom he sought assiduously to emulate, and whose ever-varying seraglio became an object of fascination. But Lewis's presentation of himself to women, and to the men with whom he conferred about women, had a polemical edge to it, a toxicity entirely lacking, as far as one can tell, in John's sexual munificence. From an early age, Lewis cultivated what could be termed anti-pathos: a strategic, rather than merely tactical or opportunist, avoidance of sentiment. This strategy was to manifest itself in his art as a preference for the abstract, in his writing as a preference for satire and invective, and in his politics as a tough-mindedness shading almost imperceptibly into advocacy of tough action. The painters with whom he consorted - Walter Sickert, William Rothenstein, Augustus John - chose to regard him as a poet. "The fine arts they imagined were already in good hands," he recalled in Rude Assignment (1950), his second volume of autobiography, "namely their own." But it was as a writer of prose sketches that he first made his mark, when three pieces appeared in the English Review in May, June and August 1909. His literary career was thus one of several launched by the Review's perceptive editor, Ford Madox Ford (or Hueffer, as he then was). Lewis is said either to have thrust his bundle of manuscripts wordlessly into Hueffer's hands, or to have burst into the bathroom and read them aloud, while the editor sat in his tub, as O'Keeffe puts it, "nonchalantly plying his sponge". These sketches were the product of holidays in Brittany, where Lewis had found, or thought he had found, a culture whose ritualised antagonisms were a physical reflection of his own developing metaphysical commitment to anti-pathos. By August, it seems, the editor's charm had worn off. "Hueffer," he explained to Moore, "is a shit of the most dreary and uninteresting kind." At this stage, Lewis would have been more widely known as a writer than as an artist. However, the success of Roger Fry's first post-impressionist exhibition, in 1910, generated a flurry of experiment in the visual arts, and Lewis took up his brush again, to considerable effect. Within a year so, his work was sustaining comparison with that of major figures in the continental avant-garde. There followed, between 1913 and 1915, the period of his most intense commitment to geometrical abstraction. Blast appeared, Vorticism arose. During what he thought of as the 'Blast days', that heady period of Vorticist carnival brought to a halt, in his case, for a while at least, by the combined effects of gonorrhoea and officer training, Lewis trafficked assiduously between media. "My literary contemporaries," he recalled in Rude Assignment, "I looked upon as too bookish and not keeping pace with the visual revolution." He would show them the way in a novel, Tarr (1918), which was about as abstract as he could make it, though in the end not altogether un-bookish. In an original and highly instructive chapter, Edwards demonstrates the lengths to which Lewis went to keep abstraction going after the war. As he rightly insists, the paintings and drawings of the immediate postwar period offer a glimpse of what a critical English Modernism in dialogue with the European avant-garde might conceivably have looked like. Before and during the war, avant-gardists had made quite a splash, even in an England that relied for its excitements on the dreary and uninteresting Hueffer. After the war, however, Lewis's expectation that he might be able to emulate in England the success Picasso had achieved in France soon began to fade. He had always attributed his own relative lack of success to the deficiencies of the culture in which he found himself operating, and in 1924 he set art and literature aside in order to concentrate on a systematic analysis of those deficiencies. The neglect endured by genius in the modern world is a constant theme in books like The Art of Being Ruled (1926) and Time and Western Man (1927). The former attributes postwar revolutions in attitude and lifestyle to monopoly capitalism's insatiable appetite for markets; the latter examines the deepening connections between the emergence of a consumer society and developments in modern literature and philosophy. At their best, these books have the diagnostic value of the cultural criticism of Walter Benjamin or Siegfried Kracauer, with both of whom Lewis shared a fascination for Charlie Chaplin, if little else. When Edwards claims that Lewis's polemical writings constitute "a permanent insight into the nature of modernity", I'm very nearly ready to believe him. The reservation has to do with the trace in the arguments they mount of an impulse that might be regarded as mildly psychotic. Lewis meant The Art of Being Ruled as a survival guide, an antidote to Machiavelli. So intent was he on tough-mindedness, however, on a thorough-going decontamination of liberal pieties, that he came to regard the imminence of Fascist rule with an equanimity which could easily be (and was) mistaken for endorsement. Equally disturbing, in its way, is the chapter on Ezra Pound in Time and Western Man. Lewis begins by recalling the generosity and grace Pound had unfailingly shown towards him whenever he was in need of help. He then declares that for the purposes of his 'new enterprise' he must henceforth dissociate himself altogether from his former ally and benefactor, now exposed as a 'revolutionary simpleton' and a parasite on genuine talent. The critique, although by no means unperceptive, has an edge to it which derives in large part from the satisfaction Lewis so obviously took in not being grateful. In 1921 Lewis had embarked on another ambitious project, a Rabelaisian fictional anatomy of postwar Britain. Two hefty portions, held back for a while by his skirmishes with the spirit of Charlie Chaplin, finally and circuitously achieved publication at the end of the decade: The Childermass (1928), a work of theological science fiction set in an encampment of the dead on the banks of the River Styx; and The Apes of God (1930), a satire on amateurism in general, and Bloomsbury amateurism in particular, in which Richard Wyndham features as the vacuous Dick Whittingdon. Lewis also renovated his Vorticist creed by publishing a revised edition of Tarr, in 1928, and collecting his early Breton sketches and essays, in much-altered form, as The Wild Body (1927). Anti-pathos finds a name in these works: satire, laughter, the absurd. Laughter, Lewis explained in Inferior Religions, a scintillating essay which serves as a manifesto for The Wild Body, is the "brain-body's snort of exultation". Laughter at once acknowledges and expresses (or performs, since it is "all that remains physical in the flash of thought") the idea that the absurdity of the human condition is not relative - the product, sometimes comic, sometimes tragic, of social and cultural difference - but absolute. For Lewis, laughter is what being might look like from the point of view of non-being; and antagonism, which puts being at risk, is the primary cause of laughter. "The opposing armies in the early days in Flanders stuck up dummy-men on poles for their enemies to pot at, in a spirit of ferocious banter." The fiction of the 1920s indefatigably keeps non-being's point of view in mind by means of a kind of prose impasto: a poultice or compress of descriptive detail applied to human existence in order to draw out its fundamental absurdity, its basis in antagonism. The main casualty of these convulsive literary mantraps is the idea of 'character' as a steadily deepening awareness of self and world. One might find a precedent for them in Rabelais, perhaps, or in that noted Vorticist firebrand, Charles Dickens. But Lewis's concoctions have a pungency all their own. The account in Bestre, one of the Wild Body stories, of a woman whose "nodular pink veil" is an "apoplectic gristle" round her stormy brow has stayed in my mind ever since I first read it thirty years ago. In November 1930 Lewis travelled to Berlin to find a German publisher for The Apes of God. Two months earlier, the German people had elected 107 National Socialists to the Reichstag. The National Socialist German Workers' Party could now claim 17.5 per cent of the total vote, second only to the Social Democrats' 21.9 per cent. Lewis watched from a balcony in the Berlin Sportpalast as Goebbels and Goering held forth to a crowd of twenty thousand. In the world's face, as ever, he also took in the lavish decadence of late Weimar democracy, checking for himself the stubble on the chins of the transvestites. On his return to London, unable to resist such an opportunity for diagnosis on a world-historical scale, he wrote the first study in any language of Adolf Hitler and the rise of National Socialism. His motive was to create tolerance in Britain for this latest Continental manifestation of authoritarian doctrine, and he therefore argued that Nazi anti-semitism was a mere sideshow, a "racial red-herring". The book brought him a visit from Dr Hans-Wilhelm Thost, English correspondent for the Vslkischer Beobachter and Der Angriff, and a spy, who thought it "not at all bad for an Englishman", but rather misleading where the Judenfrage was concerned. Its argument slung together pretty much at random, its jacket cheerfully festooned with swastikas, the book still haunts Lewis's reputation. It is, for example, the prime exhibit in John Carey's withering indictment of his life and work in The Intellectuals and the Masses (1992). Edwards discerns a "new humanity and concern for ordinary people" in Lewis's fiction and painting from 1935 onwards. The head-banging had to stop sometime, and it may have stopped during the series of operations Lewis underwent between 1932 and 1937, as an old gonorrhoeal scar in his bladder became infected (O'Keeffe has the details). Edwards sees in the return to portraiture after 1937, in novels like The Revenge for Love (1937) and Self Condemned (1954), sometimes regarded as Lewis's best, and in Monstre Gai and Malign Fiesta (1955), which resume The Childermass, a 'recognition of the experience of the other'. The later work, he says, constitutes a Kierkegaardian advance from aesthetics through ethics to theology. No doubt the imminence of mere death, as opposed to the vital deadness advertised by the Vorticist mantraps, had something to do with it. Edwards looks in great detail at the process of self-examination and the commitment to theological enquiry which give the later work a new and formidable gravity. The problem with this work, as he acknowledges, is that its agenda required it either to reject or to transform the principle of creative antagonism. Under taxing scrutiny, in Self Condemned or Malign Fiesta, the psychosis eventually dissolves, and with it a great deal else. "Just as Lewis's drawing lost a certain kind of intensity when he began to recognise the inner reality of others," Edwards observes, "so did his writing." In the writing, at least, the loss is absolute. The opening pages of Self Condemned would have been a rank embarrassment to the author of Inferior Religions. Edwards proves a subtle and informative guide to Lewis's deepening moral and spiritual preoccupations, and many readers will find his defence of the later work entirely persuasive. I didn't, quite, in the end, because a part of me wants to insist that wild bodies are what Lewis did best. It's the apoplectic gristle, stupid. Edwards's study deserves to remain for some time the standard point of reference in debates about the overall shape and status of Lewis's work, and it will have the entirely beneficial effect of diverting attention away from the over-emphasised 'Blast days'. Gristle-fanciers, however, may continue to find themselves drawn to The Wild Body and its like. In Inferior Religions, Lewis spoke of beauty as an "icy douche" of "ease and happiness" provoked by whatever suggests the perfect conditions for an organism. For Leonardo, he said, beauty was a "red rain on the side of shadowed heads", for Uccello it was a "cold architecture of distinct colour" and for Korin the "symmetrical gushing" of water. "Cézanne liked cumbrous, democratic slabs of life, slightly leaning, transfixed in vegetable intensity." Of these, Lewis's own idea of beauty was closest to Cézanne's. Unlike Cézanne, however, he did the transfixing by anti-pathos. Whether or not it brought him much ease and happiness is hard to say.

fields.headline: Saucy ads a turn-off with women
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Most women are turned off by sexually explicit images on poster billboards according to a new survey. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Most women are turned off by sexually explicit images on poster billboards, according to a survey published today.

More than two-thirds of the women polled in a survey commissioned by Bella magazine thought advertisers went too far in using sex to sell products.

And almost half said a poster for lingerie manufacturer Gossard, which depicted a woman lying alone on a bed with the caption "If he's late, you can always start without him", was offensive.

The ad has now been banned by the Advertising Standards Authority.

Around half the 500 women questioned also objected to a poster for Organics shampoo, which featured a woman peering down the front of her bikini bottom to check her "real hair colour".

And a third of those surveyed also claimed they found French Connection's FCUK slogan distasteful.

The findings come just weeks after the Advertising Standards Authority controversially ordered that posters showing a picture of a naked Sophie Dahl, striking a suggestive pose for Opium perfume, should be taken down.

But not everyone objected to saucy advertisements, with one in four women saying they brightened up their day.

"Our poll shows that whilst some women, myself included, find these ads amusing, the majority don't want to be bombarded with provocative images every time they walk to work or pop out to the shops," said Bella editor-in-chief Jackie Highe.

fields.headline: BBH bags Ericsson account
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Telecoms giant Ericsson is believed to have handed its £100m global account to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Telecommunications giant Ericsson is believed to have handed its £100m global consumer advertising account to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, giving a major billings boost to one of the UK's best-known agencies.

The news represents a significant loss for Young & Rubicam, which has handled the account for the past five years.

Ericsson was one of Y&R's biggest clients and spent almost £10m a year on advertising in the UK alone.

Ericsson is understood to have been unhappy with the agency's recent campaign, which had used the line, "Make yourself heard".

Ericsson will not announce the decision before January 26, when it releases its end-of-year results.

The company is currently in a closed period in the run-up to its results announcement and no one at BBH nor Ericsson was available for comment.

BBH pitched against Abbott Mead Vickers and TBWA for the Ericsson account.

Pitches were held before Christmas and the decision was made last week. Ericsson and BBH are now in final negotiations over fees.

Ericsson is the second major global account BBH has picked up in recent months. The agency is also understood to have won the $50m task of launching Microsoft's new Xbox games console in Europe.

fields.headline: AOL's marketeer Hawkins leaves
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Keith Hawkins, AOL's group marketing director for the UK, is leaving the company, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
AOL's group marketing director for the UK, Keith Hawkins, is leaving the company and his role split between two new marketing directors, it emerged today.

AOL said Hawkins, hired in August 1999 to launch its free net access service Netscape Online, has left to "pursue other opportunities".

His shoes have been filled by Sharon Lang, a marketing consultant to AOL, who becomes director of marketing for AOL's brand, and Clare Lawrence, previously director of marketing planning and services, who becomes director of marketing for customer acquisition.

AOL denies that the changes are the result of its recently cleared £140bn merger with Time Warner.

Instead it says the changes were prompted by the "unimagined" success of its flat rate net access service, launched last November.

Ms Lang will look after overall strategy and advertising for AOL's portfolio of UK brands - AOL, CompuServe and Netscape Online - while Ms Lawrence will be responsible for direct marketing and other customer recruitment techniques.

The shake-up has created speculation in adland that AOL will now review its UK advertising arrangements.

Campaign magazine recently judged AOL's long-running TV commercials featuring "prissy know-all" Connie as the Worst Advertising Campaign of the Year.

AOL presently spends around £12m a year on ads created by Mortimer Whittaker, with media bought by BBJ.

Both Ms Lang and Ms Lawrence will report to new chief operating officer Lori Friedman, who has joined from Donovan Data Systems where she was executive director.

Ms Friedman, in turn, reports to UK managing director Karen Thompson.

fields.headline: Bush faces a different Russia
fields.standfirst: The new US president must find a new way of dealing with Moscow, writes Ian Traynor in Moscow
fields.trailText: The new US president must find a new way of dealing with Moscow, writes Ian Traynor in Moscow.
fields.body:
The Russia that Bill Clinton has just put behind him is a very different proposition from the country that he inherited from George W Bush's father, and while Washington has been agonising over the past two years about ''Who lost Russia?'', there is no doubt that US-Russian relations are at a much lower ebb in 2001 than they were in the heady, optimistic days of 1993 when Bill Clinton entered the White House and Boris Yeltsin was in his iconoclastic prime.

Eight years on from Clinton's project to steer Russia towards democracy and free markets - an often fitful, hesitant and confused policy - Russia is under a new, younger and very different leadership from the Yeltsin clan.

Hugely popular and more vigorous, President Vladimir Putin is also displaying authoritarian instincts. Fears for freedom of the press and of religion are rife. The economy is growing due to high oil prices, but mired in corruption with capital fleeing the country at alarming rates, while inward investment is minimal.

A recent assessment by the CIA bleakly forecast unremitting decline on all fronts in Russia despite Putin's pledges to restore Russian greatness and international clout.

''Between now and 2015, Moscow will be challenged even more than today to adjust its expectations for world leadership to its dramatically reduced resources,'' the CIA study predicted. ''Whether the country can make the transition in adjusting ends to means remains an open and critical question, according to most experts, as does the question of the character and quality of Russian governance and economic policies. The most likely outcome is a Russia that remains internally weak.''

If the Putin feel-good factor has made Russians feel better about themselves in the past year, the romance with the west has soured. Both the government and wider society bear grudges towards the west, especially America, and are convinced that the ulterior Clinton motive was not to entrench democracy and improve the quality of life in Russia, but to keep Russia down, promote its weakness, and ensure that America remained unchallenged as what Madeleine Albright has called ''the indispensable power.''

The key geo-strategic moves disenchanting the Russians came in Clinton's second term with the expansion of Nato into the former Soviet satellites of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic and the Nato war against Yugoslavia in 1999 which Russian nationalists insist on seeing as a Pax Americana to be enforced around the Russian periphery, for example, in Chechnya.

More broadly, the incoming Bush administration as well as Clinton-supporting Russia experts now dismiss the Clinton era as one of squandered opportunities as regards Russia.

In a recent book, Princeton professor, Russia expert, and democrat, Stephen Cohen, describes Clinton's policy on Russia as the biggest American foreign policy disaster since Vietnam.

In a recent article outlining the views of the new administration, Condoleezza Rice, Bush's national security adviser, declared that ''the problem for US policy is that the Clinton administration's ongoing embrace of Yeltsin and those who were thought to be reformers around him quite simply failed. US support for democracy and economic reform became support for Yeltsin. His agenda became the American agenda.''

This is the central criticism of Clinton's Russian policy - that it was too closely identified with the fortunes of Yeltsin rather than concentrating on building more durable democratic and economic institutions and structures. The German chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, directed the same criticism at his predecessor, Helmut Kohl - that policy towards Russia in the 90s was over-concentrated on male-bonding leaders, the chumminess of the Bill 'n' Boris act or the Boris and Helmut extravaganzas. Tony Blair appears to be trying to recreate this kind of relationship with Putin.

The American anthropologist, Janine Wedel, in various books and articles, has analysed in devastating detail how US policy through the 90s was hijacked by a small and unaccountable clique of Russian and American economic liberals grouped around Anatoliy Chubais in Russia and free market economists at Harvard.

The result was unwavering Washington support for a clique which pushed through shock therapy and mass privatisation with questionable results. The entire edifice of economic reform then degenerated further into hugely corrupt sell-offs of national industry at knockdown prices to a small clique of favoured businessmen in return for their support of the Yeltsin Kremlin.

The outcome now is that in Russia, Chubais and the so-called oligarchs are the most reviled figures in Russia, making it popular for Putin to take politically motivated potshots at those of the oligarchs who incur his disfavour, while in America the aid gravy train is grinding to a halt and Russia fatigue has set in.

''[Clinton's] America certified that reform was taking place in Russia where it was not,'' argued Ms Rice. ''The realities in Russia simply did not accord with the administration's script about Russian economic reform.''

''Many Russian futures are possible, ranging from political resurgence to dissolution,'' the CIA predicts. ''The general drift, however, is toward authoritarianism, although not to the extreme extent of the Soviet period ... [Russia's] domestic ills will frustrate its efforts to reclaim its great power status.''

Despite Clinton's efforts and notwithstanding Putin's central promises to Russia, the Bush administration finds itself dealing with an ever weaker Russia. The fear is that weakness could be a bigger problem than a healthy, happy Russia.

fields.headline: Report slates council's social services
fields.trailText: Social care services provided by Southend on Sea borough council are too expensive and restrictive and show few signs of improvement, a joint report by the audit commission and the social services inspectorate has warned. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Social care services provided by Southend on Sea borough council are too expensive and restrictive and show few signs of improvement, a joint report by the audit commission and the social services inspectorate has warned.

The report, part of a series of reviews to assess the performance of social services departments in England and Wales, found users and carers were less positive about Southend's services than those in the 80 other authorities examined so far.

The joint review team found wide variations in the quality of the authority's services with those for older people, the mentally ill and people with learning difficulties lagging behind children's services.

It recommended the development of more cost-efficient services aimed at preventing hospital admissions and enabling users' independence rather than relying on institutional and expensive in-house services. Eligibility criteria and assessment practices also need to be revised to ensure services are not just accessible to users with high levels of need.

The report warns that opportunities to improve the independence of people with learning difficulties are restricted, as most services are provided in large day centres or residential and nursing homes. Three residential units are also not up to registration standards.

Older people receive fewer services than in other authorities due to restrictive eligibility criteria, low expenditure and the high costs of services. Care planning is also limited and lacks clear targets.

The local mental health strategy remains aspirational and key aspects of the national service framework for mental health services are missing. There has been little investment in community-based services such as 24-hour nurse-staffed accommodation aimed at averting hospital admissions.

Information about all services is limited and some buildings lack disabled access.

The review also recommends that Southend takes a longer-term approach to financial planning to develop more cost-efficient services, as its nursing home and residential care arrangements are more expensive than those in comparable authorities are. It also needs a performance management framework to set out and monitor the targets for its services.

However, the joint review identified several areas of good practice that could be built on to improve Southend's services. These included thorough check-ups to ensure the quality and safety of children's services and the establishment of user and carer forums to contribute to planning.

John Bolton, director of joint reviews, acknowledged that the authority had improved its children's services but said: "Southend must adopt a more holistic approach to service delivery."

A spokeswoman for Southend on Sea borough council said the authority had already established a performance management framework, improved access to buildings and reduced the costs of home care.

Councillor Verina Wilson, executive councillor for health and social care, said: "The council has made significant improvement in its social services provision since we received informal feedback from the joint review team in May last year, but we know that there is much more to be done."

Eligibility criteria and assessment practices also need to be revised to ensure services are not just accessible to users with high levels of need. The report warns that opportunities to improve the independence of people with learning difficulties are restricted, as most services are provided in large day centres or residential and nursing homes. Three residential units are also not up to registration standards. Older people receive fewer services than in other authorities due to restrictive eligibility criteria, low expenditure and the high costs of services. Care planning is also limited and lacks clear targets. The local mental health strategy remains aspirational and key aspects of the national service framework for mental health services are missing. There has been little investment in community-based services such as 24-hour nurse-staffed accommodation aimed at averting hospital admissions. Information about all services is limited and some buildings lack disabled access. The review also recommends that Southend takes a longer-term approach to financial planning to develop more cost-efficient services, as its nursing home and residential care arrangements are more expensive than those in comparable authorities are. It also needs a performance management framework to set out and monitor the targets for its services. However, the joint review identified several areas of good practice that could be built on to improve Southend's services. These included thorough check-ups to ensure the quality and safety of children's services and the establishment of user and carer forums to contribute to planning. John Bolton, director of joint reviews, acknowledged that the authority had improved its children's services but said: "Southend must adopt a more holistic approach to service delivery." A spokeswoman for Southend on Sea borough council said the authority had already established a performance management framework, improved access to buildings and reduced the costs of home care. Councillor Verina Wilson, executive councillor for health and social care, said: "The council has made significant improvement in its social services provision since we received informal feedback from the joint review team in May last year, but we know that there is much more to be done."

fields.headline: Maiden bullish over ad growth
fields.trailText: 12pm: Ad billboard company Maiden Group has shrugged off concerns over a downturn with a bullish trading statement, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Advertising billboard company Maiden Group has shrugged off concerns over the health of the advertising sector by issuing a bullish trading statement.

Analysts have predicted a slowdown in advertising revenue growth for TV and newspaper companies, but Maiden said it had enjoyed a healthy start to the year.

"With such an encouraging start to the year, the board is most confident of Maiden's prospects for 2001," the company said in a statement.

Maiden said "significant volumes" of business have been booked for April and May, when a general election is widely expected, and January sales have already risen by 37% compared with the same period last year.

A Maiden Group spokeswoman confirmed that political advertising had boosted April and May bookings, but has not dominated sales.

Chief executive Ronald Zeghibe has already warned political parties that advertising space will be scarce over the next few months, thanks to massive rebranding campaigns from Andersen Consulting and the Post Office.

Companies such as Procter & Gamble are also turning to outdoor billboards as TV audiences become more fragmented due to the rise of digital and cable broadcasting.

fields.headline: Monsoon sheds e-commerce
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Monsoon, the high street clothes and accessory retailer, is to shut down its e-commerce operation after failing to attract users.
fields.body:
Monsoon, the high street clothes and accessory retailer, is to shut down its e-commerce operation after failing to attract users. The company said it was disappointed that it was unable to justify the £400,000 a year running costs but said there would be no big financial write-off connected with next month's closure.

The website will continue to operate as a marketing tool but there will be no live transactions. Monsoon estimated it needed annual sales of £800,000 to justify the project but admitted it was barely making a quarter of this amount.

"It is disappointing but we have learned quite a lot of lessons and we do not rule out going back into [e-commerce] at a future date," the financial director, Andrew May, said.

He said the trouble stemmed from the nature of the businesses run by Monsoon and its subsidiary Accessorize. Customers wanted to go into shops and try on the garments.

The closure was announced following a positive interim trading performance with pre-tax profits up 8% at £13.8m on the back of a 14% rise in turnover to £85.4m.

Like-for-like sales for the period ending 25 November rose 5%, while the figure to December 23 was 3%. The chairman, Peter Simon, warned: "We need to continue the like-for-like sales growth achieved in the first half for our profit growth to be maintained."

The company said the weakness of sterling had pushed up the costs of buying from Asian countries and its gross margin fell 0.7% in the half.

The stock market concentrated on Monsoon's positive trading figures and its shares ended the day up 0.5p at 69.5p. Over the period the company opened 13 new UK stores and eight overseas.

The company says that future expansion will come from its growing international operation. Monsoon is particularly excited by strong results coming from Accessorize operations in markets such as Greece.

"I think they are on the right track and long term it is right to go overseas with Accessorize. It is an exportable concept," Joan D'Olier, retail analyst at Deutsche Bank, said.

fields.headline: ITV wins news battle
fields.standfirst:
Jan 23: BBC and ITV in news row
Last night's running orders
Jan 18: BBC plans 'brighter' news
fields.trailText:
11am: News at Ten was the clear winner in last night's battle of the bulletins, pulling in nearly twice as many viewers as BBC1, writes Jason Deans.
Jan 23: BBC and ITV in news row
Last night's running orders
Jan 18: BBC plans 'brighter' news
fields.body:
News at Ten was the clear winner in the battle of the 10pm news bulletins, pulling in nearly twice as many viewers at its BBC1 equivalent.

The ITV bulletin returned after an absence of nearly two years with 8.1m viewers, while BBC1's Ten O'Clock News managed just 4.3m.

News at Ten had been widely expected to win the battle of the bulletins, after ITV scheduled ratings blockbuster Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? immediately before it.

Leaving nothing to chance, ITV also scrapped the ad break between the two shows, so that Millionaire ran on until shortly after 10pm and straight into News at Ten.

And it promoted the return of News at Ten heavily with Chris Tarrant breaking away from the quiz show to remind viewers about the bulletin on several occasions last night.

But the BBC bulletin still improved on its audience from last Monday, when it drew just 3.5m viewers.

webTitle: McGregor and Carlyle set for Mary, Queen of Scots biopic

fields.headline: McGregor and Carlyle set for Mary, Queen of Scots biopic
fields.trailText: The Trainspotting stars are in line to play suitors to the Scottish queen in a film about her early life which will be produced by Sean Connery's production company
fields.body:
Following our earlier story about the forthcoming British film depicting the early life and love affairs of Mary, Queen of Scots, it now looks likely that Trainspotting co-stars Ewan McGregor and Robert Carlyle will re-team to play love rivals for the Scottish queen.

Cracker scribe Jimmy McGovern is to write the script for the movie, which will be produced by Sean Connery's production company, Fountainbridge, with backing from the BBC. Although nobody has yet been signed up to play Queen Mary, ananova reports today that McGregor and Carlyle will play suitors to the young Scottish queen, imprisoned for much of her life by her arch rival, Queen Elizabeth I of England.

Scottish actor Douglas Henshall and Jude Law are also apparently being sought to play major supporting roles. Connery himself is not expected to take a leading part, although he has not ruled out a cameo. A 'source' close to the production told ananova: "Sean wants to gather the cream of Scottish talent together for this one. He feels Scottish history should be told by the Scots whenever possible."

McGregor, whose film career has failed to hit the highs after 1996's Trainspotting, despite his performance in The Phantom Menace, will be seen next in Baz Luhrmann's musical/drama Moulin Rouge, alongside Nicole Kidman. Carlyle, who last appeared in the British football film, There's Only One Jimmy Grimble, will be on cinema screens soon in To End All Wars, the story of four prisoners of war forced to build a railroad through the Burmese jungle.

fields.headline: BBC and ITV in news ratings row
fields.standfirst: Last night's running orders
fields.trailText:
10.15am: The BBC claims ITV went for higher ratings by cutting the ad break before News at Ten. By Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll.
Last night's running orders
fields.body:
ITV bosses are facing down claims they scheduled their way to higher ratings by cutting the advertising break before last night's relaunched News at Ten.

One senior BBC news boss said: "By running straight from Millionaire into the news without a break, ITV is not giving a true picture of how the ratings will look when News at Ten beds down."

But a spokeswoman for the ITV network said claims were "the same old rubbish from the BBC".

ITV was also criticised for delaying the start of the bulletin by two minutes.

Last night's return of News at Ten after nearly two years - fronted by a rather nervous Sir Trevor McDonald - started with a lead-in from ratings grabber Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

ITV led on the possibility that Railtrack executives could face prosecution over the Hatfield crash.

The BBC's Ten O'Clock News, fronted by Peter Sissons, opened with an exclusive interview with Paul Mukonyi, the hijacker who nearly caused a jumbo jet to crash on a flight to Nairobi.

ITV's bulletin was in keeping with the traditional News at Ten agenda.

It covered the big stories of the day directly and had a greater focus on domestic news than the BBC, which covered three foreign stories.

The BBC's news was accused of leading with an exclusive just for the sake of it.

However, it did its best to demonstrate how it would be superior to ITV in breaking late stories from Westminster.

The BBC broke the results of the Lords' vote on human embryo-cloning after the News at Ten had gone off air.

The BBC news' first night was also conspicuous for its beautifully filmed reports.

These were about an oil spill threatening the Galapagos Islands and people perishing from the cold in Siberia.

ITV, on the other hand, excelled in domestic human-interest stories.

The decision to lead on rail safety, embryo-cloning and the MMR vaccine was a classic ITV mix.

Roger Mosey, the BBC's head of TV news, said its bulletin had been a "professional product" in the face of tough competition from ITV.

He added the BBC was "particularly pleased to have a late-breaking story with the embryo vote after ITV had gone off air".

The ITV spokeswoman said News at Ten had made a "very strong return".

She noted the programme had two big exclusives - interviews with William Hague and Lynne Bezant, the 56-year-old woman expecting twins.

She added: "The war of words between the broadcasters can stop because viewers can make up their own minds now about what they prefer.

"We are in this for the long term - this is not about newspaper headlines."

In the face of a ratings disaster, the BBC was quick to declare a victory for quality news.

Richard Sambrook, BBC deputy director of news, said: "Last night's bulletins clearly showed the difference between us.

"The BBC Ten O'Clock News provided the most comprehensive, best quality bulletin for viewers.

"We had twice as much news, twice as much foreign coverage, twice as many live reports and were able to get the result of the late-night vote on embryo research.

"Our bulletin included full regional coverage and original material from around the world; ITVs lasted a mere 16 minutes and had no regional news."

The BBC also took a swipe at ITV for its coverage of the aftermath of the mud-slides in El Salvador.

One insider said: "ITV's El Salvador piece was way out of date.

"It reported rescuers were still desperately digging for a survivor. Two hours earlier, PA reported they had given up hope."

webTitle: Galliano steals a march with superhero army

fields.headline: Galliano steals a march with superhero army
fields.trailText: What does £50,000 buy you these days? At Christian Dior haute couture, it will buy you a white T-shirt. A very beautiful white T-shirt - made to measure to fit just so, embroidered with jewelled hearts and Coca-Cola bottles, and finished with fine lace at the sleeves - but a white T-shirt just the same. It is thought to be the most expensive T-shirt ever made.
fields.body:
What does £50,000 buy you these days? At Christian Dior haute couture, it will buy you a white T-shirt. A very beautiful white T-shirt - made to measure to fit just so, embroidered with jewelled hearts and Coca-Cola bottles, and finished with fine lace at the sleeves - but a white T-shirt just the same. It is thought to be the most expensive T-shirt ever made.

Shocked? Well, that is the whole point, of course. John Galliano, the virtuoso British designer at the reins of the venerable Parisian house of Dior, can never seem to decide whether he wants the audience to gasp with disapproval or sigh with wonderment. It is testament to his irrepressible talent that, for all his shock tactics, it is still the sheer beauty of the clothes that takes your breath away.

After the antics of recent seasons - one show featured S&M fetishwear and porn film dialogue, another dallied with blasphemy - the grand dames of the front row must have been bracing themselves.

The theme for this collection was cartoon and character. First came outfits showing models as female Clark Kents, halfway between their daytime office persona and their superhero alter ego: sexy secretaries with paperclips in their hair, tight black pencil skirts sheer to reveal capacious knickers in the style of Wonder Woman - but in black, emblazoned with Dior in diamante.

Tight, curvy jackets seemed to have been not so much deconstructed as blown open by a small bomb to reveal the corsets beneath. Next came an odd section inspired, the designer explained, by Doris Day and the idealised housewife: models in trapeze-shaped dresses, suggesting pregnancy or babywear, accessorised with pink hair rollers and carrying dolls as babies.

Then an army of female superheroes strutted on. These were superheroes dressed like baddies: Wonder Woman wore a studded leather thong over her hotpants, a jewelled denim jacket and corset-laced boots. Pocahontas wore a feather headdress with a leather corset, fringed knickers and ankle boots.

The finale of the show, named Paradise Island, payed tribute to Xena, Warrior Princess. The floor-length evening gown in gold smocked satin is likely to be on several front row shopping lists - although probably without the rabbit pelts tangled into the model's hair.

fields.headline: Galapagos oil catastrophe
fields.standfirst: Race to evacuate rare animals as 150,000-gallon slick closing on islands threatens to destroy unique habitats
fields.trailText: Some of the world's rarest animals were being evacuated from their habitats in the Galapagos archipelago last night as an international clear-up team failed to contain a 150,000 gallon spillage of diesel oil which is advancing to new islands.
fields.body:
Some of the world's rarest animals were being evacuated from their habitats in the Galapagos archipelago last night as an international clear-up team failed to contain a 150,000 gallon spillage of diesel oil which is advancing to new islands.

Three days after the Ecuadorean tanker Jessica started leaking oil, the slick covers more than 300 square kilometres within one of the most fragile and untouched marine ecosystems in the world. it threatens the islands' unique species of plants and animals that were crucial in helping Charles Darwin develop his theory of evolution when he visited the Galapagos in 1835.

Ecuador's environment minister said the accident had already caused "extremely severe" environmental damage. David Bellamy, president of the Galapagos Foundation, told Radio 4's The World at One: "Here you have a unique series of ecosystems which are under immense pressure anyway. It is a catastrophe."

Last night the spillage was due to reach Espanola island, the southernmost tip of the archipelago, 600 miles west of the mainland. The oil had already spread west to Santa Fe island, home to the Santa Fe land iguana, and was continuing north to the central Santa Cruz island.

The bay of San Cristobal island, where the Jessica ran aground last Tuesday, was described as "a black pond" by Stalin Suarez, of the Galapagos national park's crisis team.

"It's a pretty big spill," he said. "It's sad if it reaches any island. We are trying to see in what way we can make the impact the minimum."

A US coastguard team has joined the Ecuadorean operation and on Sunday started a round-the-clock pump-out of the remaining 100,000 gallons still in the tanker. At least 31,000 gallons has been cleared, according to Mr Suarez. Captain Edwin Stanton said he would try to transfer the fuel into empty tanks within the ship that are still intact.

Pressure from the surf, however, was creating new fissures and speeding up the leak. A strong tide could cause the tanker to break apart.

"The bottom line is once oil gets out of a ship its virtually impossible to remove it or contain it on the ocean," Capt Stanton said. More than 150 environmentalists, park rangers and even tourists were preparing to alleviate the potential effects on wildlife. Animals are being evacuated from coastal areas to prevent them being harmed. Even though the Galapagos is best known for reptiles such as the giant tortoise, it contains 28 unique bird species which are more susceptible to oil slicks. Volunteers were being sent to beaches to bring affected birds to veterinary stations. By last night only a small number of boobies, pelicans and sealions had been reached by the oil.

Paola Diaz, of the Charles Darwin Centre on Santa Cruz island, said recuperation priority would be given to the lava gull, the rarest gull in the world, baby sealions and petrels.

The long-term danger is that the fuel will sink to the ocean floor, destroying algae vital to the food chain, threatening marine iguanas, sharks, birds and other species.

The islands are important because their remoteness and barrenness has given rise to many species not found anywhere else. Almost all the reptiles, half the plants and a quarter of the species of fish are unique.

The oil spills are just the latest problems facing the UN world heritage site. Large commercial fishing boats are now invading the waters of the 7m-acre Galapagos marine reserve, taking thousands of tons of fish illegally.

In the past few weeks, lawless bands of Ecuadorean fishermen have violently attacked conservation installations, ransacked municipal offices, torched a national park vehicle, harassed tourist groups and taken rare captive-bred giant tortoises hostage, in an attempt to gain higher quotas.

The Jessica was on a routine trip to service a private tour boat operator and Petrocomercial, an arm of the state oil company that provides the islands with fuel, when it ran aground 500 metres off San Cristobal island. A pipe in the ship's marine room burst on Friday, starting the leak.

Almost all the reptiles, half the plants and a quarter of the species of fish are unique. The oil spills are just the latest problems facing the UN world heritage site. Large commercial fishing boats are now invading the waters of the 7m-acre Galapagos marine reserve, taking thousands of tons of fish illegally. In the past few weeks, lawless bands of Ecuadorean fishermen have violently attacked conservation installations, ransacked municipal offices, torched a national park vehicle, harassed tourist groups and taken rare captive-bred giant tortoises hostage, in an attempt to gain higher quotas. The Jessica was on a routine trip to service a private tour boat operator and Petrocomercial, an arm of the state oil company that provides the islands with fuel, when it ran aground 500 metres off San Cristobal island. A pipe in the ship's marine room burst on Friday, starting the leak.

webTitle: An opportunity for a stronger voice at local level

fields.headline: An opportunity for a stronger voice at local level
fields.trailText: The government's action plan for neighbourhood renewal, released last week, represents the boldest move in a generation to improve the lives of people living in deprived areas, writes John Routledge
fields.body:
The government's action plan for neighbourhood renewal, released last week, represents the boldest move in a generation to improve the lives of people living in deprived areas.

Ideas for improving public and private services have been gathered together in a blueprint intended to narrow the inequalities between the richest and poorest areas. But will it work?

The ingredients to make a difference are all there and the rhetoric certainly reads better than previous government attempts to revive flagging estates. This plan recognises the long-term nature of solving problems such as high concentrations of crime, poor health, unemployment, failing schools and low self-esteem.

It has the virtue of bringing partnership working to the delivery of mainstream services through local strategic partnerships (LSPs).

In the past, regeneration was something that was done to communities by remote and unaccountable partnerships, usually dominated by councils. Although local authorities will still be major partners on the LSPs, they will be closely scrutinised for openness and fairness by government offices in the regions.

Local residents, community and voluntary groups will have their own budgets to help them influence the LSPs, and "community chests" - small pots of money for localised distribution - to carry out their own projects. In effect, we are witnessing the birth of a new form of local governance giving a stronger voice to local people at neighbourhood level.

In theory, faceless bureaucrats and "control freaks" in town halls should get their come-uppance as more services are delivered at neighbourhood level and LSPs introduce a more open form of partnership working. But whether the action plan succeeds will largely come down to how well public bodies can adapt to the culture change it represents.

As a network of community and voluntary groups, Urban Forum campaigns for more community involvement in urban renewal initiatives.

The neighbourhood renewal action plan has taken on board several of the proposals the forum put to the government's social exclusion unit, which developed the plan. These include direct investment into community and voluntary groups that support local residents and a package of learning and training to develop their skills.

Writing a good strategy is only a beginning and most of the hard battles lie ahead. Many people who live in regeneration areas have seen initiatives come and go and are understandably sceptical that neighbourhood renewal is any different. They will take some convincing.

The best chance of success is to start with a listening campaign before devising new initiatives as part of the plan.

Next, local people should be empowered to have more influence over how local services are delivered, including opportunities for residents to deliver their own projects.

Well-informed residents - together with support for their community organisations - could start to bring about a real change in neighbourhood management, liberating councils to play a more strategic role in local governance.

In this way we could see local democracy reinvigorated and the creation of better places for people to live.

 John Routledge is chief executive of Urban Forum.

fields.headline: Moore returns full-time to BBC Entertainment
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Play UK's Myfanwy Moore is returning to full-time programme-making at BBC Entertainment, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Play UK channel editor controller Myfanwy Moore is returning to full-time programme-making in the BBC Entertainment department.

Ms Moore retained her role as editor of new comedy within BBC Entertainment when she moved to Play UK, the jointly-owned BBC/Flextech music and comedy pay-TV channel, in 1999.

She will now return to programme-making full-time within BBC Entertainment.

A BBC spokeswoman said that with Play UK growing and doing more origination, Ms Moore had decided it was no longer possible to do both jobs.

Ms Moore's Play UK role has been advertised. The closing date for applications is the end of this month.

webTitle: Why my child won't have the MMR jab

fields.headline: Why my child won't have the MMR jab
fields.standfirst: Peter Todd, a lawyer investigating the vaccination controversy, explains why he shares the concerns of his clients
fields.trailText: Peter Todd, a lawyer investigating the vaccination controversy, explains why he shares the concerns of his clients
fields.body:
The government is to spend a further £3m on advertising the benefits of the MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) vaccine. It hopes this will be enough to persuade people like me (father of nine-month-old Alexander) to have him vaccinated despite concerns of a possible link between MMR and bowel disorders and autism.

I have already seen Department of Health television advertisements for the vaccine which depict a baby left on the edge of a towering cliff. Is it a good thing to expose your baby to such risks, the ad asks.

Vaccination is a good thing and has undoubtedly saved millions of lives worldwide through the virtual eradication of smallpox, polio and many other serious and crippling illnesses. I am keen on vaccines: my son has already been immunised against diptheria, tetanus and acellular pertussis, polio, HIB and meningitis C. On Thursday he will have the TB vaccine too.

However, when Alexander's invitation to attend the GP's surgery for the MMR vaccination drops through the letterbox in the next few months, he won't be going.

I first became involved in the MMR controversy in April 1998 when the firm of solicitors I work for in London, Hodge Jones & Allen, took over responsibility for investigating a group of potential cases.

Since then I have travelled the country meeting families who think their children have suffered because of the vaccine. I have taken statements, researched medical records and tried to analyse this issue. A handful of cases in the early days soon became a flood and we have been contacted by more than 2,000 families who linked the vaccine to the onset of their children's health problems.

I have heard many similar stories of an uncomplicated pregnancy and birth followed by normal development during the first year: the mastery of a few words, good eye contact, affectionate hugs, consideration of the feelings of others. It all seems fine.

Then the MMR vaccine at 12-15 months, followed within a few months of a noticeable change: loss of eye contact, regression of speech, the child retreating into "a world of their own" and the gradual onset of the terrible tragedy of autism. This entails a lifetime of care and support and catastrophic financial implications for the family. A ballpark estimate for the financial cost of a lifetime of care and loss of earnings could be £3m.

Many people argue that the signs of autism cannot be spotted before 12-15 months and that the only association with the vaccine is that they occur at around the same time. Perhaps, but if autism is congenital then why is normal development followed by regression? Andrew Wakefield - the doctor who originally raised concerns over the jab - could be right that the evidence is stacking up against MMR.

· Peter Todd is a partner at the law firm Hodge, Jones and Allen, which is representing families who say their children have suffered ill effects as a result of the MMR vaccine

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: No Worries! by Marcia Williams and Noughts and Crosses by Malorie Blackman
fields.body:
No Worries!

Marcia Williams

(Walker Books, £4.99)

Age: 6-10

In fact, this book is all about worries, but presented in such a way that they are sensibly considered before being rationalised and diminished. The cartoon-style illustrations are an ideal means of conveying concerns -bed-time fears, getting-lost-in-the-supermarket fears, feeling under-loved fears - without over-dramatising or belittling them. The speech bubbles are accessible to the most tentative reader and the light-hearted feel of the book avoids any didactic overlay. This cheering book offers an excellent starting point for fruitful discussion and, perhaps, the odd healthy revelation. It ends with the message that worries tend to evaporate if they are talked about.

Noughts and Crosses

Malorie Blackman

(Doubleday, £10.99)

Age: 12-17

Sephy and Callum's relationship dates from early childhood, during which neither realises the significance of their respective social status - she is a Cross, he a Nought. The society in which they grow up operates a disturbingly plausible version of apartheid which erodes their innocence. Callum witnesses tragedy within his family due to the draconian laws which Sephy's father, a government minister, oversees. Yet, through it all, an undoubted connection draws them together. This epic tome packs some powerful political punches to which readers will undoubtedly respond. But Blackman never compromises the story, which is dramatic, moving and brave.

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Sikhism
fields.trailText: Sikhism
fields.body:
Sikhism for children

Suitable for: younger children

Carol Rainbow, a primary teacher, has created this site to teach younger children the history, beliefs and way of life of Sikhs. Informative and colourful.

Tour of the Golden Temple

Suitable for: KS2/3

Dedicated to Sikhism, this site includes a resources page, with a glossary of religious terms, Sikh names and an enlightening section on gurdwaras (including the historical gurdwaras of the Punjab and a virtual tour of the Golden Temple at Amritsar). It requires Netscape 3/Internet Explorer 3, but a more powerful system is preferable.

Hukamnama

Suitable for: KS3/4

Features both historical and spiritual dimensions of Sikhism, relating to the Sikh community today. Listen to the hukamnama from Amritsar (Real Player needed), updated daily. And read the text of the hukamnama, have it emailed to you or take a "cyber hukan" from Siri Guru Granth Sahib. You can also see a western Sikh art exhibition held in 1999.

Artefacts

Suitable for: KS3 and teachers

Part of Strathclyde University's site, it features a range of Sikh artefacts, including the "five Ks". Pictures fit onto an A4 sheet for ease of printing and can be saved into a word-processed or other document (jpeg format).

Teachers' links 1

Suitable for: teachers

A wealth of links and resources from the Religious Exchange Service. Features all major world religions. Allows you to search generally or via themes of texts, art, festivals, pilgrimage, buildings, rites of passage, community and ultimate questions.

Teachers' links 2

Suitable for: teachers

Ideal for those researching RE resources. A search under Sikhism found over 40 links, though many were to the same website. Has links to curriculum advice, explores how to use ICT in RE and lists places of worship for educational visits.

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: Romans
fields.trailText: Romans
fields.body:
A Roman town

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

Based on Sue White's research on Caistor St Edmunds, which was once Norfolk's capital.Good description and site map of the Roman town of Caistor, plus photo tour option.

What did the Romans do for us?

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils & teachers

Includes a study of a fort at Hadrian's Wall, and examines what the Romans did for us, mosaics, life in Roman Britain for women, Roman recipes, and an audio drama of Boudicca's rebellion.

The Roman baths

Suitable for: KS1/2

Before visiting Bath, go to this official site to stir up enthusiasm. Includes a tour of the baths and pump room, printable photos and good cross- curricular references.

A Roman villa

Suitable for: KS2

Pupils will enjoy pictures of the Roman villa at Littlecote, Berkshire, but may find the text about gods and goddesses and the Roman army a bit challenging.

Roman Empire

Suitable for: teachers

Well illustrated, emphasising Rome and empire rather than just Britain. Informative on Roman coins, although the text is aimed at adults.

Festivals

Suitable for: teachers

Great for teachers researching the seasonal Roman and Greek festivals, but not stimulating for children.

Hadrian's Wall

Suitable for: strong KS2 pupils

Information and practical advice for visitors. See map under "Exploring the Wall".

A Roman temple

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils

Select The Virtual Mithraeum for a video tour of a ruined Roman temple. Good visually, though there's not a lot left of the temple.

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: DrugSense and Europe in the Round
fields.body:
Europe in the Round

(Vocational Technologies, £60 + vat), tel: 01252-337055.

Age: KS3 & 4

This CD supports all aspects of the national curriculum with a European dimension, and includes population studies and geography of place. Content goes beyond the needs of secondary geography. Students interact smoothly with images and data. It's easy to use, and graphical and statistical aspects enable students to make comparisons and find links. It can also be used easily in small groups, with students able to take material away to create new analyses and tables. This CD could become a standard tool for exploring the statistics, images and background of Europe.

DrugSense

(New Media Press, £74.99 + vat )

Age 9-13

Offers much to teachers introducing drugs awareness. Mainly a science package, it has strong links to PSHE and ICT. All nine activities can be edited by the teacher, enabling valuable differentiation. Children work in interactive environments, such as the police station, amusement arcade and pub. The presentation is progressive in its structuring of accurate, well-researched material, produced with the help of the police and drug education specialists. It's easy and fast to use and has clear supporting documentation, a boon for busy teachers. It can also support less willing learners through hours of focused learning.

 Read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

fields.headline: Box clever
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones  wonders whether she should punch a bit harder ... or not
fields.trailText: Janet Jones wonders whether she should punch a bit harder ... or not
fields.body:
"What happened," came the question "to the person who was writing those really good pieces in Guardian Education?"

"You know. The good ones we used to read aloud in the staffroom... every week."

"Who wrote them?" (There's nothing like a little jealousy to get one asking key questions.)

"I don't know."

"You don't know?" The jealousy receded. Someone unknown is less provoking.

"No."

"Oh." Realisation dawned. "They were anonymous?"

"Yes."

"Ah." Another key question came to mind: "What was so good about them?"

"They were hard-hitting."

So there you have it. We should be flexing our muscles and thumping if we want to be read aloud in staffrooms. Not bullet points. Bullet punches.

The next key question must be who or what we should be hitting. If you are going to land a punch you have to land it on something. There has to be an us and a them: goodies and baddies.

Who are the baddies in further education? Or, to put it another way, who are the goodies?

The candidates could be:

Teachers

Students

Support staff

Middle management

Senior management

Funding council

Government

Electorate

Or even, if you believe it exists, society.

So, for the hitting to start, first pick your baddie and your goodie.

In further education this is usually theoretical - I have seen one colleague punch another though that was nothing to do with the day job - and, anyway, if you look closer you discover the factions get blurred: there is much educational and literal intermarrying. Teachers marry students. Students marry support staff. Support staff marry middle management. Middle management was married to funding council. You get the picture.

Blurred factions as targets do not lend themselves to straight hitting. While hitting within factions is much the same as wood v trees.

To return to my questioner (who did write those really good pieces?) - he is as philosophically blurred as most of the rest of us. In fact he is more intermarried than many of us. For all his demands for hitting hard, I do not believe there has been a hint of a hit in his life. And I do not think that has prevented him from being really good.

Who are the baddies in further education? Or, to put it another way, who are the goodies? The candidates could be: Teachers Students Support staff Middle management Senior management Funding council Government Electorate Or even, if you believe it exists, society. So, for the hitting to start, first pick your baddie and your goodie. In further education this is usually theoretical - I have seen one colleague punch another though that was nothing to do with the day job - and, anyway, if you look closer you discover the factions get blurred: there is much educational and literal intermarrying. Teachers marry students. Students marry support staff. Support staff marry middle management. Middle management was married to funding council. You get the picture. Blurred factions as targets do not lend themselves to straight hitting. While hitting within factions is much the same as wood v trees. To return to my questioner (who did write those really good pieces?) - he is as philosophically blurred as most of the rest of us. In fact he is more intermarried than many of us. For all his demands for hitting hard, I do not believe there has been a hint of a hit in his life. And I do not think that has prevented him from being really good.

fields.headline: More money for disabled students
fields.standfirst: Colleges demand a bigger slice of the funding, reports  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Colleges demand a bigger slice of the funding, reports Simon Midgley
fields.body:
Colleges will today plead that they should get more money than universities to improve access for the disabled because they serve more than twice as many students.

The special educational needs and disability bill, which gets its second Commons reading today, earmarks £20m for English colleges over the next two years.

This compares with £56m set aside for such spending in higher education institutions. While backing the new legislation, Judith Norrington, the Association of Colleges' director of curriculum and quality, said that in order for colleges to make learning accessible for as many disabled learners as possible more money would need to be found in the years to come.

"It's such a worthwhile purpose that we want to do it properly, and it needs to be effectively resourced. The current funding on offer would not meet total needs by any means and we would look for further support over future years."

Ms Norrington said that further education - with more than 4m students in some 420 colleges in England compared to some 1.6m students in considerably fewer higher education institutions - deserved proportionately greater funding.

The thrust of the current bill is that the needs of disabled learners should be met wherever reasonable - that they should be entitled to access to buildings and places where they can learn.

Underpinning the legislation will be guidance to make sure people get learning support. There will also be regulated pre-16 and adult appeals processes and a greater emphasis on integrating disabled learners into mainstream education whereverpossible.

The Association of Colleges is to draw up a list of things that each college will need to do to ensure access. This will also lead to some sense of what costs are likely to be involved.

Some years ago the Further Education Funding Council did a survey in one region of England to see what kind of costs could be involved in improving accessibility by introducing lifts and ramps, etc. Ms Norrington says that extrapolating from this figure suggests a national bill of some £150m.

The funding council is keen that work-based training providers should be required to make the same improvements to accessibility as colleges, under the same regulatory regime. And in the same way organisations offering students work placements should also have to take reasonable steps to support disabled learning.

At present the legislation emphasises that individuals must make it clear that they are disabled or have special educational needs. However the association wants to make it a joint responsibility with colleges to find out whether an individual has a disability or needs help.

webTitle: The future of the car showroom - a woman

fields.headline: Death of the salesman
fields.standfirst: John Crace has seen the future of the car showroom - and it's woman
fields.trailText: John Crace has seen the future of the car showroom - and it's woman
fields.body:
Oy John, fancy a new motor. If Toyota's experience is anything to go by, the chances are you don't. Or at least you may want the motor, but you could do without the stress of the heavy sell. Put simply, car salesmen tend to come equal first on most people's job hate lists. Along with journalists.

Car showroom culture has survived pretty much intact since the 1960s. There have been a few innovations - the water cooler, the coffee machine and the polystyrene cups - but the acres of impenetrable glass frontage caging a handful of predatory shiny-suited men remain an indelible image. Eighteen months ago Toyota GB commissioned research into what their customers felt about their 225 UK dealerships. The findings, which may well come as little surprise to anyone who has ever tried to buy a car, made salutary reading.

"It turned out that some people preferred visiting the showroom when it was closed," laughs Simon Frith, Toyota's general manager of dealer development. "At night they could look through the windows without feeling they were being hunted by salesmen or being laughed at for their ignorance." Other findings were equally illuminating. Customers disliked the toilets and the parking facilities in particular and the whole ambience in general. "We started off imagining we would have to redesign the layout," continues Frith, "We soon realised we'd have to change the whole culture. We particularly needed to rethink how we treated women customers. Women account for 40% of individual car sales and are by far the most influential voice in a family purchase; yet most women felt patronised or ignored."

Further research led to two pilot schemes being introduced at showrooms in Bristol and Grimsby. Out went all barriers, in the forms of desks and salivating salesmen and in came a "host" to welcome people into the showroom and to be alert to their needs. Those that wanted to be left alone would be left alone, those who wanted help got it and everyone was encouraged to treat the place - including the inside of the cars - like home. The quantitative research into the effect on sales has yet to be completed, but the qualitative research into customer satisfaction has been overwhelming and the scheme is to be rolled out through the rest of the dealerships from June onwards.

Two key new trends have emerged. First is that the best man for the job may well be a woman. Toyota believe that women are generally best suited to the host role and are keen to redress the balance between male and female sales staff which currently stands at about 9 to 1 in favour of men. Second is that Toyota plan to debunk the myth of the born salesman by insisting that all sales staff, from the showroom manager to the man - or woman - employed to clean the cars, must have between two to five days training.

"We have employed CDA, a culture change specialist with expertise with other top service clients, such as GNER and Allied Domecq, to help devise a training package," says Robin Giles, Toyota GB's dealer representation manager. "Staff will be taught behavioural skills, such as recognising body language and working as a team, and will learn to understand the importance of branding and how other retailers treat their customers. We are also working on a different reward structure that is not so heavily weighted in favour of commission."

Training will also have knock-on benefits. Most dealerships have a staff churn of 40% per annum with 85% of the vacancies being filled by sales staff from other dealerships and Toyota hope to create a more stable workforce.

Toyota's problems are typical of car dealerships throughout the country. Yet, although there is a general recognition that Toyota have correctly identified the issues, rivals are less sure of their solution. "Customers still want face-to-face interaction," says Renault dealer, Jason Mahon. "If they are handing over that sort of money they want to talk to somebody." We shall see.
