fields.headline: Unions ride again
fields.standfirst: After years of decline trade unions are enjoying a revival and even the shop steward is sporting a new name
fields.trailText: After years of decline trade unions are enjoying a revival and even the shop steward is sporting a new name
fields.body:
Fred Kite, the late Peter Sellers' sublime portrait of a union shop steward in the classic comedy film I'm all right Jack, was many things: posturing buffoon, blustering windbag and general figure of mockery.

But even his worst enemies wouldn't have called him a "learning rep". It hardly conveys the anathema of "scab" or "blackleg," but it sounds distinctly iffy to anyone rooted in the industrial relations of the 50s, 60s and 70s.

And yet in today's employment landscape, stewards can refer to themselves as "learning reps" without blushing.

Demands for better wage packets and improved working conditions remain at the top of the collective agenda. But waving the flag for more and better training of their members is the most obvious sign of a renaissance in the trade union movement.

Figures alone suggest that unions are enjoying a revival of fortunes. Last year total recruitment went up by more than 100,000 compared to 1999 - the first serious up-turn for more than two decades, according to the Trades Union Congress (TUC). Although not a massive rise (there are, after all, 6.7m workers affiliated through their unions to the TUC, with another 1m outside the organisation) it is nonetheless a significant increase after years of shedding members and public hostility.

The unions' rediscovered passion for education and training is apparent on a number of fronts, a fact recognised by their traditional adversaries - the bosses. The Confederation of British Industry is the first to hold up its hand and acknowledge the part now being played by unions in forging better industrial relations through more organised and improved work-based training provision.

Anne Lindsay of the confederation's learning and skills group says the unions, many of whom are major employers in their own right, are pushing at an open door.

"Training is now seen as vital to companies, particularly in the new global economy, and trade unions are partners. They now recognise profits count and that the surest way to get results is to improve training opportunities and reskill the workforce," she explains.

The TUC, led by general secretary John Monks, who also happens to be a member of the 15-strong Learning and Skills Council (one of the big tasks will be handling the unions' "learning fund"), has helped reinvent the trade union movement, according to Sarah Perman, director of the Partnership Institute.

The institute, launched by Tony Blair last week, is perhaps symbolic of the ending of the old "them and us" relationship. It is being backed by both the TUC, which is providing five staff and a network of 26 consultants; and chambers of commerce. Already Barclays Bank, Birmingham Health Trust and a major meat-packaging company have come on board to explore new collaborative arrangements between staff and employers, with training being the common currency, Perman points out.

"Training is the major part of our work. We want to create a culture- change in the workforce and we are working hand-in-hand with employers to do so," she says.

"The issue now is about helping employers improve productivity and helping unions gain respect and new members - in other words, growth for both."

All this is a long way from the public loathing trade unions commanded during the 1980s and 1990s, declares Liz Smith of the TUC's Learning Services initiative.

"We are now enjoying a revival. Twenty years ago trade unions were at the heart of developing apprenticeship courses and other forms of youth training schemes. But successive Tory governments then dismantled our role. Although we did work with the training and enterprise councils, they had a difficult task which did not leave a lot of scope for us to influence training provision."

Smith cites several examples of today's unions shaping the agenda. More than 2,000 work-based learning reps - union representatives who in the past had been the rabble rousers and prime recruitment levers on the shop floor - have been equipped over the last two years with new skills to help promote the desirability of training. The learning reps are the important intermediaries, negotiating with employers and training providers, spreading the training message up and down the line.

"The language has changed," Smith says. "We seek to form partnerships with employers, because we share the benefits of having a better trained workforce. Unions are also helping employers understand the need for greater flexibility in the way training is done. It is not just about sending people on courses, but giving them time off work, having colleges come to do more training in the workplace, and training times that are realistic."

One of the most innovative schemes involves Walls, the ice cream-makers, whose learning reps across the country are helping workers - mostly women with no qualifications - draw up learning plans.

"This has made quite a difference to the culture of the company," Smith claims. "And I suspect that this cultural shift towards giving staff opportunities to learn is having an impact on the bottom line - selling more ice cream."

A crucial demand, from the unions' perspective, is the need for UK workers to get a statutory right to time off work to improve their skills. Although a lot of voluntary agreements have been forged with employers, the continued absence of the sort of legally binding contract enjoyed by many employees elsewhere in Europe rankles deep.

Unions believe there is a limit to how far they can exert influence in the training arena unless workers are given, say, five days paid leave to study.

However, legislation will not solve everything, Smith says. "Unions can still do more to improve workers' self-esteem, alter their perception of learning, help them get over the failure attitude and provide encouragement, particularly in the area of basic skills."

webTitle: So you want to learn... chimney sweeping

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Chimney sweeping
fields.trailText: Chimney sweeping
fields.body:
Oh, I was expecting the chimney sweep. That's me.

But chimney sweeps ought to be covered in grime. And speak like Dick van Dyke, no doubt. You've seen too much Mary Poppins, sir.

But isn't getting caked in soot the real fun of the job? Not in my book.

So what is the job? Chimney sweeps, often described as chimney technicians, provide a maintenance service that ensures domestic and commercial/ industrial chimneys are kept free from chemical deposits and other obstructions such as cobwebs, birds' nests and leaves. Sweeping ensures that heating systems are safe, effective and efficient, and prevents carbon monoxide poisoning and chimney fires.

I suppose it's a dying art. Far from it. Increasing concerns over carbon monoxide poisoning from faulty appliances and flues and gas safety in general has increased the demand for chimney sweeping. But we don't just sweep.

You dance on the rooftops? No, but there are sweeps who repoint and rebuild chimney pots; fit birdcages and cowls. They also fit and repair fireplaces, boilers, firebacks and hearths, supply fireplace parts, reline chimneys.

OK I get the message. We also turn up at weddings to bring good luck!

Are you usually self-employed? Yes, the majority of chimney sweeps are, although some may work for private firms, for instance, solid fuel distributors.

Is there any training? It is essential for chimney sweeps to be trained so that their work is carried out in a safe and proper manner. Sweeps must be CORGI registered (Council of Registered Gas Installers) if they are dealing with gas appliances. To become CORGI registered it is necessary to get a certificate of competence through the National Accredited Certification Scheme (ACS) for Individual Gas Fitting Operatives.

What about for general sweeping? The National Association of Chimney Sweeps, (NACS) offers advice and training at their own training centre which is accredited by the Construction Industry Training Board and can offer NVQ level 2 in basic sweeping techniques. It also offers the complete CITB/City & Guilds NVQ level 2 course in chimney engineering and other courses in association with a variety of professional bodies such as the Heating Equipment Testing and Approval Scheme (HETAS), the Oil Firing Technician Association for the Petroleum Industry (OFTEC) and CORGI.

Telephone 01785 811732

Website: www.chimneyworks.co.uk

Email: nacs@chimneyworks.co.uk

Telephone 01256 372200 nacs@chimneyworks.co.uk

fields.headline: Niche market
fields.standfirst: Stuart Bartholomew fights the cause for specialist colleges
fields.trailText: Stuart Bartholomew fights the cause for specialist colleges
fields.body:
Working in a specialist college of art and design has frequently felt like membership of an endangered species. The predators have been the multi-subject institutions who have effected mergers and acquisitions under the banner of economies of scale. National funding methodologies have been prejudicial for small colleges.

For those associated with specialist education, there is a basic instinct. Big is worse - invariably size becomes the negative of quality. The last four decades have witnessed the progressive demise of specialist colleges. In the further education sector these have been reduced to a handful. Higher Education institutions have faired better, but still represent a small volume of student provision and only 1.6% of the £4bn allocated by the Higher education Funding Council.

Whilst the environment for specialist colleges has often been hostile, it has not moderated the demand for places by students. Applications to The Arts Institute for the last academic session increased by 98.7%. It was the largest rise recorded by the Universities Central Admissions System. Just as parents are reacting to the large and frequently soulless comprehensive, some students feel their learning is inhibited by being pushed from pillar to post in large colleges and universities.

It is gratifying to note recent changes in attitude to specialisation and the associated size of institutions. The secretary of state in his recent statement, Excellence and Innovation, invites further education col leges to identify their capability to provide excellence and innovation in a particular specialism. The Higher Education Funding Council for England has made progress in recognising the financial challenges faced by small, specialist colleges, as has the Further Education Funding Council in its memorial year. The broadening of research assessment funding has also recognised the importance of creative disciplines in original and scholarly work.

Such a change in attitude is based upon hard evidence that specialist colleges punch above their weight. In art, design and media, their record in producing graduates for the creative industries is legend. Collectively, the specialist institutions have alumni who dominate art, design, film, television, fashion, new media and creative arts, both at home and abroad. The national performance in producing high-quality professionals in creative disciplines is internationally respected. Institutions like my own, which recently congratulated a former student, Wolfgang Tillmans, on winning the Turner Prize are better known in Berlin than Bournemouth!

There are now more receptive minds in government departments that realise that the creative industries are not a fringe benefit for our economy, but are at the very heart of it. As a whole these industries generate a staggering £60bn each year. They contribute 4% of GDP and employ 1m people. The value added to successful practitioners is significant. Their creative skills are frequently honed in small specialist institutions.

The case for specialism is in part the case for art and design itself. It concerns the existence of a working environment committed to creative work. Such places are academically led, rather than pushed by administration. They allow students to do what the title of the course says they can do, and much more. Connections between making work, professional practice and research are natural rather than symbolic. Above all, the specialist college values the individual.

Specialist colleges cannot be average. They have to be good. The sector as a whole might note that reputation for excellence is not secured by elite selection. The specialist institutions have traditionally widened access and often welcome those who have been rejected elsewhere in the education sector. Their success in lifelong learning relates to a belief in the individual and of the benefits secured from working in a creative environment.

Specialisation does not imply isolation from the further or higher education sector. Specialist colleges have been the vanguard for collaboration. CADISE, a consortium which links seven specialist institutions in southern England, is a model forum for the exchange of good practice and cooperative venture. It is an association of equal membership, unencumbered by the top-heavy management that fetters so much innovation in large education establishments.

It wasn't long ago that towns and cities viewed their colleges of art and design as part of the civic culture. The progressive suffocation of these institutions will be seen by historians as a foolish sacrifice to the rationalising tendency. Let us hope that retentive managers whose ambition is to tidy up will be replaced by those with commitment to excellence for all students.

fields.bodyText: Working in a specialist college of art and design has frequently felt like membership of an endangered species. The predators have been the multi-subject institutions who have effected mergers and acquisitions under the banner of economies of scale. National funding methodologies have been prejudicial for small colleges. For those associated with specialist education, there is a basic instinct. Big is worse - invariably size becomes the negative of quality. The last four decades have witnessed the progressive demise of specialist colleges. In the further education sector these have been reduced to a handful. Higher Education institutions have faired better, but still represent a small volume of student provision and only 1.6% of the £4bn allocated by the Higher education Funding Council. Whilst the environment for specialist colleges has often been hostile, it has not moderated the demand for places by students. Applications to The Arts Institute for the last academic session increased by 98.7%. It was the largest rise recorded by the Universities Central Admissions System. Just as parents are reacting to the large and frequently soulless comprehensive, some students feel their learning is inhibited by being pushed from pillar to post in large colleges and universities. It is gratifying to note recent changes in attitude to specialisation and the associated size of institutions. The secretary of state in his recent statement, Excellence and Innovation, invites further education col leges to identify their capability to provide excellence and innovation in a particular specialism. webTitle: The pros and cons of the Tories' university funding plans

fields.headline: Golden goodbyes
fields.standfirst: Andrew Oswald  on the pros and cons of the Tories' university funding plans
fields.trailText: Andrew Oswald on the pros and cons of the Tories' university funding plans
fields.body:
Completely wrong on the details; completely right on the underlying idea. That is the most sensible reaction to the new Conservative Party proposals for funding our universities. Let us take our hats off to the Tory party for innovative thinking, but encourage them to send their Model T back to the factory to be painted in a more sensible colour - like blue with a red interior.

"Nobody will be paying more" is a great slogan for a general election campaign but a rotten idea. The rich should pay much more. And saying that loans will only have to be repaid when you get to £20,000 a year, rather than the present £10,000, is illogical and a sop to middle-class students with banners.

First, let us think about pounds and cents. We need, yes, to set some of Britain's universities free. Except at a few places like mine, which has decided to be entrepreneurial and shape its own destiny, universities are being ground relentlessly into the third division. Absurdly low levels of funding have decimated us. The lack of cash, forced on universities with the weasel words "efficiency savings", has meant that today's undergraduates often get a poor learning environment. Carpets are frayed; paint is missing; the computers are merely second-rate.

But it is the brain cells behind the chalk that matter more. University lecturers earn less than train drivers which, no disrespect at all intended to train drivers, means we just cannot recruit. Economics departments all over the country, for example, struggle to find Brits with first-class honours degrees who are interested in teaching. Our graduating students start on higher pay than those grading the finals' scripts. A young economics lecturer earns little more than £20,000 a year. Yet his or her equivalent in the United States makes £50,000.

Second, stop pounding education and see sense. True, the pay is ridiculous. But that is not all new. I remember going in for my first mortgage, when I was newly teaching at Balliol College Oxford, and the building society chap behind the desk could not believe how little I earned. He thought I was joking.

What has changed more is the freedom and time to think. They're gone. The jackboots and jargon of the so-called Quality Assurance Agency inspectors have arrived. It is essential in your lectures to know the difference between aims and objectives (no, I am not kidding). And one has to know what the difference is between summative assessment and formative assessment (really). And there is no time (if you have 57 personal tutees, how can you be personal, let alone think?). And one has to fill in forms, and forms, and, yawn, oh no it is midnight, forms.

All this is a disgrace. We are at the start of a century in which it is the power of ideas, not of things, that will dominate. The only reason that you do not hear this more is that many university staff are scared to speak up and have been jumped on so many times that only their heads are visible above the Grimpen Mire of government over-regulation.

It is an excellent idea to think of giving universities a golden goodbye. Teresa May deserves to be congratulated. Freedom and competition work. Endowments paid for by selling radio spectrum would be fine, though we must accept that some universities will prefer to stay in the public sector. Of course, it is not really coming from radio spectrum; it is just coming out of the taxpayers' pot into which the radio spectrum dosh will have been deposited. But if it makes it more politically sellable to use that language, no harm done.

Yet problems abound. It is daft to offer universities freedom with your right hand and then snatch it back with the left. For goodness sake let them charge fees. What is wrong with that? The whole philosophy of the Conservative Party is to allow the market to work. And markets mean prices.

We must worry about fairness and what is called "access", or, in other words, allowing children from poor backgrounds to go to university. Totally right. But what is forgotten is that the current system is itself hopeless. Our universities are stuffed full of well-off youngsters. On every graduation day, a sea of parental Jaguars replaces the ranks of teachers' battered Escorts.

If Britain is serious about educating high-school students from underprivileged families, and it should be, then we should be targeting our taxpayers' hard-won money. Give large university scholarship grants to young men and women from hard-up homes. Make them really large.

But what on earth is the point of making the taxpayer stump up for Brooklyn Beckham to go to university?

 Andrew Oswald is professor of economics at Warwick University. He was an adviser to the Greenaway Report on the future funding of higher education

webTitle: Survey shows adult literacy courses are not hitting the mark

fields.headline: Poor progress report
fields.standfirst: Survey shows adult literacy courses are not hitting the mark
fields.trailText: Survey shows adult literacy courses are not hitting the mark
fields.body:
The first national survey of adult literacy courses for a generation shows that students on them still make disappointingly little progress in reading and even less in writing. The findings have shocked ministers just weeks before Tony Blair launches New Labour's major strategy to tackle the country's basic skills problem.

But they see the results as vindicating their determination to be the first government to make a serious effort to reduce the estimated 20% of the adult population with poor or no literacy and numeracy.

Malcolm Wicks, the minister for lifelong learning, who has direct responsibility for the new strategy, said: "The results are dismal and they are a real spur for action. There are a lot of good things going on, but the overall national picture is dire."

The report - Progress in Adult Literacy: Do Learners Learn? by the National Foundation for Educational Research (NFER) - is the first national survey of adult literacy provision since the mid 1970s, said Alan Wells, director of the Basic Skills Agency, which commissioned it.

There is a shortage of reliable research in this field, not just in the UK, but anywhere in the world, he said.

The mid-70s picture showed only a quarter of learners made significant progress, half made "only very modest progress", and a quarter showed no improvement.

"It would be encouraging to report that this recent NFER study showed many more adults making substan tial progress... encouraging, but it wouldn't be true," said Wells.

There is also scant research on the relative effectiveness of different teaching and learning methods, according to Dr Greg Brooks, of Sheffield university, who co-authored the new report.

Not enough is known about what works and what doesn't in teaching adult literacy, he told an "international colloquium" on the topic, organised by the DfEE last week.

Over three days, experts from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Ireland, and from the Flemish education department described their national or regional approaches to the problem. Most made it clear that increasing hopes are pinned on information technology and specially designed computer-learning packages, many available on the internet.

But Malcolm Wicks told the conference he remained to be convinced, despite the growth of these innovative learning materials, that ordinary people with basic skills needs would be attracted to use them.

Holding the event so close to the launch of the government's new strategy did not imply "floundering around" for solutions, he said.

"I think we know that the quality of materials has to be enhanced greatly. We know that inspection makes a difference. We can build on the national literacy strategy which is proving so successful in schools."

Susan Pember, director of the DfEE's new Adult Basic Skills Strategy Unit, stressed that the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority had now defined the basic skills curriculum and that intensive training of teachers to deliver it had just started.

Brooks said that the new survey, which scrutinised students on 71 courses run by further education colleges and local education authorities, showed that tutors were largely part-time. Although well qualified, they lacked opportunity for professional development. Classroom assistants able to address individual needs made a real difference, but were not available to 40% of tutors.

The students were given tests before and after the courses. The reading students showed a "small but statistically significant improvement". Writing students showed no significant reduction in errors and no increase in complexity in their retests.

webTitle: Balancing scientific openness with scientists' safety

fields.headline: Testing time for government
fields.standfirst: More openness in animal experiments is to be balanced with the safety of scientists, as  Lee Elliot Major  reports
fields.trailText: More openness in animal experiments is to be balanced with the safety of scientists, as Lee Elliot Major reports
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, is to be advised to make the details of animal experiments more public. But advisers are likely to argue that the identities of scientists involved in experiments, and the details of commercially sensitive projects, should remain secret.

The conclusions, expected to be published in the coming weeks, come from the Animals Procedures Committee, the independent group of experts which advises the home secretary on the licensing of experiments "carried out on living, protected animals which may cause them pain, suffering, distress or lasting harm".

They are set to provide the home secretary with yet more dilemmas over the government's policies on animal testing, after Straw last week put his weight behind new legislation aimed at preventing animal activists violently intimidating staff at research laboratories. Amendments to the criminal justice bill could lead to an expansion of restrictions on picketing houses and acting in an intimidatory way.

Tony Blair, the prime minister, last week also gave his personal backing to Huntingdon Life Sciences, the beleaguered animal testing laboratory under siege from animal rights protesters. The protesters are now calling on the company's financial backer, the Royal Bank of Scotland, to withdraw financial support from the Cambridge-based company.

It is thought that the spectre of further protests helped to scupper Cambridge University's plans for a £20m cognitive research laboratory, which was to house animal experiments.

The government, however, is keen to keep scientific and pharmaceutical companies in the country, believing their research projects may one day help to alleviate human illness.

The government last year reported a massive increase in scientific experiments on animals as work intensifies on the human genome project.

In fact, both sides of the fractious debate over animal testing could take something from any government move towards more openness in the licensing of animal experiments.

Some scientists applying for licences fear that more disclosure of information would put their personal security as well as that of their family at risk from animal rights activists. But other researchers argue that more openness would lead to less suspicion and wider public appreciation of the benefits of animal experiments.

The Animals Procedures Committee has been consulted on how the government's Freedom of Information Act should impact on the licensing of animal experiments. It is just one of many consultations being undertaken in a reappraisal of the government's policies 10 years after the original Animals Procedures Act was passed through parliament.

After announcing the consultation last year, Professor Michael Banner, the chairman of the committee, said: "There are important arguments for increasing the amount of information which is available to the public in this field and there are also arguments against. We think it right to have a full consultation exercise before we offer the home secretary our detailed advice about the issue."

Last week, one of the officials on the secretariat for the committee, Richard West, said the report on the consultation was likely to propose more openness, while recognising limits for reasons of personal safety and commercial confidentiality.

The committee received a large number of responses to the consultation paper - some 2,500 in total. Individual respondents tended to favour openness with constraints for reasons of personal safety. Pharmaceutical and research companies preferred to err more on the side of secrecy, particularly for commercially sensitive projects.

webTitle: The UK is the place to do MBAs

fields.headline: Weather permitting
fields.standfirst: A new report shows the UK has toppled the US as the place to do MBAs, reports  Donald MacLeod
fields.trailText: A new report shows the UK has toppled the US as the place to do MBAs, reports Donald MacLeod
fields.body:
There are plenty of reasons for doing an MBA - including the chance to catch a bit of sunshine. That's the pitch at this week's MBA fair in London from Griffith University in Australia, which claims studying near the beaches of Queensland could cost less than doing the course in the UK.

Nice try, but it doesn't disguise the fact that Britain is regarded by major companies all over Europe as the best place to do an MBA.

A survey by Cox Communications, based in Germany, found in a survey of 37 major companies that the UK has supplanted the US, where the MBA was developed, as the place to get the best course. With about 100 business schools, Britain has more programmes to offer than other European countries. It also has some of the best known schools, such as London Business School and Cranfield.

The report's author, William Cox, said he was surprised at the weak showing of the US - second bottom in the league of countries mentioned by respondents to his survey: "In the past, the USA was considered the best place to do an MBA. Now European firms see Europe as the best place."

He believes European schools are more international than their American counterparts. "While IMD in Switzerland, for example, boasts roughly 98% foreign students, Harvard Business School normally enrols between 30% and 40%. Clearly American schools are more nationally oriented. This means that their case studies are likely to cover American corporate situations, their faculty was educated in the US and is American, and the skills needed to deal with corporate problem cases are more likely to be successful in the USA than in Europe."

Switzerland comes second to the UK. It is the home of the headquarters of numerous multinationals and a country with a strong service sector. Two of Europe's best-known schools -IMD in Lausanne and the GSBA Zurich - are located there. GSBA Zurich has established itself as the largest and most successful business school in German-speaking Europe.

Germany and France followed closely behind Switzerland. Asia was not mentioned once.

When it came to the type of MBA programme companies wanted to see, there was a clear preference for two-year part-time courses. As Cox points out: "Executive programmes are becoming increasingly popular because they allow experienced professionals to do their MBAs. Companies responded that they think the ideal time to get an MBA is later in life, after gathering some management experience. Yet successful executives are reluctant to interrupt their careers and thus prefer either part-time programmes or shorter full-time variants."

One-year full-time MBAs were more popular than the two-year courses offered by places like Manchester Business School and Rotterdam School of Management.

If the survey findings are correct, they may give business schools a jolt into changing one of their most cherished features, the case study. Executives say they want to learn by studying current problems facing corporations - "living case studies" - rather than the historic case studies most commonly provided by business schools.

Case studies of current corporate situations are a relatively new phenomenon in business school education, as Cox points out. "They address a company's problems as they exist at the time of the course and as they develop in the case of the MBA program. As such, they are the most realistic form of case study. Even so, only the GSBA Zurich is truly known to rely heavily on living cases.

"The most widely practised type of case study is the analysis of past corporate cases in which the case is actually a history of a company's situation. Students are given the case but normally not the solution. They are expected to develop various possible strategic options in an active class discussion. The point of all cases is to develop the skills of analysis and decision-making, not to learn a lot of cases for the sake of quoting them, as lawyers do."

Most American schools use domestic cases and most European schools rely on international cases. But the Americans produce the bulk of case studies used, so many European schools are likely to use US cases as well. Also very popular is the idea of developing and writing a business plan. Business plans require students to demonstrate what they have learned in all areas of business administration, from strategic planning to financial management to human resource management. They are thus good tests of how well an MBA candidate can apply what he or she has covered. Most management jobs require a certain amount of entrepreneurial thinking and acting.

When it came to specialising in one aspect of business for part of the course, executives thought entrepre neurship was the most popular option. There was also a strong feeling in favour of teaching MBA courses primarily or solely in English. Most said fluent English should be an admission requirement.

 Cox Communications, email: mba@mba.de
Griffith University Graduate School of Management: www.gu.edu.au/faculty/gsm/

"They address a company's problems as they exist at the time of the course and as they develop in the case of the MBA program. As such, they are the most realistic form of case study. Even so, only the GSBA Zurich is truly known to rely heavily on living cases. "The most widely practised type of case study is the analysis of past corporate cases in which the case is actually a history of a company's situation. Students are given the case but normally not the solution. They are expected to develop various possible strategic options in an active class discussion. The point of all cases is to develop the skills of analysis and decision-making, not to learn a lot of cases for the sake of quoting them, as lawyers do." Most American schools use domestic cases and most European schools rely on international cases. But the Americans produce the bulk of case studies used, so many European schools are likely to use US cases as well. Also very popular is the idea of developing and writing a business plan. Business plans require students to demonstrate what they have learned in all areas of business administration, from strategic planning to financial management to human resource management. They are thus good tests of how well an MBA candidate can apply what he or she has covered. Most management jobs require a certain amount of entrepreneurial thinking and acting. When it came to specialising in one aspect of business for part of the course, executives thought entrepre neurship was the most popular option. There was also a strong feeling in favour of teaching MBA courses primarily or solely in English. Most said fluent English should be an admission requirement.  Cox Communications, email: mba@mba.de Griffith University Graduate School of Management: www.gu.edu.au/faculty/gsm/

webTitle: All work, not much pay: Unison's new advice website for working students

fields.headline: All work, not much pay
fields.standfirst: Today Unison, the UK's biggest trade union, launches the first website for working students. Its aim, says Sally Ramsden, is to equip them against potential exploitation by employers
fields.trailText: Today Unison, the UK's biggest trade union, launches the first website for working students. Its aim, says Sally Ramsden, is to equip them against potential exploitation by employers
fields.body:
Paul Sandi puts in at least 24 hours' worth of hard work each week. The only problem is that it's not for his studies as a full-time marketing undergraduate at Middlesex University. Instead, it's for two part-time jobs which, besides taking up so much time and thereby potentially jeopardising his academic performance, are not giving him a fair deal.

As a student employed through an agency he takes home £2 an hour less than other directly employed sales assistants at his local BT shop. And he feels threatened when he has to deliver pizzas at night in an area where a co-worker was recently stabbed.

"I think I signed something with the agency but I'm not sure what or even when," says Paul, 20. "I end up trying to do assignments in the early hours and revise after night shifts. Of course working affects your studies, but everyone's doing it."

Chances are that with almost 75% of all students working, at least one has served you in a shop, poured you a drink or answered your call some time in the last week. And they're likely to be juggling an average 20 hours of employment a week with full-time studies, usually in low-paid, casual jobs in the service or care sectors with little security or protection.

Research also shows that in this era of pay-your-way degrees, just under half of all working students don't have written contracts, even though this is illegal and leaves them open to abuse. Some are forced to work extra hours without extra pay and miss out on sick and holiday pay. More than a third report health and safety problems at work - ranging from unsafe working practices to actual injury. Many feel their academic institutions don't understand the problems they face trying to balance casual work with studies.

To help pre-empt or remedy such difficulties, the largest UK trade union, Unison, is today launching a website (www.troubleatwork.org.uk) for working students. It offers information and advice on work-related problems. It covers everything from how to make sure you get paid properly and handling difficult bosses or customers to juggling work with studies and dealing with stress and money worries. Working students are encouraged to get proper advice about work problems, join the relevant union and communicate with student welfare and tutors when their studies are affected.

"It's not a substitute for joining a union, but a way of reaching young people who are busy trying to keep up with studies and make ends meet," says Unison's general secretary, Dave Prentis. "Students now make up a significant part of the labour force but know little about their rights at work, and have little job security or protection. We want them to get a decent deal at work and know where they can go to get help."

Trade unions are waking up to the fact that students are working and that they need more support at work than they're getting. Many students don't realise that they can join a trade union while still at college and that most offer special rates for young members or those in higher education. But having a bit of back-up on the job can make a real difference.

Bradford University student Labhaoise McGrane, 20, worked part-time on the till and stacking shelves for the local supermarket chain, Jackson's, for four months last year. Her first month's pay cheque was withheld while she waited for her National Insurance number to come through. It was only after she let drop that she had been in contact with the shop workers union, Usdaw, that she eventually got the back pay due.

"I found out from the union that I should have been receiving two-thirds of my wages before I got my NI number and I'm still trying to claim back emergency tax," says McGrane. "I don't think any of it was deliberate. They just didn't know how to deal with students like me."

Some work problems can be much more serious. Sussex University student Simon Jones was killed on his first day of work unloading cargo in the hold of a ship. After a vigorous campaign by Jones's family and friends, Euromin and its manager are set to go on trial charged with corporate manslaughter.

Talk to any university tutor, counsellor or welfare officer and stories of employment abuse abound. One postgraduate student from Thailand received no pay at all despite working long hours in a local restaurant over a six-month period.

"She came to student advice too late to do anything about the employer," recalls Richard Wilson, senior counsellor at the University of Bradford Counselling Service. "But we accessed hardship funds and gave her psychological support. In the end she somehow managed to get her degree."

International students may be particularly vulnerable because they are less likely to know about their employment rights in the UK and may be even more desperate for the money. The irony is that at a time when most students are working long hours, they are also under increased pressure to perform well academically. Dr Denise deCaires Narain is sub-dean of the School of African and Asian Studies at Sussex, where she lectures in Caribbean literature and oversees the welfare of more than 650 students.

"Ten years ago people came here to devote three years of their lives to study," she says. "Today's students are squeezing in academic life around paid work, yet we still expect students to do the same amount of academic work if not more. And they desperately want to do well because of the costs now involved for them and their families and they know that in a more competitive job market, employers want good degrees."

DeCaires Narain estimates that around 10 students are dropping out each year from her faculty. "They're working long hours, doing poor academic work and running up huge debt. Most intermit and come back after a year off having earned some money. But a few just leave because they can't make the academic work and employment pressures add up."

Sussex University is ensuring more students can access professional counselling and centralising services such as student loans, hardship funds and welfare advice under one roof.

One interesting phenomenon is the huge growth of job shops on campuses. There are now an estimated 80 such services across the country, operating on the principle that if students have to work, it's better to vet external employers or even employ students at the university.

University job shops usually say students should work no more than 15 hours a week on top of their studies. They hand out codes of practice to students and employers, based on guidelines drawn up by, among others, the National Association of Student Employment Services.

The Cubie Report on financing in Scottish higher education suggests that students work a maximum 10 hours a week during term-time, that universities should establish part-time employment schemes and advise on how to balance studies with earning money.

But attempts to regulate student employment seem unlikely to deter cash-strapped students or the growing demand for part-time, casual labour. The UK already has one of the highest rates of working students in Europe and the Office of National Statistics predicts that by 2006 over half of all under-20s in the labour force will be students.

There is already some evidence of a rise in suicide rates among students. Universities UK (formerly the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals) is sponsoring research into the scale of the problem and strategies to reduce it, which will be published this summer.

Recent studies reveal poorer mental and physical health among students than in the rest of the population, and link rising levels of depression to growing financial pressures, hours worked and the competing demands of university and employment.

"Students have never been under more pressure. From day one they're facing academic, social and employment pressures, stress and even danger at work," says one of the researchers, Dr Ron Roberts, now at the Institute of Psychiatry in London. "They're anxious and depressed and can't study. It's a mass, ill-thought out social experiment for which we're all going to pay in the future."

The first website offering information and advice for working students, www.troubleatwork.org.uk, is launched by Unison in conjunction with the NUS.

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: Round-up of research news and views
fields.body:
The third degree

 Are the police about to get a new high profile dog-handler? Education secretary David Blunkett's scheduled speech at Southampton University in March is already being seen as his valedictory - a year after his Greenwich announcement on the future of the higher education sector.

Academic heads are now convinced that Blunkett has his heart on Jack Straw's job at the Home Office after the general election. And what will this mean, apart from Lucy helping out with prison patrols, the biggest obstacle to top-up fees would be gone.

 Aspiring teachers seeking information on the internet are met with the disappointing message "The TTA website will return soon." The fact that the Teacher Training Agency is less well known than the Tibetan Terriers Association says a lot about the body trying to sort out the current crisis in our classrooms.

 Recent history is an appalling record of bloodshed - and that's just what the historians say about eachother. Richard Evans' new edition of In Defence of History, out next month, glances aside from his main attack on the postmodernist enemy for a sideswipe at Open University professor Arthur Marwick for his "arrogant and unreflective subjectivity" and "gems of homespun wisdom". "The main characteristic of the Marwickian metaphor seems to be its complete absence of identifiable meaning".

 Stories? Gossip? Contact us at: donald.macleod@theguardian.com
lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News Life class

The number of UK universities would need to be halved to resemble the larger academic institutions that populate other European countries, Sir David Watson, director of Brighton University, has said. The chairman of the Universities UK longer-term strategy group believes that the 100 or so universities in the UK will increasingly look to mergers to cut costs and respond to new government schemes.

Watson chairs the inaugural session in today's UUK conference on future cooperation and collaboration in the academic sector. The topic will also be discussed at next week's annual conference for the Higher Education Funding Council for England. Academic heads will be discussing research funding, business links, accountability, widening participation, and pay and equal opportunities at the conference, to be held at UMIST in Manchester. Unlike previous years, however, there will not be any guest speakers for the event.

Research news

Steal a march

Though universities in the forthcoming research assessment exercise will only know the worst when results are out in a year's time, rumours suggest all funding councils will cut funds for university departments rated 3 or below. But submit, say, your very best researchers now and who knows...

It's all around us

The secret to improving the public image of biotechnological research (alias Frankenstein foods) lies in the matrix. But no, it's not sci-fi and dark glasses. Dr Kate Millar of the School of Biosciences at Nottingham is to identify issues arising from new biotechnologies, using an analytical tool called an "ethical matrix" that will bring together researchers, regulators, industry, and the public for debate.

Universe

Imitation is the sincerest form...

A Japanese professor, intrigued by the intense silence in his lectures, switched off the lights to reveal the glow of scores of cellphone monitors. Later two thirds of students admitted receiving or sending text messages on their i-mode phones during classes and 30% were doing four per lecture on their kei-tais. Universities are now using text messages to chase students up for tuition fees.

Getting the bird

The president of Little Big Horn College, Janine Pease-Pretty on Top, has been fired from her job at a meeting of the Crow Tribal Council. She had been criticised for her running of the two-year tribal college founded in 1980 on the Crow Indian Reservation in Montana. One Henry Real Bird was named as interim president.

webTitle: University inspectors face a growing struggle to monitor academic standards

fields.headline: Masters of what?
fields.standfirst: As universities offer increasingly flexible business courses to attract students already in work, inspectors face a growing struggle to monitor academic standards, says  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: As universities offer increasingly flexible business courses to attract students already in work, inspectors face a growing struggle to monitor academic standards, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
It was a proud local MP who turned up in July 1999 to help present the the Queen's Award for Export Achievement to the Durham Associates Group. The communications and marketing company had received the ultimate business accolade for its successful overseas operations.

The company's work ranges from corporate video and network TV production, to public relations and computer aided design. But it was successful exports of a different nature which had particularly earned the award: academic degrees. Only one month before, prime minister Tony Blair, MP for Durham, had announced a new target of boasting the numbers of overseas students in UK universities by 75,000 by 2005.

But now part of Durham Associates, a subsidiary company called the Management Development Centre (MDC) faces a review of the UK-based business postgraduate degrees it runs for home and foreign students. Academic quality watchdogs are carying out an audit of the business and management school at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside.

Students on the courses are awarded "top-up" masters degrees after only two weekend seminars and a 20,000-word dissertation completed while still at work. According to MDC's marketing material, one student completed their degree in just six months.

The doctoral programme run by MDC, meanwhile, involves only 12 weekend seminars, and a 40,000 to 50,000-word dissertation, once again completed while students are still in full-time work. And according to MDC at least one student completed his doctorate after only two and a half years under the programme. This is highly unusual in the academic world: most students slave away full-time for up to four or five years to complete their PhDs.

MDC says that the programmes are of high academic standards. The masters degrees are only open to students who already have professional marketing diplomas, and the doctorates are only completed by high-flying business executives.

It is a flash point which illuminates some of the fundamental tensions surfacing in the academic world. Quality inspectors are desperately trying to keep an eye on academic standards as the higher education sector rapidly expands. And if the quality of postgraduate degrees is being questioned, it is not just the UK's academic reputation that is at stake, but the value of all the masters and doctoral degrees hard won by everyone else.

At the same time, the sector is on the cusp of a new innovative era - providing more flexible degrees, serving new types of student customers, and increasingly being located in different parts of the world. And as this week's MBA fair testifies, the entrepreneurial spirit is nowhere more vibrant than in the postgraduate professional business sector, one of the most lucrative areas of higher education.

The masters and doctoral courses run by MDC cost students £2,750 and £19,500 respectively, excluding VAT and accommodation costs.

It was MDC which first approached the quality inspectors. According to senior officials at the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education, the company apparently expressed disquiet about its plans to define masters qualifications so that programmes comprising mainly undergraduate modules would be prevented from using the masters title.

The plans are part of the agency's qualifications framework to be published later this month, which represent a major overhaul for the academic sector, with many undergraduate courses losing their status.

Adverts in educational sections of professional magazines called for enrolments to part-time MBA and DBA programmes run by MDC at the premises of the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM).

"These offered substantial accreditation of prior learning, especially for potential students working in a commercial context," says the director of programme review at the QAA, Dr Peter Milton. "Such arrangements are relatively uncommon for qualifications at this level and we therefore investigated briefly and informally the validation arrangements with the validating university, as well as discussing the programmes with representatives of the CIM."

All part-time and full-time degrees at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside will be scrutinised as part of a review of the university's business and management school due in the autumn term of 2001.

MDC's marketing material set off several alarm bells that alerted the antennae of the quality inspectors. In one press release, for example, the company boasts that one student finished his doctorate in 30 months. Another student tells how she was able to get through a masters degree in just six months.

Derek Crothall, the university's pro vice-chancellor, stresses that it is top-up masters degrees, not full-time masters, that are offered. Entry moreover depends on the student already holding a postgraduate diploma from the CIM. Only one exceptional student completed the degree in six months, but the norm is one year of study. And one outstanding student completed a doctorate in two and a half years, but the average time is four years.

"ULH is absolutely satisfied that these postgraduate degrees are of the academic standard required," says Crothall. "External examiners' reports have always been good."

Examination of the masters and doctoral dissertations is carried out by experienced academics approved by the university, he says.

David Picken, from Durham Associates, says that students are sent an extensive list of course notes, textbooks and papers which they must go through prior to the weekend seminars for both masters and doctoral programmes. Recommended reading for courses includes books, websites, trade bodies, downloadable papers, journals, marketing magazines, marketing research resources, and newspapers.

The executive DBA (doctor of business administration) is relatively new, he says, and is based on the American model, but universities operating similar programmes include Hull and Bournemouth. There are also about 20 other universities providing similar top-up masters programmes for the CIM diploma holders.

According to Picken, the two study weekends for the masters courses are conducted by two university tutors, and are extremely extensive

"There are two assignments for each weekend - one done during the weekend and handed in on Sunday, one to be handed in two weeks after each weekend," he says. "Students must pass this coursework before they are allowed to submit a research proposal, which goes to the university, and only when internal approval is obtained can work be started on the dissertation. Coursework is marked by course tutors, cross marked and then internally moderated at the university. All marks are ratified by exam board."

Whatever the outcome of the autumn inspection, though, MDC's ac tivities will not continue under the current arrangements. After a wide-ranging review of its international activities, ULH says - for reasons unconnected with quality - that it is terminating its agreement with MDC.

Picken said: "ULH is concentrating on its virtual campus and so we, like 16 or 17 other managing and promotional agents, have been told the contracts will not be renewed. That happened 18 months ago but we are both working with existing students to see them through their courses without any problem."

Milton says: "This will not occur before our review of the relevant provision later this year, however, and we expect to look closely at these programmes in the context of a normal subject review."

ULH meanwhile says it has received very positive feedback from students on the course. Some 500 have graduated or are currently studying for masters degrees and doctorates worldwide through MDC and MDC international, which runs similar courses in five other countries.

"I considered that the teaching was excellent and feedback from students supported this view," said one auditor employed by the university.

The masters and doctoral courses run by MDC cost students £2,750 and £19,500 respectively, excluding VAT and accommodation costs. It was MDC which first approached the quality inspectors. According to senior officials at the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education, the company apparently expressed disquiet about its plans to define masters qualifications so that programmes comprising mainly undergraduate modules would be prevented from using the masters title. The plans are part of the agency's qualifications framework to be published later this month, which represent a major overhaul for the academic sector, with many undergraduate courses losing their status. Adverts in educational sections of professional magazines called for enrolments to part-time MBA and DBA programmes run by MDC at the premises of the Chartered Institute of Marketing (CIM). "These offered substantial accreditation of prior learning, especially for potential students working in a commercial context," says the director of programme review at the QAA, Dr Peter Milton. "Such arrangements are relatively uncommon for qualifications at this level and we therefore investigated briefly and informally the validation arrangements with the validating university, as well as discussing the programmes with representatives of the CIM." All part-time and full-time degrees at the University of Lincolnshire and Humberside will be scrutinised as part of a review of the university's business and management school due in the autumn term of 2001. MDC's marketing material set off several alarm bells that alerted the antennae of the quality inspectors. In one press release, for example, the company boasts that one student finished his doctorate in 30 months. Another student tells how she was able to get through a masters degree in just six months. Derek Crothall, the university's pro vice-chancellor, stresses that it is top-up masters degrees, not full-time masters, that are offered. Entry moreover depends on the student already holding a postgraduate diploma from the CIM. Only one exceptional student completed the degree in six months, but the norm is one year of study. And one outstanding student completed a doctorate in two and a half years, but the average time is four years. "ULH is absolutely satisfied that these postgraduate degrees are of the academic standard required," says Crothall. "External examiners' reports have always been good." Examination of the masters and doctoral dissertations is carried out by experienced academics approved by the university, he says. David Picken, from Durham Associates, says that students are sent an extensive list of course notes, textbooks and papers which they must go through prior to the weekend seminars for both masters and doctoral programmes. Recommended reading for courses includes books, websites, trade bodies, downloadable papers, journals, marketing magazines, marketing research resources, and newspapers. The executive DBA (doctor of business administration) is relatively new, he says, and is based on the American model, but universities operating similar programmes include Hull and Bournemouth. There are also about 20 other universities providing similar top-up masters programmes for the CIM diploma holders. According to Picken, the two study weekends for the masters courses are conducted by two university tutors, and are extremely extensive "There are two assignments for each weekend - one done during the weekend and handed in on Sunday, one to be handed in two weeks after each weekend," he says. "Students must pass this coursework before they are allowed to submit a research proposal, which goes to the university, and only when internal approval is obtained can work be started on the dissertation. Coursework is marked by course tutors, cross marked and then internally moderated at the university. All marks are ratified by exam board." Whatever the outcome of the autumn inspection, though, MDC's ac tivities will not continue under the current arrangements. After a wide-ranging review of its international activities, ULH says - for reasons unconnected with quality - that it is terminating its agreement with MDC. Picken said: "ULH is concentrating on its virtual campus and so we, like 16 or 17 other managing and promotional agents, have been told the contracts will not be renewed. That happened 18 months ago but we are both working with existing students to see them through their courses without any problem." Milton says: "This will not occur before our review of the relevant provision later this year, however, and we expect to look closely at these programmes in the context of a normal subject review." ULH meanwhile says it has received very positive feedback from students on the course. Some 500 have graduated or are currently studying for masters degrees and doctorates worldwide through MDC and MDC international, which runs similar courses in five other countries. "I considered that the teaching was excellent and feedback from students supported this view," said one auditor employed by the university.

webTitle: If you ask me...about taking children out of school for holidays

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: The ideal time for my family to take our annual holiday overlaps one week with the autumn term. I'd rather not take my children out of school (they'll be going into years 3 and 5 at primary), but I don't think it will do them any harm. The headteacher takes a dim view of taking children out of school during term, but can she stop me?
fields.trailText: Should I take my children out of school for a family holiday?
fields.body:
John Coe of the National Association of Primary Education

Many parents do take their children out of school during term time for family holidays, and I don't feel it should be too frowned upon. I don't see strong reasons for giving up your time away as a family just for the first few days of term. It might be felt a child will feel a bit strange coming back late and renewing friendships and so on, but it's not as if your two are going to a new school. If that was the case, and particularly if they were making the transition from primary to secondary, I'd caution against being on holiday - that's a crucial time and your child does need to be in it along with everyone else. But in the circumstances you've outlined, I would not have those worries at all. I think you should go and have a chat with your children's headteacher, explain the circumstances of your holiday, and I'd be very surprised if she didn't agree.

Duncan Roberts Headteacher, Honeywell Junior School, London

Contrary to what some parents seem to think, extra holiday isn't a right. What the regulations say is that a school can grant up to 10 days' additional leave in any school year for family holidays, and it can grant more if the case is exceptional. In practice, I'd judge each case on its merits. I often take a generous view, but I do have concerns in this case.

I'd strongly advise you against taking your children away for that particular week, because of its importance at the start of the school year. You might think your children are just "settling in" and not doing anything very important for the first few days: in fact they're getting used to a new teacher, perhaps to new pupils, and to their new classroom.

And increasingly, due to the demands of the national curriculum, they are working hard after just a day or two of warm-up and revision. So your child could miss out both socially and academically by missing this week - not to mention the possible disruption to the class when she or he does eventually arrive.

If what you were asking for was a few extra days tacked onto half-term, I'd take a different view - this wouldn't be as crucial. I'd also look, in every case, at the actual reasons for the request for extra holiday. Personally, I don't think saving a bit of money because holidays are cheaper is a good reason - though a family wedding or a special occasion might merit the leave.

 Coming next: My daughter is dyslexic and needs to re-take her A-levels to get the grades she requires for university. Can she get any funding for this? Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we are asking leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your 'problems', marked "If you ask me", to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London, EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933, or e-mail to: education.letters@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Smoke screen
fields.standfirst: We don't really know why so many teenagers smoke, let alone how to discourage them. But a former school nurse is hoping to remedy that
fields.trailText: We don't really know why so many teenagers smoke, let alone how to discourage them. But a former school nurse is hoping to remedy that
fields.body:
It is just before morning registration. As chattering children and teenagers trudge resignedly into Bournville School, four year-nine pupils peel off into a small room to the side of the entrance hall. Their bags hit the floor leadenly, and the 13- and 14-year-olds slide warily into the seats around a table on which Emma Croghan is perched. She used to be a school nurse, but not one of those starchy and formidable matrons of an outdated stereotype. Just 28, she is warm, informal and evidently used to persuading youngsters to talk about subjects they would rather not discuss with adults. Smoking, in this case.

This quartet have already filled in one of the 14-page questionnaires devised to elicit information for Croghan's four-year investigation into the tobacco trade in schools. They have been selected at random from their contemporaries here in south Birmingham to answer further questions. Anonymity has been guaranteed. We'll call them David, Paul, Lara and Jane. All I am allowed to know is that one is a regular smoker, one smokes occasionally, one has given up smoking and the other doesn't smoke at all. It soon becomes fairly evident which is which.

"My mate buys them for me," Lara admits. "She looks 16 when she's got her make-up on."

"You can buy them from lads who hang around the bushes," David puts in. "I know because I've seen them," he adds as an afterthought.

"What do they charge?" asks Croghan.

"About 30p," says Jane.

"That's a good profit, isn't it?" the former nurse suggests, pointing out that the retail price of one cigarette is around 16p. They shrug, and she asks: "Where do people get the money from?"

"Dinner money," says Paul, who looks small for his age.

"Don't you go home starving?" Croghan persists.

Paul shrugs again. But he goes on to reveal what happens when teachers find cigarettes in your possession. "They take them off you and use them in science," he says, darkly. He goes on to explain about a machine that demonstrates the effect on a lung of the tar from one cigarette. "Did that make you think?" Croghan asks.

Paul nods.

"Enough to stop you smoking?"

He nods again. And the response is revealing because it goes against the current orthodoxy that frightening children about their long-term health doesn't work. "Some children do listen to the message," says Martin Donovan, head of Birmingham's health education unit, "and either give up or stick to the vow that they made in year seven that they're not going to do it." Nowhere near enough, though, he concedes. "Just recently, a mother told me she had found £30 on her son, and he admitted he had made it by selling cigarettes at 25p each."

Emma Croghan is well aware of the profiteering. "Some of them are charging 50p for one fag," she says. She's also well aware that smoking at school has gone on for generations. At least two things have changed in recent times. One is a general upsurge in teenage smoking, particularly among girls - an increase from one in five smokers in 1986 to one in three by 1996. The other change is that the smokers have come out from behind the bike sheds.

Croghan knows one school where the main trader walks up and down corridors, opening his blazer to reveal a display of cigarettes, like a spiv selling nylons in wartime London.

While she was still a nurse, she flew out to Colorado to look at anti-smoking initiatives in American schools. "Their technique was to get the kids angry about exploitation," she says. "They can target disaffected black youths, for instance, by telling them how tobacco companies supply their products for rap artists to promote."

Could that technique work here?

"I don't know. Nobody has done much to find out why so many schoolchildren smoke. We assume that the girls want to lose weight and the boys want to look like Puff Daddy or Eminem. There are five or six assumptions that we make as adults, but perhaps we're getting it wrong."

Croghan's chance to look at ways of getting it right came when she gave a presentation to her school governors about her trip to Colorado. Among the audience was a professor of epidemiology at Birmingham University who suggested she might like to do research closer to home. A grant of £116,000 has since been forthcoming from the National Health Service. The former school nurse is spending her first year on a masters degree looking at the supply-and-demand dynamics of tobacco in schools. Another three years will be spent on a PhD investigating ways of countering the problem. Surely, though, she can't hope to cut off the supply completely?

"No, there'll always be a hard core who will get cigarettes, come what may. But if you could lower consumption in schools by 20% that would be quite an achievement."

And long overdue, if our next port of call is anything to go by. College High School is administratively in Sutton Coldfield but, in reality, very much part of workaday north Birmingham. Croghan distributes her questionnaires in a period devoted to personal and social education.

"Please answer the questions honestly," she implores, "and try not to consult with your friends." A forlorn hope. A group of girls are soon discussing the contents amid smirks and giggles. "Royals!" snorts one. "You'd have to be crap to smoke Royals." Brands, it seems, are as important in cigarettes as in any other aspect of youth culture. Benson and Hedges or Sovereign seem to be the labels of choice for today's discerning pupils. As Croghan collects the forms, she reassures the class that no teachers will see them. "I don't care if they do," booms a large girl with reddish hair. Then she turns to her friend and says: "Come on, let's go and have a fag."
