webTitle: Location, location, location: the geographical discrepancies in school funding

fields.headline: Location, location, location
fields.standfirst: Why is Aimee's school is richer than Naomi's? Phil Revell navigates the postcode lottery
fields.trailText: How much is yours worth? Phil Revell navigates the postcode lottery
fields.body:
Name: Naomi Element

Age: 10

School: Landywood Primary School, Staffordshire

How much is she worth? Her school receives £1,640 a year to educate each individual pupil. There are a total of 500 pupils on the roll, so the school receives £820,000 from Staffordshire LEA.

With £1,640 a school could buy:

* A full-time newly qualified teacher for 5 weeks.

* A classroom assistant for 8.5 weeks.

* A complete redecoration of the school hall.

* 235 books for the library.

* A violin and weekly violin lessons for one child for an entire year.

* Enough netballs, soccer balls, rugby balls and markers for the entire school.

Naomi's headteacher says: "Once I've allocated resources to the things I have to deliver, I've nothing left for the arts, for music, for PE - all things which develop the whole child."

Name: Aimee McCartan

Age: 10

School: St Bernadette's RC Primary School in Birmingham

How much is she worth? Her school receives £1,970 a year to educate each individual pupil.

There are a total of 630 pupils on the roll, so the school receives £1.24m from Birmingham LEA.

With £1,970, a school could buy:

* A full-time newly qualified teacher for 6.5 weeks.

* A classroom assistant for just over 10 weeks.

* A complete redecoration of the school hall - and 15 chairs.

* 281 books for the library.

The system that delivers taxpayers' money to Britain's schools is about as clear as mud, and children are the direct losers, the new chief inspector of schools, Mike Tomlinson, will argue next month. In Ofsted's annual report he will criticise the current muddle of grants and allowances, bids and quotas, and underline the effect on schools of widespread budget variations.

Central government has forced schools to follow a national curriculum and local authorities are deluged with targets and directives. But government is silent about the amounts of money which should be spent in schools: there's no national entitlement, no minimum standard.

Instead there is a system where taxpayers' money is divvied up in Whitehall on the basis of a complex formula that few people pretend to understand. This Standard Spending Assessment (SSA) is supposed to take into account local needs and circumstances; in reality it's simply a reflection of what an area has received in the past.

Nearly half the money local authorities spend comes down this route, but there is no guarantee that the money Whitehall earmarks for schools will end up in the classroom. Some authorities spend more than the government recommends, many spend less and all use their own local funding formula to finally decide how much the education of an individual child is worth.

A recent Audit Commission report condemned the funding disparities and called on the government to use the extra money being pumped into education over the next three years to level the funding field. "These variations need to be challenged," said the report. "Unfortunately the lack of transparency in the system means that such a challenge isn't always possible."

The "variations" amount to a postcode lottery, where school budgets can differ for no apparent reason. For primary school children, the highest funding authority is Kensington and Chelsea in London, with a spend of £2,873 per pupil. Nottinghamshire spends just £1,582 - nearly £1,300 less, a shortfall equivalent to half a million pounds a year for an average-sized primary school.

For secondary children, Kensington and Chelsea heads the national funding figures again, with a figure per pupil of £3,626. Northumberland spends £1,862, leaving a 1,000-pupil school in that area nearly £2m out of pocket.

These are huge differences. Schools with the extra funding will be able to afford smaller classes, more special needs support, more books, more materials - more of everything.

"Very few parents are aware of these issues," says John McNally, head of St Bernadette's RC primary school, in Birmingham. "The vast majority of parents assume that the money is the same wherever you live."

Comparisons between rural and urban authorities are often branded unfair, with accusations that critics have failed to take into account the special circumstances in each local area. London local authorities are particularly resentful of contrasting figures, which ignore the considerably higher costs in the capital.

But even neighbouring schools with broadly similar circumstances can have wildly different budget allocations. Alan Stockley is head of the Landywood Primary School in Staffordshire. Landywood is an urban area just 10 miles north of Birmingham's city centre. His annual budget for 500 pupils is £820,000. "If my school was inside Birmingham I would be getting an extra £223,500 a year," he says. A few miles to the south, John McNally's school gets £1,241,532. Staffordshire gives its schools an average of £1,640 per primary pupil. In Birmingham the average figure is £2,087.

"Everything stems from these numbers," says Stockley. "If I was in Birmingham I could buy more books, spend more on the buildings. I could employ more teachers, more support staff. I'm having to do much of the administration myself and my staff get no administration time at all."

"We originally came from Birmingham," says Peter Element, whose 10-year-old daughter Naomi is in year 6 at Landywood. "It was my choice to move to Staffordshire, but I didn't realise that the funding was so low here."

Meanwhile, in Small Heath, John McNally can afford things that his Staffordshire colleagues can only dream about. "I have money for support staff for special needs and a host of other things," he says.

McNally is keen to emphasise the fact that his situation isn't perfect. His classes are too large. "I would like to see more funding here," he says. "But we all have the same curriculum to deliver. We should be aiming to level the funding upwards."

Even within authorities there can be bizarre anomalies created by the complex formulae used to distribute funding. In most areas primary schools are funded much less generously than their secondary neighbours.

John Cash is head of Westgate primary in Suffolk's Bury St Edmunds. With 289 pupils on roll he receives £504,181 to run his school, £1,744 per pupil. But a middle school in the same area, catering for 273 pupils, receives £661,256, whilst a local high school receives £1,051,419 for just 294 pupils, an individual pupil allocation of £3,576, double that received by the primary school.

"Teachers in primary schools," says Cash, "need time away from the children for meetings and preparation. How can we do that with this level of finance?" Cash accepts that the more complex curriculum in middle and high schools should be reflected with more money. "But over £150,000 more?" he asks.

Headteachers' organisations have been bending the ear of anyone who would listen on the subject for some time, but they argue that the solution has to be a levelling up. "I don't want other schools' money," says Stockley, "I want equal money."

The government points to a green paper produced by John Prescott's Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions, which suggests a reform of the system. The results of the consultation process are currently being studied by ministers.

"But why for the first two years of government did they do absolutely nothing?" asks Phil Willis, Liberal Democrat education spokesman. "Prior to '97 there were clear statements that they were going to reform this process. There was a real commitment; every school in the country expected some kind of new formulae."

The green paper says that changes could begin in the 2004/2005 budget year, but it would take a further three years for changes to work through the funding system.

"That's a timescale of 10 years, from the '97 election to the implementation of the changes they promised," says Willis. "An entire school population has been allowed to move through a system which is patently unfair."

David Kidney chairs F40, the all-party group of MPs calling for a fairer funding system for the poorest authorities. Kidney argues that, with proposals on the table, the government could move quickly to correct the situation: "It wouldn't be impossible to see a white paper before the election. If, as the green paper says, there will be no losers in any funding change, there's no reason why the government shouldn't be moving on this issue."

But heads' organisations aren't happy with the green paper. They would prefer to see direct funding of schools through the DfEE, together with a national formula which would guarantee a minimum level of funding for every child. "There's a national curriculum, national tests, a national inspection system, national pay rates," argues John Dunford from the Secondary Heads Association. "A national funding system is essential."

"Where are the equal opportunities for these children?" asks Alan Stockley. "All schools are under pressure to meet government targets on literacy and numeracy. But once I've allocated resources to the things I have to deliver, I've absolutely nothing left for the arts, for music, PE - all the things which help develop the whole child."

Parents are left scratching their heads. Under the current system it's almost impossible for a parent to get a meaningful statement about education funding in their area. If parents want to find out how much their LEA gives a school for educating their child, all they can do is ask a string of questions. How does the local funding formula work? How much is given to their child's school? How much of the education budget is held back to be spent centrally and what does the local authority spend its central funding on? Then they have to try to make some sense of the answers.

"The system needs changing," says Peter Element. There needs to be transparency and equality. "All children need the same support. They all study the same things, don't they?"

In Ofsted's annual report he will criticise the current muddle of grants and allowances, bids and quotas, and underline the effect on schools of widespread budget variations. Central government has forced schools to follow a national curriculum and local authorities are deluged with targets and directives. But government is silent about the amounts of money which should be spent in schools: there's no national entitlement, no minimum standard. Instead there is a system where taxpayers' money is divvied up in Whitehall on the basis of a complex formula that few people pretend to understand. This Standard Spending Assessment (SSA) is supposed to take into account local needs and circumstances; in reality it's simply a reflection of what an area has received in the past. Nearly half the money local authorities spend comes down this route, but there is no guarantee that the money Whitehall earmarks for schools will end up in the classroom. Some authorities spend more than the government recommends, many spend less and all use their own local funding formula to finally decide how much the education of an individual child is worth. A recent Audit Commission report condemned the funding disparities and called on the government to use the extra money being pumped into education over the next three years to level the funding field. "These variations need to be challenged," said the report. "Unfortunately the lack of transparency in the system means that such a challenge isn't always possible." The "variations" amount to a postcode lottery, where school budgets can differ for no apparent reason. For primary school children, the highest funding authority is Kensington and Chelsea in London, with a spend of £2,873 per pupil. Nottinghamshire spends just £1,582 - nearly £1,300 less, a shortfall equivalent to half a million pounds a year for an average-sized primary school. For secondary children, Kensington and Chelsea heads the national funding figures again, with a figure per pupil of £3,626. Northumberland spends £1,862, leaving a 1,000-pupil school in that area nearly £2m out of pocket. These are huge differences. Schools with the extra funding will be able to afford smaller classes, more special needs support, more books, more materials - more of everything. "Very few parents are aware of these issues," says John McNally, head of St Bernadette's RC primary school, in Birmingham. "The vast majority of parents assume that the money is the same wherever you live." Comparisons between rural and urban authorities are often branded unfair, with accusations that critics have failed to take into account the special circumstances in each local area. London local authorities are particularly resentful of contrasting figures, which ignore the considerably higher costs in the capital. But even neighbouring schools with broadly similar circumstances can have wildly different budget allocations. Alan Stockley is head of the Landywood Primary School in Staffordshire. Landywood is an urban area just 10 miles north of Birmingham's city centre. His annual budget for 500 pupils is £820,000. "If my school was inside Birmingham I would be getting an extra £223,500 a year," he says. A few miles to the south, John McNally's school gets £1,241,532. Staffordshire gives its schools an average of £1,640 per primary pupil. In Birmingham the average figure is £2,087. "Everything stems from these numbers," says Stockley. "If I was in Birmingham I could buy more books, spend more on the buildings. I could employ more teachers, more support staff. I'm having to do much of the administration myself and my staff get no administration time at all." "We originally came from Birmingham," says Peter Element, whose 10-year-old daughter Naomi is in year 6 at Landywood. "It was my choice to move to Staffordshire, but I didn't realise that the funding was so low here." Meanwhile, in Small Heath, John McNally can afford things that his Staffordshire colleagues can only dream about. "I have money for support staff for special needs and a host of other things," he says. McNally is keen to emphasise the fact that his situation isn't perfect. His classes are too large. "I would like to see more funding here," he says. "But we all have the same curriculum to deliver. We should be aiming to level the funding upwards." Even within authorities there can be bizarre anomalies created by the complex formulae used to distribute funding. In most areas primary schools are funded much less generously than their secondary neighbours. John Cash is head of Westgate primary in Suffolk's Bury St Edmunds. With 289 pupils on roll he receives £504,181 to run his school, £1,744 per pupil. But a middle school in the same area, catering for 273 pupils, receives £661,256, whilst a local high school receives £1,051,419 for just 294 pupils, an individual pupil allocation of £3,576, double that received by the primary school. "Teachers in primary schools," says Cash, "need time away from the children for meetings and preparation. How can we do that with this level of finance?" Cash accepts that the more complex curriculum in middle and high schools should be reflected with more money. "But over £150,000 more?" he asks. Headteachers' organisations have been bending the ear of anyone who would listen on the subject for some time, but they argue that the solution has to be a levelling up. "I don't want other schools' money," says Stockley, "I want equal money." The government points to a green paper produced by John Prescott's Department for Environment, Transport and the Regions, which suggests a reform of the system. The results of the consultation process are currently being studied by ministers. "But why for the first two years of government did they do absolutely nothing?" asks Phil Willis, Liberal Democrat education spokesman. "Prior to '97 there were clear statements that they were going to reform this process. There was a real commitment; every school in the country expected some kind of new formulae." The green paper says that changes could begin in the 2004/2005 budget year, but it would take a further three years for changes to work through the funding system. "That's a timescale of 10 years, from the '97 election to the implementation of the changes they promised," says Willis. "An entire school population has been allowed to move through a system which is patently unfair." David Kidney chairs F40, the all-party group of MPs calling for a fairer funding system for the poorest authorities. Kidney argues that, with proposals on the table, the government could move quickly to correct the situation: "It wouldn't be impossible to see a white paper before the election. If, as the green paper says, there will be no losers in any funding change, there's no reason why the government shouldn't be moving on this issue." But heads' organisations aren't happy with the green paper. They would prefer to see direct funding of schools through the DfEE, together with a national formula which would guarantee a minimum level of funding for every child. "There's a national curriculum, national tests, a national inspection system, national pay rates," argues John Dunford from the Secondary Heads Association. "A national funding system is essential." "Where are the equal opportunities for these children?" asks Alan Stockley. "All schools are under pressure to meet government targets on literacy and numeracy. But once I've allocated resources to the things I have to deliver, I've absolutely nothing left for the arts, for music, PE - all the things which help develop the whole child." Parents are left scratching their heads. Under the current system it's almost impossible for a parent to get a meaningful statement about education funding in their area. If parents want to find out how much their LEA gives a school for educating their child, all they can do is ask a string of questions. How does the local funding formula work? How much is given to their child's school? How much of the education budget is held back to be spent centrally and what does the local authority spend its central funding on? Then they have to try to make some sense of the answers. "The system needs changing," says Peter Element. There needs to be transparency and equality. "All children need the same support. They all study the same things, don't they?"

webTitle: 'A shambles' -  verdict on Liverpool John Moores

fields.headline: 'It's a shambles'
fields.standfirst: An external examiner gives his verdict on Liverpool John Moores
fields.trailText: An external examiner gives his verdict on Liverpool John Moores
fields.body:
The monitoring of standards at Liverpool John Moores University was in a "shambolic" state two and a half years ago, a former external examiner of the university has said.

External examiners scrutinising chemistry degrees at the university were unable to check some examination marks as they had been "locked in a safe" and the keys had been lost, says a confidential examiner's report seen by the Guardian. Other slip-ups include the setting of identical questions in successive exams - errors the examiners say were not picked up because of the lack of quality assurance procedures at the university.

The stinging criticisms come a week after the Guardian reported student complaints over an untyped and poorly presented examination paper on the BSc degree course in outdoor and science education at the university. "Over a four-year stint that ended two and a half years ago, I became increasingly concerned at the lack of effective quality assurance measures at the institution," said Professor Richard Joyner, dean of research at Nottingham Trent University. "I have visited six institutions, and it is the only case where I had serious concerns. My concerns were indicated in a highly critical external examiner's report, but I never received any official response."

He added: "The thing that really worried me about the university was the fact that quality assurance processes at the departmental level and central level were shambolic."

According to an external examiner's report for chemistry degrees compiled by Professor Joyner in July 1998, lax monitoring procedures led to a litany of problems in the chemistry degree courses. These included the need to scale up marks, after they were found to be too low for students, and the setting of identical exam questions in successive years, and for first sitting and resit exams. Assessment board meetings were not effectively conducted, according to the report, with doubts about the situation of individual students "getting worse with time".

The report says that a "shambles" was experienced at the first semester module assessment board, when it was only possible to finalise the marks on four out of seven modules. "Marks for one module were inappropriately scaled, for another were 'locked in a safe' and for the third those presented to the board bore little relationship to those indicated on the examination scripts," it says. "I have never experienced anything like this, and I hope never to again."

The university's press officer, Janet Martin, said that the university had no comment to make about the content of the report itself, and stressed that the university was under no obligation to respond to the remarks. "We would not normally respond to the external examiner personally, the report is produced as part of their contract with the university, although he was informed by a member of the programme team that his concerns had been addressed."

Martin added that other external examiners at the time and subsequently had been highly complimentary and all the issues raised by the report had been acted on.

A full investigation meanwhile is now underway at the university to find out how a handwritten exam paper with scribbled corrections came to be presented to students on the outdoor and science education course last December, as revealed by Guardian Higher last week. The students on the course are now concerned that continuing industrial action at the university could jeopardise their job prospects. As part of action against rationalisation plans at JMU, some lecturers are withholding exam marks. Students need the marks as part of initial applications for teaching positions.

In a separate development staff have called for a public inquiry into alleged mismanagement at the Liverpool Institute of Performing Arts - the "fame school" established by Sir Paul McCartney, which receives funding via the university. Concerns about financial procedures raised in a joint audit by JMU and the Higher Education Funding Council for England would be fully dealt with said the university. The academic side of the school was extremely good, added a spokesman.

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Magnetic Money Teacher
fields.trailText: Magnetic Money Teacher
fields.body:
(www.hope-education.co.uk, tel: 08702 433400, £29.95)

Age 5-8

The manufacturer says: This giant purse and the jumbo-sized coins bring a whole new meaning to the term, Big Money. The magnetic purse can be hand-held or suspended and, with over 200 magnetic coins from 1p up to £2, they offer excellent facilities to explain values, comparisons, sequencing, addition and subtraction, plus much, much more.

Key stage one coordinator, Lyndhurst Primary School, London, SE5, says: "What a groovy product! It was clear and easy to see when working with the whole class. A bright resource which stimulates children's learning and is good for practical real life situations. The maker's guidelines were clear but not really necessary as it was so simple to use. The product is very good for identifying different coins and can be used for various different lessons, eg adding and subtracting money, ordering coins by amounts, finding change in given amounts. I've never seen anything like this product before. Obviously you could do the same thing with a real purse and money, but this is much better for use with a large group. It's bright, attractive and easy for little hands to handle."

Curriculum links

Maths KS1: Using and applying number; counting; calculations; mental methods; solving numerical problems.

webTitle: Back to front: the triangular classroom

fields.headline: Back to front
fields.standfirst: As one school introduces the triangular classroom,  Joanna Moorhead asks if it matters where children sit
fields.trailText: As one school introduces the triangular classroom, Joanna Moorhead asks if it matters where children sit
fields.body:
We've had them in rows, we've had them in a horseshoe. We've had them in small groups of four or six (the preferred option in most of today's primary schools). Now, though, comes news of the triangle-shaped pupil formation: not just a formation, in fact, but a triangle-shaped classroom, no less.

The pioneering classrooms, unveiled last week, are at a special school called Cam House in Dursley, Gloucestershire. Because the school caters for boys aged 11-16 taken out of mainstream education due to behavioural and emotional difficulties, classes are no more than eight - so the triangle formation is rather different there than it would be in a conventional 30-pupil class.

"It works by putting the longest line of pupils on the front row, and then tapers towards the back with just one pupil on the back row," explains Gail Howells, who teaches at Cam House. "The big advantage is view: I can see them all better. It's a very flexible arrangement, too - it means it's easy to regroup them quickly, if we want to, during a lesson. I don't think the pupil at the back necessarily feels isolated, but if he did we could easily change the formation and bring him up to the second row.

"The children themselves say they like it - one of them told me he feels he has a better view, particularly of the board. One of the big advantages at the moment is that it's all new and a bit of a novelty, but I feel it will continue to work well. And although there are particular circumstances about our school, I think it would be worth looking at in the wider context."

The truth is that the rights and wrongs of classroom formation have been a neglected science over recent years. "Until the 60s you heard a lot about the individual learner and not a lot about anything else," explains Peter Kutnick, professor of educational research at the University of Brighton. "Since then we've had a growing awareness of learning as a social process, and we've found out there's a learner-learner structure in which pupils help one another to master a skill or task. On the back of this, we got this new classroom structure of small groups sitting around tables, but what we didn't do was back that up by training teachers properly in how to teach the skills the children need to learn effectively in their groups." In other words, we set up the structure before putting the theory in place - and we've been living with the consequences ever since.

In fact, points out Kutnick, around 60% or 70% of a pupil's work is individual. So wouldn't it be more sensible to have children grouped in something other than around small tables?

The answer, according to Nigel Hastings, professor of education at Nottingham Trent University, is that it certainly would: in fact, he says, everything points to the fact that anything but group seating is considerably better for individual work. "We know from research already done that when the task is an individual one, if you switch the arrangement to something other than group seating the effect is to increase the amount of time the average child spends actively engaged in the task. For children who are most easily distracted, you could double the work rate."

Exactly what alternative formation you use is less important than that it isn't groups, says Hastings. "The implication of this isn't a return to rows," he stresses. "You can have a horseshoe or an L-shape or another formation. The crucial thing is that for individual tasks, children aren't sitting opposite one another."

Later this year, Hastings will publish work reviewing the available evidence on classroom formation and detailing case histories in which teachers are already putting his theory into practice with positive results. It will show that where children are changed from working in small groups to working in different formations for individual work, their "on task" time increases by between 16% and 124%. Children in older primary school classes, who work alone for the larger part of the day, could gain most from teachers taking on board Hastings' findings.

The key, says Hastings, is flexibility. "In the examples we've looked at of teachers who are working flexibly, there are usually two or three basic classroom layouts. The teacher changes them depending on the task. Pupils either know themselves how to rearrange their desks, or there are seating monitors who take charge of rearranging the formation."

What Hastings has to say sounds so much like basic common sense that it's extraordinary that we've spent three decades hardly questioning why our children spend their time working around small tables, some with their backs to the teacher and unable to have eye contact with the adult in charge. The status quo has become so orthodox it's rarely questioned - and what's more there's evidence that teachers are afraid to put different ideas they may have into practice, says Hastings.

"There seem to be worries about being thought out of line for changing classroom formations - some teachers seem to think they'll come in for criticism from their heads or their colleagues or even maybe Ofsted, if they try something different," he says. "But what we found in our research is that this is rarely the case.

"Another fear teachers have is that rearranging desk formations will cause a lot of disruption and noise at the start of a class. But again, that wasn't the case in practice - we timed classes where it happened and the formation change was usually completed in around a minute."

Perhaps strangely, the education department has no policy on classroom layout. When it reads what Professor Hastings has to say, and given that the literacy and numeracy strategies put so much emphasis on whole-class teaching, perhaps that will change.

fields.standfirst: Today's rumours think putting desk chairs on polished wooden floors is a stupid idea, and not a little dangerous
fields.trailText: Celtic manager Martin O'Neill has placed a £15m price tag on Henrik Larsson, reports the Sun. But Manchester United are testing his resolve with a £10m offer for the Swedish international.
fields.body:
Celtic manager Martin O'Neill has placed a £15m price tag on Henrik Larsson, reports the Sun. But Manchester United are testing his resolve with a £10m offer for the Swedish international.

Hassan Kachloul is expected to choose between Southampton and the open road today, claims the Express. Saints are not prepared to meet the Moroccan's £20,000-a-week wage demands - Ipswich and Spurs are keeping tabs on the situation.

Leicester may make a £300,000 bid for Brentford midfielder Martin Rowlands, according to Teamtalk.

Arsenal have made a £1m bid for Crewe youngster Dean Ashton. But Dario Gradi is refusing to sell the 17-year-old striker, saying: "If we decided to sell them at a young age we might as well have told them to join a big club in the first place."

Gianluca Vialli is poised to join Nottingham Forest in order to complete his FA coaching certificate, according to the Daily Mail. The former Chelsea manager will then take over at Fiorentina with Leicester striker Roberto Mancini.

fields.headline: Leo Burnett's Fergus to depart
fields.trailText: 10am: Jeff Fergus, Leo Burnett's group president for Europe, the middle east and Africa, is to leave, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Jeff Fergus, Leo Burnett's group president for Europe, the middle east and Africa, is to leave the company following a global reorganisation.

Mr Fergus, who opted to leave rather than relocate to the US, will be replaced by Steve Gatfield, Leo Burnett's Chicago-based chief operating officer.

Regional finance director Peter Walker is being promoted to chief operating officer for Europe, the middle east and Africa.

"Under Jeff's leadership we have enjoyed substantial business success in Europe over the past three years, which is very evident in the quality of our work and new business growth," said Linda Wolf, Leo Burnett Worldwide chairman and chief executive.

"We respect his decision not to move to Chicago for family reasons."

fields.headline: Benetton cleans up ad campaign
fields.standfirst: Jan 19: Reprieve for Benetton ad star
fields.trailText:
8.30am:Benetton has abandoned shock tactics with its new ads, opting instead for the more mundane theme of clothes. By Daniel Rogers.
Jan 19: Reprieve for Benetton ad star
fields.body:
It was banned in several countries for its provocative adverts featuring images of umbilical cords, condemned prisoners and dying Aids victims.

But now, a seemingly chastened Benetton is giving itself a spanking new image, abandoning shock tactics and instead opting for the rather more mundane theme of clothes.

Benetton is to roll out a billboard and press drive in over 100 countries from mid-February, promoting its spring-summer 2001 collection.

It will be the first ad outing since the devastating "Death row" campaign last year, which caused widespread outcry and eventually led to the departure of creative director Olivieri Toscani after 18 years with the company.

"Post Toscani, the new advertising is concentrating on products rather than issues," said a Benetton spokeswoman.

It was created by 27-year-old British photographer James Mollison from the Benetton-funded Fabrica arts institute in northern Italy.

The huge media buying operation is also co-ordinated from Italy.

The company said all advertising would now come out of Fabrica, which was established in 1994 by chairman Luciano Benetton.

Benetton said the new ads set out to "convey a sense of a free, contemporary product" which is "clean, fun-loving and colourful, designed to be seen on streets all over the world.

"They are produced from colourful photographs of young people - black and white - against a white background, wearing Benetton T-shirts, jumpers or swimwear."

However, the most noticeable aspect of the campaign is its concentration on everyday people sporting its gear - not unlike rival Gap - a far cry from its tradition of hard-hitting photographs on controversial issues.

The spring-summer 2000 collection was launched with Toscani's notorious "Death row" campaign which showed US prisoners under sentence of execution.

The campaign upset relatives and ultimately US retail giant Sears Roebuck, which decided to delist Benetton's stock in 400 stores. Mr Toscani departed shortly afterwards.

Other controversial Benetton campaigns have included a photograph of a dying Aids patient and a bloody new-born child attached by its umbilical cord.

However, the company was praised for using Down Syndrome models in one of its catalogues.

fields.headline: ITV to repeat Popstars midweek
fields.standfirst: Jan 22: Popstars proves big hit
fields.trailText:
9am: ITV is planning to build on the growing success of Popstars by scheduling a late-night weekday repeat, writes Matt Wells.
Jan 22: Popstars proves big hit
fields.body:
ITV is planning to build on the growing success of its reality TV sensation Popstars by scheduling a late-night weekday repeat for viewers who miss the regular Saturday edition.

The programme is scoring well with a youthful audience at teatime on Saturday, but some observers believe the scheduling is under-ambitious and that the network should aim for a wider, peaktime viewership.

So, in an attempt to catch the adults who are just as obsessive about the antics of "nasty" Nigel Lythgoe as their children, the network plans to repeat the weekend edition at 11.30pm during the week, probably on Mondays.

Last Saturday's edition pulled in 7.5m viewers, up 800,000 on the previous week's audience, according to unofficial overnights. It peaked in the last quarter-hour at about 9m.

An ITV source confirmed that the repeat was under consideration. It is likely that an announcement on scheduling will be made on Wednesday.

A newspaper revealed the identity of the band at the weekend but ITV bosses refused to confirm whether the Sunday People's story was correct, pointing out that a clutch of different hopefuls have been "revealed" in the tabloids over the past week.

However, the story appeared authoritative: it was the first time that a newspaper named a full set of five in one story.

Nevertheless, other newspapers appeared reluctant to spoil the fun for their readers and are happy to go along with the pretence that the line-up has not yet been finalised, almost certainly helped by the promise of access to the putative stars and exclusive stories when the five are finally confirmed.

webTitle: Byers to provide £54m for areas hit by job losses

fields.headline: Byers to provide £54m for areas hit by job losses
fields.trailText: The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today defend the government against accusations that it has abandoned manufacturing when he promises £54m extra cash for regions suffering most from industrial restructuring.
fields.body:
The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today defend the government against accusations that it has abandoned manufacturing when he promises £54m extra cash for regions suffering most from industrial restructuring.

His announcement comes as he meets Tony Blair and Welsh first minister, Rhodri Morgan, to discuss the closures at the loss-making Llanwern steelworks in South Wales.

The plant is owned by Corus which was formerly partly owned by British Steel. As many as 6,000 steelworkers' jobs are under threat and ministers are pessimistic of their ability to dissuade the company from going ahead with the shutdown. An announcement is expected this week.

One ministerial source said: "We have tried to deal with the company's genuine problems, but the level of pressure from Corus shareholders is high."

Ministers fear closures at Llanwern could be accompanied by job losses at the firm's Redcar plant, and even at the highly productive Nissan car plant on Tyneside.

Any cutbacks are bound to be blamed on the strength of the pound, leading pro-Europeans to demand a clearer government commitment to join a single currency.

In a speech today Mr Byers will stress the importance of manufacturing and announce an extra £54m to a new regional innovation unit to be allocated to England's nine regional development agencies.

The cash is being allocated to the regions on the basis of their relative economic position. Previously, DTI regional money has been allocated on a flat rate basis across the nine regions according to population size. A DTI official said this represented the beginning of a new regional policy. Until now policy had been "location blind". As a result, the bulk of the money will go to the north east (£8.9m), north west (£7.4m) Yorkshire and Humberside (£10m).

Mr Byers will say: "We cannot build a strong economy if we have a trail of underperforming areas. To succeed we need all parts of all our regions firing on all cylinders.

"This government intends to help areas tackle both historical regional disparities and respond to the challenges of the modern, global economy."

He will also insist that the government is not just abandoning manufacturing, but recognises its importance to the British economy.

He will point out it accounts for about a fifth of national income with almost £150bn in output per year, and employs around 4m people directly.

The RIF cash is being distributed for the first time on the basis of a region's GDP per capita, research and development spending and unemployment rates.

The cash will promote innovation and enterprise, and to support clusters and networks of businesses in their area.

Mr Morgan said: "It is no longer a question of how many days we have got left to dissuade Corus. It is a matter of time before Corus decides to have its board meeting.

"The package of assistance seems to be less important than what we are going to do if the axe falls."

webTitle: Minister seeks to end nationalist line on foreign policy

fields.headline: Minister seeks to end nationalist line on foreign policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Britain is to bring down the curtain on centuries of diplomatic tradition by cutting back on international round table negotiations in which countries push solely for their own national interests.
fields.body:
Britain is to bring down the curtain on centuries of diplomatic tradition by cutting back on international round table negotiations in which countries push solely for their own national interests.

In a pamphlet, the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, called yesterday for countries to pool resources to confront global challenges such as Aids and BSE.

As a first step, Mr Hain called for the most radical restructuring of the Foreign Office in its history. Departments based on geographical divisions should be scrapped in favour of "issues" departments such as human rights, the en vironment and conflict prevention.

Mr Hain said that the problems which came across his desk no longer responded to traditional diplomatic solutions. In a speech last night launching his pamphlet, titled The End of Foreign Policy?, he said: "Take BSE, recent devastating floods in Europe or Mozambique, militant protests at the Seattle trade summit or a computer virus sent out by two students which disabled 10m computers worldwide. Each reflects a new kind of world shaped not by old clashes of ideology or power but by more complex forces which could blight the 21st century just as the 20th."

Mr Hain's pamphlet, which was approved by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and by Downing Street, will be seen as an attempt to redefine the government's "ethical" foreign policy.

Ministers have faced severe criticism for failing to live up to their manifesto commitment to add a humanitarian dimension to British diplomacy. There was an embarrassing reminder of the ethical foreign policy record yesterday when the author of the report on the arms to Iraq scandal criticised the government for failing to change the law on arms exports. On the Today programme, Lord Justice Scott said: "It's regrettable, because I think it's important, and it's it's long, long overdue."

webTitle: Decorous start to the battle of the bongs

fields.headline: Decorous start to the battle of the bongs
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Last night Britain's two main terrestrial channels entered the hair-pulling stage of one of broadcasting's longest-running bitch-fights. By Rupert Smith.
fields.body:
You would never have known it from the chilly professionalism of the anchormen, but last night Britain's two main terrestrial channels entered the hair-pulling stage of one of broadcasting's longest-running bitch-fights.

ITV's Trevor McDonald looked glossy in a grey suit, white shirt and red tie; we had been reminded that he was a knight in the closing moments of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, when Chris Tarrant cunningly trailed the rescheduled News at Ten.

On the other side, Peter Sissons was a little crumpled, and boasted no title, but gave a fine impression of a man completely oblivious to the opposition.

The new News at Ten is a slimmed down affair, with a less portentous remix of the old bong-heavy theme music, and without that clumsy ad break that used to separate the real news from the fillers. Now weighing in at a mere 20 minutes, the Trevor Show sacrifices depth for range, and managed to cram in an impressive eight main stories, plus an "and finally" featuring Elizabeth Taylor mumbling in a silly wig.

Nearly all of the reporters were young and very attractive, suggesting that ITN are hoping to attract a lusty pre-bedtime crowd.

It was business as usual on BBC1, where Sissons presided over a show that was weightier in every sense. His reporters weren't as easy on the eye as McDonald's babes, but BBC1 exploited its longer slot with analysis, boasted some nifty graphics and still covered 13 stories.

How they must have cheered at Television Centre when the later transmission time enabled them to bring the result of a House of Lords vote on embryo research at the very end of the bulletin - a result at which the ITN crew, already tucked up in bed, could only guess.

Nobody could accuse either rival of playing to the crowd. ITV led with an item on Railtrack. BBC1's top story was an interview with Paul Mukonyi, the man who nearly crashed the Nairobi jumbo jet. Thenceforth both did a businesslike job of covering the big stories of the day; ITV's only concession to the OK! reader was Dame Elizabeth getting flustered at the Golden Globes.

Anyone expecting a dirty tricks campaign must be sorely disappointed this morning. Neither ran disparaging stories about the other; neither stooped to nudity, violence, or even a Billie Piper story to grab that lowest common denominator. A naked man appeared briefly on the ITN screen, but he turned out to be a graphic demonstrating the art of cloning.

This may be war, but the gloves - as yet - are still firmly in place.

The new News at Ten is a slimmed down affair, with a less portentous remix of the old bong-heavy theme music, and without that clumsy ad break that used to separate the real news from the fillers. Now weighing in at a mere 20 minutes, the Trevor Show sacrifices depth for range, and managed to cram in an impressive eight main stories, plus an "and finally" featuring Elizabeth Taylor mumbling in a silly wig. Nearly all of the reporters were young and very attractive, suggesting that ITN are hoping to attract a lusty pre-bedtime crowd. It was business as usual on BBC1, where Sissons presided over a show that was weightier in every sense. His reporters weren't as easy on the eye as McDonald's babes, but BBC1 exploited its longer slot with analysis, boasted some nifty graphics and still covered 13 stories. How they must have cheered at Television Centre when the later transmission time enabled them to bring the result of a House of Lords vote on embryo research at the very end of the bulletin - a result at which the ITN crew, already tucked up in bed, could only guess. Nobody could accuse either rival of playing to the crowd. ITV led with an item on Railtrack. BBC1's top story was an interview with Paul Mukonyi, the man who nearly crashed the Nairobi jumbo jet. Thenceforth both did a businesslike job of covering the big stories of the day; ITV's only concession to the OK! reader was Dame Elizabeth getting flustered at the Golden Globes. Anyone expecting a dirty tricks campaign must be sorely disappointed this morning. Neither ran disparaging stories about the other; neither stooped to nudity, violence, or even a Billie Piper story to grab that lowest common denominator. A naked man appeared briefly on the ITN screen, but he turned out to be a graphic demonstrating the art of cloning. This may be war, but the gloves - as yet - are still firmly in place.

fields.headline: Alarmist reports on refugees 'must stop'
fields.trailText: Police across Britain are to challenge the "ill-informed, adverse media coverage" of asylum seekers, which they say has contributed to a rise in racial tension and increased risk of public disorder. Alan Travis reports
fields.body:
Police across Britain are to challenge the "ill-informed, adverse media coverage" of asylum seekers, which they say has contributed to a rise in racial tension and increased risk of public disorder.

"Racist expressions towards asylum seekers appear to have become common currency and acceptable in a way which would never be tolerated towards any other minority," says a report by the Association of Chief Police Officers, which was leaked to BBC Radio 5 Live ahead of its publication next month.

The report says that the arrival of asylum groups across the UK, which has aroused racist tendencies within local populations, has led to expressions of racism (not to be confused with legitimate political debate on immigration policy) that should be challenged by the police.

"Where adequate evidence exists of criminal offences, consideration should be given to prosecute," the guide adds.

The report was leaked as the Home Office published research showing that economic migration helps to fill labour market shortages, improve public finances, and contribute to the development of industries and jobs.

The Acpo guide, drawn up with the help of Dutch police but in the main by the Kent force after their experience of clashes at Dover, says that with no action plan to manage tensions between the indigenous population and asylum seekers, significant racial tensions and public disorder may arise.

Experience over the past four years showed that where asylum communities were established there was ill-informed adverse media coverage, which contributed to heightened tension and resentment.

The guide says failure to achieve instead a "positive media message may undermine much of the police service's efforts to maintain community harmony". But it also warns that within refugee communities animosity is an "ever present danger" because of the mix of ethnic groups.

It adds: "Language and cultural barriers, along with a common misunderstanding of the role of the police, mean that asylum seekers are unlikely to report racist crimes and incidents.

"While the majority of asylum seekers have no criminal motives and wish to peacefully co-exist, some will use violence beyond our normal experience in retaliating to racist attacks, responding to criminal exploitation or resolving inter-ethnic disputes.

"Such violence will be best prevented by accurate intelligence profiles of criminals in asylum communities and racist offenders of all nationalities; and positive efforts to resolve crimes and tensions between asylum seekers."

The chief constables say that all police forces should counter alarmist views that might fuel racism. It suggests getting "key messages" across to the local media, stressing that the area welcomes thousands of visitors a year; that asylum seekers are real people who need our urgent support and could make a valuable contribution to life; that Britain has a history of absorbing cultures; and that being an asylum seeker is no fun partly because of the new, restrictive asylum rules.

With regard to the experiences of police in challenging unfounded media fears about an asylum crimewave, the report noted a case where a vicar, in a town with a large number of asylum seekers, made a public statement [saying] asylum seekers were taking housing and school places from locals. "This was not the case," says the report. "But because of his position in the community, the story made front page news. The story was highlighted by an extremist political party justifying and legitimising its position."

webTitle: Hull tested as culture clashes rumble on

fields.headline: Hull tested as culture clashes rumble on
fields.trailText: The young Kurds were scared when the doctor got to them at the police station and asked why on earth they had gone out for a night at a Hull fairground with bicycle chains in their pockets.
fields.body:
The young Kurds were scared when the doctor got to them at the police station and asked why on earth they had gone out for a night at a Hull fairground with bicycle chains in their pockets.

"We have to protect ourselves," the oldest told Hamed Bajilan, who besides being a consultant at Hull royal infirmary was acting as their translator. The doctor sighed, replying: "You don't do that here."

It was another example of the culture clash which has unsettled Hull's generally successful record at coping with more than 1,000 asylum seekers. "The police aren't the same as in Iraq," he went on. "They'll help if you get trouble from hooligans. But they won't stand for arming yourselves with bicycle chains."

Fuelling the youths' fears were the experiences of friends such as Fardin Farqu, an Afghan stabbed in the city, and Mohammed Ali, a 26-year-old Kosovan, blinded in one eye by a stone.

But since July - the end of a four-month stretch which saw 35 suspected racial attacks - Humberside police have moved into the Avenues area of the city. Partly they are on patrol; partly they are doing basic liaison work such as explaining how to change a lightbulb (it is different in Kurdish Iraq).

The refugees are concentrated near the suburban Avenues area. And the local Kwik-Save and the Indian and continental stores are where many of the Home Office's refugee vouchers end up - the glaring signal that a shopper is a refugee.

"It's a world of dark looks in queues," says Dr Bajilan, "I think specially because the asylum seekers shop where the poorest local people shop, and it's the poorest people who feel they're a threat, buying things they want or somehow threatening jobs."

In fact, no asylum seeker is legally allowed to work, but rumours spread and unemployment in Hull is still a noticeable 7.4%.

In the city centre post office the queues are more than a trivial problem too - up to now this post office has been the only one allowed to take vouchers.

But that seems likely to change, and still more pressure on the Home Office has led to the council and social services getting extra information on asylum seekers in Hull via private landlords. It means that instead of greeting refugees off the coach with "Hello number 53", officials will have names to hand.

webTitle: BA told to give 'rude' pilot his job back

fields.headline: BA told to give 'rude' pilot his job back
fields.trailText: British Airways was yesterday ordered to reinstate a pilot who was sacked after he verbally abused a woman passenger who caused a bomb alert on his plane.
fields.body:
British Airways was yesterday ordered to reinstate a pilot who was sacked after he verbally abused a woman passenger who caused a bomb alert on his plane.

An employment tribunal in Croydon, south London, criticised BA's decision to dismiss Stewart Clapson, 54, for being "rude and abusive" to the woman, who falsely claimed that another passenger had a bomb on a jumbo jet about to take off from Gatwick for the island of Barbados on October 26 1999.

Captain Clapson, a BA captain for 17 years and a pilot with the airline for 30 years, was sacked after he allegedly made a speaker announcement on the plane saying that the person responsible for the bomb alert was a "stupid woman" who had ruined everybody's holiday by delaying the plane.

After taxiing off the runway he allegedly emerged from his cockpit shouting: "Where is she? Where is she?" before confronting the woman, pointing his finger in her face and reducing her to tears.

He admitted during the hearing that afterwards he had a cigarette on the flight deck, in contravention of BA rules. "It was an extraordinary happening. I'm a smoker and in the lull I saw the possibility of having a cigarette," he said.

After being demoted to co-pilot with a salary reduction from £120,000 to £70,000, Capt Clapson, from East Molesey, Surrey, was dismissed after appealing.

The tribunal ruled that Capt Clapson should be reinstated had to the position he held immediately before he was sacked, which was co-pilot, and gave British Airways until May 1 to reinstate him.

Captain Clapson expressed relief after the hearing and hailed the decision as "an important victory for all airline captains who should not now have to worry about being second-guessed by executives on the ground in their handling of disruptive passengers".

"British Airways managers acted in a very bullyish manner and I have had little sympathy for my explanation of what happened from the start. I've had no support whatsoever from the management in the company. I want to get back to flying aircraft which is my job," he added.

A BA spokesman said after the hearing: "We are disappointed but at the same time we respect the decision of the tribunal."

fields.headline: Breast cancer surgeon's battle
fields.trailText: A pioneering breast cancer surgeon has won the support of GPs, former patients and over 4,000 signatories to a petition in the battle to clear her name after she was suspended amid allegations of clinical incompetence.
fields.body:
A pioneering breast cancer surgeon has won the support of GPs, former patients and over 4,000 signatories to a petition in the battle to clear her name after she was suspended amid allegations of clinical incompetence.

Briony Ackroyd, one of the first surgeons to perform a mastectomy and reconstructive surgery in the same operation, was suspended from work at Walsgrove hospital in Coventry last February.

Her critics allege her complication rate was too high and her patients were not fully informed of the risks.

But her supporters, including former patients, claim she has been subjected to a "witch-hunt" by a male-dominated field in which her woman's touch, such as visiting patients at home, is not appreciated.

They believe Dr Ackroyd, 52, offers women hope after they have suffered the trauma of breast removal. A spokesman for her supporters said: "She seemed to have a very special relationship with all of her patients and she provided a very special and unique service."

A spokesman for the General Medical Council confirmed last night there had been "discussions with the hospital about this doctor" after the hospital contacted them.

An investigation into the surgeon's clinical practice was launched after a family sued the hospital for negligence over an operation that went wrong, according to the Times.

The paper claims Dr Ackroyd would face being struck off the medical register when her case is heard by the GMC, probably later this year.

webTitle: Councils neglect to check air quality checks

fields.headline: Councils neglect to check air quality checks
fields.trailText: Councils in 33 towns and cities, including Liverpool and Luton, have failed to protect the public from polluting factories by not doing regular tests on air quality, the Department of Environment has revealed. David Hencke reports
fields.body:
Councils in 33 towns and cities, including Liverpool and Luton, have failed to protect the public from polluting factories by not doing regular tests on air quality, the Department of Environment has revealed.

The councils are "named and shamed" by the ministry for only checking air quality once every two years instead of every six months. The authorities, however, are paid by firms to monitor air quality outside premises.

Checks in England and Wales cover 18,200 premises including chemical, asbestos, glass and rubber factories, iron and steel foundries, incineration plants, waste oil burners and petrol stations.

From 2004, a European directive will oblige councils to give up-to-date air pollution figures. Michael Meacher, the Environment minister, has already been insisting that two checks each year on factories.

The councils and port authorities with the lowest number of checks include Gosport, Manchester port harbour authority, Rutland, Barnet, East Devon, Guildford, Southend-on-Sea, Wokingham, Thanet and Tunbridge Wells. All had under 20 inspections last year.

Merlin Hyman, director of the environmental industries' commission, said: "These problems are undermining well run companies who want a level playing field."

fields.headline: Doctor backs mother-to-be, 56
fields.trailText: The director of a Harley Street clinic which helped a 56-year-old conceive twins accused critics yesterday of wanting a "police state" where people could not plan their own families.
fields.body:
The director of a Harley Street clinic which helped a 56-year-old conceive twins accused critics yesterday of wanting a "police state" where people could not plan their own families.

Ian Craft, of the London Gynaecology and Fertility Centre, strongly defended its decision to treat Lynne Bezant, who will become the oldest mother of twins recorded in Britain.

Mrs Bezant and her husband Derek, 55, from Oxfordshire, are expecting in June. They have three grown-up children.

Their story is likely to fuel the debate over whether people have a right to children, which gathered pace with last week's internet adoption scandal. But Professor Craft, a pioneer of IVF, insisted: "It's not the least bit sensational. It's just rather lovely, I think.

"There are those people who try to be helpful in life, and those that put hurdles up. We try to be helpful."

Mr Bezant underwent a vasectomy to prevent his wife suffering further trauma having given birth to stillborn twins and suffering two miscarriages 20 years ago, but the couple regretted the decision. They turned to the clinic because it is thought to be the only one in Britain that treats women over 51. But the Bezants had to wait more than two years because egg donors preferred to help younger couples.

The couple's three children - Jenny, 32, Andrew, 30, and Chris, 26 - were said to be delighted about the pregnancy.

There is no official upper age limit for assisted conception, but a spokesman for the Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians yesterday expressed concern about the decision to treat Mrs Bezant.

Peter Bowen-Simpkins said: "The welfare of the child is paramount, and elderly parents are not considered to be in the best interest of the child."

webTitle: £3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs

fields.headline: £3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs
fields.trailText: A £3m advertising campaign to convince an alarmed public that the measles, mumps and rubella vaccination (MMR) is safe and necessary for children was announced by the government yesterday. Sarah Boseley reports
fields.body:
A £3m advertising campaign to convince an alarmed public that the measles, mumps and rubella vaccination (MMR) is safe and necessary for children was announced by the government yesterday.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, called together medical organisations, including the Royal College of Nursing and the British Medical Association, to express their confidence in the vaccination in the face of claims that it could be linked to bowel disease and autism in certain susceptible children.

The three-year controversy over the MMR jab, given to babies at 18 months and followed by a pre-school booster, has surfaced again with a paper written by Andrew Wakefield from the inflammatory bowel disease study group at the Royal Free Hospital in London and a colleague.

In February 1998 Dr Wakefield and colleagues published papers in the Lancet describ ing a link between the live measles virus used in the vaccine, damage to the gut and autism. In the latest paper, to be published in the journal Adverse Drug Reactions, Dr Wakefield questions the clinical trials assessing the safety of the combined MMR vaccine before it was introduced in Britain in 1988.

He argues that the trials were not adequate and that evidence has been ignored that shows an interaction between the live viruses that go to make up the combined MMR. Children should be vaccinated against measles, but the government should make separate vaccines available.

Public health officials fear loss of confidence in the vaccination could lead to a fatal measles outbreak, as happened last year in Ireland and the Netherlands. Vaccination rates have dropped to 75% in some places - notably parts of London. The World Health Organisation says a 95% rate is desirable to prevent outbreaks.

The Department of Health stepped up the offensive against Dr Wakefield's theories yesterday with details of a four-week national advertising campaign, due to start in February and aimed at mothers of young children. A 20-minute information video will be made available in GP surgeries and libraries.

GPs, practice nurses and health visitors, some of whom have shown doubts about MMR, will also be targeted -30,000 information packs will be sent out, there will be "advertorials" in the medical press and seminars held around the country.

"We have had discussions today with all of the major health organisations in this country about the MMR vaccination programme," said Professor Donaldson. "Every single one of them agrees that the MMR vaccine is the safest and best way to protect children against measles, mumps and rubella.

"MMR is used successfully in over 30 countries and is the vaccine recommended by the World Health Organisation. On each occasion that these health scares are raised they have been thoroughly examined and on each occasion MMR has been given a clean bill of health."

He said the publicity campaign was intended to ensure people were given factual information about the vaccine. "Britain's record on childhood immunisation is envied around the world - we should not allow it to be undermined by bad science.

"Whenever there is a health scare, parents are left confused. They should be left in no doubt after today's summit that the advice from doctors, nurses and every major health organisation is that they should have their child vaccinated with MMR."

The professional institutions issued a statement confirming this was their view. "The paper adds little to current knowledge. Our professional confidence in the MMR vaccine, its safety and effectiveness remains fully justified - there is a large body of evidence showing that the combined vaccine is highly effective and serious side effects are uncommon."

webTitle: Peers vote to permit new research on embryos

fields.headline: Peers vote to permit new research on embryos
fields.standfirst: Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government won a controversial House of Lords vote allowing new research on human embryos last night. Peers backed the government-backed motion by 212 to 92 in a free vote.
fields.body:
The government won a controversial House of Lords vote allowing new research on human embryos last night. Peers backed the government-backed motion by 212 to 92 in a free vote.

Ministers had launched a last-minute attempt to ward off a cross-party defeat in the Lords that would have scuppered its plans to extend the law to allow the research.

Earlier, as 40 peers lined up to debate whether to approve a change they claimed they had been bullied into, the government tried to placate them by promising to back an amendment accepting the move but allowing it to be scrutinised in a select committee.

The concession means that, although licences for the new research could be applied for from as soon as January 31, when the regulations come into force, they would not be not be issued until the select committee reports back.

The government would also be likely to backtrack if the committee ruled against it. "It would be very embarrassing for them, if they gave the committee their approval and then went against it," a government source said.

The 11th-hour move by the junior health minister, Lord Hunt of King's Heath, came in the face of extensive opposition by a cross-party coalition of peers - and pressure from church leaders - who claimed that the government's attempts to force through an unamendable legal order on the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act was "undemocratic" on such an important moral issue.

The free vote followed a decision in the Commons last month to back an extension of the act, which currently allows research on human embryos up to two weeks old, known as stem cells, if it concerns research into fertility, contraception or congenital diseases. The change to the act would permit unused embryos to be used for research on other diseases. In theory, stem cells derived from embryos could be used to help in Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis or other neurodegenerative illnesses.

Many research groups and biotech companies see stem cells as possible treatments for diseases that are now incurable, and charities supported by people with muscular dystrophy, diabetes, and Parkinson's, among many other diseases, have backed a series of government-appointed groups endorsing the use of embryonic stem cells in this way.

But the issue has also proved controversial, prompting accusations of eugenics and fears that this could prove the start of a slippery slope towards human cloning.

Last night Lady Warnock, who chaired the original inquiry into human fertilisation in the 1980s, said: "The word cloning sends shivers of horror down the spines of the British public."

Lord Alton, who brought yesterday's amendment calling for no order to be passed until a select committee had a chance to report back, said: "When the minister told the House of Commons a pre-14-day-old embryo had the power to facilitate cures to mankind's human misery, it simply underlined to me that, even at this early stage of development, we are not dealing with something inconsequential," he said.

fields.headline: PA hires US correspondent
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Press Association is expanding its overseas coverage, appointing its first ever American correspondent, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Press Association is expanding its overseas coverage, appointing its first ever American correspondent.

Hugh Dougherty, who currently works at the Press Association's Glasgow office, will move to New York in February, where he will cover a "showbiz, Brits and human interest beat", according to PA editor-in-chief Paul Potts.

Mr Dougherty, who is 24, joined PA three years ago from Strathclyde University's training scheme.

Mr Potts added that PA was considering sending a second reporter to Paris, to beef up PA's European coverage, but details had not been finalised.

He denied claims that the creation of the post was only made possible because of the sale of PA's successful virtual newsreader, Ananova, which was bought by Orange last year for £95m.

He said PA was treating the appointment as an "experiment", which would be assessed over the next six months.

fields.headline: No 10 took Clinton guru's advice
fields.standfirst:
Leak reveals why Blair took on tabloids over EU

Special report: New Labour in power
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Tony Blair rounded on the Eurosceptic press last year on the advice of a Clinton campaign guru, write Sarah Hall and Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Tony Blair rounded on the Eurosceptic press for the first time last year on the advice of a Clinton campaign guru who told Downing Street that it should "outwit" the hostile media, a leaked memo revealed last night.

In the run-up to Christmas, the prime minister abandoned his "softly softly" approach with the tabloids on Europe after advice from President Clinton's former political director Doug Sosnik to "grab back control of the agenda".

Mr Sosnik told Philip Gould, the prime minister's polling chief: "It's neither about simply fighting the media nor feeding the media - it is about outwitting them and setting our stall on our terms."

In a lengthy conversation last year, Mr Sosnik told the pollster that the Clinton White House had overcome its initial problems with the press with a six-point plan. In a letter to Mr Blair last spring, Mr Gould said that he had been told that Labour should follow voters rather than the media, stop moving at breakneck pace, draw up a one-year election plan and concentrate on governing rather than politicking.

Mr Sosnik's advice to take on the hostile press was taken to heart by Mr Blair last November when he lambasted the Daily Mail for its "anti-European nonsense". Speaking in Moscow, he said that papers such as the Mail were "fundamentally dishonest" about Britain's commitment to the EU's new rapid reaction force. "I'm used to the British media being impossible on the topic of Europe, but I hope the public will be given the facts," Mr Blair declared. "There is no concept of a European army."

Two days later the prime minister denounced an attack by the same paper on General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, as a disgraceful act of "utter desperation".

Mr Blair's strong words were welcomed by pro-Europeans who believed that his fear of alienating the rightwing tabloid press had allowed them to dominate the agenda.

The memo leaked last night gives a telling insight into the Blair election campaign. Downing Street appears to have accepted that the government should be careful about blinding voters with a glut of daily initiatives and activities. These result in the press being "bloated" with announcements and in the end discounting them.

In his memo, Mr Gould tells Mr Blair that President Clinton solved his communication problems by "governing rather than campaigning".

"Sosnik says the essential requirement of incumbency is to be seen to be acting governmentally rather than politically," he wrote. "Even as the election approaches we should keep a sense of governing for as long as possible."

He proposed cutting the number of announcements, altering the pace and rhythm of government, "accepting that you cannot win every day", using that as proof of resolve, and developing themes and values with policy announcements fitted around them.

The pollster also wrote that the Democrats used opportunity, community and responsibility as themes and that their entire campaign "grid" flowed from this. Referring to one of the problems that has dogged the Blair administration since it came to power, he added: "If we had a similar message we would not be in our current mess on crime."

Last night, Mr Blair's spokesman admitted that Downing Street had taken note of the memo - leaked to the Times and the Sun. "We have obviously studied the different communications needs of government and drawn on lessons from America and elsewhere," he said. But he added that many of the ideas in the leaked document were already being worked on before it was received last spring.

The memo is the latest in a series to have been leaked to the Murdoch press. Mr Blair faced severe embarrassment last July when Mr Gould's private thoughts on Labour's performance were aired in public. Last night's memo will not prove embarrassing to the government, but it will be seized on by the Tories who will mock Downing Street for copying President Clinton.

Tips from the memo

 Govern rather than campaign. Be seen to be acting governmentally rather than politically

 Less is more. Make a number of substantial weekly announcements rather than several daily ones

 Turn down the volume. Cool the temperature of debate

 Vary the pace. Mix confrontation and consensus to control the agenda

 Put values and messages at the heart of the grid. Build policy on themes and values

 Have a one-year plan before an election

 Accept you cannot win every day, that there will be bad days, bad weeks. Use this as evidence of resolve

 Discipline and focus. Set three-month targets and stick to them

fields.headline: Two more dot.coms die
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Two more dot.coms, electrical retailer Intersaver and gaming site Barrysworld.com, have closed, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two more dot.coms bit the dust yesterday after failing to find rescue packages.

Online electrical retailer Intersaver, once tipped to compete head-to-head with Dixons and Comet's online stores, has cut off its power, and gaming site Barrysworld.com has admitted that it has run out of money.

BarrysWorld has already gone into voluntary liquidation and will cease all operations on February 5.

A message on BarrysWorld.com said: "We have run out of money. We are all devastated by this situation and despite our best efforts to secure some sort of deal to keep the business alive, we have been forced to pull the plug before someone pulls it for us. It's been a fun four years."

The story is not that dissimilar at Intersaver, which has gone under leaving hundreds of customers out of pocket.

Intersaver.co.uk stopped taking orders at the end of the year after it was forced to admit to customers that it wouldn't be able to deliver their presents in time for Christmas.

Since Christmas the front page of the website has carried the simple sentence, "The store is not available".

The website also cut its phone lines, including the customer helpline and its chief executive, John Thornhill, has not been contactable for weeks.

Sources close to the company have said that it's just a matter of days until receivers are appointed.

fields.headline: Legal action threatened over travel ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: An ad campaign depicting travel agents as overpaid rip-off merchants has sparked a storm of protest, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An advertising campaign that depicts travel agents as a bunch of overpaid rip-off merchants has sparked a storm of protest that may lead to legal action against the advertiser, Direct Holidays.

The Association of British Travel Agents is considering legal action against Airtours-owned Direct Holidays after it received a flood of complaints from its members about the campaign.

Rival travel agents claim the ads are misleading because they imply it is cheaper to buy your holiday direct than through a travel agent.

"The campaign portrays travel agents in a very negative way and we have received a lot of complaints about one ad in particular," said an ABTA spokeswoman.

"If Direct Holidays is found to have breached our codes of conduct they could be subject to a fine or they could even have their membership withdrawn."

But Direct Holidays was today standing by the campaign.

"We were surprised by the extent of the reaction," said marketing director Robin Parry.

"Direct Holidays is not anti-travel agent, it is pro-consumer. The adverts demonstrate the advantage to the consumer of booking their holiday direct: if you book with us, you cut out the travel agent and his commission."

The commercials, produced by the Edinburgh agency 1576, are part of a £5m marketing campaign by Direct Holidays and are running on TV until the end of January

ABTA says it will decide in the next few weeks whether to take action against the company.

fields.headline: Duberley makes TV comeback
fields.trailText: 8.30am: One of the original faces of Sky News, Linda Duberley, is returning to TV after 10 years, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
One of the original faces of Sky News, Linda Duberley, is returning to British screens after a 10-year absence.

The former satellite TV news anchor started this week as one of the leading team of correspondents on ITV's Tonight programme alongside Jonathan Maitland and Fiona Foster.

She replaces Vanessa Collingridge, who has taken a sabbatical from the show to write a book about Captain Cook, a distant relative.

Ms Duberley, 40, quit Sky in 1991 and, after a brief spell in corporate affairs, went to Hong Kong where she set up Fox TV's Asia bureau.

She has three children and four step-children and says her "rounded experience of life" will be an asset in her job.

"I am a populist and I have always wanted to work on a show like ABC's 60 minutes. I like making news accessible," she said.
