fields.body:
ITV head of news Steve Anderson is furious with BBC suggestions that ITV offered a second rate news service.

"They threw the kitchen sink at us last night, but the figures speak for themselves. It was a clear victory for ITV," he said.

"The BBC's argument that they are offering a higher quality news services implies that we are not about quality.

"But I like to think they are the super-tanker and we are the assault ship. They will offer context, while we we are sharper and get in amongst the action.

"It is just two different approaches. We will both do El Salvador and the Galapagos but we will just do them differently," he said.

"I was glad with our own range - we covered the news with distinction," he added.

Mr Anderson said it was perfectly legitimate for ITV to plug News at Ten during Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and to run directly into the bulletin without an advertising break.

fields.headline: Politicians condemn BBC news bulletin
fields.standfirst: Jan 23: News veterans square up over ratings
fields.trailText:
2.45pm update: Opposition parties have rounded on the BBC for going head to head with ITV with its news bulletin, reports Jessica Hodgson.
1pm: News veterans square up over ratings
fields.body:
Opposition parties rounded on the BBC today for narrowing viewers' choice with the head-to-head battle of the TV news bulletins.

"It's not in the interests of the viewers for the two main channels to have their news bulletins going head to head.

Greg Dyke is trying to be too clever by half by moving the news. In the public interest, he should move the news back to 9 o'clock," said the Liberal Democrat spokesman for broadcasting.

And shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said the BBC had scored an own goal.

"The BBC's decision to move the news was a commercial one and it ill behoves them to complain when they are treated to a bit of competition in return.

"It cannot be in the viewers' interests.

"The BBC chose to move the news opportunistically to give them greater freedom, and the impetus is on them to move it back.

"This raises important issues about the BBC's ability to regulate itself, and strengthens the argument that the BBC should be brought under independent scrutiny," he said.

webTitle: Leader: C4 privatisation will diminish diversity

fields.headline: Channelling choice
fields.standfirst:
Privatisation will diminish diversity

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Should Channel 4 be privatised? At a time when a Labour government is contemplating privatisation of hitherto unthinkable assets like air traffic control, nothing can be ruled off the political agenda.
fields.body:
Should Channel 4 be privatised? At a time when a Labour government is contemplating privatisation of hitherto unthinkable assets like air traffic control, nothing can be ruled off the political agenda.

The possible sale of Channel 4 has come into play because the Conservatives - who first set it up in 1981 - have suddenly seen it not only as a source of money (£2bn to boot) but as something that will set them apart from Labour, which is committed to keeping C4 in its present form. The Conservatives' policy has seductive popular appeal. It promises that the money raised from a C4 sale would be channelled into museums and galleries. It remains to be seen whether the extra funds would be offset by cuts in the existing arts budget.

The case for retaining C4 as a non-profit-making publicly-owned broadcaster depends on two things. First, the general case for maintaining diversity in a mixed economy. Joint stock companies are fine, they are and always will be the backbone of the economy: but that doesn't mean that everything that moves has to be a joint stock company. Let a thousand flowers bloom. The existence of successful public enterprises like the Post Office, employee-owned companies like John Lewis and mutual building societies like Nationwide provide competition between different ways of doing things as well as between companies.

The second case for C4 is to maintain diversity within broadcasting. A C4 which ploughs all of its profits back into programme-making will be a different kind of broadcaster to the Skys and ITVs of this world under constant pressure to reward shareholders. This has resulted in much less imaginative and diverse programming. There is no obvious need to privatise Channel 4 to bring it up to the standards of Channel 5.

Channel 4 has been a very successful venture, increasing its market share from 2% in 1982 to 10% today. Why should success be rewarded by selling the organisation against its will? If anything, C4 has been too successful. It has boosted its ratings by buying popular programmes - many of them American imports like Friends - at the expense of its founding commitment to innovation, experiment and minority interests. The revival of debate in C4 is a timely reminder that having a public remit opens it to the sort of monitoring that doesn't happen at Sky. It is good for C4 to be goaded regularly and publicly about why it exists.

We must evolve, says 10pm bulletin's editor

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The new editor of the BBC's Ten O'Clock News has said the corporation must no longer broadcast to a 'metropolitan elite', writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The newly appointed editor of the BBC's Ten O'Clock News has said the corporation must no longer broadcast to a "metropolitan elite", as the bulletin went head to head for the first time with ITV's revived News at Ten last night.

Mark Popescu, who takes over at the BBC 10pm news after the election, indicated that the bulletin would evolve. There have been fears that his populist tradition - he is a former ITN editor and oversaw the relaunch of the BBC's Six O'Clock News - would lead to a trivialisation of the programme's agenda as the competition with ITV intensified.

But he stressed that there would be no "revolution" at the Ten O'Clock News, which has already embraced a broader agenda since being moved from 9pm last year. "You have to keep faith with the viewers. News bulletins are organic, growing things." In a memo seen by the Guardian, news chiefs acknowledge that one of the reasons for moving the bulletin was to shore up BBC1's peak-time audience share for drama and entertainment.

In public, the BBC has always maintained that the principal motivation was that 10pm was a "better time" for news and that the ratings decline of the 9pm bulletin would be stemmed.

But the agreement between ITV and the independent television commission to restore a 10pm bulletin - 20 minutes long and only on three days a week - means BBC news faces a heavy ratings defeat.

Privately, executives concede ITV is likely to win the ratings battle. In public, the BBC insists ITV's decision to run a 20 minute bulletin means it will be less comprehensive than the corporation's half-hour version. A spokesman said it would fight on quality, not short-term ratings figures. ITN's Sir Trevor McDonald said he was looking forward to returning to his traditional role as anchor of News at Ten, which was axed two years ago. "Ten o'clock is very much our time. We look forward to reclaiming it and doing well."

Mr Popescu said the BBC's Ten O'Clock News, which has traditionally been dominated by foreign and political news, was "very different" from the 6pm bulletin he currently edits.

But he indicated that the BBC had to look beyond a London-centred audience. "I think it's very important that we don't just broadcast to a metropolitan elite," he said.

It is thought that Mr Popescu will not dilute political and foreign coverage, but will seek to invest it with more impact. "First-hand reporting of international news events is what we should be doing," he said.

"ITV would find it hard to compete with the sort of resources we have around the world," he added.

webTitle: Unwed mother given 100 lashes in Nigeria

fields.headline: Unwed mother given 100 lashes in Nigeria
fields.trailText: A teenage single mother was given 100 lashes yesterday under stringent new Islamic morality laws in northern Nigeria, but three men who she says coerced her into sex, during which she became pregnant, went unpunished.
fields.body:
A teenage single mother was given 100 lashes yesterday under stringent new Islamic morality laws in northern Nigeria, but three men who she says coerced her into sex, during which she became pregnant, went unpunished.

After Bariya Ibrahim Magazu was caned, she was presented with several men who offered to marry her, and pressured to choose one, which she did.

About 100 people turned out to watch the beating of the woman who an Islamic court said is 17 years-old, but whose family claims she is just 14.

In September she became the first woman in modern times to be sentenced to a flogging in Nigeria for having had premarital sex, prompting protests from overseas but only a muted response at home. The punishment was deferred until after the birth of Miss Magazu's baby.

At her trial, prosecutors demanded that she name her baby's father. She said three married men had "forced themselves" on her, and named them. She produced seven witnesses, but the court dismissed her evidence and convicted her of the added charge of making a false accusation. Had the court believed her, the men could have been convicted of adultery and stoned to death.

The flogging was originally scheduled for January 27, the first anniversary of the imposition of Islamic law, or Sharia, in Zamfara state, before being postponed last week.

Explaining the decision to go ahead with the caning yesterday, a spokesman for the state government, Bashir Sanda, said local authorities wanted to end the international controversy created by the court's verdict and sentence.

"The governor felt he ought to act immediately to put the matter to rest," Mr Bashir said. "He ordered that the punishment should be carried out to avoid all the pressure and the tension created."

The deputy governor of Zamfara state, Mahmoud Shinkafi, said Miss Magazu was bruised but "not badly hurt" by the flogging. "Immediately after the punishment she thanked Allah for having the punishment. She walked home and when she got to her village she was very happy."

Human rights groups accused the provincial government and Sharia court of violating a pact to put the flogging on hold while Miss Magazu is breastfeeding her baby.

"It's a shock. It's a horrible thing to happen to Bariya," said Aisha Imam, head of a women's rights group.

webTitle: Police hunt down five of the Texas jailbreak seven

fields.headline: Police hunt down five of the Texas jailbreak seven
fields.standfirst: Escaped rapist commits suicide and four prisoners recaptured as FBI tracks them to trailer park
fields.trailText: Escaped rapist commits suicide and four prisoners recaptured as FBI tracks them to trailer park.
fields.body:
One of seven escaped Texas prisoners accused of killing a policeman while on the run for more than a month commited suicide last night and four more were captured after their cover as travelling Christians was blown.

The men, known as the Texas Seven, were intercepted in a trailer park in Colorado, evidently without fulfilling the most blood-curdling predictions about how the hunt for them would end.

Numerous theories about the gang's location and intentions emerged over almost six weeks, along with claims and counter-claims about who was to blame for the breakout: a system that kept prisons under-staffed and guards underpaid, or the officers who failed to prevent the prisoners' escape.

Larry Harper, 37, who had been serving 50 years for three rapes, shot himself in the chest as police attempted to persuade him to leave a mobile home last night. He had said that he would not do so until he had spoken to his father.

George Rivas, 30, the robber and kidnapper thought to be the gang's ringleader, was among the four held. A child-batterer and two murderers were also in custody.

They were picked up after a tip-off to the police from someone in the park. It was not clear whether a $500,000 (£340,000) reward had played a part in the tip-off.

Police said they did not know the whereabouts of the other two members of the gang, but believed that they might still be in the area around the trailer park, about 50 miles south of Denver.

"They were all supposed to be Christians who were travelling around the country and said they were going to be staying here," said a woman who spent time with the men the day before and did not want to be identified. She knew one of the men as Jim.

"We went out to lunch after church - he bought our dinner. We took him round some of the sights here. He was very calm and very clean-cut. You'd think he was a college guy. He was not nervous at all. We had a very, very pleasant time with him."

The men escaped from a maximum security prison 60 miles south-east of San Antonio on December 13, taking with them 14 handguns, a rifle, a shotgun and more than 200 rounds of ammunition.

There were more than 1,200 "sightings" as the nationwide hunt for the men went on, right across the southern states and even as far north as New York.

But only two of the sightings were confirmed: one when they stole police scanners from an electrical store in Houston, the other when a sports shop in a Dallas suburb was raided and $70,000 and 25 more guns and ammunition were taken.

It was during the second of these raids, on Christmas Eve, that a 29-year-old policeman, Aubrey Hawkins, was killed.

His mother, Jaynie Hawkins, said last night: "My initial reaction is one of sadness because this makes it real. Do I want to see them? Only because I want them to see me. I want to see what they look like when they see the mother of a child who's gone."

Mark Marshon, an FBI special agent in Colorado, said: "This story is by no means over. We have two subjects still on the loose. They are heavily armed and dangerous."

webTitle: Leader: UK's punitive drugs policy ignored

fields.headline: Potty policies
fields.standfirst:
Isolated UK's punitive approach ignored

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Belgium approved the social reform last week. Portugal made the same move last year and Spain and Italy even earlier. The Swiss are preparing to make the change. Why doesn't the UK follow suit and decriminalise cannabis?
fields.body:
Belgium approved the social reform last week. Portugal made the same move last year and Spain and Italy even earlier. The Swiss are preparing to make the change. The EU estimates about 40m people in the 15 member states are users of the product. What are we talking about? Decriminalisation of cannabis.

The Belgium cabinet approved the decriminalisation of personal consumption last Friday. Under the plan, it will no longer be illegal to grow, import or consume cannabis for personal consumption. The health secretary explained: "Any possession of cannabis for personal consumption will no longer provoke a reaction from the justice system unless its use is considered to be problematic or creates a social nuisance."

Once upon a time only the Netherlands was ready to recognise reality - the widespread use of cannabis by young people. Cannabis was not legalised but the Dutch police were under instruction not to arrest or pursue any individual just for possession. Now even traditional conservative states are beginning to follow suit, recognising the much feared "drugs ladder" does not operate in Holland, where even though there is decriminalisation, fewer young people use the drug than in punitive Britain.

The Dutch have successfully separated soft from hard drugs. But in Britain, by imprudently insisting on keeping cannabis in a serious harm category, ministers make it much more likely that soft drug users can find themselves buying cannabis from dealers who push hard drugs as well.

The drugs tsar defends this indefensible approach because of the wide use of police cautions in the UK. There is, by some forces, but not by others. The variations are wide. Worse still, the home secretary has still not responded to the sensible proposals from the national commission on drug laws save rejecting downgrading cannabis from class B to C. Parliament has asked for a response. It should insist on getting one.

fields.headline: Cronyism: it's the law
fields.trailText: Cronyism is a word recently invented by the Tories so that they can attack Labour for doing what Tories have done since time immemorial: appointing and promoting their mates to positions of power and influence.
fields.body:
Cronyism is a word recently invented by the Tories so that they can attack Labour for doing what Tories have done since time immemorial: appointing and promoting their mates to positions of power and influence. Not even the most ardent Tory, however, could have anticipated that thanks to a legal action brought by a Labour lord chancellor, cronyism would be sanctioned by the law.

Partly to protect it from allegations of cronyism, the civil service has always been bound by strict rules that top appointments must be advertised, and final selections made by independent boards. A relatively recent exception to this rule was established by the arrival of hosts of special advisers, who are appointed on the whim of ministers.

Soon after he took over as lord chancellor in 1997, Lord Irvine of Lairg decided that he would like a special adviser. No previous lord chancellor has ever had one, but Lord Irvine wrote to his former pupil, Tony Blair, asking permission to appoint Garry Hart, a senior partner in the big City solicitors Herbert Smith. Mr Blair was greatly impressed with his former pupil master's choice. Garry Hart, after all, was godfather to Blair's son. He gave the necessary permission and, without a single advertisement or interview, Mr Hart took up his post at public expense.

The appointment infuriated many lawyers who were sympathetic to the government and thought they might at least have been given a chance to apply for the job. Jane Coker, a well-known immigration solicitor, sued the lord chancellor, claiming that the appointment of Irvine's crony as an adviser clearly discriminated against her. The lord chancellor's reaction to the writ was one of lofty contempt. He denounced the action as "mischievous" and "politically motivated" and refused to give evidence to the tribunal. His attitude changed rather suddenly in March 1999 when the South London tribunal found unanimously that he had illegally discriminated against Jane Coker. Since he rather fancies himself as an enemy of discrimination Lord Irvine was greatly embarrassed, and announced that he would appeal.

To take charge of his case, he appointed Sir Sidney Kentridge, who made his name defending Steve Biko in South Africa and is now one of the most expensive barristers available. Another QC was appointed to support Sir Sidney. Who would hear the appeal? There was a problem. The employment appeals tribunal panel is appointed by, er, the lord chancellor. In the event, the appeals tribunal was chaired by Lord Johnston, a former Tory government's advocate depute, who sat with two lay members of the panel, both women.

Sir Sidney denounced the tribunal decision as perverse, but perverse it wasn't. In its judgment last week, the appeal court admitted they were unable to agree, and overturned the tribunal decision by a majority of two to one. The majority view was that the appointment of Garry Hart did not discriminate against Jane Coker because the lord chancellor "determined on only one person and thus can be said to discriminate against everybody else, be they men or women".

It was, they concluded, not relevant to ask who might or might not have been considered for the post, "because that ignores the reality of the situation, namely the intention on the part of the lord chancellor from the outset to appoint a single specific person. That, in our opinion, must be a free-standing right to make an appointment not least because a woman could equally have been appointed."

The phrase "free-standing right" is taken from European human-rights legislation that identifies various basic rights. These include the right to life and the right of association and free speech. And now, up comes the inalienable right to appoint your mates to high office and charge their salaries to the taxpayer. Jane Coker was given leave to appeal. But who is to hear it?

The word perverse was used again in the courts last week when the court of appeal overturned a jury's verdict in the libel case brought by Bruce Grobbelaar against the Sun. There was very little criticism of this bizarre judgment, perhaps because many people felt that Grobbelaar's behaviour may not have been above criticism. I can think of several criminal cases where the defendants may have been technically guilty but where a jury has cleared them for quite different reasons (the Ponting official secrets case and the recent acquittal of nuclear protesters at Faslane are obvious examples).

Who knows whether or not the Grobbelaar jury reckoned that the Sun is more reprehensible than the footballer? And why are juries not entitled to reach verdicts without being denounced as perverse by judges who are not elected, not chosen at random and can arrive at their exalted position only from a sheltered and privileged background?

fields.headline: Pressure on Iraq over 'new weapons'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, has rebuilt three factories which are now capable of producing chemical weapons, the US and Britain claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, has rebuilt three factories which are now capable of producing chemical weapons, the US and Britain claimed yesterday.

The disclosure is intended to step up pressure on Baghdad and signals a new hard line as George Bush begins his presidency. The US and Britain are trying to shore up efforts to contain President Saddam after the steady demolition of their trade embargo by Arab and European states.

Similar intelligence reports formed the basis for the Desert Fox bombing raid by the US and Britain two years ago.

Foreign Office diplomats have been in Washington in the last week discussing Iraq and other foreign policy issues with the new administration. An FO spokesman said: "The general assessment that Iraq may be reconstituting biological and chemical weapons is one we share."

But the Foreign Office and US state department were careful to avoid saying they had proof, as this would automatically trigger new air raids.

The claim comes just 10 days after the Pentagon made public an intelligence assessment of the threat posed by the proliferation of weapons worldwide. Its report said Iraq "shows no let-up in its pursuit to reconstitute its pre-war weapons and missile capabilities".

According to the new reports, one rebuilt factory is using a mash made from castor beans that contains a deadly biological toxin called ricin. The Iraqis claim the castor oil is used for brake fluid. Another produces chlorine, which is used for nuclear production and for cleaning water.

George Galloway, the Labour MP who has been leading the British campaign to have sanctions against Iraq lifted, said yesterday: "There is a long campaign of misinformation about the purpose of factories as a prelude for US attacks."

He described the latest reports as propaganda "to justify the increasingly unjustified siege of Iraq".

The US and the Foreign Office stressed that the reports were from officials in the old administration and should not necessarily be taken as an insight into Mr Bush's approach.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, is planning to meet Iraqi ministers next month to discuss lifting sanctions in return for allowing in UN weapons inspectors.

Although the UN weapons team, Unscom, has not been allowed into Iraq since December 1998, the International Atomic Energy Agency, a nuclear proliferation watchdog, has been allowed to continue with less intrusive inspections.

The IAEA is this week carrying out its annual inspection of nuclear material in Iraq. Four inspectors - from Egypt, Poland, Russia and South Africa - are visiting the Tuwaitha nuclear centre, 12 miles south of Baghdad, to check that low-grade material, sealed in 1998, has not been touched.

The centre was the main site for Iraq's nuclear programme before the Gulf war and is the location of the Osiraq reactor, bombed by Israel in 1981.

David Kidd, the IAEA's spokesman in Vienna, said the inspectors were carrying out tests to determine the quantity and quality of material stored.

"It's a thorough check, but no replacement for what the [UN] security council would like to have us do," he said.

Several Iraqi defectors have claimed that President Saddam is continuing to develop a bomb. Salman Yassin Zweir, an engineer who was said to have spent 13 years working for the Iraqi atomic energy commission, said recently that work resumed in secret in August 1998.

The American estimate is that it would take Baghdad at least five years to build nuclear weapons.

The US and the Foreign Office stressed that the reports were from officials in the old administration and should not necessarily be taken as an insight into Mr Bush's approach. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, is planning to meet Iraqi ministers next month to discuss lifting sanctions in return for allowing in UN weapons inspectors. Although the UN weapons team, Unscom, has not been allowed into Iraq since December 1998, the International Atomic Energy Agency, a nuclear proliferation watchdog, has been allowed to continue with less intrusive inspections. The IAEA is this week carrying out its annual inspection of nuclear material in Iraq. Four inspectors - from Egypt, Poland, Russia and South Africa - are visiting the Tuwaitha nuclear centre, 12 miles south of Baghdad, to check that low-grade material, sealed in 1998, has not been touched. The centre was the main site for Iraq's nuclear programme before the Gulf war and is the location of the Osiraq reactor, bombed by Israel in 1981. David Kidd, the IAEA's spokesman in Vienna, said the inspectors were carrying out tests to determine the quantity and quality of material stored. "It's a thorough check, but no replacement for what the [UN] security council would like to have us do," he said. Several Iraqi defectors have claimed that President Saddam is continuing to develop a bomb. Salman Yassin Zweir, an engineer who was said to have spent 13 years working for the Iraqi atomic energy commission, said recently that work resumed in secret in August 1998. The American estimate is that it would take Baghdad at least five years to build nuclear weapons.

fields.headline: Swing time
fields.standfirst:
Blair would be happy to win the next election with the big majority predicted by the swingometer. The reality might be less comfortable

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Blair would be happy to win the next election with the big majority predicted by the swingometer. The reality might be less comfortable.
fields.body:
Popularised on election-night television, the swingometer has helped make it beguilingly simple for both pundits and public to work out what votes cast might mean in terms of seats in the House of Commons - political power.

Polls show Labour winning 41% of the vote, the Tories 34% and the Liberal Democrats 17%. That represents a three-point drop in Labour's vote compared with 1997 and a three-point increase for the Tories, while the Liberal Democrats would be where they were. The traditional swingometer assumes a 3% movement from Labour to Tory in every seat. Similarly it assumes the Liberal Democrat vote would be unchanged everywhere. It produces a hypothetical outcome of Labour with 393 seats, the Tories 198 and Liberal Democrats 39, a result with which Tony Blair would doubtless be very happy.

But the swing is never exactly the same across the country. The swingometer assumes its errors will cancel out: for each seat where a swing above 3% costs Labour victory there will be another where a swing below 3% saves Labour's bacon.

However, at recent elections the errors have not cancelled out because the swings have been far from uniform. In 1992, the swingometer forecast that John Major's 8% lead would give the Tories a majority of 71; they ended up just 21 ahead. In 1997, the swingometer predicted a Labour majority of 131 rather than the 179 they actually got.

Despite this uneven record, pundits persist with the swingometer, producing forecasts that are dangerously flattering for Labour. The swingometer suggests Labour could be as much as one point behind the Tories and still have an overall majority. It says William Hague needs a 10% lead before he can hope to walk into 10 Downing Street. Little wonder swingometer users are predicting a second Labour landslide in May.

But behind the headlines showing Labour with a double-digit lead there is an important message for its polling performance. The swingometer is likely to be wrong again. And this time it is Labour rather than the Tories who can be expected to lose out.

ICM has pulled together the results of more than 12,000 interviews it conducted on a random basis in every constituency over the past few months. With such a large total of interviews spread across the country we can examine how different parts of the country are swinging. There are some important differences.

First, Labour's vote is holding up better in the south of England than in the Midlands and the north. Second, Labour is performing more strongly in those seats the Tories managed to win in 1997 than in its own seats. Labour support is falling away particularly in its heartlands. The evidence is that anti-Tory tactical voting among Labour and Liberal Democrat supporters may be on the wane.

These are not isolated findings. They fit the evidence of local, European and Scottish and Welsh elections since 1997. Clearly they should not be ignored.

Not all of this is bad news for Tony Blair. Labour's prospects are likely to be little harmed if it does relatively badly in its heartlands; all that means is that some of its thumping majorities will be a little smaller. Meanwhile, Labour's relatively strong performance in southern English seats held by the Tories may open up the prospect of some unexpected Labour gains.

Indeed the variations shown up by this analysis of the ICM data would make little difference to the overall outcome. If Labour's lead in the polls - confirmed again today - lasted until election day, its majority would be almost exactly the same as the 179 it won in 1997.

But the picture looks darker if Labour's lead falls. Then the adverse trend in marginal Labour seats in the Midlands, the north of England and Scotland begins to make a difference.

Just how this works can be seen from our new version of the swingometer, the "variometer". Instead of assuming the whole country swings the same way, our device takes into account differences in the swings in different parts of the country, as recorded by ICM. Now we see that rather than being able to win an overall majority in the Commons while still a point behind the Tories in the polls, Labour will require a lead of two points to be sure of an overall Commons majority.

True, Mr Hague's target for victory is still higher than Mr Blair's. The Tories would need to be at least 4% ahead of Labour in the polls to be sure of an overall Commons majority - but the traditional swingometer predicted that they would need to be 10 points clear.

Of course if he does call an election soon, Mr Blair will expect a majority greater than one seat. He probably needs to have a margin of about 50 if he is to deliver on his promise to win his party its first-ever safe and secure second term. And for that our variometer suggests he needs a lead in the opinion polls of nearly four points.

At the moment the polls suggest Labour should have little difficulty in hitting that target. They give Mr Blair an average lead of around 15%. But in 1997, a poll at the start of the year showed Labour 25% ahead - it was 13% by polling day. A similar drop this time and Mr Blair could find his prospects of a second comfortable majority no longer look secure.

 John Curtice is deputy director of the ESRC Centre for Research into Elections and Social Trends. Nick Sparrow is managing director of ICM Research.

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk

fields.headline: Entitled to two hours of misery in freezing mud
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: I love New Labour jargon. In culture questions yesterday MPs debated school sport. Apparently children are to have a weekly "two-hour entitlement" to take part in school sport.
fields.body:
I love New Labour jargon. In culture questions yesterday MPs debated school sport. Apparently children are to have a weekly "two-hour entitlement" to take part in school sport. When I was at school, if you'd told me that two hours running round a freezing, muddy pitch playing a game (rugby) I neither enjoyed nor understood, with a teacher who wished, even more devoutly than me, to be sitting in front of a fire with a good book, was not a fiendish punishment but an "entitlement", I might have screamed.

But apparently now the poor kids are going to have to play, not because they are told they must, but because it has magically become a fundamental, if unwanted, human right. This is due to what Kate Hoey, the sports minister, called "the rolling out of one of our new schools sports coordinators, who will be working to offer good quality provision".

One imagines the poor fellow being rolled out, possibly in a barrel, blathering New Labour platitudes about good quality provision and best practice procedures. I suppose it would be more fun than playing rugby.

Later, Julian Lewis, the crazed Tory MP, contrived to claim that the only reason the government was giving away free TV licences for over-75s was to "expose them to the BBC's propaganda, orchestrated by the cronies of this government, including the head of the corporation".

Julian, dear boy, calm down. Pensioners don't only want to watch party politicals. When EastEnders is full of people saying, "Blimey, me old mucker, me old china, cor strike a light, if taxes, waiting lists, crime and class sizes aren't all down, fanks to that Tony Blair, swelp me, I'm just a good girl, I am," that will be the time to worry. Not until.

Over in the House of Lords, they were debating stem cells and the cloning of embryos. These cloned embryos represent the very beginning of human life, even though they are nothing more than a clutch of cells.

You can easily understand why some people are worried about the ethical implications of using them for research, even though the embryos do not possess life in any meaningful way, and would not exist in the first place if they hadn't been cloned. After all, in the right circumstances, they could, just conceivably, grow into people.

So this is a truly difficult moral choice, one that would bring most of us a few sleepless nights if we had to vote on it. For that reason it's exactly the kind of conundrum that causes peers to come crashing down on one side or the other, like a playground bully on a see-saw.

We heard a lot about "the slippery slope", the implication being that if we allowed experiments on cloned embryos, the next thing would be vivisection of children who had failed their Sats.

But the whole point about moral choices is that they aren't slippery slopes. They are more like deserts of sand on which we have to find somewhere to draw a line. So people who steal the office paperclips don't necessarily go on to mug complete strangers. Tapping a naughty child on the bottom doesn't lead to the horrors of A Child Called "It".

That's what we ask our legislators to do: decide where the line is drawn, and not pretend that on all ethical questions we are as helpless as a fireman launched onto a greasy pole.

At one point in the debate, three disabled peers turned up, leading to a sort of wheelchair lock by the steps to the throne. I don't know what they're all suffering from, but some are probably victims of the kind of degenerative disease the new research - if it is allowed - will try to cure.

In a curious way, you have to envy anyone whose sense of moral certainty can survive such a sight.

webTitle: Warming could be worst in 10,000 years

fields.headline: Warming could be worst in 10,000 years
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming
Kyoto protocol in full
fields.trailText: An international group of scientists has confirmed the worst fears of environmentalists: the Earth's atmosphere could soar by almost 6C by 2100 - a rise unprecedented in the past 10,000 years.
fields.body:
An international group of scientists has confirmed the worst fears of environmentalists: the Earth's atmosphere could soar by almost 6C by 2100 - a rise unprecedented in the past 10,000 years.

The UN group reported yesterday in Shanghai that, in the worst case, the average temperature could rise by 5.8C this century, 2C higher than their original predictions. Sea levels could rise by 88cm (34.5in) by 2100, making tens of millions of people homeless in China's Pearl river delta, Bangladesh, the Nile delta of Egypt, and other low-lying regions.

"We see changes in climate, we believe we humans are involved and we're projecting future climate changes much more significant over the next 100 years than the last 100 years," said Robert Watson, introducing the latest, 1,000-page report of the intergovernmental panel on climate change.

Klaus Topfer, head of the UN environment programme, said the report "should ring alarm bells in every national capital and every local community".

The 1990s was the warmest decade for 1,000 years, said the report. Temperatures rose by an average of 0.6C during the last century, with an increase in floods and droughts. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have risen by 31% since the beginning of the industrial revolution, and scientists blame the reckless burning of fossil fuels. In one of the ironies of global politics, the scientists issued their report on the day that George Bush - who has said he is not convinced climate change is really happening - took office as the new US president.

But much of the science behind the IPCC report comes from the highest tiers of US and European research. The warnings may kickstart a political process that has been stalled since November. Developed nations met at the Hague to agree to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 5.5% by 2010 - well short of the 60% cut scientists say is needed - but the talks collapsed, largely because of US attitudes.

The researchers present the "worst case" picture, as well as projections of possi ble temperature rises if nations cooperate. But the outlook is grim. The area of northern polar sea ice has shrunk by up to 15% in the past 40 years, and the thickness of the ice has fallen by 40%. Satellite studies have shown that snow cover has shrunk by 10% in the past 30 years.

Environmentalists described the report as "terrifying". Sir John Houghton, a former Meteorological Office chief and an IPCC member, said: "The 6C depends on just how much fossil fuel we burn this next century - if we burn less, then the increase will be less. But what it means for the world is that the sea level will rise."

webTitle: Leader: Why are we waiting for export control?

fields.headline: Long arms
fields.standfirst:
Why are we waiting for export control?

Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Ambitious Foreign Office minister Peter Hain said last night that policy in the style of Bismarck and Kissinger was dead.
fields.body:
Ambitious Foreign Office minister Peter Hain said last night that policy in the style of Bismarck and Kissinger was dead. No longer could "foreign policy" be the business solely of chancelleries, generals or indeed specialists such as Chatham House, where the minister was presenting his new Fabian pamphlet.

Together climate change and environmental degradation, along with the globalisation of markets and the mobilisation of opinion by campaigning non-government organisations (NGOs), have popularised policy; the very concept of foreign is now, well, foreign. Whether Mr Hain was speaking as the young pretender or the voice of his master, Robin Cook, he makes a good point.

But it would have been sharper if he had identified weapons exports as a key example of policy left too long to secretaries of state, spies and secretive business people. The arms trade touches jobs and the domestic economy (whatever happened to Labour defence diversification?), ethics, popular sentiment of the kind personified by the Princess of Wales over landmines and - unacknowledged but a force still - UK raison d'état .

Mr Hain's silence is easy to understand. The government is plainly embarrassed at having failed to deliver. You needed only to listen yesterday to trade minister Kim Howells; he should learn Denis Healey's maxim that when you are in a hole, stop digging. Labour has not had four years to get its legislation in place - it has had seven. The shape of arms control legislation has been implicit since Mr Cook's famed parliamentary performance on the publication of the Scott report on arms in 1996.

But there, perhaps, we have the real reason for Mr Hain's silence. For all his post-modern policy, some issues demand government action on traditional lines. No UK cabinet is likely to ban weapons exports completely. One reason has been convincingly put by Clare Short: there will always be governments, often poor, which need and deserve help when they are threatened. What that entails is a subtle scheme for licensing and regulation, for (to put it crudely) identifying the good guys. Calculations about the deservingness of a foreign government will necessarily change over time.

So an essential element becomes scrutiny and debate. The criteria for exporting arms may not change but their application will. So openness becomes vital. Foreign policy (including arms licensing) can no longer be made by the power elite - Peter Hain's paean of praise to NGOs recognised that. But NGOs are not a substitute for democratic control within and between nations. The logic of Mr Hain is to bring the public on board and what better way than to give MPs direct responsibility for approving arms export licences?

On the weapons trade Labour's cupboard is not entirely bare. A European export code; tighter guidelines on what can be exported; annual reports on the trade: to the list should probably be added the paradoxical way in which Labour's hesitations and inconsistencies over the human rights dimension to its foreign policy has served to raise public consciousness. But its promised export legislation is overdue, as Sir Richard Scott himself observed - he might have added how his report's other implications for the culture and ethics of the civil service have yet to be picked up.

Perhaps Labour deserves the benefit of the doubt till its draft bill is published, though Mr Howells' talk about delaying until the measure was "right" flies in the face of a promise to involve MPs in deliberating and reshaping its content.

webTitle: Troops 'told to shoot people in back'

fields.headline: Troops 'told to shoot people in back'
fields.standfirst:
Bloody Sunday inquiry
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: A former soldier who took part in the civil rights march in Derry when 14 people died told the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday he heard troops being ordered to fire at people's backs. John McLaughlin, an ex-Royal Engineer who was 39 at the time of the march on January 30 1972, also claimed a soldier told him to "let the fucker bleed to death" when he asked if he could get help for two wounded men.
fields.body:
A former soldier who took part in the civil rights march in Derry when 14 people died told the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday he heard troops being ordered to fire at people's backs. John McLaughlin, an ex-Royal Engineer who was 39 at the time of the march on January 30 1972, also claimed a soldier told him to "let the fucker bleed to death" when he asked if he could get help for two wounded men.

One of the men, John Johnston, 59, died five months later in hospital, while Damien Donaghy, who was 15 in 1972, is the first of the injured due to give evidence this week to the tribunal in Derry's Guildhall.

Tony Blair agreed to set up the inquiry after a 26-year battle by families of the bereaved and injured. It began last March and will hear from around 1,000 witnesses over the next year or two.

The chairman, Lord Saville, is expected to rule in the next couple of weeks on whether certain military and intelligence personnel will be able to retain their anonymity, which the families' lawyers claim would undermine the proceedings.

Mr McLaughlin, who served in England and the far east, including Korea, said he was in Rossville Street, near where seven people were killed, when two army Saracens pulled up and troops with rifles took up firing positions.

"I heard the officer give the order to fire," he said. "He said something like 'identify your target and fire'. The soldiers immediately started to fire south towards the crowd at Free Derry Corner. I could not understand why the soldiers had to identify their targets because the people had their backs to the soldiers."

Mr McLaughlin then described running into a house where the two wounded men were lying.

He asked a soldier outside if he would let him get an ambulance and was told to let the teenager bleed to death. John McLaughlin, an ex-Royal Engineer who was 39 at the time of the march on January 30 1972, also claimed a soldier told him to "let the fucker bleed to death" when he asked if he could get help for two wounded men. One of the men, John Johnston, 59, died five months later in hospital, while Damien Donaghy, who was 15 in 1972, is the first of the injured due to give evidence this week to the tribunal in Derry's Guildhall. "I heard the officer give the order to fire," he said. "He said something like 'identify your target and fire'. The soldiers immediately started to fire south towards the crowd at Free Derry Corner. webTitle: Blueprint for rural renewal drawn up

fields.headline: Blueprint for rural renewal drawn up
fields.trailText: Blueprints to revitalise 100 market towns and 1,000 rundown villages are to be developed by the countryside agency, which will provide grants for essential services such as public transport.
fields.body:
Blueprints to revitalise 100 market towns and 1,000 rundown villages are to be developed by the countryside agency, which will provide grants for essential services such as public transport.

The agency, created by the government a year ago with a budget of £55m this year and £70m next, has produced a strategy to deal with rural area problems made worse by the collapse of farm incomes which have cost 41,000 jobs in the past two years.

Ewen Cameron, chairman of the agency, said: "The challenges facing the countryside are far wider than the farming crisis or the future of hunting. We want to set off a quiet revolution in towns and villages to give people control over their lives."

Around 20% of the population lives in areas classed as rural. While many rich people have moved to the country to retire or commute long distances to work the plight of the rural poor remains dire, according to the agency.

Eighteen rural districts fall within the most deprived 100 in the country. These include large areas of Cornwall, parts of Devon and Somerset, the Isle of Thanet in Kent, and the Isle of Wight.

In the north, Berwick-upon-Tweed, Pendle in Lancashire, the Wear Valley in Durham, and Scarborough in North Yorkshire all qualify.

Among programmes to be started by the agency is a training programme for parish clerks and councillors so they know what the best councils in the country are achieving and how to tap into the grant system. At the moment, parish councils can apply for £10,000 each to start local transport initiatives, but much of the money is unused through lack of applications.

Another scheme is a village- by-village indentification of sites for affordable homes for children of rural dwellers. They are often priced out of village homes because of the influx of second home owners and retired people.

These sites and the houses on them would be reserved for local people. In this way, communities would remain balanced, rather than composed of older country folk and rich incomers.

The agency is to provide health checks for market towns to measure the level of services - transport, banks, businesses, employment, health, education and housing.

One example of a town revitalised was Ulverston in the Lake District, where £2.3m was put in for regeneration and revived local services and new businesses followed, Mr Cameron said. More than 50 new businesses had started up creating 150 new jobs.

Mr Cameron will be on the Countryside Alliance march on central London on March 17, which is being organised to highlight rural concerns but its mainly a focus on the fox hunting debate.

He said yesterday: "I realise hunting is important to certain members of the rural community. Frankly, it is a distraction that takes people's attention away from serious issues like farming, affordable homes, transport and rural services."

Mr Cameron has the job of "rural advocate" - intervening when government policies could be adapted to help rural areas. The agency is attempting to improve new technology links to rural areas.

The agency is also mapping rights of way and improving access to the countryside. This is seen as a direct way of increasing rural incomes by attracting weekend visitors to rural pubs and shops.

webTitle: Culture clash in Hull, over refugees

fields.headline: Hull tested as culture clashes rumble on
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The young Kurds were scared when the doctor got to them at the police station and asked why on earth they had gone out for a night at a Hull fairground with bicycle chains in their pockets.
fields.body:
The young Kurds were scared when the doctor got to them at the police station and asked why on earth they had gone out for a night at a Hull fairground with bicycle chains in their pockets.

"We have to protect ourselves," the oldest told Hamed Bajilan, who besides being a consultant at Hull royal infirmary was acting as their translator. The doctor sighed, replying: "You don't do that here."

It was another example of the culture clash which has unsettled Hull's generally successful record at coping with more than 1,000 asylum seekers. "The police aren't the same as in Iraq," he went on. "They'll help if you get trouble from hooligans. But they won't stand for arming yourselves with bicycle chains."

Fuelling the youths' fears were the experiences of friends such as Fardin Farqu, an Afghan stabbed in the city, and Mohammed Ali, a 26-year-old Kosovan, blinded in one eye by a stone.

But since July - the end of a four-month stretch which saw 35 suspected racial attacks - Humberside police have moved into the Avenues area of the city. Partly they are on patrol; partly they are doing basic liaison work such as explaining how to change a lightbulb (it is different in Kurdish Iraq).

The refugees are concentrated near the suburban Avenues area. And the local Kwik-Save and the Indian and continental stores are where many of the Home Office's refugee vouchers end up - the glaring signal that a shopper is a refugee.

"It's a world of dark looks in queues," says Dr Bajilan, "I think specially because the asylum seekers shop where the poorest local people shop, and it's the poorest people who feel they're a threat, buying things they want or somehow threatening jobs."

In fact, no asylum seeker is legally allowed to work, but rumours spread and unemployment in Hull is still a noticeable 7.4%.

In the city centre post office the queues are more than a trivial problem too - up to now this post office has been the only one allowed to take vouchers.

But that seems likely to change, and still more pressure on the Home Office has led to the council and social services getting extra information on asylum seekers in Hull via private landlords. It means that instead of greeting refugees off the coach with "Hello number 53", officials will have names to hand.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Armed robbers kidnap family
'Hijackers hit steward'
Corrie star 'attacked man'
Drugs dentist struck off
fields.body:
Armed robbers kidnap family

Armed robbers yesterday kidnapped the wife and four-year-old son of a Post Office distribution driver as part of a raid on a van. The attackers ordered the man to drive to a Post Office cash distribution centre in Dartford, Kent, collect his co-driver and drive to Powder Mill Lane from where a "substantial amount" of cash was stolen. The mother and child were released, uninjured but shaken.

'Hijackers hit steward'

A steward was tied up then punched and kicked by armed hijackers who forced an Ariana airlines Boeing 727 to divert to Stansted last February, the Old Bailey heard yesterday. Twelve Afghan men deny hijacking.

Corrie star 'attacked man'

Vicky Entwistle, who plays Janice Battersby in Coronation Street, was arrested yesterday over an alleged assault on a 40-year-old man in Manchester.

Drugs dentist struck off

A dentist who lived a double life as a crack cocaine addict was struck off by the General Dental Council yesterday. Rajesh Parmar, 29, of Leicester, admitted serious misconduct.

Hallmark check on store rings

Trading standards officers are investigating nine-carat rings and pendants being sold for up to £100 at Argos and Littlewoods Index stores. Birmingham assay office will examine some of the items before deciding whether the gold and the hallmarks are genuine.

Scout leader 'caused death'

A scout leader yesterday denied a charge of manslaughter after 10-year-old Johnathan Attwell fell 600ft from the east ridge of Snowdon in October 1999. Peter Finlay, 50, of Bristol, will be tried at Caernarfon crown court in April.

Stepson denies sword killing

A stepfather was killed with a samurai sword after a family row in Crayford, Kent, the Old Bailey was told yesterday. Stephen Keaveney, 18, a furniture fitter, pleaded not guilty to murdering John Keaveney, 36.

Wrong number

Jane Clark, of Dunstable, Bedfordshire, who chose the wrong age for her husband Richard - 47 instead of 46 - as one of her six lottery numbers won £2.3m as one of three winners on Saturday.

fields.headline: Majority supports tests on animals
fields.trailText: The use of animals for scientific testing is supported by the majority of adults, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.
fields.body:
The use of animals for scientific testing is supported by the majority of adults, according to a Guardian/ICM poll published today.

The survey shows that 46% support animal testing and 36% oppose it.

But there are sharp differences of opinion between the generations, between men and women and between voters on the issue.

The poll is published amid the row over the future of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the research company brought to the brink of closure by animal rights activists.

The company's shares more than doubled in early trading on the stock market yesterday following a new financing deal for the laboratory over the weekend.

However, by the close they had fallen back from their peak as some investors decided to cash in their profits.

The shares had been changing hands at just 1p at the start of last week, and finished yesterday at 8.5p after touching 25p during the day. This compares sharply to the performance of the shares 10 years ago when they were trading at more than £3 each.

In a statement to the stock market, Huntingdon revealed just how perilous its position had been on Friday night when the £22m loan from Royal Bank of Scotland and US-based banks fell due.

Even with the new financing in place, Huntingdon only has enough money to continue operations for a year. It also has to repay the loan by the end of June 2006.

In addition to achieving new financing from the backers - known only as HLSF LLC - big drug companies have pledged to give the laboratories more work. Some say that this suggests that more, rather than fewer, animal tests will be the result of the protests by the animal rights activists.

The ICM poll shows that 52% of men back animal testing; 31% are against. Women are divided 41% to 41% on the question.

The younger generation back an end to testing on animals, even for medicines for human consumption. Out of those aged 18-24, 44% are against such testing, compared to 35% for it. Opposition to animal testing rises to 47%, with 31% against, among those aged 25-34.

But opinion switches sharply towards support for animal testing among the older generations. The 35-64s come out in favour by 49% to 35%, while the over 65 age group are the most firmly in favour, with 59% backing testing and only 25% opposed.

Animal rights also divides the electorate. Conservative voters firmly support the use of animals in scientific testing, with 59% backing such procedures. Labour voters, however, are marginally against by 43% to 41%.

Despite their "cuddly image" Liberal Democrat voters are also untroubled on the whole by the idea of testing on animals, with 45% expressing support for animal testing for medical research and only 35% voting against.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,004 adults aged over 18 by telephone from January 19-21.

 Police are investigating after a letter bomb was sent to a pet supplier yesterday.

Northumbria police said it was too early to link the incident, in which no one was injured, with similar parcels sent to firms dealing in agriculture and livestock elsewhere in the country.

However, detectives are liaising with their counterparts in North Yorkshire.

fields.headline: Adoption warning for internet firms
fields.standfirst:
Special report: babies for sale
More net news
fields.trailText: The government forged ahead yesterday with attempts to block access to foreign adoption websites despite protests from British-based internet service providers that the intervention would backfire.
fields.body:
The government forged ahead yesterday with attempts to block access to foreign adoption websites despite protests from British-based internet service providers that the intervention would backfire.

John Hutton, the health minister responsible for child protection, defended his decision to warn the UK Internet Service Providers' Association of possible prosecution if its members continued to relay advertisements for adoption services illegal under British law.

His action, disclosed in the Guardian yesterday, was part of the Department of Health's response to the furore over the adoption of US twins by Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the north Wales couple who bought the babies through a child broker advertising on a Californian website.

The Kilshaws will today face the first round of a battle at the high court in Birmingham where Flintshire social workers will seek to make the girls, Belinda and Kimberley, wards of court. Mrs Kilshaw said she believed her family was right over the adoption issue. "We are still fighting for our children because they are our children," she said.

Mr Hutton said the government was not "shooting at anyone" in haste to close a loophole allowing British couples to arrange adoptions overseas without the vetting that is a precondition of legal adoptions within the UK.

"We have very clear legal advice about the implications of the Adoption Act in terms of internet service providers and simply tried to relay that information," he told BBC Radio 4's World At One programme.

The 1976 act made it an offence to publish an advertisement offering an adoption service by an agency that had not been approved by a local authority. "The recent high court litigation in this country has confirmed that when an internet service provider becomes aware of illegal material on their server they do need to take action to deal with that.

"We are not saying to all the UK [internet providers] that they must go and check all material on their servers. That would be completely unreasonable and we are not unreasonable."

The government, a local authority or member of the public could inform a provider that it was carrying a website that contravened the act.

"We would of course expect the UK internet service provider to take action. I don't think that is unreasonable. We are simply saying that this is the legislation, it does impose obligations as it does on newspapers, radio, TV and other broadcasters," Mr Hutton said.

Richard Clayton of the service provider Demon, said: "This is a row about the sort of adoption law we want in the UK. To see it as an internet issue is not so much shooting the messenger as hunting out the manufacturers of cleft sticks." Blocking foreign-based internet sites was possible, but difficult and more costly every time it was tried.

David Kerr, chief executive of the Internet Watch Foundation, said the warning letter appeared to be outlawing adoption material stored by internet providers rather than the access they provided to overseas websites.

"The outcome depends on whether ministers are prepared to talk about how this can be sensibly implemented or whether they feel political and media pressure is so acute that they insist on a quick diktat that will not work," he said.

webTitle: Alarmist reports on refugees 'must stop' say police

fields.headline: Alarmist reports on refugees 'must stop'
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Police across Britain are to challenge the "ill-informed, adverse media coverage" of asylum seekers, which they say has contributed to a rise in racial tension and increased risk of public disorder.
fields.body:
Police across Britain are to challenge the "ill-informed, adverse media coverage" of asylum seekers, which they say has contributed to a rise in racial tension and increased risk of public disorder.

"Racist expressions towards asylum seekers appear to have become common currency and acceptable in a way which would never be tolerated towards any other minority," says a report by the Association of Chief Police Officers, which was leaked to BBC Radio 5 Live ahead of its publication next month.

The report says that the arrival of asylum groups across the UK, which has aroused racist tendencies within local populations, has led to expressions of racism (not to be confused with legitimate political debate on immigration policy) that should be challenged by the police.

"Where adequate evidence exists of criminal offences, consideration should be given to prosecute," the guide adds.

The report was leaked as the Home Office published research showing that economic migration helps to fill labour market shortages, improve public finances, and contribute to the development of industries and jobs.

The Acpo guide, drawn up with the help of Dutch police but in the main by the Kent force after their experience of clashes at Dover, says that with no action plan to manage tensions between the indigenous population and asylum seekers, significant racial tensions and public disorder may arise.

Experience over the past four years showed that where asylum communities were established there was ill-informed adverse media coverage, which contributed to heightened tension and resentment.

The guide says failure to achieve instead a "positive media message may undermine much of the police service's efforts to maintain community harmony". But it also warns that within refugee communities animosity is an "ever present danger" because of the mix of ethnic groups.

It adds: "Language and cultural barriers, along with a common misunderstanding of the role of the police, mean that asylum seekers are unlikely to report racist crimes and incidents.

"While the majority of asylum seekers have no criminal motives and wish to peacefully co-exist, some will use violence beyond our normal experience in retaliating to racist attacks, responding to criminal exploitation or resolving inter-ethnic disputes.

"Such violence will be best prevented by accurate intelligence profiles of criminals in asylum communities and racist offenders of all nationalities; and positive efforts to resolve crimes and tensions between asylum seekers."

The chief constables say that all police forces should counter alarmist views that might fuel racism. It suggests getting "key messages" across to the local media, stressing that the area welcomes thousands of visitors a year; that asylum seekers are real people who need our urgent support and could make a valuable contribution to life; that Britain has a history of absorbing cultures; and that being an asylum seeker is no fun partly because of the new, restrictive asylum rules.

With regard to the experiences of police in challenging unfounded media fears about an asylum crimewave, the report noted a case where a vicar, in a town with a large number of asylum seekers, made a public statement [saying] asylum seekers were taking housing and school places from locals. "This was not the case," says the report. "But because of his position in the community, the story made front page news. The story was highlighted by an extremist political party justifying and legitimising its position."

"Where adequate evidence exists of criminal offences, consideration should be given to prosecute," the guide adds. The report was leaked as the Home Office published research showing that economic migration helps to fill labour market shortages, improve public finances, and contribute to the development of industries and jobs. The Acpo guide, drawn up with the help of Dutch police but in the main by the Kent force after their experience of clashes at Dover, says that with no action plan to manage tensions between the indigenous population and asylum seekers, significant racial tensions and public disorder may arise. Experience over the past four years showed that where asylum communities were established there was ill-informed adverse media coverage, which contributed to heightened tension and resentment. The guide says failure to achieve instead a "positive media message may undermine much of the police service's efforts to maintain community harmony". But it also warns that within refugee communities animosity is an "ever present danger" because of the mix of ethnic groups. It adds: "Language and cultural barriers, along with a common misunderstanding of the role of the police, mean that asylum seekers are unlikely to report racist crimes and incidents. "While the majority of asylum seekers have no criminal motives and wish to peacefully co-exist, some will use violence beyond our normal experience in retaliating to racist attacks, responding to criminal exploitation or resolving inter-ethnic disputes. "Such violence will be best prevented by accurate intelligence profiles of criminals in asylum communities and racist offenders of all nationalities; and positive efforts to resolve crimes and tensions between asylum seekers." The chief constables say that all police forces should counter alarmist views that might fuel racism. It suggests getting "key messages" across to the local media, stressing that the area welcomes thousands of visitors a year; that asylum seekers are real people who need our urgent support and could make a valuable contribution to life; that Britain has a history of absorbing cultures; and that being an asylum seeker is no fun partly because of the new, restrictive asylum rules. With regard to the experiences of police in challenging unfounded media fears about an asylum crimewave, the report noted a case where a vicar, in a town with a large number of asylum seekers, made a public statement [saying] asylum seekers were taking housing and school places from locals. "This was not the case," says the report. "But because of his position in the community, the story made front page news. The story was highlighted by an extremist political party justifying and legitimising its position." fields.headline: Extra £54m for stricken industry
fields.trailText: The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today defend the government against accusations that it has abandoned manufacturing when he promises £54m extra cash for regions suffering most from industrial restructuring.
fields.body:
The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, will today defend the government against accusations that it has abandoned manufacturing when he promises £54m extra cash for regions suffering most from industrial restructuring.

His announcement comes as he meets Tony Blair and the Welsh first minister, Rhodri Morgan, to discuss the imminent closures at the loss-making Llanwern steelworks in South Wales.

The plant is owned by Corus which was formerly partly owned by British Steel. As many as 6,000 steelworker's jobs are under threat and ministers are pessimistic of their ability to dissuade the company from going ahead with the shutdown. An announcement is expected this week.

One ministerial source said: "We have tried to deal with the company's genuine problems, but the level of pressure from Corus shareholders is very high".

Ministers fear closures at Llanwern could be accompanied by job losses at the firm's Redcar plant, and even at the highly productive Nissan car plant on Tyneside.

Any cutbacks are bound to be blamed on the strength of the pound, leading pro-Europeans to demand a clearer government commitment to join a single currency.

In a speech today Mr Byers will stress the importance of manufacturing and announce details of an extra £54m to a new regional innovation unit to be allocated to England's nine regional development agencies.

The money is being allocated to the regions on the basis of their relative economic position. Previously, DTI regional money has been allocated on a flat rate basis across the nine regions according to population size. A DTI official said this represented the beginning of a new regional policy. Until now policy had been "location blind".

As a result, the bulk of the money will go to the north east (£8.9m), north west (£7.4m) Yorkshire and Humberside (£10m).

Mr Byers will say: "We cannot build a strong economy if we have a trail of underperforming areas. To succeed we need all parts of all our regions firing on all cylinders.

"This government intends to help areas tackle both historical regional disparities and re spond to the challenges of the modern, hi-tech, global economy".

He will also insist that the government is not just abandoning manufacturing, but recognises its continuing importance to the British economy.

He will point out it accounts for about a fifth of national income with almost £150bn in output per year, and employs around 4m people directly and is the most dynamic sector of the economy.

The RIF cash is being distributed for the first time on the basis of a region's GDP per capita, research and development spending and unemployment rates.

In a speech welcomed in advance by the main manufacturing union, the AEEU, Mr Byers will announce that the cash will go to promote innovation and enterprise, and to support clusters and networks of businesses in their area.

At the weekend Mr Morgan admitted: "It is no longer a question of how many days we have got left to dissuade Corus. It is a matter of time before Corus decides to have its board meeting. The package of assistance seems to be less important than what we are going to do if the axe falls."

fields.headline: Poll in PM's constituency gives backing to regional government
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's calls for a clear response on regional government from voters was partly answered yesterday, in a poll showing almost 70% support in Tony Blair's constituency.
fields.body:
The government's calls for a clear response on regional government from voters was partly answered yesterday, in a poll showing almost 70% support in Tony Blair's constituency.

The survey in Sedgefield, County Durham, showed a broad level of dissatisfaction with the scale of central government's role in decision-making, and approval for devolving powers to an elected, regional body.

Pollsters analysed responses to statements put to local people in the telephone poll.

The results, published yesterday by the Campaign for a North East Assembly, were:

"Too many decisions about the north east region are made by central government." Agree 68%, disagree 13%, no view 19%; "People in the north east should have more democratic control over what happens in their region." Agree 76%, disagree 11%, no view 13%; "A directly elected assembly for the north east should decide on issues like generating jobs and developing major roads and public transport." Agree 69%, disagree 16%, no view 15%.

The phone poll took in 224 voters in the constituency, and was put together by volunteers under the guidance of Howard Elcock, professor of government at the University of Northumbria.

webTitle: Jay says Westminster should shut down at 6pm

fields.headline: Jay says Westminster should shut down at 6pm
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Parliament should meet from 9am to 6pm each day, in the same way as the Scottish parliament, the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, has proposed.
fields.body:
Parliament should meet from 9am to 6pm each day, in the same way as the Scottish parliament, the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay, has proposed.

Her remarks will infuriate traditionalists who are already fighting relatively small reforms to end Commons votes on most nights by 10pm.

A group of backbench Tory MPs - led by Eric Forth and David Maclean - have kept the Commons up until 3am or 4am at times since Christmas in protest at the reforms.

In an interview with the website e-politix, Lady Jay said: "If we look at the Scottish parliament, they have school holidays, they have 9am to 6pm sittings most days when they meet. Why not do that kind of thing at Westminster?"

She suggested parliament should not be regarded as "something that people turn up to in a leisurely way at 4pm when most sensible people will perhaps be beginning to think that this was the end of the working day".

She accepted that such reforms might be difficult to apply in the Lords since many peers have outside jobs. But even the Lords, she insisted, could be more family friendly.

Lady Jay, who is also minister for women, denied that she and Tessa Jowell, employment minister, and Margaret Hodge, education minister, were trying to persuade Tony Blair not to promote marriage as the best model for society.

She said the government's view on family policy and the status of marriage would not be different from the view set out in the neutral green paper.

Lady Jay added that no decision had yet been taken on the closure of the women's unit, or its transformation into a unit opposed to discrimination against both men and women.

Lady Jay also defended the decisions of the women's unit to campaign on issues such as body image.

She said: "Every time you read in the newspaper that 15 year olds have been given boob jobs for Christmas you realise how significant that particular initiative is."
