webTitle: Peers question haste of stem cell law change

fields.headline: Peers question haste of stem cell law change
fields.standfirst:
Lords debate on embryos
Special report: ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government's determination to rush through changes in the law that would allow the testing of stem cells derived from cloning of embryos for medical research was denounced in the Lords yesterday.
fields.body:
The government's determination to rush through changes in the law that would allow the testing of stem cells derived from cloning of embryos for medical research was denounced in the Lords yesterday, with one peer attacking minsters' refusal to allow a bill affecting "the elimination of countless embryos" while permitting one on fox hunting.

Lord Alton, the former Liberal MP, said democracy would be brought into disrepute, and public cynicism in parliament deepened, if ministers forced through an unamendable legal order at the end of this month without giving peers a chance to fully examine it in a select committee.

Urging peers to show "prudence and caution", and not to be "blinded by science", he added: "This is a curious constitution in which we can find parliamentary time for a bill which protects foxes but can't find time for a bill which will lead to the manufacture and elimination of countless embryos."

In an impassioned debate attended by Lady Thatcher, and with 40 speakers, Lord Alton argued the government's move raised constitutional, legal, scientific and ethical concerns.

Ministers were behaving "wholly inappropriately" in using an unamendable order to deal with an issue of such importance, while the active lobbying by the Department of Health for a change to the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act was unprecedented on a free vote issue.

As far as science was concerned, Lord Alton said experts were divided on whether the new research could be carried out on adult stem cells, casting doubt on whether extending research to embryonic stem cells - the area of controversy - was really necessary.

He questioned the morality of treating the human embryo as "just another accessory to be created, bartered, frozen or destroyed. These are not trivial questions that preoccupy a few moral theologians," he added. "They are at the heart of our humanity."

The deputy leader of the Tory peers, Lady Blatch, said she had lost her 14-year-old son to an illness compounded by his diabetes - one of the diseases which the research could cure - yet would still be opposing the government's order. Despite ministers' protestations, the science on stem cell research was "anything but clear", and the case for a select committee to question scientists further was "overwhelming.

"Why is the government in such a hurry?" she asked. "Why is it that a matter of such importance isn't being dealt with through primary legislation?"

The Bishop of Oxford, one of 11 clerics who last week signed an open letter urging peers to support calls for a select committeee to consider the "huge philosophical and ethical implications of these developments", outlined the theological arguments for not regarding the pre-implantation embryo as having a soul, and described the early embryo as having a "special status", rather than an "absolute status".

Research on this could only be morally justified, he argued, if it was "the only way to achieve the desired knowledge, and if the knowledge was of such benefit that it outweighed this special status". The real question, then, was whether it was really necessary to conduct the research on embryonic as opposed to adult stem cells - and the fact scientific opinion was divided on this justified a select committee.

Lady Warnock, the cross-bencher who chaired the original inquiry into human fertilisation in the 1980s, said she "deeply wished" peers had had time to analyse the extension in the act in a select committee. "I think there has been a mistake, I think we have been bullied and pushed to do things more quickly than we should and I deplore that," she said.

While admitting she would still vote for the new research, she warned: "There's a belief among the general public that a huge moral step is being taken and it's being taken without the benefit of normal parliamentary procedures. The word cloning sends shivers of horror down the spines of the British public ... the fear is that there will be no serious monitoring of research, that we will rush down the slope to the cloning of the whole human being."

But the junior health minister, Lord Hunt, emphasised the order would not permit human reproductive cloning. The human fertilisation and embryology authority - which issues licences for stem cell research - would forbid it, and anyone without a licence could be imprisoned for 10 years.

What a change to the act would permit, was an extension of the 1990 act to allow research into degenerative diseases - such as Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, diabetes and strokes - as well as into congenitive diseases and infertility. "What you are being asked to do is to, in addition to research for effective contraception, in addition to research into congenital diseases, that embryos may be used to find treatments into serious and debilitating illnesses which affect literally millions of people," he said.

fields.headline: Doctor 'failed to detect child's tumour'
fields.trailText: A nine-year-old girl died from a large cancerous tumour a month after her GP diagnosed dehydration and told her mother to "stop being paranoid", it was alleged yesterday.
fields.body:
A nine-year-old girl died from a large cancerous tumour a month after her GP diagnosed dehydration and told her mother to "stop being paranoid", it was alleged yesterday.

Krishna Mohan Singh said the child, who had a distended stomach, should take plenty of fluids and rehydration salts but failed to examine her on two occasions, the General Medical Council's professional conduct committee was told.

The young girl was violently sick on a third visit to the surgery. Just before she slipped into a coma and died, a hospital scan revealed a tumour so large - over 25cm (10in) in diameter - it had displaced her kidneys.

Dr Singh denies serious professional misconduct, by failing to examine the child, referred to as Miss A.

The girl's mother, Mrs B, said her daughter began eating less and complaining of a "bulging stomach" at the end of November 1998. She went to the surgery in Heston, Middlesex, on December 2, where Dr Singh's partner diagnosed constipation and prescribed a laxative. But days later Mrs B was alerted to blood on the lavatory seat after her daughter had been to the bathroom.

"She had some clothes which she said made her tummy look fat," said Mrs B. "I found out that she had not been to the toilet as normal. There was blood on her nightclothes."

On December 8 she took her daughter to Dr Singh who prescribed rehydration salts. "He said don't be a paranoid mother," Mrs B said. "He didn't look at me and didn't stop to listen to me." Dr Singh did not look at the child at this time, nor on a subsequent visit.

But on January 13 1999, the child saw Dr Singh again and when he did examine her said "I don't know what this can be. I've never seen anything like this - you will have to take her to hospital".

After the child was sick she was rushed to West Middlesex hospital then on to Chelsea and Westminster hospital. Mrs B said: "I realised she was extremely unwell but I didn't realise the seriousness."

Munther Haddad, a consultant paediatrician, said the child's abdominal distension was increasing before their eyes. "In spite of aggressive resuscitation we lost her at 11pm."

The GMC heard that Dr Singh's referral letter said there was no history of diarrhoea or vomiting, and did not mention the large mass in her stomach.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Man sues over boy that was not his son

fields.headline: Man sues over boy that was not his son
fields.trailText: A businessman was given the go-ahead yesterday to sue his former lover for deceit after discovering he was not the father of the boy he thought was his son.
fields.body:
A businessman was given the go-ahead yesterday to sue his former lover for deceit after discovering he was not the father of the boy he thought was his son.

The ground-breaking high court ruling allows the 53-year-old man to sue for damages for emotional distress and for the cost of maintaining the boy and his mother for the eight years they lived together.

The man's solicitor, now his wife, said he was claiming up to £250,000, to cover the cost of maintaining his former partner and her son, now 12, plus interest and an unquantified sum for emotional distress.

Neither the man, who is from the West Midlands, nor his former partner, who is aged 44 and lives in the north of England, can be identified because of a court order protecting the identity of the child.

The man had a vasectomy in 1975 and he and the woman started living together in 1984. In 1988 she had a son which he claims she led him to believe was his. His solicitor said he began to suspect the boy was not his because as he grew older he looked less like the man. In 1996, after the couple had parted, the man had an "unofficial" DNA test on a hair follicle from the boy and discovered he was not his son. The result was confirmed by an official test last year.

Lawyers for the boy's mother had argued that civil actions for deceit or fraud could not be brought in the context of cohabitation or marriage. Virtually all the decided cases involve commercial disputes. The English courts had never pronounced on the point but, citing US and Canadian cases, Mr Justice Stanley Burnton ruled that domestic partners could be sued for fraud.

The boy's mother, who has also married, said that she was disappointed that the case was allowed to go to trial.

Her solicitors said: "We consider it is simply wrong that a man can have a close and loving relationship with a woman for 13 years and her child for eight years and then seek to recover every penny he has ever paid out in respect of them.

"We believe that the deceit action is an attempt by the claimant to avoid his financial debt to the defendant in respect of the former family home, now standing at over £65,000."

The damages claim is expected to be heard before the end of the year. At that hearing the judge will decide whether there was a fraud and, if so, what if any damages the man should receive.

Mr Justice Stanley Burnton warned yesterday that his decision meant only that a claim could be brought. The man might not win damages even if deceit was established.

He had "considerable sympathy" for submissions by the woman's counsel that it would be "distasteful and morally offensive" for the man to get back all the money spent on the woman and her son. Awarding him the total sum would not take account of the fact that he had enjoyed their companionship for many years.

The judge began his judgment by recalling Richard Dehmel's poem, Verklarte Nachte (Transfigured Night), where a woman confesses to her lover that the baby with whom she is pregnant is not his. "He forgives her, and accepts the child as his own. In this case the opposite is alleged to have occurred."

Mark Harper, family law partner in the London solicitors firm Withers, said: "It seems like an Americanisation of English law. I don't see how it can help a couple resolve their differences amicably."

The boy's mother, who has also married, said that she was disappointed that the case was allowed to go to trial. Her solicitors said: "We consider it is simply wrong that a man can have a close and loving relationship with a woman for 13 years and her child for eight years and then seek to recover every penny he has ever paid out in respect of them. "We believe that the deceit action is an attempt by the claimant to avoid his financial debt to the defendant in respect of the former family home, now standing at over £65,000." The damages claim is expected to be heard before the end of the year. At that hearing the judge will decide whether there was a fraud and, if so, what if any damages the man should receive. Mr Justice Stanley Burnton warned yesterday that his decision meant only that a claim could be brought. The man might not win damages even if deceit was established. He had "considerable sympathy" for submissions by the woman's counsel that it would be "distasteful and morally offensive" for the man to get back all the money spent on the woman and her son. Awarding him the total sum would not take account of the fact that he had enjoyed their companionship for many years. The judge began his judgment by recalling Richard Dehmel's poem, Verklarte Nachte (Transfigured Night), where a woman confesses to her lover that the baby with whom she is pregnant is not his. "He forgives her, and accepts the child as his own. In this case the opposite is alleged to have occurred." Mark Harper, family law partner in the London solicitors firm Withers, said: "It seems like an Americanisation of English law. I don't see how it can help a couple resolve their differences amicably."

webTitle: Councils neglect to check air quality checks

fields.headline: Councils neglect to check air quality checks
fields.trailText: Councils in 33 towns and cities, including Liverpool and Luton, have failed to protect the public from polluting factories by not doing regular tests on air quality, the Department of Environment reveals.
fields.body:
Councils in 33 towns and cities, including Liverpool and Luton, have failed to protect the public from polluting factories by not doing regular tests on air quality, the Department of Environment reveals.

The councils are "named and shamed" by the ministry for only checking air quality once every two years instead of every six months. The authorities, however, are paid by firms to monitor air quality outside premises.

Checks in England and Wales cover 18,200 premises including chemical, asbestos, glass and rubber factories, iron and steel foundries, incineration plants, waste oil burners and petrol stations.

From 2004, a European directive will oblige councils to give up-to-date air pollution figures. Michael Meacher, the Environment minister, has already been insisting that two checks each year on factories.

The councils and port authorities with the lowest number of checks include Gosport, Manchester port harbour authority, Rutland, Barnet, East Devon, Guildford, Southend-on-Sea, Wokingham, Thanet and Tunbridge Wells. All had under 20 inspections last year.

Merlin Hyman, director of the environmental industries' commission, said: "These problems are undermining well run companies who want a level playing field."

webTitle: £3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs

fields.headline: £3m advert drive to promote MMR jabs
fields.standfirst: Medical establishment seeks to restore faith in vaccine
fields.trailText: A £3m advertising campaign to convince an alarmed public that the measles, mumps and rubella vaccination (MMR) is safe and necessary for children was announced by the government yesterday.
fields.body:
A £3m advertising campaign to convince an alarmed public that the measles, mumps and rubella vaccination (MMR) is safe and necessary for children was announced by the government yesterday.

The chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, called together medical organisations, including the Royal College of Nursing and the British Medical Association, to express their confidence in the vaccination in the face of claims that it could be linked to bowel disease and autism in certain susceptible children.

The three-year controversy over the MMR jab, given to babies at 18 months and followed by a pre-school booster, has surfaced again with a paper written by Andrew Wakefield from the inflammatory bowel disease study group at the Royal Free Hospital in London and a colleague.

In February 1998 Dr Wakefield and colleagues published papers in the Lancet describ ing a link between the live measles virus used in the vaccine, damage to the gut and autism. In the latest paper, to be published in the journal Adverse Drug Reactions, Dr Wakefield questions the clinical trials assessing the safety of the combined MMR vaccine before it was introduced in Britain in 1988.

He argues that the trials were not adequate and that evidence has been ignored that shows an interaction between the live viruses that go to make up the combined MMR. Children should be vaccinated against measles, but the government should make separate vaccines available.

Public health officials fear loss of confidence in the vaccination could lead to a fatal measles outbreak, as happened last year in Ireland and the Netherlands. Vaccination rates have dropped to 75% in some places - notably parts of London. The World Health Organisation says a 95% rate is desirable to prevent outbreaks.

The Department of Health stepped up the offensive against Dr Wakefield's theories yesterday with details of a four-week national advertising campaign, due to start in February and aimed at mothers of young children. A 20-minute information video will be made available in GP surgeries and libraries.

GPs, practice nurses and health visitors, some of whom have shown doubts about MMR, will also be targeted -30,000 information packs will be sent out, there will be "advertorials" in the medical press and seminars held around the country.

"We have had discussions today with all of the major health organisations in this country about the MMR vaccination programme," said Professor Donaldson. "Every single one of them agrees that the MMR vaccine is the safest and best way to protect children against measles, mumps and rubella.

"MMR is used successfully in over 30 countries and is the vaccine recommended by the World Health Organisation. On each occasion that these health scares are raised they have been thoroughly examined and on each occasion MMR has been given a clean bill of health."

He said the publicity campaign was intended to ensure people were given factual information about the vaccine. "Britain's record on childhood immunisation is envied around the world - we should not allow it to be undermined by bad science.

"Whenever there is a health scare, parents are left confused. They should be left in no doubt after today's summit that the advice from doctors, nurses and every major health organisation is that they should have their child vaccinated with MMR."

The professional institutions issued a statement confirming this was their view. "The paper adds little to current knowledge. Our professional confidence in the MMR vaccine, its safety and effectiveness remains fully justified - there is a large body of evidence showing that the combined vaccine is highly effective and serious side effects are uncommon."

webTitle: Witnesses wary of rail inquiry team

fields.headline: Witnesses wary of rail inquiry team
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Police and rail inspectors investigating the Hatfield rail crash have found some witnesses reluctant to give evidence to the inquiry team, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Police and rail inspectors investigating the Hatfield rail crash have found some witnesses reluctant to give evidence to the inquiry team, it emerged last night.

This reticence has been reported to the national rail recovery team, chaired by Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, and attended by senior managers from throughout the industry. Potential witnesses are bound by law to give evidence. Failure to do so could result in a prison sentence.

After Hatfield Railtrack carried out its own inquiry during which it is understood several staff refused to make statements.

Anthony Smith, national director of the national rail passengers' group, said last night that the public wanted the facts to be established so that something like Hatfield did not happen again. The desire to prosecute seemed to be getting in the way of a full investigation into the crash.

The government has ruled out a public inquiry into Hatfield on the grounds that it would get in the way of a criminal trial of those held responsible for the crash.

Official sources yesterday confirmed that corporate manslaughter charges could be laid against up to six senior executives at Railtrack and the maintenance company Balfour Beatty, which was responsible for the Hatfield site. It has since lost a new £250m contract.

Don Foster, Liberal Democrat spokesman, said: "It is not normal to have a full blown inquiry after every accident. On this occasion, the case was not made. But if there is a case to be made against Railtrack and Balfour Beatty, it must be done swiftly."

Mr Foster said the government should seriously consider the fact that rail accident prosecutions had failed due to inadequacies in the law. He said the law had to be overhauled and companies should be accountable for the safety of employees and customers.

The Home Office has been considering a change in legislation but there will not be time to act until after the election.

Railtrack is to be heavily criticised by an independent report into rail cracking, commissioned by the company after Hatfield. An inquiry team has examined the phenomenon of "gauge corner cracking", found at the Hatfield site.

The report will censure both Railtrack and its contractors for incompetence and negligence in dealing with the problem. It will advise Railtrack to establish a centrally controlled unit to co-ordinate work. Within days of Hatfield, 300 "serious" rail cracks were discovered by engineers.

 A train driver who ignored a red signal close to the site of the 1999 Paddington crash has been suspended. The Thames Trains turbo passed a red signal at Ladbroke Grove on December 5, on the same stretch of track as the crash which left 31 dead and 200 injured.

Railtrack confirmed it was holding an investigation into the incident in which a Paddington to Bedwyn train jumped a red light and passed a signal by half a coach length.

 An on-call Railtrack troubleshooter was taking a legitimate break when a member of the public videoed him asleep in his trackside office, Railtrack said yesterday. The manager was on call in case of emergencies along a 40-mile stretch of the Plymouth to Penzance line.

fields.headline: Organic only stance hurts Iceland
fields.trailText: The much-publicised decision by Iceland, the frozen food chain, to sell only organic food has received a chilly reception from shoppers.
fields.body:
The much-publicised decision by Iceland, the frozen food chain, to sell only organic food has received a chilly reception from shoppers.

During December the retailer's sales fell by 5.5%, which it blamed on a failure to sell as much organic food as it had expected.

While the company was selling its organic products at lower prices than rivals, they still cost more than Iceland shoppers were prepared to pay. At the same time, Iceland had compounded the problem by abandoning its "buy-one-get-one free" promotions which had been popular with its cost-conscious customers.

However, the inability of Iceland to tempt customers to buy organic exclusively was not interpreted as a sign that the scramble for organic produce was over. The market as a whole is predicted to grow each year by as much as 40%.

Bill Grimsey, Iceland's new chief executive and the man responsible for turning around the DIY retailer Wickes, said that organic food would remain in Iceland's chill cabinets but non-organic products would be re-introduced. Of the policy by the previous management to sell only organic produce, Mr Grimsey said: "It was clearly a very bold but premature thing to do".

When the strategy was announced in June, it was regarded as a public relations coup. Even though Iceland was late to embrace organic produce, it was the first retailer to throw out non-organic items altogether. It claimed to have bought 40% of the potential world supply of organic vegetables, but promised to take £8m off its profit margins to keep prices down for consumers. However, while that strategy has clearly backfired on Iceland, and caused a sharp fall in Iceland's share price yesterday, its rivals and retail experts did not write off the organic market.

Sainsbury's organic sales are growing every year. It has 1,000 organic products on offer, generating £3m a week. Waitrose also claims £2m of organic sales a week.

"Iceland mainly concentrates on frozen foods and it is the perishable items that are more likely to attract consumer interest," said an analyst from Verdict Research, the retail consultancy. Overall, Iceland admitted its sales had fallen 1.5% in the half year to the end of December.

Booker, the cash and carry group with which Iceland is merging, reported flat sales over the period but a 1% rise over the Christmas period.

webTitle: £2.6m award for child disabled by farm bacteria

fields.headline: £2.6m award for child disabled by farm bacteria
fields.trailText: A seven-year-old boy, brain damaged and disabled by the E coli bacteria he picked up on a school visit to a farm, was yesterday awarded agreed damages of £2.6m.
fields.body:
A seven-year-old boy, brain damaged and disabled by the E coli bacteria he picked up on a school visit to a farm, was yesterday awarded agreed damages of £2.6m.

Tom Dowling, who was four at the time of the accident in June 1997, needs round-the-clock care, cannot move his arms or legs, is fed by a tube through his stomach, and communicates by blinking, smiling and crying.

Tom's infection, and other less serious E coli incidents, have already brought about a review of health and safety guidance, but a growing number of scientists do not believe it advisable for children under five to be exposed to such risks. The Department of Health and the Department of Education have recommended increased supervision for younger pupils, but have been reluctant to advise any ban. However, a task force set up by the food standards agency and the Scottish executive is investigating whether more precautions are needed on all farmland that is open to the public.

A European committee has suggested that events from rock festivals to boot sales should not be held on pasture recently used by livestock. In 1999, there were 1084 recorded cases of infection by E coli 0157. Symptoms range from mild diarrhoea to big changes in the body's fluids.

Barnet education authority in north London and Bowman's Farms Ltd admitted 95% liability for Tom's injuries at a hearing a year ago. It heard that his case was the third at an open farm near St Alban's, Hertfordshire, within a few months, but the other children concerned had suffered far milder infections.

Tom's parents, Tracy and John, who are now separated, were in the high court in London to hear Bernard Livesey QC, for the education authority and farm, express "how sad" it was that Tom had suffered such injury. He goes to a special school in north London, having been a pupil at Edgware infants school at the time of the incident.

Jill Greenfield, the Dowlings' solicitor, said: "They think it is a good settlement but no amount of money can compensate for what has happened to Tom."

Barnet council, whose insurer is meeting 40% of the compensation costs, expressed regret for the "terrible consequences of a routine school visit".

Martin Kempson, Barnet's education director, said the authority had written to schools reminding them of safety guidance shortly before the "tragic incident".

The National Farmers' Union said precautions could be taken to reduce risks. A spokeswoman added that 12m people enjoyed visits to farms last year without incident.

webTitle: Posh tells how designer gear went awol

fields.headline: Posh tells how designer gear went awol
fields.trailText: She is more used to performing in front of adoring fans in concert halls across the world.
fields.body:
She is more used to performing in front of adoring fans in concert halls across the world.

But yesterday Victoria "Posh Spice" Beckham made a one-off appearance in the unglamorous setting of Isleworth crown court in west London.

Under strip lighting and in front of an audience of 12 jurors she was asked to describe how eight pieces of Louis Vuitton luggage, containing almost her whole wardrobe of designer clothes, went missing at Heathrow airport and the manner in which some of her valuables were recovered.

The court was treated to an insight into her lifestyle and a glimpse into her marriage with Manchester United footballer David Beckham.

There was even the odd moment of homespun philosophy about the relationship between women and their clothes as items of Mrs Beckham's clothing were paraded.

Mrs Beckham was giving evidence at the trial of 20-year-old Mark Oliver, unemployed. He is accused of stealing some of the clothes, which went missing as she returned from Miami last April.

The jury was told that she and her baby, Brooklyn, arrived back on a British Airways flight at Heathrow and transferred on to a British Midland flight to Manchester.

When she got there, four of her suitcases were missing. Mrs Beckham said that almost her entire wardrobe, as well as most of Brooklyn's clothes and many of his toys, had been in the cases.

But then a mysterious caller contacted her "nail technician", saying he had found some property belonging Mrs Beckham. Three or four days later these arrived in the post.

Among the items was a baby book with a blue velvet cover which contained a lock of Brooklyn's hair, some lyrics she had penned while in America, and copies of contracts.

The nail technician passed on a phone number for the caller, who turned out to be Oliver. Mrs Beckham phoned him. She told the court he claimed he had found two rubbish bags in the back of his dumper truck.

She said he claimed his friends had told him to sell the documents or post them on the internet but he had not done so because he had a conscience.

Mrs Beckham said she told him that if he found other items he should contact her security man.

She also told him about a silver picture frame containing a photograph of David with Brooklyn on his shoulders which her husband had given her. Oliver told her he was going back to the rubbish dump and Mrs Beckham should call him back five minutes later, she said.

When she rang back their conversation was, as the prosecution put it, a "pantomime". Mrs Beckham described how he had given the impression he was climbing over a wall into the tip. Within 30 seconds he had found the frame.

In June police officers searched the house of Oliver's parents and found Mrs Beckham's clothes in his sister Sadie's wardrobe.

Mrs Beckham was shown the clothes which were recovered. They included a Ralph Lauren denim jacket, three jackets by Plein Sud, and two glittery vest tops. But most attention was paid to a sparkly three-piece Ralph Lauren swimming costume - exhibit five.

The bikini top and sarong were recovered but the bikini bottoms remained missing. The prosecution pointed out, all the bottoms were missing.

Mrs Beckham estimated that they would be worth between £700 and £800 and pointed out that most had only been worn once or twice.

Oliver said he was not a "designer label" man. He insisted he found the items in bags left on the back of his truck. But he admitted that he had not gone back to the tip to hunt for the frame but into his parents' garage.

He said he had left them there because his mother did car boot sales. He admitted he had been excited to speak to Mrs Beckham.

Oliver also said that Mrs Beckham's security man had told him when he picked up the picture frame that he would not get a reward because she was a "bit tight".

Oliver said: "If I had known the clothing was Mrs Beckham's, I would have returned it to her."

Oliver, of Stanwell Village, Middlesex, denies theft and two alternative charges of handling stolen goods. The trial continues.

He admitted he had been excited to speak to Mrs Beckham. Oliver also said that Mrs Beckham's security man had told him when he picked up the picture frame that he would not get a reward because she was a "bit tight". Oliver said: "If I had known the clothing was Mrs Beckham's, I would have returned it to her." webTitle: Pilot sacked for being rude gets job back

fields.headline: Pilot sacked for being rude gets job back
fields.trailText: British Airways was yesterday ordered to reinstate a pilot who was sacked after he verbally abused a woman passenger who caused a bomb alert on his plane.
fields.body:
British Airways was yesterday ordered to reinstate a pilot who was sacked after he verbally abused a woman passenger who caused a bomb alert on his plane.

An employment tribunal in Croydon, south London, criticised BA's decision to dismiss Stewart Clapson, 54, for being "rude and abusive" to the woman, who falsely claimed that another passenger had a bomb on a jumbo jet about to take off from Gatwick for the island of Barbados on October 26 1999.

Captain Clapson, a BA captain for 17 years and a pilot with the airline for 30 years, was sacked after he allegedly made a speaker announcement on the plane saying that the person responsible for the bomb alert was a "stupid woman" who had ruined everybody's holiday by delaying the plane.

After taxiing off the runway he allegedly emerged from his cockpit shouting: "Where is she? Where is she?" before confronting the woman, pointing his finger in her face and reducing her to tears.

After being demoted to co-pilot with a salary reduction from £120,000 to £70,000, Capt Clapson, from East Molesey, Surrey, was dismissed after appealing.

The tribunal ruled that Capt Clapson should be reinstated had to the position he held immediately before he was sacked, which was co-pilot, and gave British Airways until May 1 to reinstate him.

Captain Clapson expressed relief after the hearing and hailed the decision as "an important victory for all airline captains who should not now have to worry about being second-guessed by executives on the ground in their handling of disruptive passengers".

A BA spokesman said after the hearing: "We are disappointed but at the same time we respect the decision of the tribunal."

webTitle: Scientists predict milder winters and an end to Europe's ski industry

fields.headline: A world of extremes as the planet hots up
fields.standfirst:
Scientists predict milder winters in Britain and an end to Europe's ski industry
Special report: global warming
Kyoto protocol in full
fields.trailText: As the intergovernmental panel on climate change set out yesterday, the Earth is warming faster than at any time in the last 10,000 years.
fields.body:
If the predictions in yesterday's report by leading climate scientists proved correct, millions living in Britain and other northern climes would gain from milder winters and a longer growing season but, further south, people would suffer the consequences of intense heatwaves that would kill many unused to extreme temperatures.

Insect pests would proliferate and there would be an increase in malaria; sun-seekers would find the Mediterranean too hot for holidays in July and August.

As the intergovernmental panel on climate change set out yesterday, the Earth is warming faster than at any time in the last 10,000 years and man is causing the increase by burning fossil fuels, cutting down forests and making changes in agriculture.

The changes predicted would cause coastal areas to be inundated and lead to major population changes. They would end the ski industry in Europe, cause the disappearance of many of the world's glaciers on which communities rely for regular summer water supplies, and have serious effects on agriculture.

The growing season for many of the staple crops in Africa would be cut too short for a reliable harvest because of excess heat and lack of moisture, and in Europe the Mediterranean fringe would be too dry for cereal crops. Many of the world's forests would die because of changes in water supply and the increasing heat.

Night-time average temperatures would increasingly leave much larger areas frost-free, leading to increases in insect life. Heatwaves would increase over all northern land areas and droughts, already observed to be increasing in Africa and Asia, would become more severe.

According to the report, nearly all land areas, including northern Europe, Asia and the United States, will warm far faster than average, possibly by as much as 8C.

Climate models worked out by giant super-computers have become far more reliable since the last report in 1995. This, combined with the climate changes observed over two decades, has convinced scientists that something very serious is happening and that it cannot be a natural process. There is far greater unanimity among the world's scientists over the issue than among politicians.

The floods in Britain and other parts of northern Europe are entirely consistent with climate-change predictions. There has been an increase of 2% in cloud cover but it is the rise in rainfall during heavier storms that has caused the floods. This is expected to get worse each decade.

A reduction in snow cover and in the area of sea ice in the Arctic has been seen since the late 60s and is expected to accelerate. In the same period the remaining ice in the Arctic ice cap has become 40% less thick.

A fall of two weeks in the annual duration of lake and river ice-cover in mid and high latitudes of the northern hemisphere has already been observed.

A widespread retreat of mountain glaciers is expected to continue. Most of the sea-level rise observed in the last century has been caused by the melting of glaciers in places such as the Alps and because of the thermal expansion of the oceans. So far the giant ice caps on Greenland and Antarctica have been slow to react, but this will change.

Although the amount of sea-level rise in this century is slightly less than predicted in 1992, the report emphasises that the process will go on for thousands of years because of the time taken for the giant ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica to react to increased temperatures.

Capitals drowned

Local warming over Greenland is likely to be one to three times the global average. If this warming were sustained, the complete melting of the Greenland ice cap would result in a rise in sea level of about seven metres (23ft), enough to drown all the major capitals of the world. A local warming of 5.5C would be likely to result in a contribution from Greenland of three metres to sea-level rise over 1,000 years.

If the West Antarctic ice sheet melted over the same period this would add another three metres to sea level.

One of the fears of scientists was that the flow of fresh water from the melting Greenland icecap would slow down or even halt the Gulf Stream, which warms Britain and the rest of Europe. The report says that while this may happen in the distant future, it is unlikely to have a serious effect this century.

The report says that the burning of fossil fuels is going to be "the dominant influence" on climate in the next century. As the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere increases, the ability of plant life on land and in the oceans to soak it up decreases. In 1750 the concentrations of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere were 280 ppm (parts per million). By 2000 the figure had increased 31%.

The report says the present carbon dioxide concentration has not been exceeded in the last 420,000 years and probably not for 20m years. It is now going up at the rate of 4% a decade and is expected to accelerate to reach 540ppm-970ppm by the end of the century. If it reaches the top of this range the temperature will rise up to 6C, two degrees higher than predicted five years ago.

The rate of warming is much higher than in the 20th century and at any time in the last 10,000 years since the ice age ended.

Methane concentrations have gone up 151% since 1750, partly due to fossil fuel burning, but also because of increase in rice culture and cattle, both of which generate methane from rotting vegetation. Landfill sites produce methane for the same reason but there are signs that these increases are levelling off.

Nitrous oxide, also a potent greenhouse gas, produced by industry, motor transport and agriculture continues to increase and concentrations have not been exceeded in 1,000 years.

Other attempts by man to reduce pollution for other reasons are now known to increase global warming. The complex atmospheric changes which cause the hole in the ozone layer also allow heat to escape from the Earth. If the ozone hole is mended, as scientists predict it will be, then the Earth will heat up faster than it otherwise would.

Stopping acid rain and reducing the burning of forests will also allow more heat to reach the Earth. This will partly be offset by an increase in tiny droplets of water from storms and spray but the net effect will be a warmer Earth.

webTitle: Press reports hurt Israeli leader's bid to soften his warrior image

fields.headline: The two faces of Ariel Sharon
fields.standfirst:
Press reports hurt Likud leader's bid to soften his warrior image
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The mask of a new-look Ariel Sharon, who is trying to re- package himself as a moderate rightwinger in Israel's prime ministerial election, slipped badly yesterday when newspapers seized on recent comments of his denouncing the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, as a liar and murderer.
fields.body:
The mask of a new-look Ariel Sharon, who is trying to re- package himself as a moderate rightwinger in Israel's prime ministerial election, slipped badly yesterday when newspapers seized on recent comments of his denouncing the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, as a liar and murderer.

Mr Sharon's remarks, circulated widely in the Israeli press in advance of their publication in the New Yorker yesterday, could torpedo the former general's efforts to shed his reputation as a restless warmonger ahead of the February 6 vote.

The reports coincide with claims by his far-right coalition allies in their campaign ads that if the Likud leader is elected he would launch missile attacks on Tehran - and possibly even Cairo - to keep the Muslim world at bay.

The far-right politician, Avigdor Lieberman, who has a following among Russian immigrants, also said that a Sharon government would reoccupy the Palestinian town of Beit Jala, if Palestinian gunmen open fire on the adjacent Jewish settlement of Gilo.

With two weeks to go until the vote, Mr Sharon is nearly 20 points ahead of the prime minister, Ehud Barak, in opinion polls. However, his minders will only feel assured of victory if he succeeds in expunging his military and political exploits from the Israeli collective memory.

Some 40% of Israeli voters are too young to remember the most notorious episodes from Mr Sharon's chequered past. As defence minister in 1982 he led Israel's invasion of Lebanon, which culminated in the massacre of hundreds of innocent Palestinians in a Beirut refugee camp.

In the 1950s he led a commando raid on the village of Kibiya, in the West Bank, which resulted in the massacre of 69 Palestinians, many of them women and children.

In the 1970s his feverish promotion of Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza earned him the nickname the "bulldozer".

These historical images are in sharp contrast to the Likud party's new slogan, which proclaims: "Only Sharon can bring peace". Campaign television advertisements show Mr Sharon, 72, dressed up as a cuddly figure playing with his grandchildren.

Yesterday, the Likud leader, who has famously refused to shake Mr Arafat's hand, said he would be willing to negotiate with the Palestinian leader, and that he has opened contacts with other Palestinian officials.

However, the comments published in the New Yorker diverge markedly from the new-look Sharon. In an interview last November before he was a prime ministerial contender, he told a reporter, Jeffrey Goldberg, that Mr Arafat was "a murderer and a liar. He's an enemy. He's a bitter enemy."

Mr Sharon expressed no remorse for a provocative visit to the holiest Muslim site in Jerusalem on September 28, which ignited the recent violence, in which 370 people have been killed.

"Look, I unmasked the Palestinians! That's what I did," he said.

He also mocked Muslim claims to the Haram al-Sharif, saying: "You know, the Koran doesn't mention Jerusalem once. When the Jews pray, all over the world, they face the Temple Mount. When an Arab prays, he prays to Mecca. Even when an Arab is on the Mount, his back is to it. Also some of his lower parts."

In a subsequent interview with Mr Goldberg this month, Mr Sharon tried to paint a different picture of himself, one of a national leader with his own strategy for negotiating with the Palestinians.

Although he has yet to reveal his peace plan in full, he has declared the Oslo peace process of the past seven years as dead and buried, and said he will not honour any agreement produced at the Israeli-Palestinian talks now under way in the Egyptian resort of Taba, on the Red Sea.

Instead, Mr Sharon forsees a series of interim agreements, with no further transfers of territory, and the Palestinians confined to the 42% of the West Bank that they currently control.

The exposure of the two faces of the Likud leader is a godsend for Mr Barak, whose dwindling band of supporters are fighting a desperate campaign to remind Israelis of the former general's past.

"For those who thought for a moment that Sharon had changed, the mask has blown up in our faces, and what has been revealed behind it is his true face," a statement from Mr Barak's campaign office said.

Their efforts got another boost yesterday when Mr Sharon was publicly confronted by an Israeli teenager who blamed him for her father's deep psychological scars from serving as a soldier in Lebanon.

webTitle: Greek bombing raises fears among foreign diplomats

fields.headline: Greek bombing raises fears among foreign diplomats
fields.standfirst: Athens accused of dragging its feet on security
fields.trailText: European Union diplomats in Athens complained yesterday that the Greek authorities are stalling on requests for security changes to protect embassy employees, made in the wake of the murder of Brigadier Stephen Saunders.
fields.body:
European Union diplomats in Athens complained yesterday that the Greek authorities are stalling on requests for security changes to protect embassy employees, made in the wake of the murder of Brigadier Stephen Saunders.

The delays are doing little to assuage growing doubts about Greece's ability to crack down on political violence and terrorism ahead of the 2004 Olympic Games in the capital.

Greece has long been regarded as a weak link in the international fight against terrorism. But foreign diplomats in Athens have become increasingly nervous since Sunday night, when a remote-controlled bomb injured Vassilios Michaloliakos, a rightwing member of parliament.

No group or person has claimed responsibility for the explosion, which left the opposition MP with facial and chest injuries. But police were yesterday investigating the possibility that it was the work of November 17, the elusive terrorist group responsible for the murder of Saunders, the British military attache in Athens, on June 8.

There have been no arrests nor firm leads during a 25-year spell of bombings, rocket attacks and shootings by the November 17 group, which has killed 22 people and injured more than 100.

The murder of Saunders sent a shock-wave through the diplomatic community here, prompting western and European embassies to begin an urgent review of their security measures.

Diplomats in Athens have been a frequent target for the group, which espouses an explosive mix of Marxism and extreme nationalism.

Foreign missions, however, have also borne attacks by other, less lethal, anti-western or anarchist fringe groups.

Diplomatic vehicles and those belonging to western businesses are regularly the target of firebombs; the Italian embassy has had eight cars set alight in the past two years.

European diplomats cite "bureaucratic foot-dragging" and "a lack of attention" by the Greek authorities in dealing with their safety concerns.

The British embassy, for example, is pressing for the relaxation of rules which limit the number of armour-plated cars permitted for personal protection; the car that Saunders was driving when he was murdered was not reinforced.

The Greek government allows one armoured car for every three diplomatic staff. Britain is thought to have asked for an extra three cars to add to their pool. Foreign embassies in London, by contrast, are allowed one armoured car for each diplomat.

Other embassies, including those of Germany, Belgium and Italy, have been frustrated by the progress of applications for Greek number plates, which would make their vehicles less of a target. They are also perplexed by the lack of clear guidelines on extra police guards for senior embassy staff.

"It does not give a good message," one EU diplomat said. "Security and safety is supposed to be the government's top priority. We don't doubt the Greek government's political will to fight terrorism, but they don't seem to be able to get their notorious bureaucracy moving. And that could be very dangerous for us."

Another European diplomat complained about Greek double standards. After the arrest of the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, in February 1999, Greek embassies in several European capitals were stormed by angry Kurds.

"Following that, we did everything we could to enhance the security around Greek embassies," he said. "But that helpfulness doesn't seem to have been reciprocated."

The Greek government has promised that a new law to fight terrorism will go before parliament next month. But anxious diplomats say that until arrests are made, no amount of legislating will convince them that Athens is winning the fight against terrorists.

webTitle: Trio of Asian leaders faces trying times

fields.headline: Trio of Asian leaders faces trying times
fields.trailText: One down, one tottering badly and another struggling even to get up: several south-east Asian leaders are having a tough time keeping the hounds at bay over corruption claims.
fields.body:
One down, one tottering badly and another struggling even to get up: several south-east Asian leaders are having a tough time keeping the hounds at bay over corruption claims.

But, as is the nature of politics in the region, neither Joseph Estrada in the Philippines, Abdurrahman Wahid in Indonesia nor Thaksin Shinawatra in Thailand are giving up without a fight.

Mr Estrada is undoubtedly in the least enviable position. Forced from office on Saturday by a peaceful popular uprising sparked by his rampant immorality and alleged corruption, his position worsened yesterday when prosecutors formally charged him with six offences, including perjury, graft, bribery, and economic plunder. The latter carries the death penalty, although few pundits feel the disgraced ex-actor will suffer such a fate.

Anticipating such a move, Mr Estrada pre-empted his accusers by issuing a terse statement saying that he had not resigned; he was merely unable to continue functioning as president and had therefore ceded temporary authority to his former deputy, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo.

Few people believe it will do him any good. "This is just the last-death throes of the Estrada administration," said former president Fidel Ramos.

Mr Wahid is proving equally feisty. Accused of involvement in two financial scandals that cost the state £4m, he yesterday faced up to his tormentors - a 50-strong panel of legislators - and treated them with contempt.

The panel expected the half-blind Muslim cleric who became Indonesia's first democratically elected president in October 1999, to submit to questioning, but he refused and stormed out after 30 minutes. Such maverick behaviour has become a trademark of the Wahid presidency, but opposition is mounting and impeachment is a real possibility. Crucially, unlike Mr Estrada, Mr Wahid still has the support of his vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri.

Mr Thaksin, whose Thais Love Thais party won the first-ever majority in the lower house, might never experience such travails. Not only are more than 50 of the 500 constituencies having to hold new ballots, due to extensive claims of vote-buying, but Mr Thaksin is under investigation for a false declaration of assets.

Mr Thaksin described such alleged transgressions as a genuine mistake. He said the investigations should cease ecause Thais had known about the allegations and had voted for him in record numbers. The constitutional court could take months to reach a verdict, leaving the country in limbo.

fields.headline: Céline manuscript rediscovered
fields.trailText: The original manuscript of one of the most influential and disturbing masterpieces of 20th-century literature has resurfaced after being missing for more than 50 years.
fields.body:
The original manuscript of one of the most influential and disturbing masterpieces of 20th-century literature has resurfaced after being missing for more than 50 years.

French researchers had spent 20 years trying to track down the 876-page manuscript of Journey to the End of the Night, written in black ink and crayon by Louis-Ferdinand Céline. Their hunt ended this month when a Parisian bookseller said he had been contacted by an anonymous British collector asking him to sell the manuscript for him.

The bookseller, Pierre Bers, refused to identify the collector or explain why the manuscript had wound up in his hands.

The manuscript was last seen on May 29 1943 when the sick and impoverished writer sold it to a Parisian art dealer for Fr10,000 (£970), along with a small painting by Renoir.

The manuscript could fetch up to £500,000 under auction at Piasa in Paris in April.

"Its reappearance, after 50 years of mystery, is a literary bomb, as explosive as the book's original publication in 1932," said literary critic Valerie Duponchelle of Le Figaro newspaper.

A writer and doctor, Céline (1894-1961) was one of the most controversial Frenchmen of his day - a war hero, anti-semite and Nazi sympathiser, dubbed during his lifetime as "a writer created by God to scandalise".

Journey to the End of the Night (1932) was his first novel, and an immediate success. A coruscating critique of modern society, war and mass production, the book was written in earthy, contemporary French vernacular.

Its modern anti-hero had much in common with Céline. Indeed, the book covered the author's life from 1913 to 1932 - from the trenches in the first world war (Céline was seriously wounded at Ypres), to running a trading post in Africa and working on a Ford assembly line in Detroit.

Typical of the book's bleakness is this passage: "In this world we spend our time killing or adoring, or both together. 'I hate you! I adore you!' We keep going, we fuel and refuel, we pass on our life to a biped of the next century."

His second novel, Death on the Installment Plan (1935), was also a success.

During the war, he was denounced on the BBC as a traitor and fled to Berlin. In 1951, he was permitted to return but his new works were badly received.

Bearing similarities to Samuel Beckett or Thomas Bernhard, Céline's works have influenced writers such as Henry Miller, Kurt Vonnegut and William Burroughs.

fields.headline: Prestwick stake sold for £33m
fields.trailText: Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, yesterday sold off its holding in Prestwick airport, near Glasgow, for £33m to a team of Scottish businessmen.
fields.body:
Stagecoach, the bus and train operator, yesterday sold off its holding in Prestwick airport, near Glasgow, for £33m to a team of Scottish businessmen.

Omniport, based in Scotland and backed by an Australia-based investment group and the Royal Bank of Scotland, plans to create a chain of regional airports.

Bill Barr, its chairman, said that emerging market conditions in Europe and the US presented the company with an "immense opportunity" to create a regional airports business centred in Scotland.

Stagecoach, which bought the airport in 1998, said that it was selling off Prestwick to con centrate on its bus and train operation. The sale includes the repayment of £7m debt.

Stagecoach suffered a big commercial blow when Fedex, the American freight carrier, was refused landing rights at Stansted and subsequently pulled out of Prestwick.

Stagecoach has spent £10m on the airport. Traffic has been steadily improving. The low cost carrier, Ryanair, uses it, and 900,000 passengers passed through it last year. Martin Griffiths, Stagecoach's financial director, said that Prestwick would not be thriving today without Stagecoach. The sale of the airport was consistent with its strategy of focusing on road and rail.

The Prestwick acquisition is the starting point for Omniport's wider ambitions. It is already the preferred bidder for a management contract to run Pease airport in Boston.

fields.headline: Software firms fear hard landing
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Results will point to trend in fragile market
fields.trailText: Britain's battered software sector will this week start to discover whether concerns about a slowdown in IT spending have been overblown. On Thursday Misys, the financial services-focused software supplier, kicks off a raft of fourth-quarter 2000 earnings announcements scheduled to include updates from Autonomy, Baltimore and London Bridge Software.
fields.body:
Britain's battered software sector will this week start to discover whether concerns about a slowdown in IT spending have been overblown. On Thursday Misys, the financial services-focused software supplier, kicks off a raft of fourth-quarter 2000 earnings announcements scheduled to include updates from Autonomy, Baltimore and London Bridge Software.

The corresponding period last year gave impetus to one of the strongest bull runs in the sector's history but a widespread valuation correction has hit every important technology stock over the past three months.

Europe's leading software firms lost 40% of their value over the last quarter, according to Credit Suisse First Boston. The European IT services sector, which includes the likes of Logica and Sema, has fallen in value by almost two-thirds since its peak last march, UBS Warburg says.

A year ago Misys, the business software company, was a darling of the stock market with shares touching £13.70. Yesterday they fell a further 9.5p to 660p - after Lehman Brothers said the company faced challenging second-half targets to meet its expectations.

The internet boom which fuelled rises in high technology stock has evaporated. Security expert Baltimore's stock is off 70% from its high and shares in Autonomy - the intelligent software company led by Mike Lynch - were once worth more than £45 but are now trading at £23.40. Analysts say that the gloss has steadily been wiped off as dot.coms have gone to the wall - erasing large potential markets for e-commerce.

All this turbulence has hit punters hard. While some investors made fortunes out of the software and IT sector last year, others failed to cash in their chips before the slump.

Aside from the bursting of the Nasdaq bubble, the slide has not been helped by concerns about the wider economy and slowing growth forecasts. Investors fear that if a recession really does bite, highly valued software stocks will be one of the first to suffer.

The US Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates may increase investors' appetite for risk and their confidence in technology stocks - but the omens are not good. A recent InformationWeek survey of IT executives found that they expect IT spending growth to slow from 11% in 2000 to 7% this year.

CSFB analyst David Clayton is cautious. "Providing the recent bumps in the economy do not lead to a full-blown recession, IT spending should continue to grow - but at a much slower pace than in 2000," he said.

UBS Warburg says that companies providing basic software solutions to big businesses - packages such as database management systems and financial accounting systems - should perform in line with the broader macroeconomic trend. "Hardest hit should be areas that do not form part of the core IT infrastructure ... like e-commerce applications targeted at specific ar eas such as online sales and e-procurement software," the bank warns.

UBS Warburg is bullish about the growth rates for firms offering customer relationship management, IT security and knowledge management products.

Recent positive comments from Logica and Sema suggest that revenue growth is starting to return after the millennium bug-induced spending clampdown but there is still a risk of customers delaying decisions on orders until the wider economic picture becomes clearer. The underlying argument remains that new technologies coming onto the market could fundamentally change for the better the way business operates. But, for investors, do the potential short-term returns outweigh the risks of piling into tech stocks? UBS Warburg says "the sector does not yet offer good value", particularly if investors are looking for returns of more than 10%.

Companies with strong sales channels and experienced and conservative management teams look the safest bet over the next nine to 12 months. UBS Warburg recommends Autonomy, Logica, Guardian IT, SurfControl and Orchestream. Merrill Lynch rates Morse a long-term buy.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Cars | Cendant | Sabena | Celltech | Babcock
fields.body:
December dip hits car output

A disastrous December led to the number of cars produced in Britain last year dipping by 8.8% to 1.63m, official figures indicate. December saw 97,000 cars produced - 32.3% down on the same month in 1999 total, the office for national statistics said.

In the six months ending December 2000, total car production fell by 22.9% compared with the previous six months. Commercial vehicle production last year fared somewhat better - with numbers falling only 0.9% to 184,000.

Total commercial vehicle production for the six months ending December 2000 was 31.5% down on the previous six months.

"In the short-term, things are not looking good, but in the long-term things are positive with Jaguar, Land Rover and Toyota among companies set to increase production," a spokesman for the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said.

Cendant adds Cohen to board

Cendant Corporation, the world's largest hotel franchiser, said yesterday that it has named former US secretary of defence William Cohen to its board of directors.

The New York company said Mr Cohen, 60, was elected to join the board immediately, which will bring the board's number of directors to 14 and the number of outside directors to 11.

EC looks at Sabena subsidy

The European commission is to study a recapitalisation plan for troubled Belgian airline Sabena to see whether planned subsidies by Belgium's government could be classified as unfair state aid.

The Belgian government, which owns 51% of Sabena and has in the past pumped large sums of money into the loss-making carrier, said on Saturday that it had reached an agreement in principle to contribute €100m (£64m) to Sabena's recapitalisation. Switzerland's SAirGroup, which owns SwissAir and controls 49% of Sabena, would inject €150m.

Celltech strikes US drug deal

Britain's biggest biotechnology company, Celltech, has struck a deal with the US firm Johnson & Johnson to develop drugs which cut off the supply of blood to cancer tumours.

Under the deal, Johnson & Johnson will take on development of the drugs, which are in laboratory trials, in return for an advance payment and royalties on future sales.

The news sent Celltech's shares up 66p to £13.28, after a sharp rise last week amid excitement at an auction for the company's new arthritis treatment - which four companies, including Glaxo SmithKline, are vying to buy.

Babcock in MOD tie-up

Engineering services firm Babcock International is to sign a memorandum of understanding with the Ministry of Defence on possible involvement in the warship support programme. The agreement, to be signed tomorrow, is for possible partnering arrangements between Babcock Rosyth and the Clyde naval base to supply engineering maintenance and support to the fleet.

fields.headline: Recovery in the second half
fields.trailText: To borrow that old football cliché, it was a game of two halves for the London market yesterday. Pushed down in the first half of the session by a lower than expected flotation price for Orange and a profits warning from PC maker Dell, leading shares turned around in mid-afternoon as Wall Street recovered its poise after a jittery opening.
fields.body:
To borrow that old football cliché, it was a game of two halves for the London market yesterday. Pushed down in the first half of the session by a lower than expected flotation price for Orange and a profits warning from PC maker Dell, leading shares turned around in mid-afternoon as Wall Street recovered its poise after a jittery opening.

According to traders, US investors are increasingly looking through bad news like that from Dell and focusing on the lift falling US interest rates should give to equities. This is giving the London market some much needed confidence.

At full time, the FTSE 100 was showing a gain of 22.7 points to 6,232 - a good performance considering it hit 6,162.9 at one point. A strong showing from banking stocks like Standard Chartered , up 43p to £10.84 on the back of a Deutsche Bank upgrade, and Royal Bank of Scotland , 40p better at £16.20, delivered most of the upside.

The FTSE TechMark 100 index was down 12.99 points at 2,774.66 and the FTSE mid 250 index was off 10.5 points at 6,701.4.

Market turnover was disappointing - just 1.9bn shares by 6pm - reflecting the fact many institutions want to hear what Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says to the senate budget committee on Thursday before making any moves. Coming just days before the next Fed meeting, Mr Greenspan's testimony will be closely monitored for any clues about the size and timing of the next rate cut.

It was no surprise to see telecom stocks across Europe head lower after the pricing for the Orange float came in at a 20% discount to most analysts' expectations. A number of telecom companies, including BT and KPN, are looking to spin off their mobile phone operations this year, primarily to cut debt built up in the third-generation licence auctions last year.

BT fell 6p to 698p, while Vodafone lost 4.5p to 231.5p, as analysts revalued the company to reflect the Orange price tag. As if to prove the point, Goldman Sachs slashed its price target on Vodafone to 320p from 460p.

Commenting on the downgrade it said: "The reduction reflects the reality of a market which, post-3G licence costs surprise and fall in tech stocks, is pricing cellular assets more conservatively."

On the speculative front, BG moved up 3.75p to 263.75p as the north American takeover tale took a fresh twist. According to weekend press reports it is US group Phillips Petroleum which could be stalking BG. According to industry watchers Phillips is about the same size as BG, so a merger of equals and not a 325p-a-share bid would be the most likely structure of any deal.

In the meantime, another takeover favourite, Powergen , was being driven high by reports that ScottishPower , up 7p to 429p, and RWE are potential buyers of the electricity company alongside Germany's E.ON. Analysts at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney think Powergen, 23p better at 718p, will not sell out for anything less than 800p.

Celltech , Britain's biggest biotech, topped the blue-chip performers chart, with a rise of 66p to £13.28, which came after news of an alliance with US drug maker Johnson & Johnson to develop cancer drugs.

IT services group Misys was going the other way, off 9.5p at 660.5p, after Lehman Brothers said it would not be surprised if the company issued downward guidance to earnings forecasts when it announced interms on Thursday.

In the mid-cap universe, health care firm Medisys was again the worst performer. It followed Friday's 10% drop with a fall of 21p, or 17.72%, to 97.5p yesterday as analysts continued to lower forecasts in reaction to news of a later-than-expected US launch for its Futura safety syringe.

Dealers said Medisys's broker, Nomura, had lowered its 2002 profits forecast to £10.6m from £26.7m previously.

Travel promotions company Landround added 22p to 297p with private client brokers pushing the stock after the company made an upbeat presentation on Friday.

webTitle: Persimmon set to takeover Beazer housebuilders

fields.headline: Housebuilders change bid partners
fields.standfirst: Beazer forced into Persimmon's arms after Taylor Woodrow snaps up Bryant
fields.trailText: Beazer, the housebuilder, looks ready to fall to a £528m bid from rival Persimmon after confirmation yesterday of an agreed £536m takeover of its proposed partner Bryant Group by Taylor Woodrow.
fields.body:
Beazer, the housebuilder, looks ready to fall to a £528m bid from rival Persimmon after confirmation yesterday of an agreed £536m takeover of its proposed partner Bryant Group by Taylor Woodrow.

Beazer and Bryant had planned to merge under the Domus banner but this plan was scrapped when Bryant accepted an increased offer of 80p cash plus 0.72 new Taylor Woodrow shares for each Bryant share.

Persimmon is expected to firm up its own indicative offer of 92.5p cash plus 0.349 new Persimmon shares for each Beazer share within the next 48 hours.

Jobs will be on the line because Persimmon promised to deliver £20m of annual cost savings when it put forward its initial proposals last week.

Beazer, whose shares fell 4p to 179p at close last night, said it was evaluating the offer but warned there could be no guarantee of a firm takeover bid from Persimmon whose shares were down 3.5p at 261p. Analysts said Beazer was weaker than ever following the decision by Bryant to go elsewhere.

Mark Hake, building analyst with Merrill Lynch, said: "Beazer has no other options unless someone else steps in with a higher offer [than Persimmon] at this very late stage and I do not see that happening. Persimmon might have to pay slightly more cash or an offer of say £550m."

Taylor Woodrow's offer to create Britain's fifth biggest housebuilder was priced at £556m on the basis of Friday's close. But the offer was worth £20m less at close of trade last night as Taylor Woodrow's shares slid 12p to 165p, while Bryant's rose 3.5p to 195.5p.

Some Taylor Woodrow shareholders were claiming dissatisfaction with the price of the proposed Bryant takeover but analysts said there was not much chance of their rejecting the deal.

Taylor Woodrow believed it can squeeze cost savings and margin improvements of up to £15m annually, without major job losses, a spokesman said.

He explained: "This agreement is not about downsizing. The two companies are a very complimentary fit. There will be savings from bringing together two headquarters but most of the savings will come through increased purchasing power and operational integration."

Hubert Reid, chairman of Bryant, said he strongly believed in the need to improve quality that would have resulted from Domus but added: "Taylor Woodrow's superior offer now represents superior value for our shareholders and a further opportunity to pursue improvements in quality and productivity."

Mr Hake said the latest flurry of consolidation activity inside the housebuilding sector had only just begun. "I think we will see one or two more deals between middle ranking housebuilders over the next 12 months," he said.

webTitle: Down at heel Converse files for bankruptcy protection

fields.headline: Down at heel Converse files for bankruptcy protection
fields.trailText: Converse, the American sports shoe manufacturer that dared to challenge the mighty Nike, yesterday filed for bankruptcy protection.
fields.body:
Converse, the American sports shoe manufacturer that dared to challenge the mighty Nike, yesterday filed for bankruptcy protection.

It plans to end manufacturing and close three north American plants with the loss of about 1,000 jobs.

Made famous by its light-weight basketball boots, Converse recently sought to take on Nike's successful "Air" range producing a trainer filled with "lighter than air" helium.

Based in North Reading, Massachusetts, the company has filed for protection under chapter 11 of the US bankruptcy code and said that it expects to have the necessary financing to continue operations while it restructures.

Converse has signed an agreement with Global Brand Marketing Inc to license Converse-brand footwear in the US. "When royalty income from GBMI is added to that of our existing licensing agreement, Converse will be generating a substantial stream of royalty income," said chief executive Glenn Rupp.

The company said it would close three manufacturing plants in north America by March and shift production to suppliers in Asia. It will cut about 1,000 jobs at the plants in the US and Mexico. Converse has already sold its factory in North Reading for $15.1m (£10.3m).

Converse said it has signed a credit facility with a lenders led by Bankers Trust, a subsidiary of Deutsche Bank Alex Brown, which will allow it to use cash generated from continuing operations and free up funds necessary to meet supply and sales obligations.

webTitle: Glynwed  to concentrate on making Aga cookers

fields.headline: Glynwed casts cookers as lead in Aga saga
fields.trailText: Glynwed International, the Midlands engineer, has sold the bulk of its business to concentrate on making Aga and Rayburn cookers.
fields.body:
Glynwed International, the Midlands engineer, has sold the bulk of its business to concentrate on making Aga and Rayburn cookers.

The company will change its name to Aga Foodservice Group and plans a marketing drive to sell the icons of middle class country kitchens in British cities and overseas. More than 700,000 Agas have been sold to figures including Paul McCartney and Bill Gates, and the novels of Joanna Trollope have been critically dismissed as Aga sagas.

A store selling the cookers will open in Knightsbridge, London, and the company will also offer its kitchenware, refrigeration products and food services on the web.

Tony Wilson, Glynwed chief executive, said the Aga brand had not received the deserved exposure because it had been dwarfed by the group's other business. This would be remedied by selling the pipe systems business to a privately-owned Belgian group, Etex, for £786m. Mr Wilson will move with the heavy engineering side which was three times bigger than the cooker division.

Aga, which in 1999 made operating profits of £19.4m on sales of £192.8m, will come under the control of finance director William McGrath.

Analysts said there should be a good future for the small but well-focused business.

Aga was bought from Sweden by Glynwed 40 years ago. The enamel cast iron stove was designed by Dr Gustaf Dalen, a physicist and Nobel prize winner who lost his sight in 1922 during an experiment with pressurised gases. Confined to home, he combined a small and efficient heat source, two large hotplates and two generous ovens, into one robust unit.

Glynwed will hand back nearly £400m of the pipes sale price to shareholders. The rest will be used to pay off Aga debt and leave it with cash for acquisitions.

Mr Wilson said Glynwed had led the way in consolidating the pipe production sector but more restructuring was needed. "Given the sentiment on the UK stockmarket we could not keep on heaping up the debt [needed for takeovers]. We would have liked to have done more. It is frustrating but this deal is good for everyone - employees and shareholders."

In November, Glynwed delivered what was interpreted as a profits warning and said it was undertaking a strategic review to ensure shareholders received full value. The deal with Etex needs clearance from shareholders and regulators both in Europe and north America. Completion is expected in March.

Shares in Glynwed, which have outperformed the engineering and machinery sector by 25% in the past 12 months, rose nearly 9% in early trading yesterday before dropping back to close up 11p at 231p.

The deal price was considered good for Glynwed and some analysts said it confirmed Mr Wilson's belief that negative sentiment about engineers on the stockmarket was leading to some gems being overlooked.

Glynwed has spent the past three years concentrating on just two divisions and raised more than £300m from disposals while spending £500m on acquisitions. The pipes division made £67.3m operating profits on sales of £607.3m.

Analysts said Glynwed's move would increase pressure on other mid-size engineering companies to come up with imaginative ways of creating more value.

webTitle: Atlantic sacks 350 to refocus on small business market

fields.headline: Atlantic sacks 350 to refocus on small business market
fields.trailText: Scottish telecoms operator Atlantic Telecom sacked 350 staff - a third of its workforce - from its London and Aberdeen offices yesterday, saying they were no longer needed as the company is shifting its focus.
fields.body:
Scottish telecoms operator Atlantic Telecom sacked 350 staff - a third of its workforce - from its London and Aberdeen offices yesterday, saying they were no longer needed as the company is shifting its focus.

The company said the cuts would help it save £30m next year and ensure it starts seeing positive cash flow earlier than analysts' predictions of 2004.

Atlantic, which uses radio signals to connect to the fixed-line network - bypassing the local loop - decided last year to concentrate on the more lucrative small business market, rather than focusing on residential customers.

Chief executive Graham Duncan said the redundancies were mainly from the company's residential sales and support groups. "We announced this change of strategy nine months ago," he said.

"But these things take time. We've looked very critically at the cost base, and the huge change in valuations of telcos. We must assure the cost base is in line with our strategy."

Atlantic's share price rose 5% on the news to 115p.

As of December 31, Atlantic held cash reserves of £190m, with losses in the first half of 2000 reaching £53.5m.

"We do have a great deal of cash available," said Mr Duncan. "In this climate, the route to profitability and amount of cash is very important."

Total revenue reached £30m in the first half of 2000, but At lantic is investing heavily in building up its network in the UK, the Netherlands, and Germany, its main target markets.

Atlantic follows smaller European operators such as Viatel and Redstone, which are cutting jobs or scaling back their expansion plans to move into profit sooner.

It is almost impossible for such companies to raise money in the debt and equity markets because of the change in sentiment that triggered the slump in technology and telecoms shares.

"As much as there might be optimism over the price of raising fresh funds with US interest rates falling, in reality a lot of operators have cut back their business plans," said Investec analyst Christian Maher.
