webTitle: Klein seals peace with a kiss

fields.headline: Klein seals peace with a kiss
fields.trailText: A kiss on the cheek ended fashion's most talked about feud yesterday as designer Calvin Klein settled his acrimonious trademark dispute with Linda Wachner, head of clothing manufacturer Warnaco.
fields.body:
A kiss on the cheek ended fashion's most talked about feud yesterday as designer Calvin Klein settled his acrimonious trademark dispute with Linda Wachner, head of clothing manufacturer Warnaco.

The financial details were not disclosed but both sides professed themselves happy that a court battle expected to last four weeks and to generate acres of negative newsprint had been dismissed within minutes of the case opening.

Speaking outside the Manhattan courtroom, Mr Klein told the Guardian: "The agreement is confidential, but all I can tell you is that I am very happy."

Ms Wachner, who owns 20% of Warnaco, appeared equally relieved that the eight-month legal battle was over. "It's good for the brand and good for business," she said.

Mr Klein had sued Ms Wachner and her firm for breaching the terms of a contract to produce and sell his jeans and hurting the value of his brandname. After he called her a "cancer" in his lawsuit, and vulgar on primetime television, Ms Warnaco countersued.

Things turned even nastier last week when Mr Klein launched a separate attempt to have the licence terminated because of Warnaco's heavy debt burden and falling share price. Warnaco shares have fallen from $13.50 (£9.22) to a low of $1.25 since May. Yesterday, they rose almost $1 on the news to more than $3.

Mr Klein appeared to have won his battle against Warnaco's use of discount retailers to sell his jeans.

A joint statement said: "The parties look forward to expanding jeanswear sales consistent with the image and prestige of the Calvin Klein products and to expanding and concentrating the distribution of Calvin Klein jeanswear products in department and specialty stores."

The licensing agreement is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to both sides. The statement added that settlement would "protect and promote the integrity and success of the Calvin Klein brand for their mutual benefit and the benefit of other Calvin Klein licensees".

People familiar with the matter suggested tensions became particularly acute after Mr Klein tried to sell his company last year and found buyers unwilling to take on the long-term agreement. Mr Klein denied that the settlement had changed his mind over a possible sale. "The company is not for sale," he said.

Both claim and counter-claim were settled yesterday. However, last week's filing in a state court has been postponed rather than settled outright, according to David Boies, attorney for Mr Klein. Warnaco has been given a year to bring its debt to equity ratio within the terms of the licence.

Both sides seemed slightly surprised that a deal had been reached. Mr Klein referred to "not just 11th hour but 11.59".

Even the clothes the protagonists wore to court appeared to suggest the gulf between them. The 58-year-old Mr Klein arrived in a grey suit with matching shirt and tie. Ms Wachner, aged 54, wore a leopard-print scarf over a baggy black jacket and sported red-framed glasses.

There was some regret among the lawyers that the trial had been aborted.

Mr Boies said: "This was going to be a good case. [It involved] fascinating people, an interesting industry, charges and counter-charges. But the fact of the matter is that we are in the trial business and Calvin Klein, Barry Schwartz and Linda Wachner are in the jeanswear business and fundamentally what's best for business has got to take precedence."

fields.headline: Dell issues profit warning
fields.standfirst: Gloomy news from Bush's friend conrms fears of faltering economy
fields.trailText: Dell Computers, one of the world's largest personal computer manufacturers, yesterday joined the queue of hi-tech companies warning of faltering demand and reduced earnings and profits.
fields.body:
Dell Computers, one of the world's largest personal computer manufacturers, yesterday joined the queue of hi-tech companies warning of faltering demand and reduced earnings and profits.

Following similar gloomy signals on slowing computer sales in recent weeks from Apple, Hewlett-Packard and Gateway, Dell announced it had slashed its earnings expectations for the three months to the end of January to 18-19 cents per share, down from its previous estimate of 26 cents (17.7p).

The company founded by 35-year-old Michael Dell - a friend of George Bush - added to the rain on the former Texas governor's inauguration parade, only one day after he entered to the White House, blaming "deterioration in global economic conditions and overall demand" for the weaker earnings figures.

The news also cast a pall over the start of Wall Street's working week. Dell's shares slipped more than 6% to $24 in early trading, down by more than $1 compared with Friday's closing price on the New York markets.

The Nasdaq and Dow Jones share indices also made early losses, as the warning from the world's second largest PC maker dragged down the rest of the equity market.

Wall Street analysts are now waiting to see if the poor run of results for the sector at the end of last year is being repeated in sales and performance for the first quarter of this year.

Dell said it expected its fourth-quarter revenues to rise at least 25% from a year earlier, to between $8.5bn and $8.6bn, slightly below its previous estimate of $8.7bn, made back in November.

Jim Schneider, the company's chief financial officer, said that the magnitude of the economic slowdown at the end of last year "has been greater than anyone expected". But a strategy of aggressive price cuts had helped bolster Dell's unit sales.

"Had we not taken that action it is likely that revenues for the quarter would have been significantly lower," he said.

The company attempted to paint the earnings warning in a positive light, pointing to encouraging growth in market share, and robust sales of computer notebooks and internet servers.

Mr Schneider said Dell expected to see its unit sales rise by 40% year-on-year for the fourth quarter, which is likely to be four times faster than growth in the overall market.

Analysts expect PC sales - which ran at 20% growthlast year - to fall to single digits growth this year.

Mr Dell hinted that the company was prepared to aggressively cut its costs to maintain its sales growth.

"We are bringing the full competitive force of our direct business model to bear on the marketplace to benefit customers, accelerate market-share gains and position Dell for profitable, long-term growth," he said. "We intend to succeed on all counts."

Despite the faltering earnings figures, Mr Dell remains the wealthiest businessman in Austin, Texas, where the company is housed on two huge campuses. Mr Dell lives in a third campus in Austin, a 33,000 sq-ft compound known as "the castle". When local tax officials attempted to gauge the value of the walled compound they were refused entry. They hired a plane and used aerial photographs to value the property at $35m - although Mr Dell had it reduced to $11m on appeal.

fields.headline: Windows set for $220m ad spend
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft is gearing up to spend about $220m (£150m) on marketing its Windows 2000 computer operating system - almost one year after the product was launched.
fields.body:
Microsoft is gearing up to spend about $220m (£150m) on marketing its Windows 2000 computer operating system - almost one year after the product was launched.

The company yesterday announced plans to spend the money on boosting its latest operating system for networked PCs and web servers, which first went on sale in February last year.

Last week Microsoft reported sales of Windows 2000 totalling $2.06bn in the second quarter of last year, with the company claiming that the package had "gained momentum".

However, slower-than-expected take-up among Microsoft's business clients has seen the company attempt to entice users, especially in the high-end server market presently dominated by its rivals, Sun Microsystems and IBM.

"This is a case where our marketing has actually lagged some way behind our products and delivery," Mike Delman, Microsoft's general manager of advertising and events, said.

The company also intends to roll out its revised Windows operating system entitled Whistler, which is a desktop version of the Windows 2000 system for individual PC users.

The splash of spending on Windows 2000 will be dwarfed later in the year by the start of the estimated $500m international marketing launch of Microsoft's X-Box video games console.

The company also intends to roll out its revised Windows operating system entitled Whistler, which is a desktop version of the Windows 2000 system for individual PC users. The splash of spending on Windows 2000 will be dwarfed later in the year by the start of the estimated $500m international marketing launch of Microsoft's X-Box video games console.

fields.headline: Orange courts public at cut-price £41bn
fields.trailText: France Telecom and Orange executives took the stage in London and Paris yesterday to announce the details of Orange's initial public offering.
fields.body:
France Telecom and Orange executives took the stage in London and Paris yesterday to announce the details of Orange's initial public offering.

The French company opened a share offer for up to 15% of Orange at between 733p and 860p per share, valuing Europe's second biggest mobile phone group at £35.2bn to £41.3bn.

Through a combination of shares and exchangeable bonds, France Telecom said it would raise nearly £8bn in the offering, off-setting the £24bn it paid for Orange last summer.

Deputy chief executive Gra ham Howe pointed to Orange's promising earnings as a gauge of how well investors would approach the offering.

Orange's ebitda - earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation - jumped to €906m (£580m) in the first half of last year, as compared with €919m for the whole of 1999, Mr Howe said.

Chris Godsmark, telecoms analyst at Investec, said that the ebitda of Orange is ahead of its rival, Vodafone.

Despite this lead over the market leader, Mr Godsmark thought Orange's shares were still too dear. "We think the Orange discounted [share] price is still high," Mr Godsmark said. "The issue is going to be to what extent people are prepared to pay a premium to Vodafone."

Orange is courting retail as well as institutional investors by offering a discount to interested private parties who sign up through its website or HSBC bank branches. Mr Howe announced a television advertising campaign that will run in France, Germany, Italy, and the UK. The campaign promotes Orange's upcoming next-generation mobile phone services as well as the share offering, set for February 12.

Although the price is considerably lower than France Telecom had intended when it bought Orange, early demand for the shares has been promising. About 600,000 retail investors have already applied to purchase shares, which could inspire enthusiasm from institutional investors, analysts said.

"To have retail demand that strong is a good selling tool when they come to talk to institutional investors," Mr Godsmark said.

Yesterday also gave an opportunity for Orange's new management team to present itself to the public. Hans Snook, founder and former chief executive, is stepping down from day-to-day operations and taking on an advisory role to the board of directors.

Jean-François Pontal is the new chief executive, Mr Howe assumes the role of deputy chief executive, and France Telecom's Michel Bon remains as chairman.

Mr Howe said that Orange's future value would come from providing customers not just with voice services, but with a new range of other applications, creating what he termed a "personal assistant for life".

The new services include mobile banking, travel planning, entertainment and shopping.

As part of the new TV campaign, the company is also promoting possibilities for connecting to household appliances through Orange. In the future, Mr Howe said, machines would talk to other machines through Orange, humans would talk to machines through Orange, and humans would continue to talk to each other through Orange.

fields.headline: Anne Macnaghten
fields.standfirst: Violinist with a passion for taking music to children
fields.trailText: Violinist with a passion for taking music to children.
fields.body:
A celebrated violinist and teacher, Anne Macnaghten, who has died aged 92, was best known for the Macnaghten concerts, a series she founded in 1931 with the composer Elisabeth Lutyens and the conductor Iris Lemare to champion the works of young, unknown contemporary composers.

The all-female Macnaghten String Quartet, founded by Anne in the same year, was the focus of many of the performances. Britten's Sinfonietta, Op 1, was premiered at one such concert in 1933, as was Michael Tippett's First String Quartet (1935), and Gerald Finzi, Elizabeth Maconchy and Alan Rawsthorne were among the many other composers whose works had their first hearing as part of the concerts. Ralph Vaughan Williams was one of their most vocal supporters.

The Macnaghten Quartet reformed in 1947, with Arnold Ashby as cellist, and Macnaghten married him in the same year. Under her direction, the ensemble stimulated children's interest in listening to music through demonstration concerts in schools, a cause to which she was passionately committed from 1947-78, in Barking, then Ealing, Cambridgeshire and Hertfordshire.

An inspirational and generous teacher, Macnaghten had many private pupils through out her life. At 70, she began tutoring adult amateur players at the Macnaghten String Quartet Weekends, run by the Benslow Music Trust in Hitchin, Hertfordshire, only stopping as a result of a fall she suffered two years ago.

Although music was her first love, her political beliefs were also deeply important to her: the dogmatic streak which came from her commitment to Marxism gave her the determination to stand up for her principles, both musical and political.

Anne Macnaghten was the youngest daughter of Sir Malcolm Martin Macnaghten, MP for Londonderry from 1922 to 1928 and a high court judge. She and her sisters, Mary and Bridget, lived a privileged life in Kensington and Northern Ireland; all three rebelled against their middle-class background and adopted socialist beliefs.

Anne began learning the violin at the age of six with the celebrated soloist Jelly d'Aranyi. "She wasn't really a very good teacher," Macnaghten told the Strad magazine in 1983, "but she had a terrific temperament as a player. She made a tremendous impact on me."

Her music lessons stopped during the second world war, but from the age of 10 she had lessons with Oliver Williams. Anxious to follow in her sisters' footsteps and live abroad, she went to study with Walther Davisson at the Leipzig Conservatory in 1925, at the age of 17, although her studies there ended abruptly after two years, when her mother, displeased at a reported liaison with another student, arrived to take her home.

Back in Britain, a chance meeting with Lutyens in 1931 led to the founding of the Macnaghten concerts, based at the Ballet Club Theatre (later the Mercury Theatre) in London's Notting Hill Gate. Female composers featured prominently in the series: Macnaghten always said this was not due to feminist concerns, but because women found the most difficulty in getting their works heard. From 1932, the series was known as the Macnaghten-Lemare concerts, and from 1935-37, when Lemare ran them on her own, they were renamed the Lemare concerts.

They resumed again in 1952 under the auspices of the newly-formed Macnaghten New Music Group, with Vaughan Williams as president. With the help of Arts Council funding, the concerts continued for many years, and though Anne Macnaghten ended her direct involvement with the organisation in 1978, the last New Macnaghten concert season was held in 1994, having commissioned works by many British composers, including Harrison Birtwistle and Richard Rodney Bennett.

Macnaghten's political ideals were a subject close to her heart as her first husband, Ernest Skilbeck (whom she married in 1942 and who died in 1947) had fought against Franco in the Spanish civil war. She campaigned during the second world war to open a second front to relieve the Nazi attack on the Soviet Union. In the early 1980s, she left the Communist party to join her local Labour party, for which she was still delivering election leaflets at the age of 90.

In 1962, Anne Macnaghten received the gold medal from the Worshipful Company of Musicians for services to chamber music, and in 1987 she was awarded the CBE in recognition of her lifetime's work.

Her second husband, Arnold, died in 1994. She is survived by a son, John, and a daughter, Catherine.

 Anne Macnaghten, violinist and teacher, born August 9 1908; died December 31 2000.

fields.headline: William Murnane
fields.trailText: William Murnane, who has died aged 55, was an American Egyptologist best known to the general public for his very popular Penguin Guide to Ancient Egypt.
fields.body:
William Murnane, who has died aged 55, was an American Egyptologist best known to the general public for his very popular Penguin Guide to Ancient Egypt, still by far the best-informed book on the monuments of Egypt.

Born in White Plains, New York, he was brought up in Venezuela, to where his parents moved when he was 18 months old. He returned to the United States at the age of 13, later studying history at St Anselm College, in New Hampshire, where he supplemented his income by teaching Spanish and graduated in 1966. A precocious child, his interest in Egypt began at the age of six; later, he wrote letters from college to his sister in hieroglyphs.

A variety of themes ran through Bill's activities as an Egyptologist, in particular historical issues, the recording of monuments, and the Amarna period (the controversial age of the so-called heretic king, Akhenaten, in the 14th century BC). Graduate studies at the University of Chicago led to his research on Egyptian co-regencies, the much-debated system by which a number of Egyptian kings placed their anointed successors on the throne with them for a time. His 1973 PhD (awarded with distinction) was published as Ancient Egyptian Coregencies.

In 1977, he joined the staff of the University of Chicago's Epigraphic Survey, based at Chicago House, Luxor, the long-standing mission that specialises in the documentation of unpublished monuments. There, Murnane worked on the temples of Karnak and Medinet Habu, and developed his concern for threatened monuments.

His Road To Kadesh (1985, revised 1990) was an offshoot of the Chicago work on the battle reliefs of Sety I at Karnak, while his United With Eternity remains the most authoritative popular work on the temples of Medinet Habu. He was deeply concerned about the temple of Karnak and how much needed to be recorded. In 1981, he published some older Chicago records of the great hypostyle hall, and last year was busy there again.

Murnane remained at Luxor until moving to the University of California at Berkeley in 1986. The following year, he went to the University of Memphis, becoming professor of history in 1994.

His interest in the Amarna period, which perhaps went back to examining the controversial co-regency of Amenhotep III and Akhenaten, led to his producing the first proper edition of the Amarna boundary stelae (with Charles van Siclen in 1993), and a pioneering volume of translations in readable English of the texts of that confused period (Texts From The Amarna Period In Egypt, 1995).

Music, especially opera, also played a great role in Bill's life. He could sing too: one night, he and Charles van Siclen were moved to pay a moonlight visit to the Valley of the Kings, where the beauty of the scene had such an effect on Bill that he broke into an impromptu aria, which was quickly answered by two gunshots. Next day, they were told that the sound had been taken for the call of a hyena.

Murnane was the ideal colleague, a real "gentleman scholar". He is survived by his mother and sister.

fields.headline: Betting levy to be replaced
fields.trailText: The Treasury's determination to use the Budget in March to restrict the growth of tax-free internet betting will be signalled by the financial secretary, Stephen Timms, today.
fields.body:
The Treasury's determination to use the Budget in March to restrict the growth of tax-free internet betting will be signalled by the financial secretary, Stephen Timms, today.

Alarmed at the prospect of lucrative gambling revenues being lost to offshore locations, chancellor Gordon Brown intends to press ahead with plans to scrap the current 9% levy paid by punters on bets and replace it with a flat-rate levy on profits made by bookmakers.

Treasury sources said last night that Mr Timms would signal the government's intention to press ahead with the "modernisation" of betting taxation in a speech to a seminar organised by the British Betting Office Association.

While the financial secretary will say that the decision on the future of betting taxation will be announced in the Budget - expected on March 6 - he will insist that the government has "a long-term interest in keeping the industry on shore".

Revenue from gambling this year is expected to be broadly similar to the £492m raised by the Treasury in 1999-2000, but ministers are concerned that the internet provides new opportunities for gamblers to avoid the UK taxman.

The government has spent the past year talking to the industry which has shown support for a system where tax is levied on the value of stakes placed with bookmakers less the winnings paid out.

However, bookmakers have made it clear that the future of the onshore industry in the UK will depend on the tax rate being reduced, whether or not there is a change in the structure of betting taxation.

Mr Timms will say: "The British betting industry is competitive. Over the past three years turnover has risen from £6.8bn to £7.3bn. "The government wants it to remain competitive and grow. Modernising the industry must benefit everyone otherwise the customer will go elsewhere."

webTitle: Ashcroft claims dirty tricks by Labour

fields.headline: Ashcroft claims dirty tricks by Labour
fields.trailText: Lord Ashcroft is claiming to be the victim of an "unsavoury" dirty tricks campaign after the British high commission in Belize promoted an offshoot of a Bahamas group against one of his own firms.
fields.body:
Lord Ashcroft is claiming to be the victim of an "unsavoury" dirty tricks campaign after the British high commission in Belize promoted an offshoot of a Bahamas group against one of his own firms.

A commission official in Belmopan, capital of Belize, sent out leaflets to businesses detailing the savings if phone users switched from Lord Ashcroft's Belize Telecommunications network to its rival Interoute's callback service. Mike Hernandez wrote in a covering letter last October that he hoped the information was useful and asked for it to be forwarded to other groups.

Legal advice obtained by Lord Ashcroft, who is a billionaire and the Tories' treasurer, concluded it was unlawful to offer the alternative system in Belize, where he has secured an exclusive contract.

An Interoute operator said yesterday: "Belize is a destination where we cannot connect." The Foreign Office stated that it had been advised the mail shot was legal.

Colleagues of Lord Ashcroft, who has huge political and economic clout in Belize, accused Labour ministers of using the Foreign Office and the Department of International Development to pursue a vendetta over his Conservative fundraising. Allies of the peer produced the Hernandez letter a week after the FO said he had threatened to cut off the commission for using another callback system.

Ministers are threatening to refuse to cut Belize's debts unless the country scraps big tax concessions enjoyed by Lord Ashcroft. He accuses the government of double standards.

Interoute Telecommunications (UK) is a subsidiary of UK firm Interoute Telecommunications plc, run by Virgin Islands-based Shaker - a public investment firm - which in turn is owned by the Interoute Communications Group, which is incorporated in the Bahamas.

fields.headline: Relief for teacher stress
fields.trailText: I was surprised to read (Limits eased on foreign teachers, January 20) that Ofsted, the school inspection service, had failed the Heber primary school in Dulwich because of staff shortages.
fields.body:
I was surprised to read (Limits eased on foreign teachers, January 20) that Ofsted, the school inspection service, had failed the Heber primary school in Dulwich because of staff shortages. As the stress of Ofsted inspections is one of the major reasons why teachers are leaving the profession, it is rather cheeky of them to complain about the resulting staff shortages. A solution might be to allow inspectors to take up the vacancies in schools. Not only would it give inspectors an opportunity to get back to the job, but other teachers could only be uplifted by watching experts at work.
Frank Randall
Nottingham
frankmargaret69@netscapeonline.co.uk

I am not certain what Lord Puttnam means when he states that the Teaching Awards raise the profile of teaching as a whole (Teaching awards diversity plea, January 22). How many teachers, parents or members of the public could name any of the past winners, or indeed how many ceremonies there have been?

As a teacher, I have not yet met one colleague who has shown any interest in the awards. They are far more concerned with improving day-to-day conditions and reducing Kafkaesque bureaucracy, as well as wanting their salaries brought in line with other professions. Teaching awards do not buy a decent property in London, nor will they prevent the mass exodus of teachers from London schools. Teachers need action, not little awards on the mantelpiece.
Paul Haywood
London

At one time, saying I was a teacher brought forth weak jokes about endless holidays and short working hours. Today, it elicits a mixture of pity and amazed admiration. This is an unduly negative perception of what can still at times be a rewarding and worthwhile job, but it has its basis in truth. Couple this with poor remuneration and myriad graduate opportunities elsewhere, and the problems the government face are inevitable. Until this is grasped, the crisis will continue.
Paul Walker
London
P.J.Walker@tesco.net

Not only would it give inspectors an opportunity to get back to the job, but other teachers could only be uplifted by watching experts at work. How many teachers, parents or members of the public could name any of the past winners, or indeed how many ceremonies there have been? As a teacher, I have not yet met one colleague who has shown any interest in the awards. They are far more concerned with improving day-to-day conditions and reducing Kafkaesque bureaucracy, as well as wanting their salaries brought in line with other professions. Teaching awards do not buy a decent property in London, nor will they prevent the mass exodus of teachers from London schools. Teachers need action, not little awards on the mantelpiece. This is an unduly negative perception of what can still at times be a rewarding and worthwhile job, but it has its basis in truth. Couple this with poor remuneration and myriad graduate opportunities elsewhere, and the problems the government face are inevitable. Until this is grasped, the crisis will continue. Paul Walker London P.J.Walker@tesco.net

fields.headline: Solana slates EU foreign policy
fields.standfirst:
Defence chief claims bureaucracy is wrecking Europe's ability to decide on priorities
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: European Union foreign policy goals are being formulated in a "bureaucratic exercise" that lacks coherence, flexibility and effectiveness, according to a candid internal critique by the top official involved.
fields.body:
European Union foreign policy goals are being formulated in a "bureaucratic exercise" that lacks coherence, flexibility and effectiveness, according to a candid internal critique by the top official involved.

In a confidential document circulated to member states, Javier Solana, the EU's "high representative" for foreign and security policy, admitted that common strategies setting out the EU's policy towards regions such as Russia, Ukraine, the Balkans and the Mediterranean had failed to produce "a stronger and more effective EU in international affairs".

If the shortcomings were not corrected, he added in the document dated December 21, "we will widen even further the gap between [the strategies'] poor effectiveness on the one hand and on the other hand the high expectations they raise".

Mr Solana told reporters later that the system had to be radically overhauled if the EU was going to tackle foreign policy "in real time, without waiting for meetings".

Mr Solana, a former Nato secretary general, works for the union's council of ministers, where the 15 member governments cooperate.

It is his job to try to give Europe a single voice so it can act more effectively on the world stage, especially with regard to the US, in a way that reflects its economic strength.

But he has faced difficulties and frustrations since taking up his newly-created post last year, including repeated suggestions that his functions should be absorbed into Romano Prodi's supranational European commission.

Chris Patten, the British commissioner who is in charge of external relations, has also expressed concerns about a lack of coherence in the EU's foreign and aid policy-making.

European Union diplomats regularly complain that governments are not giving Mr Solana enough power.

Mr Solana is also responsible for the EU's new rapid reaction force (RRF) of up to 60,000 troops, intended to be sent on peacekeeping and humanitarian missions where Nato as a whole is not involved.

Critics of the RRF say it may end up undermining the western alliance, and may seize on Mr Solana's admission of difficulties with foreign policy-making to strengthen their opposition to the force.

The document was leaked as foreign ministers met to review European union mechanisms for conflict prevention, a high priority as the Swedish assume the presidency of the group .

"Solana is trying to add some reality to a debate which is otherwise just too woolly," said one diplomat, admitting that the report was a frank account of widely recognised problems.

Mr Solana lamented in his critique that the EU's foreign policy documents were often so "thoroughly negotiated among the member states that they do not contain real priorities". No doubt they are useful as reference documents, he added, but they have tended to become "increasingly a bureaucratic exercise".

"No sense of priority or urgency emerges from them at the political level. In the end it becomes difficult to distinguish priorities from questions of secondary importance," he said.

In the debate on conflict prevention, held in public, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, called for fresh efforts to ensure that exports of small arms only go to "legitimate governments" and not to rebels.

In Britain the government has come under renewed criticism for not doing enough to implement the findings of the Scott enquiry into the arms for Iraq scandal.

"Africa has more conflicts than any other continent in the world and it is significant that Africa is the only continent in the world where per capita GDP has declined over the past decade," Mr Cook said.

 Duncan Campbell, the British investigative journalist, told a European parliament committee yesterday that since 1993, electronic espionage by the US-led Echelon surveillance system had allowed American companies to win up to $26bn of contracts that might otherwise have gone to European rivals, including firms in Britain.

Britain participates in the system, but has always refused to acknowledge its existence. Committee members are due to meet Jack Straw, the home secretary, and Tom King, chairman of the parliamentary intelligence and security committee, in London this week.

fields.headline: Skills take the strain
fields.trailText: Industry minister Kim Howells noted the skills crisis (Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs, January 22), but did he notice the Inland Revenue and Gordon Brown decree that skills training is no longer a legitimate business expense?
fields.body:
Industry minister Kim Howells noted the skills crisis (Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs, January 22), but did he notice the Inland Revenue and Gordon Brown decree that skills training is no longer a legitimate business expense? If not, I can direct him to the IR35 provision which forces income tax and National Insurance to be paid on training for the self-employed (though the Inland Revenue is said to be considering making training a taxable perk for all employees).

As for importing skilled people from overseas, we should ask two questions. First, do we have the right to beggar-our-neighbours just because various governments have overseen massive failures in the skilling-up/reskilling of our people. And second, as the government has started a new brain drain (again, IR35) surely the first logical step would be to reverse the rule changes that are making native talent move abroad?
Xavier Gallagher
London

Well said, Kim Howells. He may rightly wonder what is happening when more pupils are staying on in the sixth form and emerging without any vocational qualifications.

We are working with industry and schools to change that. At one school, Pensnett in Dudley, we are training fourth and fifth formers in practical engineering skills. With further help from Dudley College, youngsters are getting jobs in local engineering firms with recognised NVQ qualifications.

Pensnett is applying for a grant from the DfEE to spread this vocational teaching throughout the West Midlands. We trust that Howells and his former colleagues in the DfEE will support them.
Dr Michael Sanderson
Engineering and Marine Training Authority

webTitle: Letters: Are volunteer lay magistrates good?

fields.headline: Do justice to the bench
fields.trailText: Andrew Sanders' proposals would seek to replace volunteer lay magistrates with full time district judges (Analysis, January 17). Using the criteria established in Rod Morgan's research, the costs would be prohibitive.
fields.body:
Andrew Sanders' proposals would seek to replace volunteer lay magistrates with full time district judges (Analysis, January 17). At a conservative estimate his proposals would result in the numbers of lay magistrates being reduced by a third and involve 10,000 magistrates being replaced by 300 or so district judges. Using the criteria established in Rod Morgan's research, the costs would be prohibitive.

Employing 300 district judges would cost around £30m annually in salaries alone, and because they tend to remand more defendants in custody and use prison sentences to a greater extent than lay magistrates do, there would be considerable additional costs. The savings on replacing 10,000 unpaid lay magistrates would be minimal

Apart from costs, there are many good reasons for retaining the lay magistracy, regardless of any shortcomings. Lay magistrates provide community justice: they are ordinary people who live and work in the local community and who have an intimate knowledge of that community.

They are made up of equal numbers of men and women, which is of particular significance in relation to the other areas of the judiciary where women are few and far between. Ethnic minorities are well represented, with just over the 6% in the population as a whole, and significantly more in those areas with large ethnic populations.

The lay magistracy is still seen, however, as a role for the middle classes and, as the research indicates, there is a need to recruit more magistrates from working class backgrounds. There is also a need to recruit more young magistrates.

The article makes much of the statistic that claims that only 29% of the public think that magistrates do a good job. It fails to mention that judges scored even less in the survey.

The lay magistracy provides this country with the most open and transparent criminal courts system in the world. One that allows ordinary members of the community to make the decisions in 96% of the cases that go through the criminal courts. Of those decisions made in 1999, only 4% went to appeal, a record any criminal court system could be proud of. This is not only a system worth retaining; it is one that is worth investing in.
Harry Mawdsley
Chairman of council, Magistrates' Association

The magistracy is not the prerogative of the middle class or pensioners. One of the main obstacles to anyone becoming a magistrate is firms who do not allow their employees to partake of public duties. The magistracy can only be as efficient as society lets it be. Instead of the constant attacks on the magistracy, why don't you try to persuade employers of the benefits of having a magistrate in their midst?
Fiona Williams
Birmingham

Our experience suggests that the idea of lay magistrates led by professional judges should be a promising way forward. In northern Europe the distinguishing factor is mixed professional and lay participation in first instance decisions. Denmark and Germany appear to manage as well as any with assessors led by professional judges.

On the other hand our experience of French and particularly Belgian justice would demonstrate the dangers of professional judges sitting alone or together. The steady trickle of unfairly imprisoned lorry drivers and the cases of Bridget Seisay (people trafficking) and Mark Forrester (football hooliganism) are a warning to those advocating extensions of the use of district judges sitting alone.
Stephen Jakobi
Director, Fair Trials Abroad
StephenJakobi@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Lost leader
fields.trailText: I was interested to read David McKie's recollections of the 1970 election night on the Guardian (I think it's all over, already, January 18). Predictably, there was great gloom among the leader writers on the Daily Telegraph that evening.
fields.body:
I was interested to read David McKie's recollections of the 1970 election night on the Guardian (I think it's all over, already, January 18). Predictably, there was great gloom among the leader writers on the Daily Telegraph that evening. Whatever the nuances of the polls, varying as they had for months, the consensus was that the Labour government would be comfortably returned.

Maurice Green, the then editor, however, was not convinced, citing various surprise results in the past: notably the huge Labour majority in 1945. Two of us were, therefore, required to write contrasting leaders covering possible Labour or Conservative victories. The editor was almost the last person to leave the building, "slotting in" the Heath leader (mine) when enough early results were know.

There is no comfort for William Hague in 1970, however: his party is now far further behind than the Conservatives ever were before that election.
John Cockcroft
Chelmsford

fields.headline: Adding insult to injury for the asbestos victims
fields.trailText: Thousands of asbestos victims must not be allowed to lose out on compensation payments following the liquidation of the assets of Chester Street Insurance Holdings Ltd (Payouts for asbestos victims put at risk, January 20).
fields.body:
Thousands of asbestos victims must not be allowed to lose out on compensation payments following the liquidation of the assets of Chester Street Insurance Holdings Ltd (Payouts for asbestos victims put at risk, January 20).

It is terrible enough to have contracted a killing disease through gross negligence on the part of an employer and then have to overcome a series of legal and medical obstacles before some financial recompense is awarded. To then discover that this small redress might be taken away is appalling.

The secretary of state, John Reid, has already acknowledged the seriousness of the matter. However, looking at this "as a matter of urgency" must involve a full and open investigation of the affairs of CSIH, and needs to be combined with comprehensive reassurance for asbestos victims.

The government has political, social and moral responsibilities to ensure that, irrespective of the financial circumstances of CSIH, not one victim loses out on the full payment to which he or she is entitled. It should be remembered that a significant number of the victims are shipyard workers, who from 1977 were state employees working for the nationalised British Shipbuilders. Even though many of the asbestos cases arise before 1977, sectors of the industry had already been in public ownership for several years.

A simple statement that the government will accept its responsibilities and ensure that compensation claims will be met in full will go some way towards reassuring those suffering from asbestos-related diseases.
Phil Taylor
Glasgow
philip.taylor@stir.ac.uk

You report on the latest sad twist in a long line of insults and injury to the 10,000-plus UK workers (including some as young as 17) and others (including children who had the misfortune to play near an asbestos works) who are now dying each year as a result of past exposure to asbestos dust. What the future holds, we do not yet know.

As long ago as 1898 the government of the day was warned about the "evil" effects of asbestos dust in the annual report of HM chief inspector of factories to parliament. The warnings continued throughout the 20th century and were comprehensively ignored by government, asbestos manufacturers, producers, users and disposers. They still are, sometimes.

Just compensation is one of the hallmarks of a civilised society. The insurers, Lloyd's of London among them, have made a good profit out of asbestos and its victims. Now it is time they paid. If this cannot be done under our present system then the government must pay in full our debt to these innocent victims of an industrial war. And the insurance system must be reformed, for the future victims of preventable diseases. AJP Dalton
London
eve@ajpdhazeco.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Hain seeks to end 'nationalist' line on foreign policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Britain is to bring down the curtain on centuries of diplomatic tradition by cutting back on international round table negotiations in which countries push solely for their own national interests.
fields.body:
Britain is to bring down the curtain on centuries of diplomatic tradition by cutting back on international round table negotiations in which countries push solely for their own national interests.

In a pamphlet, the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, called yesterday for countries to pool resources to confront global challenges such as Aids and BSE.

As a first step, Mr Hain called for the most radical restructuring of the Foreign Office in its history. Departments based on geographical divisions should be scrapped in favour of "issues" departments such as human rights, the environment and conflict prevention.

Mr Hain, the former anti-apartheid leader who is one of the government's most original thinkers, said that the problems which came across his desk no longer responded to traditional diplomatic solutions.

In a speech last night launching his pamphlet, titled The End of Foreign Policy?, he said: "Take BSE, recent devastating floods in Europe or Mozambique, militant protests at the Seattle trade summit or a computer virus sent out by two students which disabled 10m computers worldwide.

"Each reflects a new kind of world shaped not by old clashes of ideology or power but by more complex forces which could blight the 21st century just as the 20th."

Mr Hain added that diplomacy would have to change to cope with such important shared interests. "The responsibility of the current generation of politicians and diplomats is no longer solely to balance distinct national aims," he said. "It is to align the way nations see their own interests with the new global imperatives."

In a section of his pamphlet which will alarm Foreign Office traditionalists, Mr Hain writes of his frustration at its slowness in responding to new global threats.

"A frustration for me as a [Foreign Office] minister has been that the machine is geared to responding to new circumstances mostly by incremental shifts in emphasis."

Mr Hain's pamphlet, which was approved by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and by Downing Street, will be seen as an attempt to redefine the government's "ethical" foreign policy.

Ministers have faced severe criticism for failing to live up to their manifesto commitment to add a humanitarian dimension to British diplomacy.

There was an embarrassing reminder of the ethical foreign policy record yesterday when the author of the report on the arms to Iraq scandal criticised the government for failing to change the law on arms exports.

On the Today programme, Lord Justice Scott said: "It's regrettable, because I think it's important, and it's it's long, long overdue.

The government has pledged to publish a draft bill on arms exports. This means that the law will not be changed before the election.

"It is to align the way nations see their own interests with the new global imperatives." In a section of his pamphlet which will alarm Foreign Office traditionalists, Mr Hain writes of his frustration at its slowness in responding to new global threats. "A frustration for me as a [Foreign Office] minister has been that the machine is geared to responding to new circumstances mostly by incremental shifts in emphasis." Mr Hain's pamphlet, which was approved by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and by Downing Street, will be seen as an attempt to redefine the government's "ethical" foreign policy. Ministers have faced severe criticism for failing to live up to their manifesto commitment to add a humanitarian dimension to British diplomacy. On the Today programme, Lord Justice Scott said: "It's regrettable, because I think it's important, and it's it's long, long overdue. The government has pledged to publish a draft bill on arms exports. This means that the law will not be changed before the election.

webTitle: Chechen rebels face a new enemy

fields.headline: Chechen rebels face a new enemy
fields.standfirst:
Putin puts KGB's successors in charge of war to crush guerrillas
Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: Sixteen months into Russia's savage war of attrition in Chechnya and with no end in sight, President Vladimir Putin yesterday stripped his army generals of their command of the campaign and put the domestic security service, the main successor to the KGB, in charge of the Chechnya war.
fields.body:
Sixteen months into Russia's savage war of attrition in Chechnya and with no end in sight, President Vladimir Putin yesterday stripped his army generals of their command of the campaign and put the domestic security service, the main successor to the KGB, in charge of the Chechnya war.

In what appeared to be a vote of no confidence in the generals' ability to tame the Chechen rebels, despite repeated bragging that they have been crushed, Mr Putin put a close ally, Nikolai Patrushev, head of the FSB (domestic security service), in command and ordered him to report on his progress by mid-May.

Moscow says it has 80,000 troops in Chechnya struggling to contain what it puts at 1,000 guerrillas. But by the official tally, widely seen as too low, the Russians are being killed at the rate of more than 160 a month, with almost 500 being wounded as the rebels use ruthless hit-and-run tactics.

Its principal garrison Gudermes, long under ostensible Russian control and the headquarters for the civil administration of Chechnya, is the latest battleground, according to Russian media yesterday.

Guerrillas attacked the main hospital on Sunday, keeping Russian troops under fire for eight hours before melting away into the darkness. According to the Chechens, they left 20 Russian soldiers dead. Moscow admitted losing four soldiers and confirmed that many were injured in a cafe bomb blast in Gudermes.

The guerrillas are also targeting "collaborationist" members of the pro-Moscow Chechen administration and its local supporters every week.

The lightning speed of the attack highlights the vulnerability of the Russian conscripts, who hole up each evening in converted schools and public buildings, surrounded by mines and barbed wire. They live in fear of the rebels who attack checkpoints, mine roads and ambush Russian convoys.

Sergei Ponomarenko, a Russian who recently resigned as a local government chief in Chechnya, told the newspaper Izvestiya that the guerrillas - who routinely ignore curfews and distribute propaganda leaflets "to show who's really boss" - have seized the initiative.

When Chechen snipers hit a Russian, Moscow's forces commonly respond with indiscriminate artillery barrages which maim and kill civilians or launch "cleansing" raids on villages and towns, dragging away males of fighting age.

"This has turned into a war against an entire civilian population. That's a fact, that's the reality," Ruslan Khasbulatov, a former Russian parliamentary leader and himself a Chechen, told the Russian government recently.

Russian or loyalist Chechen administrators and military officers, meanwhile, are using their positions to line their pockets, Mr Ponomarenko said, an assertion echoed by Mr Khasbulatov who said the generals wanted the war to go on because of the opportunities for plundering and profiteering.

Mr Putin's move yesterday may be an attempt to break this cycle of viciousness and seal a victory in Chechnya. But it also seems a counsel of despair. The president recently described Chechnya as the source of "Russia's national shame". It also propelled him to power in 1999.

Yesterday's move was a snub to the army generals who, according to Mr Khasbulatov, are deliberately prolonging the war to enhance their clout in Russian politics and to exact retribution for their defeat in the last Chechen war of 1994-96.

In a decree that took immediate effect, Mr Putin put Mr Patrushev, who succeeded him as head of the FSB in 1999, in charge. The transfer of command was seen as another sign of the growing power of the security services under Mr Putin, a former career KGB officer.

The Kremlin also announced troop cuts in Chechnya, making it plain that the emphasis would be on the use of elite "anti-terrorist" FSB and crack army units. All the signs are that there will be a strong Russian spring offensive to end the war by May and proclaim victory.

With no political solution in sight and scant effort made to find one, public support for the war is ebbing and Mr Putin may be calculating that he needs to settle.

Mr Putin has instructed that the troops numbers be cut. "I have decided today on a partial withdrawal from the republic," he declared yesterday. "This does not mean the end of the counter-terrorism operation. On the contrary it will be continued, not less intensively, but with different means and forces and with a different emphasis." The war would now be waged by "FSB and interior ministry forces and defence ministry special units".

A motorised infantry division of 15,000 men and a 7,000-strong brigade of interior ministry troops would remain deployed. It was not clear how many troops were being pulled out or when.

Mr Putin also talked up the possibilities of implementing new civil administration plans to revive the economy. The plan is to plough £60m into Chechnya reconstruction this year.

But Russian civilian administrators are currently quitting their posts in frustration at the Kremlin and the military, complaining that no money is available for the restoration of the most rudimentary services and that anything of value in Chechnya is plundered by the Russian troops.

Mr Putin stated recently that his priority in Chechnya was "social rehabilitation and economic recovery", but a senior Kremlin aide told Mr Ponomarenko: "There is no programme yet for restoring the republic, so there's no point putting any money in."

The president said the command was being passed to the FSB since constitutionally this is the body charged with combating terrorism. It is true that by law the army is for fighting foreign wars and defending against external aggression rather than to crush domestic insurgency, but in Chechnya such niceties have been ignored for the past 16 months.

fields.headline: Doctor defends pregnant woman, 56
fields.trailText: The director of a Harley Street clinic which helped a 56-year-old woman to conceive twins accused critics yesterday of wanting a "police state" where people could not plan their own families.
fields.body:
The director of a Harley Street clinic which helped a 56-year-old woman to conceive twins accused critics yesterday of wanting a "police state" where people could not plan their own families.

Professor Ian Craft, of the London Gynaecology and Fertility Centre, strongly defended its decision to treat Lynne Bezant, who will become the oldest mother of twins recorded in Britain.

Mrs Bezant and her husband Derek, 55, from Oxfordshire, are expecting the babies in June. They already have three grown-up children.

Their story is likely to fuel the debate over whether people have a right to children, which gathered pace with last week's internet adoption scandal. But Prof Craft, one of the pioneers of IVF, insisted: "It's not the least bit sensational. It's just rather lovely, I think."

He asked: "Do you wish to have a police state in this country where someone is pregnant at 54 and you want to have it interrupted because she's been infertile for 10 years? There are those people who try to be helpful in life, and those that put hurdles up. We try to be helpful."

Mr Bezant, a civil servant, underwent a vasectomy to prevent his wife suffering further trauma having given birth to stillborn twins and suffering two miscarriages 20 years ago, but the couple regretted the decision. They turned to the clinic because it is thought to be the only one in Britain that treats women over 51, although Prof Craft said such cases were rare. But the Bezants had to wait more than two years for treatment because egg donors preferred to help younger couples. Eventually a donor supplied eggs, which were fertilised with sperm extracted from Mr Bezant's testes and implanted into his wife's uterus.

Mrs Bezant, a teacher, told the Mirror: "I know people may criticise us, but we've thought about this carefully for years. We're both fit, our families have all lived to a reasonable age and financially we're relatively stable. I felt if I could cope with a class of 28 children I could cope with youngsters of my own."

The couple's three children - Jenny, 32, Andrew, 30, and Chris, 26 - were said to be delighted about the pregnancy.

Prof Craft said: "If the same thing happens naturally, people are happy for someone who's long been infertile. I don't see why it's a disaster if the children are loved and wanted."

There is no official upper age limit for assisted conception, but a spokesman for the Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians yesterday expressed concern about the decision to treat Mrs Bezant.

Peter Bowen-Simpkins said: "The welfare of the child is paramount, and elderly parents are not considered to be in the best interest of the child."

The human fertilisation and embryology authority said: "If the correct procedures have been followed the clinic has the final decision."

fields.headline: 'I was horrified when I saw the capital. There was no electricity or water. It was in ruins'
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: A Russian recruit tells of terror in Chechnya.
fields.body:
Sergeant Vladimir Petrov, 20, (not his real name) had received only fleeting training in the rudiments of fighting before he was dispatched as a conscript to Chechnya last year. He had spent the earlier part of his military service driving military trucks around Moscow and had never been taught how to shoot. When he arrived in the Russian military base outside Grozny he was unarmed. It took his battalion commander 10 days to find him a gun.

"It was only the third time I'd held a weapon," he said. Within days he was accompanying tanks patrolling the Chechen capital. The experience, he admitted, was terrifying.

"It was hard to get used to the noise of whistling bullets," he said. "I was horrified when I first saw the city. There was no electricity, no water, no gas and not many buildings with roofs. I couldn't understand how people could survive there. The city was in ruins. I felt sorry for the Chechen children and the Russians who were still living among the bombed houses."

Conditions for soldiers at the nearby base, Khankala, were only slightly better. "The water was so bad that a lot of soldiers got dysentery. We drank a strange kind of tea with almost no tea leaves and received inedible rations. At night our tents were very cold."

Before he was sent into battle, Vladimir felt neutral about Russia's campaign against Chechnya. His views changed radically after a few weeks of active service.

"I knew we were there to defend Russia - but it was all so pointless. A lot of men have died and I still can't understand what for. I lost two of my friends: one was 18 and I don't know how he died, he was reported missing in action; the other was 19, and was shot while on duty in Grozny - several men with him were killed at once. [They] were very young to die and I can't see there was any point in their deaths. I think most of my battalion felt the same way."

He believes Russia should withdraw. "The Chechens will never give up fighting. The government has either to wipe out the entire region - which it can't do, because there are civilians living there - or it has to remove its troops."

Vladimir was to receive a bonus to his salary of around 810 roubles a day (£21) for the duration of his service in Chechnya. "I thought my life was worth a lot more than that, but in any case I haven't received a kopeck of the money we were promised. All they've given us is a pass that allows us to travel on the metro for free."

fields.headline: Tom Kilburn
fields.standfirst: Brilliant scientist at the heart of the computer revolution
fields.trailText: Brilliant scientist at the heart of the computer revolution.
fields.body:
Professor Tom Kilburn, who has died aged 79, made a remarkable contribution to modern society. In a career that spanned almost 40 years, from 1942 to 1981, he was at the forefront of electronics, and of the computing revolution that he himself kick-started by providing the first example of computer software. By leading the design and development of five major computer systems, he put Manchester at the heart of this second industrial revolution.

Born in Dewsbury, Yorkshire, Kilburn was educated at Wheelwright grammar school, where he enjoyed mathematics and sport, particularly running, and Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, where, from 1941, he read mathematics. While there, he was invited to a lecture by CP Snow - an event that determined the direction of his future life. Snow told the students that "interesting" work was available to them to help the war effort and, in order to prepare for it, they should take a course in electronics and join the home guard.

This Kilburn did. When he left Cambridge in 1942, he was sent to the telecommunications research establishment (TRE) billeted at Malvern. There he joined FC Williams, who led a group with responsibility for solving problems in existing electronics circuitry in radar and other key areas. They worked in Malvern school's cricket pavilion.

After the war, while still at the TRE, Williams and Kilburn realised that the lack of a suitable storage mechanism was holding up the development of electronic computers worldwide. They began to investigate the possibility of using cathode ray tubes (CRTs) to do this. When Williams took up the chair of electrotechnics at the University of Manchester in December 1946, he asked Kilburn to go with him. A year later, Kilburn, having built working prototypes, wrote a definitive report explaining how a CRT could be used as an electronic storage device.

To show convincingly that it would work in practice, he and GC Tootill then designed and built a computer with a store size of 32 words and some 650 valves; it was 16ft long, weighed half a tonne, and was affectionately known as the Baby. It worked successfully for the first time on June 21 1948. Using simple hand keys, a program was loaded into its memory and then the stored program was executed. This, probably the only complete program Kilburn ever wrote, was the first example of computer software. And so the age of the modern computer was born.

The government of the day was so impressed that ministers instructed the defence company Ferranti Ltd to construct an enhanced computer in collaboration with Williams and Kilburn. The CRT storage system (called the Williams tube in the United States) was used by computer systems around the world for a number of years, before being superseded by core store.

At the University of Manchester, Kilburn led the developments based on the Baby. By 1949, a full-sized machine, the Manchester mark 1, was being used to support a small number of users, including Alan Turing, who had taken up a mathematics post at the university in September 1948. The machine was also the prototype of the computer that Ferranti released as the world's first commercially-produced computer in February 1951.

A succession of computers followed, keeping the University of Manchester at the forefront of computer design worldwide. In 1953, the world's first transistorised computer was commercialised as the Metro Vickers MV950. In 1954, MEG, probably the world's first computer to support floating-point arithmetic, was called Mercury when Ferranti marketed it. Atlas (1962) was the world's most powerful machine of its time. Finally, MU5 (1972) introduced new concepts that were adopted as the basis for the advanced 2900 computer series developed by ICL.

The Atlas exemplifies how developments carried out by Kilburn and his team introduced key new concepts into computing. In this case, innovations included virtual memory, multi-programming, advanced operating systems, read-only memory and the compiler-compiler.

Kilburn was appointed professor of computer engineering in 1960. In 1964, he founded Britain's first department of computer science and became its professor. The department, which had an initial complement of 12 academic staff, has grown five-fold and remains at the forefront of the subject. Kilburn held almost 100 patents and received degrees, awards and honours from all over the world, including being elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1965 and appointed CBE in 1973.

He married Irene Marsden, also from Dewsbury, in August 1943. When seconded from TRE to Manchester in 1946, he initially commuted by train each day from Dewsbury, using the time to work on design problems - including deciding on the instruction set that the Baby would use, and writing the code of the first program.

He retired in 1981 but, in 1998, was persuaded to play a major role in the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the birth of the Baby, including advising the Computer Conservation Society on the rebuilding of a working replica, now in the Manchester Museum of Science and Industry.

Kilburn was a quiet, unpretentious person, who found pleasure in music and, above all, in football. He was an avid Manchester United fan and, until his wife died in 1981, attended matches regularly. He described the day in 1968 when he watched them win the European Cup as one of the best of his life. His absolute delight at the club's triple success in 1999 was a pleasure to see.

He is survived by a son and a daughter.

 Tom Kilburn, computer scientist, born August 11 1921; died January 17 2001.

fields.headline: Attack on De Vere's £4.7m goodbyes
fields.trailText: Hotels company De Vere, under attack from the active investment group Guinness Peat, made severance pay-ments of £4.7m to cover its boardroom clear-out last year.
fields.body:
Hotels company De Vere, under attack from the active investment group Guinness Peat, made severance pay-ments of £4.7m to cover its boardroom clear-out last year.

The scale of the "golden goodbyes" emerged as the firm urged shareholders to reject "ill-considered and damaging" proposals for change from Guinness Peat, which wants the company to demerge its Greens health clubs and return £100m to investors.

De Vere, formerly Greenalls, sold its pubs and restaurants arm in 1999, leading to a number of boardroom changes. Including pension settlements, former chairman Andrew Thomas stepped down with £1.12m, finance director Alan Rothwell left with £605,000 and property boss John Longden took £1.3m with him.

According to the company's annual report, Lord Daresbury, the former jockey who stepped up from chief executive to chairman, received £839,000 to soften the blow and tenanted pubs boss John Bright received an £800,000 boost to his pension fund.

Blake Nixon, a director of Guinness Peat, which has a 5% stake in De Vere, said: "These payments certainly do sound rather generous."

However, De Vere's chief executive Paul Dermody said: "The previous board did a great deal in getting £1.1bn for our pubs and restaurants. In doing so, they put themselves out of a job. It is a lot of money, but it reflected their contractual entitlements."

Mr Dermody is fighting Guinness Peat's demerger proposals, to be put to a vote at De Vere's annual general meeting on February 16. He said the two resulting businesses would be too small to attract institutional investors, and a return of cash to shareholders would leave De Vere heavily indebted.

The management looks likely to win."Guinness Peat's proposals are misguided. There's a lot of benefit in having hotels and health clubs together - things like buying food are common to both," an analyst said.

De Vere's shares declined 7p to 305p.

fields.headline: At this price?  Jarvis
fields.trailText: Paris Moayedi, chief executive of maintenance contractor Jarvis, is likely to be one of few people on a packed commuter train with a smile on his face. The company's shares rose 10.12% yesterday after the weekend announcement that it has secured an extra £12m of tracklaying work since the autumn.
fields.body:
Paris Moayedi, chief executive of maintenance contractor Jarvis, is likely to be one of few people on a packed commuter train with a smile on his face.

The company's shares rose 10.12% yesterday after the weekend announcement that it has secured an extra £12m of tracklaying work since the autumn. With the government and Railtrack deeply committed to rail investment, analysts have singled out Jarvis - the largest supplier of maintenance and track renewals in Britain - as one of the most likely contractors to benefit.

The company has been taking key contracts from competitors, notably Balfour Beatty's at Hatfield after the rail crash. Last week, Jarvis was made preferred bidder for the east coast mainline maintenance contract, again displacing Balfour Beatty.

With a number of other contract decisions pending, investors have steadily been turning to Jarvis and the shares have climbed from below 150p in November to 277.5p yesterday.

Having slimmed down the business to a core maintenance operation, the management are trying to build the trust of investors - with some success. "Jarvis shares still come with a bit of health warning," said Chris Bamberry, an analyst at Deutsche Bank. "But the market is very positive now. The company has had a troubled past - not giving the market its bad news until after the event - but they are turning things around."

Some analysts have expressed concern at the impact of new pensions accounting procedures and negotiations with Railtrack over the payment of £15m.

Nevertheless, Mr Bamberry predicts he could be upgrading Jarvis over coming months. Mr Moayedi said the company had been winning about 50% of contracts bid for and predicted a considerable payback in "a year or two". Jarvis has also developedprivate finance initiative deals with the Department for Education - another area of heavy government spending.
