fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: We were fascinated to learn that none other than former doyenne of all things hush-hush, Dame Stella Rimington, has been accused of  using feminism to promote her memoirs.
fields.body:
Have you used feminism today, dear readers? If not, don't fret: you have right up to the witching hour to employ it however you desire. This morning, Sidelines has already used feminism to change the cat litter and later plans to use it to make a pencil case.

So we were fascinated to learn that none other than former doyenne of all things hush-hush, Dame Stella Rimington, has been accused of using feminism to promote her memoirs. Downing Street is apparently furious that Rimington is justifying publishing the book by claiming that it will inspire other women. She has reportedly told colleagues: "The book will show how a woman can succeed in a man's world."

It is a curiously antiquated way to put it, particularly as it implies working to a set of binary assumptions about whose territory is whose, rather than acknowledging broader structural inequalities. But perhaps that binary is not as past tense as we'd thought, given the impending launch of a drive to put "emotional literacy" (ghastly phrase) at the heart of the political agenda. Tomorrow, Antidote, the "Campaign for Emotional Literacy", will set out its manifesto at the Houses of Parliament. Supporters include Patricia Hewitt, Helena Kennedy and Anthony Giddens, and the aim is to "create an emotionally literate culture, where the facility to handle the complexities of emotional life is as widespread as the capacity to read, write and do arithmetic".

It's an exciting agenda - but Sidelines has a few concerns. "Emotional literacy" has previously been linked with that other great catch-all, "the feminisation of the workplace", and often becomes muddled with that unbecoming binary of "lady's feelings good/man's feelings elsewhere". Is it always good to talk? The fact that women are more comfortable in the emotional arena doesn't mean they always use that confidence appropriately. And an ability to juggle with the linguistics of therapy doesn't automatically connect us to what we describe.

Meanwhile, the way we talk is actually separating us from our humanity. It is of course a truism that, as technology gives us more and more means of communication, we wind up further apart. Communication is increasingly the dissembler's art: call when voicemail's on, fire off a flirtatious email when you've never seen the recipient face to face. Increasingly, we communicate to check in rather than to chat. We tot up our contact points without taking responsibility for where that contact might lead. If this is emotional literacy, it is a truncated kind.

Thank heavens the buffoon who is now leader of the free world successfully halted his daughter Jenna's frock flop at his inaugural doodad, though a flashed nip would momentarily have distracted us from miserable musings on batty foreign policy and abortion law repeal. Also, fact fans, were you aware that Dubya's twins, Barbara and Jenna, are named after their maternal and paternal grandmothers? Succession being what it is, our bets are on wee Jenna in the Whitehouse by 2016.

webTitle: Smog hid threat of global warming

fields.headline: Smog hid threat of global warming
fields.standfirst:
Special report: global warming

Kyoto protocol in full
fields.trailText: One irony of the climate crisis is that when states enforced clean air laws, they made the global warming threat more dramatic.
fields.body:
One irony of the climate crisis is that when states enforced clean air laws, they made the global warming threat more dramatic.

Clouds of particles of sulphur dioxide and soot that once rose from factory chimneys and car exhausts all over the industrial world absorbed the sun's heat and, for a while, masked the impact of the cleaner, less obvious, atmospheric build-up of carbon dioxide and other gases.

But the same industrial sunscreen that suppressed the evidence of global warming imposed other costs. One was in the form of respiratory disease and early death among the hundreds of millions of people exposed to the polluted air of the cities and factory landscapes. The other was in the damage to forests and to the historic fabric of cities as the same particles fell to earth as raindrops of diluted sulphuric acid.

A new report from the Intergovernmental Panel of Climate Change says that the burning of straw, scrub, underbrush and forests, and of "dirty" fossil fuels, pumped enough sulphate and soot into the atmosphere to significantly lower the radiation reaching the planet's surface. Scientists call these effects "anthro-pogenic", or man-made.

But other effects that masked global warming were natural. Several volcanic eruptions between 1960 and 1991 pumped so much debris into the stratosphere that it damped down the invisible effect of the other greenhouse gases. The El Nino southern oscillation (Enso) events - cycles of sea surface warming that cause havoc to countries on either side of the Pacific and Indian oceans - have confused the picture of climate change.

According to Tom Wigley, of the US national centre for atmospheric research, however, without such natural events the picture is even more stark. Overall, the sunblocking effect of volcanic eruptions is greater than the warming effect of the El Ninos.

"Once the volcanic and El Nino influences have been removed, the overall record is more consistent with our current knowledge, which suggests that both natural and anthropogenic influences on climate are important and that anthropo- genic influences have become more substantial in recent decades," Prof Wigley writes in Geophysical Review Letters. The record suggested an increase of 0.18 C per decade.

"When Enso and volcanic effects are removed, the warming trend increases to 0.25 C per decade."

fields.headline: Estrada barred from leaving Philippines
fields.trailText: The Philippine government issued an order today barring the former president, Joseph Estrada, his wife and one of his sons from leaving the country until a corruption investigation is completed.
fields.body:
The Philippine government issued an order today barring the former president, Joseph Estrada, his wife and one of his sons from leaving the country until a corruption investigation is completed.

Mr Estrada is alleged to have stashed away millions of dollars in bribes and kickbacks. Tax collectors have confirmed they are ready to freeze bank accounts linked to the former leader.

Mr Estrada, who was forced from office on Saturday after three days of mounting protests, is under investigation on suspicion of plunder, misuse of funds, graft, perjury, bribery and possession of unexplained wealth.

More than 100 protesters gathered outside two Manila banks today, vowing to prevent Mr Estrada from gaining access to accounts he allegedly has there.

Nelson Aspe, an officer of the Bureau of Internal Revenue, said his agency expected orders to freeze bank accounts linked to Mr Estrada.

This would prevent him from accessing accounts registered in his name as well as accounts that his political opponents say he used to hide as much as 3.3bn pesos (£45m) with at least four aliases.

Lawyers for the citizens' group Volunteers Against Crime and Corruption have also asked the government to freeze any safety deposit boxes, timed deposits and term deposits linked to Mr Estrada.

The Senate president, Aquilino Pimentel, said the impeachment proceedings against Mr Estrada will reconvene later this week or early next week and then formally end. Mr Estrada's impeachment trial gripped the nation through live television coverage for 22 days.

It was indefinitely suspended last week after the entire prosecution team resigned to protest an 11-10 vote by senators, sitting as judges, to bar access to bank records they said were crucial to their case.

The resignations heightened pressure on Mr Estrada, who on Friday announced a snap election and said he would stand down. But as his support dissolved, public pressure forced him to resign immediately.

The justice department's "hold departure order" bars 24 people, including Mr Estrada, his wife, Luisa Ejercito, his son Jinggoy and several other suspects, from leaving.

Ombudsman Aniano Desierto said two of those named in the order - businessman Charlie "Atong" Ang, a close friend of Mr Estrada, and Yolanda Ricaforte, accused of helping Mr Estrada receive bribes - have already left the Philippines.

webTitle: Mandelson now recalls discussing Hinduja application with minister

fields.headline: Mandelson now recalls discussing Hinduja application with minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson's involvement in a controversial application for British citizenship by one of the wealthy Hinduja brothers deepened today when the prime minister's official spokesman admitted that Mr Mandelson had discussed the issue by phone with the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson's involvement in a controversial application for British citizenship by one of the wealthy Hinduja brothers deepened today when the prime minister's official spokesman admitted that Mr Mandelson had discussed the issue by phone with the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien.

Yesterday, the Downing Street spokesman had told journalists that Mr Mandelson's only involvement in the application was that he was asked to become involved and had refused.

Today he admitted that Mr Mandelson has since recalled having asked his officials, when he was minister for the Cabinet Office in June 1998, to set up the telephone call with Mr O'Brien after meeting the Hindujas at a function.

"The fact of the conversation was noted by an official," the spokesman said this morning. "Mike O'Brien's recollection is that it lasted no more than two minutes."

The spokesman added that Mr O'Brien recalled the conversation consisted of Mr Mandelson querying how the Hindujas' application for citizenship might have been considered in the light of changes to immigration rules then recently announced to encourage long-time residents to apply.

"Mike O'Brien has confirmed that Peter Mandelson did not make representations on behalf of the brothers or make representations on any potential application and did not support or endorse it," added the spokesman.

The news comes on the back of the Hinduja brothers' £1m donation to the Dome, a project supervised by Mr Mandelson during his time as a minister at the Cabinet Office.

The brothers - Srichand, Gopichand and Prakesh - are part of Britain's wealthiest Asian family. They are currently in India, where they are being questioned about charges that they accepted £7.1m in commission from the Swedish arms manufacturer, Bofors.

The money was allegedly paid in 1986 after they used their influence with the late Indian prime minister Rajiv Gandhi to secure the firm a huge defence contract.

fields.headline: 'Malicious racism' in youth prison
fields.trailText: A confidential prison service report following the murder of an Asian inmate by a white prisoner at Feltham, west London, has concluded that the youth jail is guilty of institutional racism. Vikram Dodd reports
fields.body:
A confidential prison service report following the murder of an Asian inmate by a white prisoner at Feltham, west London, has concluded that the youth jail is guilty of institutional racism, with ethnic minority staff and inmates enduring overt racist abuse by warders and failures by senior management.

The report, obtained by the Guardian, follows the beating to death of Zahid Mubarek by his cellmate Robert Stewart and is the most damning official indictment of racism within a British jail ever.

Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, commented: "There's no element of denial, I've been absolutely up front about the problems we have. It goes beyond institutional racism to blatant malicious pockets of racism."

But Mr Narey said no officer was facing disciplinary action over racism or allegations of intimidation because evidence had not been found identifying individuals as culpable.

The prison service commissioned an internal inquiry into the troubled young offenders' institution in September. Stewart was convicted of Mubarek's racist murder in November. Prison staff missed repeated signs that Stewart, a racist psychopath, would harm his cellmate.

The report by the senior investigating officer, Ted Butt, brands Feltham as "institutionally racist", and found a "damning indictment of how staff are failing in their duty of care towards prisoners".

It concludes: "There is evidence that racism exists at Feltham, both overtly and by more subtle methods. Minority ethnic staff should not have to tolerate the level of harassment that exists in order to feel accepted as part of the team. Similarly, prisoners should be able to live free from racist abuse by staff."

The second part of the report focuses solely on racism. It has been with Mr Narey for weeks, having been completed in December - but no date for its publication has been set.

Last night Mr Mubarek's family demanded that the government set up a full public inquiry into his death. Their lawyer, Imran Khan, said Mr Narey should call in the police: "There's no doubt there's a degree of criminal culpability by prison officers who've abused their position."

"Staff from all ethnic groups told of an underlying culture that suggests the only way minority ethnic group staff can be accepted as part of the team of Feltham is by enduring racist comments and racist banter/jokes. Senior managers know what they should be doing but have not done it. This leads the inquiry team to form the conclusion that Feltham is institutionally racist."

The report, stamped as confidential on each of its 30 pages, found a "failure by staff at all levels to take complaints of racist incidents seriously". It said some of those responsible for race training believed racist jokes could be acceptable.

Half of Feltham's 717 inmates are from Asian or Afro-Caribbean backgrounds, as are 11% of its 654 staff. The senior management is entirely white.

The inquiry team even doubted whether records detailing which staff had received race relations training were genuine.

"The training department records show that 103 members of staff have received race relations training since November 1999. Sixteen members of staff surveyed are shown as having been trained, out of these only three stated they had been trained."

The report says it is apparent that the poor state of race relations at Feltham owes much to the lack of an effective race relations management team. The inquiry team felt the team was reactive rather than proactive.

The report says warders were twice as likely to use control and restraint force against black or Asian inmates than against a white prisoner.

It also found that inmates had no faith in the complaints system and heard allegations from the board of visitors that prisoners were intimidated into keeping silent.

Mr Butt calls for a further inquiry into a host of concerns and wrote: "The use of unacceptable language, intimidating prisoners into not complaining, failures to carry out investigations of racist incidents and evident deficiencies in the regime concerning food, paint a sorry picture of Feltham prison.

"Most alarmingly, though, families contacting the board of visitors rather than the managers at Feltham to complain about racist issues, is a damning indictment of the lack of trust between prisoners, their families and Feltham prison."

The report's conclusion says: "The procedures in place for reporting and recording racist incidents are poor, inconsistent and not communicated to those who may need to use them. Similarly, the procedures for investigating such incidents are haphazard, incomplete and again inconsistently applied."

It demands that improvements in race relations must be a management priority.

The report also says that a staff member is under investigation after "requesting a Muslim visitor to remove his headgear for searching".

Imtiaz Mubarek, uncle of Zahid, aged 19 when he was murdered in March 2000, said: "This is more reason for there to be a full public inquiry into Zahid's death. Feltham is a hotbed for racism. The lack of commitment for race issues among staff contributed to Zahid's death."

fields.headline: Hague's haphazard tax ploys
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague would have saved himself months of political grief if he had unveiled last night's spending pledge when he first fleshed out the Tories' tax and spending plans last year.
fields.body:
William Hague would have saved himself months of political grief if he had unveiled last night's spending pledge when he first fleshed out the Tories' tax and spending plans last year.

The Tory leader has appeared weak and confused since the summer as he has tried to reconcile two contradictory ambitions - to portray himself as the champion of key public services while promising to cut taxes.

His stance has made Tony Blair's job easier during his weekly clashes with the Tory leader. Whenever Mr Hague lambasts the prime minister for running down public services, such as the police and the health service, Mr Blair points out that the Tories are not credible because they would cut spending.

Had Mr Hague been in a position to say that the police, the army and public transport would be safe in his hands, he may well have been able to force the prime minister on to the defensive more often.

The Tories insisted that the announcement was part of a plan to outline his tax and spending intentions over a period of months. Mr Hague took the first step in July by abandoning his "tax guarantee". Instead of guaranteeing to cut taxes in all circumstances, he promised to cut taxes if economic conditions were right.

At the same time, the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, pledged to take the knife to Labour's spending plans by keeping public expenditure in line with the economy's long term average growth rate. Mr Portillo eventually claimed that he would shave £8bn from Labour's plans, a figure which has been fleshed out in dribs and drabs.

The whole Tory strategy has appeared haphazard and fuelled speculation of tensions among senior members of the shadow cabinet.

Tory critics of the leadership say that Mr Hague and Mr Portillo have fallen into the same trap as Labour did in the early 1980s - to come up with a broad idea and leave the details until later.

Mr Hague's eleventh hour decision to ringfence Labour spending on the five areas of health, schools, transport, defence and law and order will not end bitter pre-election debates on these topics. The figures may be the same, but Tory and Labour plans on how to spend money will be different.

On education, for example, Mr Hague wants to introduce a "free schools" concept which would abolish local education authorities and hand money to individual schools direct from Whitehall. In a pamphlet last month for the right wing think tank Politiea, Mr Hague said that £4bn - or £540 per pupil - would go directly to schools.

Some of Mr Hague's thinking mirrored government policy; Gordon Brown announced that millions of pounds would be channelled directly to schools to buy books. But the government is opposed to the blanket nature of the "free schools" concept because it would scrap targeted funding on extra teachers to keeping class sizes down for infants.

Health will also prove a contentious area because the Tories want to tear down the "Berlin Wall" between the private and public sectors. At last year's Tory conference, Mr Portillo promised a "bigger cake" for health care by drawing on private finance. The prime minister has moved towards the Tories in this area when he abandoned Frank Dobson's opposition to private hospitals performing operations on behalf of the NHS.

As election fever intensifies, the two main parties will also clash over the public services which the Tories have pledged to cut. The Tories' more contentious proposals include lobbing £1bn off the welfare budget by cutting down on fraud; cutting £400m out of regional bureaucracies; saving £400m by replacing the government's New Deal welfare to work scheme; and privatising Channel 4.

When the election is over, last night's announcement by Mr Hague is likely to prove a significant event. It will go down as the moment when Mr Hague bowed to intense pressure to ringfence spending on key services, but in a way in which he retained his rightwing credentials.

webTitle: Film: The best Ben Kingsley scene

fields.headline: The best Ben Kingsley scene
fields.standfirst: Sexy Beast
fields.trailText: Sexy Beast
fields.body:
Spain. The notorious Don Logan (Ben Kingsley) has arrived at reformed criminal Gary Dove's villa to persuade him to return to London for a job. Gary (Ray Winstone), his friend Harry (James Fox) and their wives sit nervously in the living room as Logan enters. An awkward silence descends.

"How's your brother, Don?" Harry enquires.

"Malky? He's alright, I s'pose. He's Malky, innee? Dunno. You'd have to ask him."

"You patched things up with him?"

Logan stares at Harry without replying.

"How was your flight, Don?", Gary asks.

"It was alright."

Logan peers out of the window.

"So, this is a Spanish villa is it?"

"Yeah, this is it, Don," says Gary. "The old Hacienda."

"Bit remote, innit? Bit cut off?"

"No, that's what we wanted Don...Do you wanna look round?"

"Yeah, I will in a minute. When I have a piss."

Harry gets to his feet.

"Where are you going?"

"I'm just taking the ladies out for something to eat, Don. Thought I'd leave you two to it."

"What, ain't I invited?"

"No. I mean, uh... course you are, Don. I just thought..."

"Harry, I'm joking. It's alright."

He holds out a wad of notes.

"Here y'are, I'll get it."

"No, Don, that's alright. No need for that."

"H, behave. I'm paying for your meal."

Reluctantly, Harry takes the money.

"That's very kind, Don. Very nice of you. Very..."

"Shut up."

See also: Gandhi,Schindler's List, Death And The Maiden.

Don't see also: Parting Shots.

Pointless trivia: Ben Kingsley's birth name is Krishna Banji.

webTitle: Review: The Genius of Rome, Royal Academy

fields.headline: Swindlers' paradise
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle  is impressed by the violent glory that was Caravaggio's Rome
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle is impressed by the violent glory that was Caravaggio's Rome.
fields.body:
The first work in the Royal Academy's exhibition The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 is a painting of a boy in an white shirt skinning a piece of fruit. As he focuses on his task we concentrate on him, as though across a table, where he pares the rind with his knife. It is a delicate, quiet painting, the boy brightly lit against darkness. A symbol, in this show at least, of a world about to be unpeeled.

This painting, by Caravaggio, was completed in 1592, the year of his arrival in Rome at the age of 21. The date also provides the starting point for an exhibition which is much more than an art-historical stroll through the beginnings of the Baroque. Of the 143 paintings here - including works by Annibale Carracci, Domenichino, Van Dyck, Orazio and Artemisia Gentileschi, Guercino, Reni, Rubens and host of others - 15 are by Caravaggio. Wherever one looks, there Caravaggio seems to be; and wherever he is, your eyes swerve to him. And his influence is everywhere.

Yet Caravaggio, in the years following his sudden departure from Rome in 1606, after murdering a man over a wager, was dismissed as being only of interest to "eccentrics, connoisseurs and foreign artists". We cannot dismiss him now. He is too spectacular, too fierce, too extreme; still, at times, too shocking.

On his arrival Rome was, in catalogue author Beverly Louise Brown's slightly unhappy turn of phrase, a "Mecca" for artists from throughout Italy and the rest of Europe. They didn't only come to study the antique, or the wonders of the High Renaissance. Rome was rich. The church, in its various guises, offered an enormous amount of patronage, as did secular Rome. The newly elected Pope Clement VIII may have been pious, but his "papal nephews" lived in high style. Street life was turbulent, colourful and violent. It was a city of hustlers, prostitutes, gypsies, card-sharps, gamblers, pickpockets and cut-purses. We may recognise this "Paradise of Swindlers", but we wouldn't want to live there.

A boy studies his hand of cards, while we see the young card sharp fingering a concealed card from his waistband, ready to fleece the mark. The young men look similar. Perhaps they are the same boy, painted from the same model, caught in a circular, table-turning trick with time. Over the dupe's shoulder, an older accomplice signals to the grifter.

Over 30 copies of Caravaggio's 1595 The Cardsharps are known to exist, as though to multiply the deception. Deceptions indeed proliferated - Simon Vouet's painting of a young woman who laughs and lets us in on the fact that she knows that while the fortune-teller is trying to work the ring from her finger, so a dip has his hand in the fortune-teller's bag.

The popularity of such images may have partly been that they flattered the worldly sophistication of their audience, wise guys themselves who'd never fall for such a cheap trick. Yet surely there is a level at which such paintings also meditate on the trickery of art itself, and on the relationship between paintings and their viewers.

These almost Dickensian - not to say Shakespearean - scoundrels of the tavern and the street, depicted as light fingered hustlers or exaggeratedly hammy types, are matched by the more complex psychology of the beautiful androgynous Spanish castrato in Caravaggio's Lute Player, his Boy with a Basket of Fruit, his Musicians tuning up, his pretty, fated boys. Valentin de Boulogne's court buffoon and self-proclaimed count Raffaello Menicucci is painted with a certain pathos, and sympathy for the buffoon's ridiculous aggrandisements.

The alarming Hairy Harry, Mad Peter and Tiny Amon, the deformed bucolics who entertained for the Farnese household, and were a gift to Cardinal Odoardo Farnese from the Duke of Palma, are as fully human, joking and affectionate with a menagerie of pets, as they are themselves objects of our amusement. Agostino Carracci's painting of them - a sort of farcical naturalism derived from Caravaggio - is astonishing.

One of the great twists in this show is to be able to move from a painting such as this to Annibale Carracci's self portrait, a head and shoulders painting-within-a-painting, the portrait resting on an easel in a darkened room, with a vague human presence in the doorway behind.

What a curious image this is. A dog's eyes glint at the foot of the easel, a patch of white on the painter's palette catches the light. It is a small, haunting work by an artist apparently in the throes of a breakdown. This little work hits all the harder for its strangeness, its melancholy, its vacancy. There is a danger, in blockbuster shows like this, that lesser-known works will be passed-over or missed, in the rush, perhaps, to get to the gore, to Artemisia Gentileschi's Judith, Beheading Holofernes, with the blood all over the sheet, or to Caravaggio's earlier version of the same subject. Don't rush, wait.

Caravaggio, holding aloft a lantern, portrayed himself on the extreme right of his nocturnal The Taking of Christ. How much intense light Caravaggio gives us. Christ is jostled, about to be taken by a man in black armour, whose reaching arm is dramatised by a great liquid smear of reflected moonlight.

The light flattens as well as reveals, shadows engulf as much as the light illuminates. Caravaggio edits and crops with light and dark, working back into compositions whose figures were modelled from life. Part of his appeal, surely, is his almost cinematic focus, the spotlights which drag the eye over the engulfing dark, from figure to figure, face to face. This is where the drama is.

No wonder he attracted so many followers in Rome; even in 1620, 10 years after his death, there were Flemish, French and Dutch Carravagists, reworking the same scenes, the same dramas. But really, there is no competition.

One of the great things about the main galleries of the Royal Academy are the long sight-lines it affords, and Caravaggio's starkly-lit St John the Baptist (his second version of the subject), has the brooding, almost naked boy caught in stark moonlight. But the light is too intense for the moon: the coruscating wattage is too high. Was painting the only place where such contrast of light and dark could exist?

At a distance - 10 yards, 20, 30 - the painting is still readable down the long narrow vista. It has incredible visual punch. One almost begins to think of Caravaggio's most chiaroscuro works as screens, the images on them not so much painted as projected, or back-lit.

St John the Baptist faces Annibale Carracci's Hercules at the Crossroads, framed through a succession of doorways. Caravaggio's greatest rival in Rome, Carracci's method could not be more different. Where Caravaggio seems to want to evince a palpable reality, Carracci's style is all quotation and classicising. Clearly, Hercules and the figures for Vice and Virtue have been patched into the scene, which is cluttered with details which one might even think are included as much to glue the space together as they are to compound the painting's classical allusions. It is exhausting to look at.

It is no longer either fashionable nor wise to make the mistake of seeing any artist in isolation from the period or epoch that made them, their friendships and antagonisms, their patrons. This task, both the exhibition and the catalogue take on board.

Caravaggio might tower over this exhibition, and make Annibale Carracci look insipid, but this is much to do with our taste, which we also cannot avoid. I can admire Rubens's St Gregory, almost levitating in his voluminous drapes, or Guercino's depiction of the same saint, who looks like a tortoise, his wrinkled neck and querulous head poking out from his embroidery and brocade, but they don't move me.

Caravaggio's Entombment, in which Christ's limp body is lifted, almost presented to us in death, has a vividness, a pared-down gravity (the shroud falling away from the sagging body, the corner of the tomb jutting into the extreme foreground) that roots me to the spot. Compared to this, almost all else in the final room of the exhibition are just paintings.

We cannot look at Caravaggio in our secular age without seeing him in the light of modern sexual mores, modern psychology, modern pathology. Caravaggio looks forward to our time, and we look back at his. The place where we meet is the space of painting, where the world is unpeeled.

· The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 is at the Royal Academy, London, W1, until April 16. Tickets: 020-7300 8000. It will travel to the Palazzo Venezia, Rome, May-Aug 2001.

It is a small, haunting work by an artist apparently in the throes of a breakdown. This little work hits all the harder for its strangeness, its melancholy, its vacancy. There is a danger, in blockbuster shows like this, that lesser-known works will be passed-over or missed, in the rush, perhaps, to get to the gore, to Artemisia Gentileschi's Judith, Beheading Holofernes, with the blood all over the sheet, or to Caravaggio's earlier version of the same subject. Don't rush, wait. Caravaggio, holding aloft a lantern, portrayed himself on the extreme right of his nocturnal The Taking of Christ. How much intense light Caravaggio gives us. Christ is jostled, about to be taken by a man in black armour, whose reaching arm is dramatised by a great liquid smear of reflected moonlight. The light flattens as well as reveals, shadows engulf as much as the light illuminates. Caravaggio edits and crops with light and dark, working back into compositions whose figures were modelled from life. Part of his appeal, surely, is his almost cinematic focus, the spotlights which drag the eye over the engulfing dark, from figure to figure, face to face. This is where the drama is. No wonder he attracted so many followers in Rome; even in 1620, 10 years after his death, there were Flemish, French and Dutch Carravagists, reworking the same scenes, the same dramas. But really, there is no competition. One of the great things about the main galleries of the Royal Academy are the long sight-lines it affords, and Caravaggio's starkly-lit St John the Baptist (his second version of the subject), has the brooding, almost naked boy caught in stark moonlight. But the light is too intense for the moon: the coruscating wattage is too high. Was painting the only place where such contrast of light and dark could exist? At a distance - 10 yards, 20, 30 - the painting is still readable down the long narrow vista. It has incredible visual punch. One almost begins to think of Caravaggio's most chiaroscuro works as screens, the images on them not so much painted as projected, or back-lit. St John the Baptist faces Annibale Carracci's Hercules at the Crossroads, framed through a succession of doorways. Caravaggio's greatest rival in Rome, Carracci's method could not be more different. Where Caravaggio seems to want to evince a palpable reality, Carracci's style is all quotation and classicising. Clearly, Hercules and the figures for Vice and Virtue have been patched into the scene, which is cluttered with details which one might even think are included as much to glue the space together as they are to compound the painting's classical allusions. It is exhausting to look at. It is no longer either fashionable nor wise to make the mistake of seeing any artist in isolation from the period or epoch that made them, their friendships and antagonisms, their patrons. This task, both the exhibition and the catalogue take on board. Caravaggio might tower over this exhibition, and make Annibale Carracci look insipid, but this is much to do with our taste, which we also cannot avoid. I can admire Rubens's St Gregory, almost levitating in his voluminous drapes, or Guercino's depiction of the same saint, who looks like a tortoise, his wrinkled neck and querulous head poking out from his embroidery and brocade, but they don't move me. Caravaggio's Entombment, in which Christ's limp body is lifted, almost presented to us in death, has a vividness, a pared-down gravity (the shroud falling away from the sagging body, the corner of the tomb jutting into the extreme foreground) that roots me to the spot. Compared to this, almost all else in the final room of the exhibition are just paintings. We cannot look at Caravaggio in our secular age without seeing him in the light of modern sexual mores, modern psychology, modern pathology. Caravaggio looks forward to our time, and we look back at his. The place where we meet is the space of painting, where the world is unpeeled. · The Genius of Rome 1592-1623 is at the Royal Academy, London, W1, until April 16. Tickets: 020-7300 8000. It will travel to the Palazzo Venezia, Rome, May-Aug 2001.

webTitle: G2: History of the Galapagos Islands

fields.headline: Birthplace of the evolution
fields.standfirst: An oil spill is threatening the unique species of the Galapagos Islands.  Edward Larson  looks at the history of 'Darwin's Eden' and explains why it is still crucial to science
fields.trailText: An oil spill is threatening the unique species of the Galapagos Islands. Edward Larson looks at the history of 'Darwin's Eden' and explains why it is still crucial to science
fields.body:
Even at a time of shockingly bad news from around the world, word of a potentially major oil spill in Galapagos waters commands our attention. It is as if a bomb destroyed the Louvre or all the Amazon rainforest was lost in day. Our reaction is a tribute to the profound place of the Galapagos Islands and their unique animals in our scientific world-view and cultural understanding.

"It was on the Galapagos in the early autumn of 1835 that Darwin took the first step out of the fairyland of creationism into the coherent and comprehensible world of modern biology," observed the influential British biologist Julian Huxley, "for it was here that he became fully convinced that species are not immutable - in other words, that evolution is a fact."

This, Huxley went on, "effected the greatest of all revolutions in human thought, greater than Einstein's or Freud's or even Newton's." It changed how scientifically informed people view nature, life and humankind.

Evolution is more apparent in places such as the Galapagos because the environment is stripped bare. Few plants and animals could reach these remote, volcanic islands that rose from the sea within the past 10 million years, and fewer still could survive in its harsh environment. Those that did adapted to local conditions and diversified to fill various niches not open to them on the South American mainland.

The central role played by the Galapagos Islands in Darwin's discovery of evolution transformed the archipelago into a sacred site for science and a place of immense interest to biologists and eco-tourists alike. They came to call it "Darwin's Eden" and "the Galapagos wonderland" and "evolution's workshop". The workings of evolution are still more apparent on the Galapagos than almost any other place on earth. Hundreds of scientists from around the world still visit the islands every year to study the workings of evolution. They continue to find new insights.

It was 17th-century British buccaneers, in need of a safe harbour from which to harry Spanish treasure ships from Peru, who first exploited the archipelago. Then British whalers took to using it as a base for Pacific whaling. The harsh terrain discouraged colonisation, but buccaneers and whalers killed and captured the islands' great tortoises for food and began the human spoilage of the place.

A young Charles Darwin visited in 1835, as part of an around-the-world British navy surveying expedition aboard HMS Beagle. Darwin transformed western understanding of the Galapagos by seeing evolution among its bizarre animals and geological features. Within decades, emerging concepts of biological and geological change merged into a comprehensive theory of organic evolution by natural selection. Such thinking directly challenged traditional notions of purpose and meaning in life, and escalated the culture wars that pitted science against religion and reason against revelation.

As the impact of Darwin's vision grew within western culture, so did the role of the Galapagos in shaping evolutionary science. During the late 19th and early 20th century, a series of major scientific expeditions visited from Britain, Europe and the US, trying to resolve outstanding questions in evolution theory.

In the end, it was a lone English birdwatcher named David Lack, sent by Julian Huxley and the Zoological Society of London to study Galapagos finches in 1938, who unlocked the modern neo-Darwinian theory of evolution. His field work on the Galapagos explained the islands' puzzling array of finches in terms of Darwinian natural selection.

Peter and Rosemary Grant, also originally from England but now based at Princeton University in the US, have picked up and extended this work in long-term studies that continue. Their work remains among the best and most influential field studies of natural selection anywhere.

Although Darwin's finches are the islands' most famous test case of evolution in action, scientists study other Galapagos species as well. In the absence of mammals, for example, reptiles have grown exceedingly large there, particularly the tortoises and iguanas.

The few plants that managed to gain a foothold on the rocky islands have evolved into forms found nowhere else on earth - including the islands' famous cactus trees. Having developed in a land without humans, local reptiles and birds show no fear of people, making the islands a particularly popular place to study animal behaviour.

Since Darwin walked on the Galapagos Islands with his eyes wide open in wonder, the archipelago has played an ever-larger role in the history of science. "No area on earth of comparable size has inspired more fundamental changes in man's perspective of himself and his environment than the Galapagos Islands," notes Robert Bowman, the current dean of Galapagos researchers. "The unconventional flow of nature on the land and the sea has spawned revolutionary views on the origin, not only of new species, but also of life itself."

Eco-tourists followed scientists in seeking what Darwin saw, threatening those very sites by their numbers and transforming the Galapagos into a test case for environment protection from the people who love it too much. The flow of eco-tourists began in the 1960s, attracted by reports that visitors could easily walk among giant tortoises, large land and marine iguanas, flamingos and blue-footed boobies.

Swimming with friendly sea lions and seemingly tame hammer-head sharks became a popular attraction, drawing hundreds of thousands of tourists from Europe and the Americas.

During the past half-century, the archipelago became Ecuador's first national park, a founding "Man in the Biosphere" preserve for Unesco and one of the United Nations' initial World Heritage Sites. More scientific papers have been published about the Galapagos than any other group of oceanic islands except Hawaii, and the pace intensifies, perhaps in an effort to get it done before it is too late.

A half-century ago, Julian Huxley spoke of the islands' past and future for science. "The Galapagos archipelago is historically of great scientific importance, since it was its fauna and flora which more than anything else convinced Charles Darwin of the fact of evolution," Huxley wrote of the archipelago's past. Of its future he then added, "It provides indeed one of nature's most clear-cut experiments in evolution, and for this reason, and as a memorial to Darwin's great achievement, its flora and fauna should be studied, preserved and safeguarded."

Word of an oil spill that could threaten fragile animal habitats, particularly for sea lions and blue-footed boobies, troubles scientist and environmentalists alike. Why, they ask, would anyone allow an oil tanker anywhere near this place?

 Edward Larson is a professor of history and law at the University of Georgia and author of Evolution's Workshop: God and Science on the Galapagos Islands, which will be published by Allen Lane, The Penguin Press in July.

webTitle: Daglish blames Barnes for Celtic's poor form last season

fields.headline: Daglish blames Barnes for Celtic's poor form last season
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish has blamed John Barnes for Celtic's disastrous season last year.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish has blamed John Barnes for Celtic's disastrous season last year.

Dalglish, who was sacked from his position as director of football by Celtic last summer, claims Barnes' poor signings and his troubled relationship with Mark Viduka were the reasons for the club's poor performance.

Barnes, who joined Celtic in the summer of 1999, broke the Scottish record with the £5.75m signing of Eyal Berkovic and later splashed out another £6m on the Brazilian defender Rafael Scheidt. He also brought in Ian Wright, Olivier Tebily and unknown Stephane Bonnes - all of whom have failed to make an impact.

"It was John who signed all the players at Celtic. I don't know who was the worst although there were more bad ones than good ones," said Dalglish.

"Obviously there was some consultation between us but, at the end of the day, the guy who is responsible for who plays, how we played and where and when we trained is the guy who is ultimately responsible for buying players," he added.

Dalglish also confirmed that a dressing room conflict between Barnes and now Leeds striker Mark Viduka during the Scottish Cup defeat by Inverness had ended Barnes' reign as head coach.

Barnes was sacked after the humiliating 3-1 defeat after which Dalglish flew back from the continent. "I don't think he has been soured by what happened," said Dalglish. "John had the best start to a season of any Celtic manager other than Jock Stein, although Martin has now surpassed that.

"However, after the winter break things started to go wrong. We drew with Kilmarnock and then lost 3-2 to Hearts after being 2-0 up. Inverness Caley then beat us in the Scottish Cup and John had a problem with Mark Viduka in the dressing room. That was the beginning of the end for him."

fields.headline: Di Canio steals the show for Hammers
fields.trailText: Di Canio's drive checks Charlton.
fields.body:
He came to check on the progress of some of his England hopefuls but Sven-Goran Eriksson went away once again marvelling at the talent of Paolo di Canio, the man he tried to sign for Lazio in one of his last acts as their coach.

The Italian striker, an avid Lazio fan, scored the equaliser which landed West Ham a richly deserved Premiership point in this London derby. In truth the Hammers' dominance had warranted a first win over Charlton at the Valley for 44 years.

"They've been the best side we've played this season," said the home manager Alan Curbishley. "We've gained a point tonight, we know that, we're not naive."

It was an exhibition of passing and movement like the one that handed Charlton a 5-0 drubbing at Upton Park on Boxing Day, but last night the Hammers' finishing was awry.

Curbishley's team could really have done with a more encouraging performance to take into Saturday's FA Cup third-round replay with Dagenham and Redbridge, especially as they took the lead on seven minutes.

The understanding in West Ham's defence should have been better as Paul Konchesky's precise through-ball put Shaun Bartlett goalside of Hannu Tihinen and the South African's low shot escaped Craig Forrest, who played instead of the injured Shaka Hislop.

But the defence's uncertainty was understandable because they had never played together before. Five players who would have made the starting line-up were missing through injury or suspension and the manager Harry Redknapp has been like shopaholic in the January sales.

Three recent arrivals appeared in defence, with Rigobert Song and Tihinen joined by the debutants Christian Dailly and Sébastien Schemmel, on loan from Metz. The French club's president has described the latter's personality as "phenomenally unstable" but last night his football looked very secure.

Eriksson was taking in his fifth game in 10 days and casting a particular eye on the West Ham midfielders Frank Lampard, Joe Cole and Michael Carrick, with the latter doing most to impress the England coach.

Once the trio got a grip on the game West Ham dominated comprehensively, though the equaliser was a long time coming. Frédéric Kanouté should have scored after 37 minutes but he managed to head Cole's cross wide from close range. Minutes later Lampard's astute through-ball put Di Canio behind the defence but the Italian dragged his chance wide.

Claus Jensen went close for Charlton just before the break, but they had been completely on the back foot throughout. And though they reorganised with a back five in the second period, West Ham's sweet passing continued to unsettle them.

After 55 minutes Cole seemed certain to score after neat interpassing between Kanouté and Schemmel set up the newcomer for a cross which found Cole 12 yards out. The 19-year-old had time to take aim but Andy Todd's chest stopped his shot on the line and the referee waved away claims for handball.

What they really needed was a familiar moment of inspiration from Di Canio or Kanouté. The Frenchman had been quoted earlier in the day as saying he wanted to join a bigger Premiership club to improve his international chances and added that he did not want to go north because there it is always cold, raining and full of small houses. Perhaps his small mind failed to notice, but that was a perfect description of the area around the Valley last night. Anyhow, he later stated that he is happy to stay at Upton Park - for now.

It was Di Canio who saved West Ham's bacon, picking up the ball on the right of the area and with familiar brilliance firing in an unstoppable shot.

Later Redknapp announced yet more arrivals, the 22-year-old Bulgaria striker Svetoslav Todorov, bought for £500,000 from Lovech, becoming the seventh since Rio Ferdinand left before Christmas.

And next week the manager hopes to sign the Japan defender Tsuneyasu Miyamoto. Let us hope the dressing-room has enough coat pegs.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Five minutes with John Burnside
fields.standfirst: John Burnside spoke to us down the phone from Scotland. Find out about how his home became an inspiration for his Whitbread Award-winning poetry collection, The Asylum Dance, and listen to audio clips of the interview. (You will need RealAudio, download it here for free).
fields.trailText: John Burnside spoke to us down the phone from Scotland. Find out about how his home became an inspiration for his Whitbread Award-winning poetry collection, The Asylum Dance, and listen to audio clips of the interview
fields.body:
Can you tell me a little about the Asylum Dance?
The Asylum Dance was written after I'd moved back to Scotland and was a response to moving to my old home area of Fife. It's to do with where you live, what home is, what it means to dwell on a certain place in a philosophical sense as well as in a kind of practical/physical sense. Living, in this particular example, by the sea, in a certain kind of community which has to do with fishing, and the history of that community and the way people have lived here in the past and the way people live here now.

 Audio clip

How long have you lived there?
I moved south when I was 11 years old, moved to England. I've lived in all kinds of places, all parts of England. I moved back to Scotland about five or six years ago. It took me a long time to get home but I'd always planned to come back.

Having written seven collections of poems, two novels and a collection of short stories. Which discipline do you prefer and which do you see yourself as?

I don't see myself as any one thing. Not just a poet or mainly a novelist or anything like that. I really like to try my hand at everything and I think it's probably dangerous to let oneself be pigeon-holed, not necessarily by other people but in one's own mind. I like to think of myself as sort of open to doing things and exploring different ways of expressing some of the ideas that interest me.

 Audio clip

How do you see your poetry in terms of the internet?

The way I mainly use the internet is keeping in touch with poets that live far away. My main interest is contemporary American poets and some Spanish language poets and I keep in touch with their work through either their websites or email. Even workshop stuff - I've got a couple of friends in America who send me poems to discuss during the composition and I sometimes send poems to them and ask for advice or comments or questions. It's a feeling of response, a sounding board somewhere, to hear what they think of something. It's difficult to get a perspective on one's own work sometimes, a sense of distance, whereas someone else can look at it and say 'well I think what you're doing is going in the right direction' or 'I think somehow you're missing the point here'... so I use the internet for that kind of informal workshopping.

 Audio clip

In general, do you think the internet helps poetry become more accessible to people who wouldn't necessarily go into a bookshop and buy a collection?

I am very attached to the book, I have to say that. There's something about poetry on the page and holding a book in your hand which is very satisfying and special. I think it's good for people to use the internet to become aware of what's happening. I think what's happened in the past is that if you're a British reader you maybe tend to read British poets and may not be aware of what is going on in America. There are lots of interesting, different things going on in America. In the past one was only made aware of the mainstream of what was happening in another country. Now you can hear what's happening in more underground currents, alternative currents or peripheral currents as well as what's happening in the mainstream. People can go out into the internet and find out about poets they might not have necessarily have heard of otherwise.

fields.headline: Return of a homegrown hero
fields.standfirst:
David Kitt
Pod, Dublin
***
fields.trailText:
David Kitt
Pod, Dublin
***
fields.body:
It shouldn't have been like this. David Kitt, delicate songsmith and homegrown hero, is battling for the attention of his local Saturday night crowd amid a sea of Guinness - and he's losing. But it was always going to be a tough night. "I haven't done a gig in a while and I'm a bit nervous," he admits, although his dedication overrides the rustiness. With eyes cast firmly downward he picks a gentle rhythm from his guitar, and as the crowd chatter on and pints of the black stuff are passed around, it's sink-or-swim time.

Kitt's mini-album, Small Moments is a snapshot of lo-fi brilliance that is both accessible and loveable, and whimsical without becoming sickly. Each studied beat and distilled influenced melody is there because Kitt loves it and wants you to also. If David Gray had spent more time clubbing and listening to Charlie Mingus he could have sounded as cool as this.

Another Love Song might fit snuggly into the so-called new-acoustic movement, were it not for the subtly distracting beats beneath the simple sweetness of the lyrics. The kids love it. "You can sing louder, help me out," Kitt encourages, aware that if you can't beat 'em, it's wise to get 'em joining in. But the mass chorus betrays the fragility of the song cruelly.

The faster tunes work best tonight. Headphones is sassy jazz-pop, while Pale Blue Light, from his forthcoming second album, is all breakbeats and jagged guitar, pointing to a more free-form, fuller sound. Kitt's voice is smooth and sublime as he moves his head and hips to its fractured dance rhythm, playing off against the deliberately discordant clarinet. There's a lot going on, but all subtlety is lost in the cave-like venue.

Kitt at least appears to be enjoying himself. "Having attended the better days of the end of house music here, it's very strange being up here," he tells us, finishing off the dregs of his own Guinness. Maybe it's the shared recollection of halcyon dancing days that ultimately endears Kitt to the crowd. That doesn't mean that they'll put down their pints and give him the respect he deserves, but they do show some affection, with warm applause and dewy-eyed looks from the girls. And when Kitt encores with a sparse version of the Specials' A Message to You, Rudy, he wins the war for their hearts at last.

webTitle: Notebook: Markets calm on Dell profits alert

fields.headline: Out of the twilight, into the comfort zone
fields.standfirst: Markets calm on Dell profits alert
fields.trailText: Notebook: The speed with which sentiment towards the American economy has changed has been remarkable. Only a couple of months ago analysts were anxiously scanning labour market data looking for signs, not of recession, but of overheating.
fields.body:
The speed with which sentiment towards the American economy has changed has been remarkable. Only a couple of months ago analysts were anxiously scanning labour market data looking for signs, not of recession, but of overheating.

Now the worry is whether the economy is about to fall off a cliff. There are those who argue that asking whether or not the US can avoid a recession is the wrong question.

For them recession has already arrived; fourth-quarter performance last year was grim and the first three months of this year will not be any better.

The signs from corporate America are adding to the gloom. Yesterday computer maker Dell warned that its fourth-quarter results would not match expectations. News from the old economy was worse. Eaton, a diversified manufacturer, said its fourth-quarter net income was down - hit by hard times in the motor industry.

Europeans should go easy on the schadenfreude. The Ifo measure of German business confidence has fallen for a seventh month in a row. Forecasts that the 12-nation bloc will see 3% growth in GDP this year look optimistic.

Policymakers have several options. Philippe D'Arvisenet, group chief economist at BNP Paribas, for example, believes the downturn in the American economy leaves the US Federal Reserve plenty of scope for cutting interest rates aggressively.

The incoming Bush administration could help matters, too, by promised tax cuts.

They would take time to come through but Mr Bush could woo consumers into the comfort zone, according to Mr D'Arvisenet, by making it clear this year that the benefits will be in pay packets and bank accounts early next year.

As the clouds gather, however, there is one glimmer - if not precisely of hope, at least of modest reassurance. Yesterday's profits warning from Dell did not send the equity markets into a nose dive. Dell shares, it is true, took a hit but losses on Wall Street generally were muted.

That might be because the markets are becoming inured to less than joyous tidings from Dell.

But it may also be that they believe they have priced in what is really happening to the world's biggest economy.

Green retreat

Pity poor Bill Grimsey, the new hands-on chief executive of Iceland. A mere two weeks into the job and the City is left reeling at the retailer's trading performance over Christmas.

The problem stems from the decision taken by previous chief executive Stuart Rose to go green. By deciding to ditch all other veg and concentrate on organic last year, Iceland took the moral high ground. It now appears, however, that customers were less than impressed. Green issues rank somewhere behind more traditional retail approaches such as Iceland's own buy-one-get-one free strategy which was run down to help cover the cost of the organic push.

Mr Grimsey has shown he is prepared to take decisions. He has already ditched some of the incumbent management. Yesterday, he made it clear that buy-one-get-one free promotions are back with a vengeance. Organic food will stay, but be supplemented by other produce too. That is a sensible start.

Mr Grimsey will also need to show the City that the weak sales from Iceland do not bode ill for the pledge of £50m of cost-savings promised from the merger with Booker. At least £5m was expected to come from enhanced sales.

As the shares tumbled yesterday, City sentiment would not have been improved by recollections that just before Christmas chairman Malcolm Walker sold 4m shares - netting £13.5m.

Orange gripe

Speaking of pricing, there were predictable grumbles yesterday about the amount France Telecom wants investors to stump up for shares in Orange.

In an ideal world the French group would probably not have floated Orange just now, given the rout in the telecoms sector since February last year. But it needs the flotation to provide it with cash to reduce its hefty debt burden as well as handy acquisition currency.

As the recent debt offerings from BT show, there is investor appetite for telecoms paper. The question is the price.

Institutional investors, who have not always had the happiest of rides in the sector, know that events are moving in their favour. The telecoms groups need highly rated paper to make acquisitions and cash to fund the purchase of third generation mobile phone licences and associated networks.

The Orange sale is just one of a whole wave. BT is expected to float BT Wireless, Deutsche Telekom is lining up an offering of T-Mobile International shares, Holland's KPN is tipped to bring its mobile subsidiary to the market. Right now, telecoms is a buyer's market.

fields.headline: The Rider
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.body:
Derevo, Anton Adassinski's shaven-head clown outfit, has won itself a cult following across the world since it was founded in Leningrad in 1988, and picks up prizes at festivals the way the rest of us pick up colds. That doesn't mean everything that emerges from its Dresden headquarters is exceptional. This 1992 piece, performed as part of the London international mime festival, is a case in point.

Perhaps if we had seen it before either the aggressively energetic Red Zone or the touchy-feely Once it would have made more impact. Here it emerges as a scrappy, embryonic work with flashes of unsustainable brilliance. Most importantly, whereas the fairytale Once stayed just the right side of whimsical, this piece often strays the wrong side of fey. Physically, the work lacks the razor-sharp precision that gave Once its edge and made it so memorable.

According to Adassinski, The Rider is inspired by the life of the itinerant actor: "people who have so many characters and performers inside them that they hardly know any more who they are". This lack of stable reality is reflected in the way that the stage is magicked into a playground, an enchanted place where doves sit on trees and griffins perch on a flimsy toy castle that transforms into a toy theatre. A princess, a pierrot, a sailor, a couple of giggly Gretchens and an old man with a fairytale beard drift across the landscape, occasionally interacting and always throwing off their masks and changing into other shapes and characters. One of the marvels of the piece is that there are only four performers but a cast of thousands.

There are some intriguing, cheeky set pieces: the bearded man's insane, glorious attempts to fly, caught in mid-air while Edith Piaf sings No Regrets; a violent fight between two men in which neither of the protagonists actually touch each other. This is a place where the guns are toys and the water upon which the sailor sails his boat is imaginary.

This idea of shows within shows is neatly done, but there is not enough to carry an 80-minute piece. Without greater intellectual ballast or the helping hand of narrative, the evening quickly slides into a series of episodes, only some of which are meaningful and hit the mark. Like the absurdist ditty A Whiter Shade of Pale that the show uses, this is a light fandango, nothing more.

fields.headline: Orton still entertains and shocks
fields.standfirst:
Entertaining Mr Sloane
Arts Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Entertaining Mr Sloane
Arts Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Does is it still shock? Thirty-seven years after its première, at this same theatre, does Joe Orton's play retain its primal kick? On the evidence of Terry Johnson's coolly farcical production, emphatically yes: partly because we are more alert now to the play's misogynist cruelty and partly because of the glittering contrast between style and content.

Coldly considered, the action is unremittingly sordid. Sloane, a murderous, bisexual thug, insinuates himself into the home, and bed, of the sexually infantile Kath while also attracting her gaily butch brother Ed. He impregnates Kath, excites Ed by working as his leather-clad chauffeur, and then kicks their father to death. But the exploiter turns victim when Ed and Kath blackmail him into becoming their shared sexual slave.

What makes the play shocking, and funny, is the formal decorum of Orton's language. Harold Hobson, in his original review, compared the play to Jane Austen's Northanger Abbey; and it is the Janeite contrast between Gothic substance and elevated style that gives the play its charge. When Kath famously says, "Until I was 15, I was more familiar with Africa than my own body", or when Ed claims that it is his "liberal principles" that have led him to be foolishly protective, we are in a world where language is used as an elaborate masquerade.

But the virtue of Johnson's production is that it exposes Orton's genuine heartlessness; and it does this by heightening its farcical quality. When Kath vamps the willing Sloane, she appears from behind swagged curtains to a Mario Lanza record like a downmarket Cleopatra; and when Sloane attacks her in the final scene, her dentures go flying across the room, only to be caught by Ed.

Even if Kath is finally triumphant, there is no escaping the rancid misogyny behind Ed's line to his sister that "You showed him the gate of hell every night."

Johnson, in short, brings out the play's cold-hearted swagger. He is helped by a wonderfully over-the-top William Dudley set that, with its murky mural of swirling bodies, reminds one of the collage that decorated Orton's own room. And the performances tread a fine line between verbal comedy and physical farce. Alison Steadman as Kath veers superbly between an affected gentility and a rank coarseness when the chips, and the trousers, are down. Clive Francis as Ed almost salivates at the prospect of a uniformed Sloane and captures exactly a certain kind of blazered, gay muscularity, and Neil Stuke's Sloane is a ruthless blond predator who always sits with legs conveniently splayed.

In the end, I find something slightly chilling about Orton's own amorality. But there is no denying his power as a comic stylist or the play's ability to leave one pleasurably shocked.

Until April 6.
Box office: 020-7836 3334.

fields.headline: Pension funds pay the price for last year's hi-tech rollercoaster ride
fields.trailText: Only six of the 67 main pension fund managers made money for their customers last year, one of only three years on record when the average pension fund produced a negative return.
fields.body:
Only six of the 67 main pension fund managers made money for their customers last year, one of only three years on record when the average pension fund produced a negative return.

One of the six was Phillips & Drew, which reversed its poor performance of recent years. It leapt from the bottom to the top of the industry's league tables in 2000 as its decision to shun telecoms and technology stocks finally paid off.

According to the Combined Actuarial Performance Services (Caps) annual survey of pension fund performance, the last time the average pension fund produced a negative return was in 1994. The only other occasion was in 1990.

The survey, used by fund managers to try to persuade companies and local authorities to trust them with their pension schemes, shows that last year produced a reversal in fortunes for the fund management firms at the top and bottom of its league of 67 firms.

The sharp divergence in the performance of the managers reflected the violent swings in the stock market during the year.

fields.headline: Mike McKoy and Bobby Wellins
fields.standfirst:
606 Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
606 Club, London
***
fields.body:
With his German and Jamaican parents, singer Mike McKoy doesn't have the most obvious background to interpret the samba songs of Joao Gilberto. But if he hadn't announced his roots on stage, only a Brazilian would have known. McKoy, who made a powerful impression playing opposite Elvin Jones at Ronnie Scott's in London last year, is a big man who cares about the little things - and he makes this meticulous attention count without suffocating improvisation. Every drifting nuance and vaporous inflection of this most ethereal of idioms was carefully cherished in a performance of bold coolness, which grew in stature as the battle with a noisy packed house increasingly went McKoy's way.

The essentials of Joao Gilberto's music are low volume, the hypnotic sway of the samba pulse, the speech inflections of Portuguese, and lazy melody lines shaped by very unorthodox harmonies. Instead of opting for the seductively whispered, English-language, Astrud Gilberto version of jazz-samba that made the style such a hit in the 1960s, McKoy went for the real McCoy; as a result the musicality of the speech sounds, the more emphatic percussion and the immense grace of the melody lines had their proper due.

McKoy accompanied himself, Joao Gilberto-style, with softly throbbing acoustic guitar chords, while his rhythm section expertly supplied what this understated idiom demands: a strong but unobtrusive undercurrent of harmonic security and effortlessly shuffling swing, with some telling piano variations later in the show.

If McKoy's own role was tough enough to discharge without drifting into musical tourism, the role of the tenor saxophone - magically invented by the late Stan Getz on the original American-Brazilian collaborations - was an even harder act to follow. But McKoy picked the perfect candidate in Scottish tenorist Bobby Wellins, who achieved that role just as imposingly.

Wellins (who played one of the greatest of all recorded Brit-jazz tenor solos in a Getzian style, with Starless and Bible Black for Stan Tracey in the mid-1960s) is a master of the art of insinuation in an improvised solo. He inhabits the rippling-water rhythms of Brazilian music as if his childhood had been spent in Rio rather than Glasgow. He delicately balanced restrained, coasting-behind-the-beat minimalism with briefly quickening bursts of double-time on Desafinado, sounded smokier and fuller in tone on its percussive successor, and wound himself caressingly around the vocal line in a counter-melody on Girl from Ipanema.

In the wrong hands, jazz-samba can be a great insomnia cure. In the right ones, its understated virtues burst into bloom all over again.

webTitle: Polke's splodgy dots and bad gags

fields.headline: Polke's splodgy dots and bad gags
fields.standfirst:
Sigmar Polke
Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh
**
fields.trailText:
Sigmar Polke
Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh
**
fields.body:
If this exhibition had been mounted last summer, how fashionable it would have been. That dizzy vogue for all things dotty will come back to you with a vengeance as you wander round this frustrating, boring, only momentarily gripping show of Sigmar Polke and his dots. All painted in 1996, these 40 gouaches make up the series Music of Unclear Origin; they're described in the catalogue as "cosmic tasters" of his artistic output, but, with two or three exceptions, these are underwhelmingly prosaic works, uniform in tone and style.

Appropriating Benday dots (the coloured dots used in newspaper and advertising production), blown up into a black mesh-like layer, Polke's work has Pop-art references and echoes of Roy Lichtenstein in particular. But he favours complex layering over Pop's simplicity, and tries too hard in these paintings to muster humour and irony - particularly in the titles. Once you've realised that the titles exist separately from the works, that they are the gag, they begin to grate. This is typical: "Of course! Of course!" I Hastily Poured Walter Another Vodka from the Unbelievably Expensive, Ice-Encrusted Bottle, then I Poured Myself Another Few Drops.

Next to such outpourings are variations on Polke's theme: dots, from lace-like fine ones to big, clumsy splodgy ones; acidic bright colours; washes of creamy paint like spilled milk. A painting called You Can Prevent Milk Boiling Over by Putting a Velvet Insole into Your Shoe brings together a Jackie Onassis face, a pair of 18th-century lovers, mad gold streaks and some delicate architectural lines. Ignoring that title nagging you to smile, the painting does have an engaging free-fall energy.

That's about all there is to this series of paintings. If they had been painted 30 years ago, they might have told us something we had yet to discover about mass culture. As it is, there are only rare moments of insight or real visual pleasure here. Such a Delicious Taste of Spring is Polke at his most abstract, an explosion of insect green on a citrus yellow background. There are no dots, only the dynamism of the colours, the elegance of the lines.

At Polke's most figurative, another painting with a cumbersome title includes a watchtower, not unlike the one at Checkpoint Charlie. Polke was born in Silesia, emigrating to West Germany in 1953, so it's hard not to read recent history into the image. The tower, against a murky grey background, stands in a mass of raspberry pink colour, like a web. It could be blood, it could be lost lives. You stand still, wonder, and want to know more. Sadly, that's not the case for most of the work on show.

Until March 18.
Details: 0131-624 6200.

webTitle: A pitiless Requiem of fire and steel

fields.headline: A pitiless Requiem of fire and steel
fields.standfirst:
Verdi's Requiem
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Verdi's Requiem
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Saturday marks the centenary of Verdi's death, and tributes to the greatest of all Italian composers are underway worldwide. At the Barbican, Antonio Pappano and the London Symphony Orchestra gave the Requiem to an audience jittery with expectancy. Even though there were a few flaws, we weren't disappointed.

Pappano's interpretation is a mixture of fire and steel, delivered with hair-raising ferocity. The opening of the Dies Irae is unremitting in its savagery, knocking you sideways with its violence. Quantus Tremor is turned into a rigid march that seems to drag the souls of the dead to their judgment. The Lacrimosa has an unusually relentless tread. Throughout, playing and choral singing have an electric, knife-edge precision that opens out layers of detail that you haven't heard before. The fugues of the Sanctus and the Libera Me, their complex polyphony negotiated with painstaking clarity, sound like a babble of voices raised first in exultant prayer then quashed in horror.

Much of this is revelatory, but the revelations come at a price. Though the performance is strong on terror, it lacks pity. Power alternates with ritual solemnity, rather than genuine human anguish. Pappano can be unyielding in places where spaciousness is necessary, urgently pushing the Recordare onwards when it needs to form a still point amid the turmoil. He has a fondness for extremes of dynamic contrast, by turns mannered and devastating; the way the opening seems to slide imperceptibly out of silence into sound, for instance, has an extraordinary magic. He lingers over pauses and silences, occasionally breaking the momentum.

The quartet of soloists, however, is fairly devastating, each embodying an archetypal response to the cataclysm around them. The mezzo, Violetta Urmana, presides over the proceedings with the hieratic ritual detachment of a priestess, in marked contrast to the soprano, the great Renée Fleming, whose voice, a flash of pure gold, swoops with elation and despair. The tenor, Jorge Antonio Pita (a last minute replacement for the indisposed Ramon Vargas) is quietly sorrowful; at his best he sounds like the young José Carreras, though occasionally you're aware of effort. René Pape, the bass (another very great voice), sings with rugged, Stoic power. Despite its flaws, the whole is a remarkable achievement.

Performance repeated tomorrow.
Box office: 020-7638 8891.
